In situations governing hourly employees, the work period as specified in the act will be defined as the 14-day period that corresponds with the present 26 village pay periods. Said period shall begin at 12:01 a.m. on the first day and run for 14 consecutive days thereafter. 
(c)  Definitions and usage. As used in this division, the following words and phrases, namely, unscheduled absence, leave year, accumulated leave, current leave, accrued leave, administrative leave, non-pay status, contagious disease, leave without pay (LWOP), absence without leave (AWOL), pregnancy, court leave, official duty, military leave, prime vacation time and temporary assignments, shall be defined as hereinafter provided in the text in which the particular word or phrase is used and such definition is provided. The provisions of this division are set forth plainly and without extensive introduction in the nature and style of an employee handbook. In this connection, the village's employees are encouraged to use the same as an employee handbook. 
(d)  [Modification of benefits.] The corporate authorities, however, as duly elected representatives of the residents, and in keeping with state statutory provisions, have the right to alter, modify, amend or eliminate any and all employee benefits depending of the needs of the municipal corporation and the corporate authorities' evaluation of the welfare of the employees of the municipal corporation. 
(e)  Labor contract agreements superseding. No benefits as provided for in this division apply to any employee covered by a labor contract agreement, in force or expired less than two years unless provided for in writing. 
(Ord. No. 85-19, § 1, 12-23-85; Ord. No. 2003-17, § 2, 5-27-03; Ord. No. 2003-18, § 2, 5-27-03) 
Sec. 2-101. - Eligibility for and responsibilities concerning leave. 
(a)  Responsibilities. 
(1)  Appropriate village officials shall: 
a.  Administer the leave program; 
b.  Inform employees of their leave balance; 
c.  Approve or disapprove requests for leave; and 
d.  Control unscheduled absences. 
(2)  Village employees shall: 
a.  Request leave; and 
b.  Obtain approval before taking leave, except in cases of emergency. 
(b)  Eligibility. 
(1)  Employees covered by the leave program are: 
a.  Full-time employees; and 
b.  Permanent part-time employees. 
(2)  Employees not covered by the leave program are: 
a.  Nonpermanent part-time employees; 
b.  Part-time temporary employees; 
c.  Auxiliary police; and 
d.  Employees who work on a fee or contract basis (e.g., an independent contractor). 
(c)  Unscheduled absence. 
(1)  Unscheduled absences are defined as any absence or absences from work which are not requested and approved in advance. 
(2)  Management responsibilities. It shall be the responsibility of appropriate village officials to control unscheduled absences by: 
a.  Informing employees of leave regulations; and 
b.  Discussing attendance records with individual employees when such discussion is warranted. 
(3)  Employee responsibilities. It shall be the responsibility of the employee to maintain his or her assigned schedule and to make every effort to avoid unscheduled absences. In addition, each employee must provide acceptable evidence for absences when required. 
(Ord. No. 85-19, § 1, 12-23-85) 
Sec. 2-102. - Annual leave. 
(a)  General provisions: 
(1)  Purpose. Annual leave is provided to employees for rest, recreation and for personal and emergency purposes. No employee is credited at the beginning of a leave year with more than 40 hours of previously accumulated annual leave. 
(2)  Definitions: 
Accrued leave is defined leave which is earned but is unused by an employee during any period during the current leave year. 
Accumulated leave is defined as the total unused leave which remains to the credit of the employee at the beginning of any leave year. 
Current leave is defined as leave which an employee earns by bi-weekly pay periods during the current leave year. 
Leave year is defined as a year which shall begin the first day of the first complete pay period in the calendar year and ends on the day before the first day of the first complete pay period in the following calendar year. 
(b)  Eligibility. Only the following earn annual leave, namely: 
(1)  Full time employees; and 
(2)  Permanent part-time employees. 
(c)  Accrual and crediting for full-time employees. 
(1)  Full-time employees shall earn annual leave based upon the number of creditable years of service in accordance with the schedule provided on the following accrual chart unless modified by the corporate authorities: 
Leave
Category Creditable 
Service Maximum 
Leave per Year Category 2 Less than 1 year .025 per hour of normally scheduled straight time hours Category 4 1 year or more, but less than 6 years .050 per hour of normally scheduled straight time hours Category 6 6 years or more, but less than 10 years .063 per hour of normally scheduled straight time hours Category 8 10 years or more .077 per hour of normally scheduled straight time hours  
(2)  Credit at beginning of leave year. Full-time employees are credited at the beginning of the leave year with the total number of annual leave hours that they will earn for that leave year. 
(3)  Changes in employee's accrual rate. Full time employees that will experience a change in an accrual rate during that year will be credited with leave hours calculated using each rate applicable for the time to be scheduled during the year. 
(4)  Change from part-time to full-time. An employee who changes from part-time to a full-time status after the start of a leave year will be credited with the annual leave earned for the remainder of the leave year at the category status granted. 
(5)  Non-pay status is defined as any day or part of a day or shift for which the employee is not receiving compensation either in the form of work hours, annual leave, or sick leave or while receiving workers compensation TTD benefits. Leave credit for periods in which an employee is in non-pay status is reduced during the leave year as follows: 
a.  When an employee's absence in non-pay status totals the equivalent of one pay period of regular service during the leave year (ten days or 80 hours if 40-hour work week and corresponding ratio of hours for less than 40-hour work schedule) credit for leave is reduced by the amount of leave earned by the employee in a pay period; and/or 
b.  When an employee has one or more periods of non-pay status during the year, all hours from such periods in non-pay status (during periods in which the employee earned annual leave) are totaled to reduce leave credit. 
(d)  The corporate authorities reserve the right to craft annual leave benefit availability to other employees on an individual basis. 
(e)  Authorization required. Except for emergencies, annual leave for all employees must be requested and approved in advance by appropriate village officials. 
(1)  Emergencies. An exception to the advance approval requirement as provided in section 2-102(e) hereinabove, is made for emergencies; however, in such situations, the employee must notify appropriate authorities as soon as possible as to the emergency and the expected duration of the absence. As soon as possible after return to duty, employees must explain the reason for the emergency to an appropriate village official. Such appropriate village official shall then approve or disapprove the leave as requested. When the request is disapproved, the absence may be recorded as leave without pay (hereinafter referred to as "LWOP") or absent without leave (hereinafter referred to as "AWOL") at the discretion of the appropriate village official. 
(2)  Request for, or notification of, absence. Application for annual leave is made in writing on an appropriate form designated by each appropriate village official. 
(3)  Approval/disapproval. The appropriate village official is responsible for approving or disapproving application for annual leave. If said appropriate village official does not approve an application for leave, the application is returned to the employee with the reasons for disapproval given in writing. 
(4)  Retention period. Request forms are retained by the appropriate village officials for two years from the date the leave is taken or disapproved. 
(5)  Insufficient leave balance. If the leave is approved and the employee has insufficient leave balance, the village automatically changes annual leave to LWOP when processing the employee's pay. 
(f)  Leave charge information for full-time employees. Full-time employees shall be charged in accordance with the following schedule for the purposes of leave: 
Employee Category Minimum 
Unit Charge All full-time 
employees Quarter hour  
(1)  Additional leave. Additional leave is granted in multiples of quarter hours. 
(2)  Holidays. Leave cannot be charged for national legal holidays, days designated as holidays, or absences authorized by village ordinance or resolution. 
(g)  Leave charge information for permanent part-time employees. Permanent part time employees shall be charged in accordance with the following schedule for purposes of leave: 
Employee Category Minimum 
Unit Charge Permanent part-time employee Quarter hour  
(1)  Permanent part-time. A permanent part-time employee who is granted annual leave and performs service on the same day is not allowed to work more hours than would total eight hours when combined with leave hours. A part-time employee who has been credited with 40 hours or more of paid service (work, leave, or a combination of work and leave), in a service week is not granted paid annual or sick leave during the remainder of that service week. Absences in such cases are treated as non-duty time, not chargeable to paid leave of any kind. Supervisors should avoid granting leave resulting in the requirement for overtime pay. Part time employees who request leave on days that they are scheduled to work, except legal holidays, may be granted leave provided they can be spared. Leave charged cannot exceed eight hours on any one day. The appropriate village official may also consider a request for annual leave on any day a part-time employee is not scheduled to work. The 40 hours' paid service in a service week may not be exceeded. 
(h)  Vacation planning: 
(1)  Granting of vacation leave. For all regular employees, both full-time and permanent part-time, vacation leave is granted when requested to the extent practicable. 
(2)  Prime vacation time is the period beginning with the Sunday of the first full week in June through the Saturday following Labor Day. 
(3)  Maximum length of continuous leave. The maximum length of continuous annual leave during prime time shall not exceed 14 days. There shall be no restriction during the remainder of the year. Appropriate village officials shall have the authority to deny extended vacations when staffing indicates potential problems in supplying necessary village services. 
(4)  Maximum number of employees on vacation. Appropriate village officials shall determine the maximum number of employees that can be on vacation at one time. This policy shall be made known to the employees of the various village departments. 
(5)  Vacation selection. Vacation selection for the prime time period shall be made on the basis of seniority by department. Submission of vacation requests shall be made and assigned by a specified date prior to the prime time period. All other vacation selection shall be made on the basis of submission date. 
(i)  Separation adjustments: 
(1)  Collection for unearned leave; refund. Separating employees who are indebted for unearned annual leave (or sick leave) have to refund the amount paid to them for such unearned leave. If employees do not make refunds, deductions are made from any salary due them. 
(2)  Collection for unearned leave; exception Collection is not required in the case of death or in the case of separation due to a disability which prevents an employee from returning to duty. 
(3)  Payment for accumulated leave. A separating employee may receive a lump sum payment for accumulated annual leave subject to the following conditions: 
a.  Before qualifying period. An employee who separates before completing the qualifying period forfeits terminal leave payment for accumulated leave. 
b.  On or after qualifying period. An employee who completes the 90-day qualifying period, even if separated at the close of business on the 90th day, is entitled to a terminal leave payment for leave accumulated. 
c.  Before last Friday of pay period. An employee whose separation is effective before the last Friday of a pay period does not receive leave credit or terminal leave payment for the leave that would have accrued during that pay period. 
d.  Lump sum payment. Lump sum payment for annual leave at the time of retirement does not affect the amount or commencement date of annuity payments. 
(Ord. No. 85-19, § 1, 12-23-85; Ord. No. 97-08, § 1, 1-27-97; Ord. No. 2003-18, § 3, 5-27-03; Ord. No. 2017-01, § 2, 1-23-17; Ord. No. 2018-08, § 2, 6-11-18) 
Sec. 2-103. - Sick leave. 
(a)  Purpose. The purpose of sick leave is to insure employees against loss of pay if they are incapacitated for the performance of duties because of illness, injury, pregnancy and confinement, and medical (including dental or optical) examination or treatment. Sick leave may also be used in the case of death of an immediate family member of the employee. The term "immediate family member" includes husband, wife, father, mother, son, daughter, brother, sister, brother-or sister-in-law, or parent-in-law of the employee. Sick leave for this purpose in all cases is limited to three days' work. 
(b)  Accrual and crediting. For the purposes of providing sick leave, each employee shall be subject to the accrual and crediting procedure as follows unless modified by the corporate authorities: 
Full time employees working normally scheduled straight time hours of 35 to 40 per week shall earn sick leave at a rate of .0347 per straight time hour worked. 
(1)  Crediting in general. Sick leave is credited at the end of each bi-weekly pay period in which it is earned. Sick leave (earned, unused and not compensated as set forth below) accumulates without limit. 
(2)  Full time employee annual payments for unused annual sick leave earned in that calendar year shall be paid after the close of each calendar year per the following conditions (unless an employee declines payment in writing). 
a.  If zero hours of sick leave are used, three days of regularly scheduled straight time hours will be paid to the employee from the unused sick leave balance. If any sick leave hours up to the three such days of pay are used, that number of hours used will be subtracted and the remainder will be paid to the employee. Remaining hours after annual payments of unused sick leave will be added to an employee's sick leave accrual balance. 
b.  Unused sick leave annual payments will be made to employee during January of the next calendar year. 
(3)  Non-pay status is defined as any day or part of a day or shift for which the employee is not receiving compensation either in the form of work hours, annual leave, or sick leave or is receiving workers compensation TTD benefits. Sick leave is not accrued during any period an employee is in a non-pay status. 
(c)  General policy for authorizing sick leave. Sick leave cannot be granted until it is earned, except as provided hereinafter in section 2-103(e). 
(1)  Restriction. An employee in sick leave status may not engage in any gainful employment unless prior approval has been granted by the appropriate village official. 
(2)  Conditions for authorization. Sick leave will be authorized to an employee: 
a.  In case of illness or injury, if said employee is incapacitated for the performance of his or her official duties; or 
b.  In case of pregnancy and confinement, if said employee meets the various qualifications and restrictions set forth in section 2-105 governing absences for maternity/paternity reasons; or 
c.  In case of medical, dental or optical examination or treatment, if such absence is necessary during the employee's regularly scheduled tour (every effort should be made to schedule medical and dental exams closest to either the beginning or end of a workshift); and 
d.  In cases of contagious disease, if such employee: 
1.  Care for a family member afflicted with a contagious disease; or 
2.  Has been exposed to a contagious disease and would likely jeopardize the health of others employed by the village. 
Such employee must submit evidence supplied by the village's health officer or an appropriate letter or certificate signed by a physician certifying the need for the period of isolation or restriction. 
e.  In case of care of immediate family household member. "Immediate family household member" is defined as spouse, father, mother, parent-in-law, or dependent children living in your household. Sick leave for this purpose in all cases is limited to 48 hours annually. 
(3)  As used in subsection (2)d. above, contagious disease is defined as a disease ruled as requiring isolation, quarantine or restriction of movement of the patient for a particular period of time by the village's health authority. 
(4)  Application for sick leave. Except for unexpected illness/injury situations, sick leave must be requested and approved in advance by the appropriate village official. 
(5)  Unexpected illness/injury. An exception to the advance approval requirement as provided in subsection (4) above, is made for unexpected illness/injury; however, in such situations employees must notify their department head or other appropriate village official as soon as possible as to their illness/injury and expected duration of absence. As soon as possible after return to duty, the employee must submit a request for sick leave. Employees may be required to submit acceptable evidence of incapacity to work as outlined in provisions of section 2-103(c)(8), documentation requirements. The appropriate village official must then approve or disapprove the leave request. When the request is disapproved, the absence may be recorded as annual leave, if appropriate, as LWOP, or AWOL, at the discretion of the supervisor as provided in section 2-103(c)(7) of this division. 
(6)  Request for, or notification of, absence. Application for sick leave is made in writing, in duplicate. 
(7)  Approval/disapproval. The appropriate village official is responsible for approving or disapproving applications for sick leave by signing a copy of the sick leave request. When a request is disapproved, the granting of an alternative type of leave, if any, must be noted along with the reason for the disapproval. A determination that the particular absence constitutes absence without leave must be similarly noted. 
(8)  Documentation requirements. Certain documentation must be provided in connection with each absence and leave request in the following particulars: 
a.  For periods of absence of three days or less, supervisors may accept the employee's statement explaining the absence (medical documentation or other acceptable evidence of incapacity for work is required only when the employee is on restricted sick leave, or when the appropriate village official deems documentation desirable for the protection of the interests of the village); 
b.  For periods of absence of three days or more, employees are required to submit medical documentation or other acceptable evidence of incapacity for work to the appropriate village official; 
c.  For periods of absence excused as sick leave for extended period, employees are required to submit, at appropriate intervals, but not more frequently than one time per pay period, satisfactory evidence of continued incapacity for work unless an appropriate village official has knowledge of the continuing incapacity for work. 
(9)  Return to duty after extended leave. Employees on extended leave shall, upon returning to work, be scheduled to the shift which coincides with that shift they would have been working had they not been off on leave. 
(10)  Medical documentation or other acceptable evidence. When employees are required to submit medical documentation pursuant to these regulations, such documentation shall be furnished by the employee's attending physician or other attending practitioner. Such documentation shall provide an explanation of the nature of the employee's illness, or injury, in sufficient detail to indicate to the appropriate village official that said employee was (or will be) unable to perform his normal duties for the period of absence. Medical statements to the effect that a particular employee was "under my care," or "received treatment," will not be acceptable evidence of incapacitation to perform duties. All such statements must be sufficiently detailed to satisfy the requirements of this section. In the alternative, appropriate village officials may accept proof other than medical documentation if they believe it supports a particular application for sick leave. 
(11)  Failure to furnish required documentation. If acceptable proof of incapacitation is not furnished, the absence may be charged to annual leave, LWOP or AWOL. 
(12)  Restricted sick leave; reasons for restriction. Appropriate village officials who have evidence indicating that an employee is abusing sick leave privileges may place such employee on the restricted sick leave list. In addition, employees may be placed on the restricted sick leave list after their sick leave use has been reviewed on an individual basis and the following actions have been taken: 
a.  The particular employee's employment file has been reviewed for absences by the appropriate village official; and 
b.  The particular village official has shared a discussion of the employee's absence record with the particular employee. 
(13)  Notice and listing. Village officials must provide written notice to employees that their names have been added to the restricted sick leave listing. The notice must explain that, until further notice, the particular employee or employees must support all applications for sick leave by medical documentation or other acceptable evidence. 
(14)  Recision of restriction. The appropriate village official shall review the quarterly leave. If there has been a substantial decrease in absences charged to sickness, the employee's name must be removed from the restricted sick leave list and the employee must be notified in writing of such removal. 
(15)  Performance ability questioned. When the reason for an employee's sick leave is of such nature as to raise justifiable doubt concerning the employee's ability to satisfactorily and/or safely perform his duties, a "fitness for duty" medical examination may be requested through such appropriate village official. A complete report of the facts, medical or otherwise, should support the request. 
(d)  Charging sick leave: 
(1)  Sick leave shall be charged against all full-time employees according to the following general rules: 
a.  Sick leave is not charged for legal holidays or for non-work days established by village ordinance or resolution; and 
b.  Sick leave may be charged on any scheduled work day of an employee's basic work week, including Saturdays and Sundays. 
(2)  The charging of sick leave shall be made in accordance with the following minimum unit charge: 
Employee Category Minimum 
Unit Charge All full-time 
employees Quarter hour  
(3)  Sick leave shall be charged against part-time employees in accordance with the following general rules and procedures: 
a.  Absences due to illness shall be charged as sick leave on any day that an hourly rate employee is scheduled to work, except an authorized paid holiday; and 
b.  Except as provided in section 2-103(g)(1), paid sick leave may not exceed the number of hours that an employee would have been scheduled to work, up to: 
1.  A maximum of eight hours in any one day; 
2.  Forty hours in any one week; or 
3.  Eighty hours in any one pay period (in the event that a dispute arises as to the number of hours the permanent part-time employee would have been scheduled to work, the schedule will be considered to have been equal to the average hours worked by other part-time employees in the same work location on the day in question); 
4.  Limitations as provided hereinabove shall apply only to paid sick leave and not to a combination of sick leave and work hours (part-time employees who have been credited with 40 hours or more of paid service-e.g., work, leave or a combination of work and leave-in a service week, shall not be granted sick leave during the remainder of that service week. Absences in such cases shall be treated as non-duty time not chargeable to paid sick leave of any kind). 
(4)  The charging of sick leave for all part-time employees shall be in accordance with the minimum unit charge schedule set forth as follows: 
Employee Category Minimum 
Unit Charge All part-time 
employees Quarter hour  
(e)  Advance sick leave: 
(1)  Sick leave not to exceed 30 days (240 hours) may be advanced in cases of serious disability or ailment if there is reason to believe the employee will return to duty. Sick leave may be advanced whether or not employees have annual leave to their credit. 
(2)  Medical documentation required. Every application for advance sick leave must be supported by medical documentation as to illness and reason. 
(3)  Additional sick leave. Additional sick leave may be advanced even though liquidation of a previous advance has not been completed, provided the advance, at no time, exceeds 30 days. Any advance sick leave authorized is in addition to the sick leave which has been earned by the employee at the time the advance is authorized. 
(4)  Liquidating advance sick leave. The liquidation of advance sick leave is not to be confused with the substitution of annual leave for sick leave to avoid forfeiture of the annual leave. Advance sick leave may be liquidated in the following manner: 
a.  By charging the sick leave against the sick leave earned by the employee as it is earned upon return to duty; or 
b.  By charging the sick leave against any equivalent amount of annual leave, at the employee's request if the annual leave charge is made prior to the time such leave is forfeited because of leave limitation regulations. 
(f)  Leave charge adjustments: 
(1)  Insufficient sick leave. If sick leave is approved, but the employee does not have sufficient sick leave to cover the absence, the difference is charged to annual leave or to LWOP at the employee's option. 
(2)  Insufficient sick and annual leave. If sick leave is approved for employees who have no annual or sick leave to their credit, the absence may be charged as LWOP, unless sick leave is advanced as outlined in section 2-103(e). LWOP so charged cannot thereafter be converted to sick or annual leave. 
(3)  Disapproved sick leave. If sick leave is disapproved, but the absence is nevertheless warranted, the appropriate village official may approve, at the employee's option, a charge to annual leave or a charge to LWOP. 
(4)  Absence without leave. An absence which is disapproved is charged as LWOP and may be administratively considered as AWOL. 
(5)  Annual leave charged to sick leave. If an employee becomes ill while on annual leave and the employee has a sick leave balance, the absence may be charged to sick leave. 
(g)  Retirements or separations: 
(1)  Use of sick leave at time of separation or retirement. Payment for earned but unused sick leave at the time of separation or retirement, will be made at the rate of 50 percent of the unused balance up to a maximum payment of 320 hours. 
(2)  Separation by death. If an ill employee dies without returning to duty and without making application for sick leave, such appropriate village official may grant sick leave for the period of illness or disability immediately prior to death. If the employee was in pay status on the day of death or immediately prior to death, the employee's beneficiary shall be entitled to receive compensation without charge to leave for the date of death. The latter applies whether or not such employee has leave to his credit. 
(h)  Collection for unearned sick leave. Collection for used but unearned sick leave at the time of separation is made in the same manner as for unearned annual leave (see section 2-102(i)(1) and (2) for information pertaining to the collection of unearned annual leave). 
(Ord. No. 85-19, § 1, 12-23-85; Ord. No. 2003-18, § 4, 5-27-03; Ord. No. 2017-01, § 3, 1-23-17; Ord. No. 2018-08, § 2, 6-11-18) 
Sec. 2-104. - Leave without pay (LWOP). 
(a)  Leave without pay (LWOP): Leave without pay is defined as an authorized absence from duty in a non-pay status. LWOP may be granted upon the employee's request and covers only those hours which the employee would normally work or for which the employee would normally be paid. In this respect, LWOP differs from an absence without leave (AWOL) in that AWOL is a non-pay status due to a determination that no appropriate leave can be granted in a particular situation either because: 
(1)  The employee did not obtain advance authorization; or 
(2)  The employee's request for leave was denied. 
(b)  Restriction policy. LWOP in excess of two years is not approved unless specifically provided for. 
(c)  Administrative discretion. Each request for LWOP shall be carefully and closely examined and a decision shall be made as to the request based upon the needs of such employee, the needs of the village, and the costs to the village. A decision to grant LWOP is a matter of administrative discretion and shall not be granted solely on such employee's demand. 
(d)  Condition of LWOP. In granting approval for extended LWOP, the application for such LWOP must demonstrate a reasonably expectation that the employee will return to work at the end of the approved period. 
(e)  Leave credit reduction. Employees on LWOP for a period or periods totalling 80 hours (the normal number of work hours in one pay period) during a leave year shall have their leave credit reduced by the amount of leave earned in one pay period. 
(f)  Restricted use of LWOP. LWOP shall not be granted to any employee for the purposes of enabling such employee to "try out" for alternate employment or to accept other employment. 
(g)  Acceptable reasons and instruments. The following subsections provide acceptable reasons for granting LWOP and instructions as to the grant of LWOP and various restrictions relating to LWOP: 
(1)  Personal reasons: LWOP may not exceed 30 days during each leave year. 
(2)  Employee has no leave to cover vacation during choice vacation period: LWOP may be granted to cover the absence. 
(3)  Full-time attendance at a college or university: 
a.  Restricted to full-time employee. 
b.  An official transcript of courses taken must be submitted to the appropriate village official. 
(4)  Personal illness or injury: 
a.  LWOP may be granted after accumulated accrued sick and annual leave have been exhausted, except the employee may request LWOP prior to exhausting annual leave. 
b.  A medical document from the attending physician or practitioner must be obtained prior to approval, the same as for sick leave. 
c.  Applications for LWOP to cover a period in excess of 30 days in any one year in cases of illness or injury, are reviewed and acted upon by the appropriate village official. 
d.  An employee normally will not be separated from the service because of LWOP taken due to illness for a period of less than one year. An employee may be separated if required to be absent for more than one year, unless there is cause to expect recovery and return within a reasonable time after the end of one year in LWOP status. 
e.  The separation of an employee after one year of continued absence without pay does not prevent an eligible employee from filing an application for retirement. 
(5)  Injury in line of duty: 
a.  An employee may choose to use annual or sick leave until it is exhausted prior to being placed on LWOP. 
b.  On favorable adjudication of a claim by the Office of Workers' Compensation Programs. LWOP may be substituted for a period of sick and/or annual leave, so that the employee may accept disability compensation for the period of absence. The appropriate village official must advise employees of their right to file an application for injury suffered in line of duty. 
c.  An employee who elects LWOP during a pay period in order to receive compensation under the Federal Employees Compensation Act earns leave during that part of the pay period in which the employee is in pay status, despite general prohibition against earning leave for a part of a pay period. 
(6)  Maternity absence (see section 2-105): An employee absent for maternity reasons may request LWOP for periods of absences which are not medically certified as being due to incapacitation for the performance of duty. 
(7)  Military duty for scheduled drills or for periods of training: An employee enlisted under the Reserve Forces Act of 1955, who has completed the initial period of active duty training of not less than three months or more than six months may be granted LWOP for scheduled drills or periods of training. 
(8)  Military duty for any purpose, training or otherwise: Eligible members of the National Guard or reserve components of the Armed Forces ordered to active duty for training or for any other purposes, for a specified period of time not to exceed one year, but in excess of the total time allowable under military leave and annual leave shall be granted. 
(h)  Required forms, leave request. A request for LWOP must be made by written application. All requests for LWOP must provide written justification and a statement as to the reason why the desired absence is required. 
(Ord. No. 85-19, § 1, 12-23-85) 
Sec. 2-105. - Absence for maternity/paternity reasons. 
(a)  Absence for maternity reasons. Maternity absence is not a separate type of leave. All policies, regulations and procedures as applied generally to leave also apply to absence for maternity reasons. 
(1)  Pregnancy is defined as a condition which eventually requires the employee to be absent from the job because of incapacitation. For leave purposes, a period of absence covering pregnancy and confinement is to be treated like any other condition which incapacitates the employee from the performance of duty. As a means of accommodating this temporary incapacitation, appropriate leave is available to the employee. 
(2)  Granting leave. Maternity absences may be a combination of sick leave, annual leave, and LWOP in the following particulars: 
a.  Sick leave to the extent available, may be used to cover the time required for physical examinations and periods of incapacitation; and 
b.  Annual leave or LWOP may be used to cover absence due to reasons such as the need for a period of adjustment following birth and recuperation, or for time to make arrangements for the care of the child or children only if requested by the employee and approved by the appropriate village official (an employee need not exhaust sick and annual leave prior to requesting LWOP). 
(3)  Request for leave. An employee shall inform such appropriate village official as soon as possible of her intention to request leave for maternity reasons and indicate the type of leave desired, approximate dates, and anticipated duration to allow the supervisor to prepare for any staffing adjustments which may be necessary. The length of absence from duty for maternity reasons is a matter requiring joint determination by the said employee, her physician and the appropriate village official. 
(4)  Request for light duty/temporary reassignment. Department heads shall make every reasonable effort to accommodate requests for light duty or temporary reassignment to other available work for which the employee is qualified and which is requested due to maternity reasons. Such requests shall be accompanied by appropriate medical recommendations. 
(b)  Absence for paternity reasons. A male employee may request only annual leave or LWOP for purposes of assisting or caring for his minor child or children or the mother of said child or children while she is incapacitated for maternity reasons. Approval of leave for these reasons is consistent with the policy of granting leave in any other situation where leave is requested due to the incapacitation of said employee's spouse. Each such leave request shall be considered on its own merits. 
(Ord. No. 85-19, § 1, 12-23-85) 
Sec. 2-106. - Court leave. 
(a)  Absences for court or court-related service. Leave shall be granted in relation to court or 
court-related service in accordance with the following schedule: 
Nature of
Service Court 
Leave Official 
Duty Annual 
Leave 
or LWOP (1) Jury service, state or 
local court X (2) Witness service: a. In official capacity X b. Not in official capacity on behalf of private party X  
(b)  Determining nature of court service. The appropriate village official shall ascertain the exact nature of court service in order to determine whether the particular employee is entitled to court leave or official duty status. If a summons to witness service is not specific or clear, the appropriate village official shall contact appropriate authorities to determine the party on whose behalf the witness service is to be rendered. When the exact nature of court service is determined, records shall be accordingly noted. 
(1)  Court leave is defined as the authorized absence (without loss of, or reduction in, pay, leave to which otherwise entitled, credit for time or service, or performance rating) of an employee from work status for jury duty or for attending judicial proceedings in a nonofficial capacity as a witness on behalf of a state or local government. 
(2)  Employee's eligibility for court leave. Court leave shall be granted only to full-time and permanent part-time employees. All other employees shall be ineligible for court leave and must use either annual leave or LWOP to cover the period of absence from village duty for court service, however, such employee or employees may retain any fee or fees received incident to such court service. 
(3)  Granting court leave; pay status requirement. Court leave shall be granted only to eligible employees who, except for jury duty or service as a witness in a non-official capacity on behalf of a state or local governmental agency, would be in work status or on an annual leave. An employee on LWOP when called for such court service, although otherwise eligible for court leave, shall not be granted court leave; however, such individual may retain any fees or compensation received incident to court service. 
(4)  Employee on annual leave. If an eligible employee while on annual leave is summoned for jury duty or service as a witness in a non-official capacity on behalf of a state or local governmental agency while on annual leave, the employee's annual leave shall be canceled and the employee shall be placed on court leave for the duration of such court service. Employees who are not entitled to court leave must use annual leave or LWOP for the period of absence from duty for such court service. 
(5)  Overtime. No overtime is allowed for court service performed while an employee is on court leave. 
(6)  Fees in general. Employees who receive jury or witness fees for court service while on court leave must remit such fees to the appropriate village official. The amount of fees shall be retained by the village and may not exceed the amount of salary otherwise payable to the employee for the hours of court leave. Any such excess may be retained by the employee. The employee is entitled to retain an amount equal to the per diem allowance authorized. 
(c)  Official duty: 
(1)  Official duty status: An employee is in an official duty status (as distinguished from a leave status and without regard to any entitlement to court leave) if assigned by the village or summoned by proper authority to testify or produce official records on behalf of the village. 
(2)  Compensation. Employees who perform witness service in an official duty status shall be paid their regular salaries as employees, including any applicable night differential. In addition, such employees shall collect the authorized fees and any allowances for travel and subsistence expenses and retain an amount equal to actual allowable expenses. 
(3)  Witness services in a nonofficial capacity on behalf of a private party. An employee who testifies in a nonofficial capacity (as a private individual) on behalf of a private party is not performing official duty. The employee's absence shall be charged to annual leave or LWOP and the employee may retain any fees or compensation received for such witness service. 
(Ord. No. 85-19, § 1, 12-23-85) 
Sec. 2-107. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2007-30, § 2, adopted September 24, 2007, deleted § 2-107, which pertained to military leave and derived from Ord. No. 85-19, adopted December 23, 1985. 
Sec. 2-108. - Holiday leave. 
(a)  Holiday leave prerequisites. All village employees shall be required to work the scheduled work days both before and after any designated holiday and, in the event that the particular holiday is a scheduled workday, on the holiday as a prerequisite to receiving the holiday leave benefit. Any village employee who is absent on the day before or after a designated holiday, and whose absence is unexcused, shall not receive holiday leave benefit. 
(b)  Holiday observance. The following ten days shall be observed as holidays by the village and all village employees who have satisfied the aforementioned prerequisites shall be paid the rate of pay established as such holiday pay for each such holiday: 
(1)  New Year's Day; 
(2)  Dr. Martin Luther King Day; 
(3)  Good Friday; 
(4)  Memorial Day; 
(5)  Independence Day; 
(6)  Labor Day; 
(7)  Veteran's Day; 
(8)  Thanksgiving Day; 
(9)  Christmas Day; 
(10)  Presidents' Day. 
(c)  Holiday on nonscheduled workdays. 
(1)  Saturday. When a holiday falls on a Saturday, the preceding Friday shall be observed as the holiday. 
(2)  Sunday. When a holiday falls on a Sunday, the following Monday shall be observed as the holiday. 
(3)  Non-scheduled workday. When a holiday falls on an employee's nonscheduled workday, the first scheduled workday preceding the holiday is hereby designated as the employee's holiday. 
(Ord. No. 85-19, § 1, 12-23-85; Ord. No. 90-4, § 1, 2-26-90; Ord. No. 2001-33, § 2, 9-10-01; Ord. No. 2002-04, § 2, 2-11-02) 
Sec. 2-109. - Administrative leave. 
(a)  Administrative leave. Administrative leave is defined as absence from duty authorized by such appropriate village official, without charge to annual or sick leave and without loss of pay. Such leave must be approved by the village president. 
(b)  First aid examination and treatment for on-the-job injuries or illness: 
(1)  Employees on regular tour. If an employee on regular tour of duty is injured and the injury can be treated so that the employee can return to duty during that tour, the employee shall be excused without charge to annual or sick leave. The employee shall not be required to clock out when leaving the place of duty for first aid examination or treatment. 
(2)  Employee in overtime status. When an employee is directed by an appropriate village official to an on-site or off-site medical unit due to injury, all time spent waiting for and/or receiving medical attention, on the service day on which the injury occurred which would have been worked but for the medical attention, shall be credited as work time even though overtime hours may be involved. 
(Ord. No. 85-19, § 1, 12-23-85) 
Sec. 2-110. - Temporary assignments. 
(a)  Temporary assignment. Temporary assignment is defined as the placement of an employee in another established position for a limited period of time to perform duties and responsibilities other than those specifically set forth in his position description when a formal reassignment and/or promotion personnel action is not required. 
(b)  Light duty assignment. Employees may be assigned to light duty as follows: Employees recuperating from a serious injury or illness who are unable to perform their regularly assigned duties, may (if administratively feasible) be temporarily assigned to such duties as they can perform for a short period of time pending their recovery. Generally, these employees should be required to present acceptable medical evidence and such appropriate village official must be convinced that they can perform such light duty assignment without risk of further injury. Such appropriate village official is under no obligation to provide light duty assignments; moreover, such official shall take into account the employee's present abilities in developing and arranging light duty assignments. 
(c)  Termination of temporary assignment. A temporary assignment may be terminated at any time by such appropriate village official, either at his own discretion or at the request of the particular employee or employees. 
(Ord. No. 85-19, § 1, 12-23-85) 
Secs. 2-111-2-120. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - VILLAGE ADMINISTRATOR 

Sec. 2-121. - Position created; appointment, etc. 
    There is hereby created the position of village administrator. The village administrator shall be appointed by the president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees to serve an undetermined period at the pleasure of the president or by a mutually agreeable contract of employment. 
(Ord. No. 84-1, § 1(1.25.1), 2-13-84; Ord. No. 94-9, § 1, 6-27-94) 
Sec. 2-122. - Persons eligible. 
    The village administrator shall be of high moral character and have administrative experience. He shall be knowledgeable in management. No village trustee, village president or village clerk shall hold the office of village administrator during their term of office or within one year after their terms of office expire. 
(Ord. No. 84-1, § 1(1.25.2), 2-13-84; Ord. No. 85-4, § 1, 3-25-85; Ord. No. 85-6, § 1, 7-10-85; Ord. No. 94-9, § 1, 6-27-94) 
Sec. 2-123. - Outside employment. 
    The village administrator shall not be employed by any other person or governmental body during the period of his village employment, unless specifically authorized by the board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 84-1, § (1.25.3), 2-13-84; Ord. No. 94-9, § 1, 6-27-94) 
Sec. 2-124. - Vacancy in office. 
    In case the office of village administrator shall become vacant for any reason, the president, with the advice and consent of the board of trustees, may appoint an individual to act as temporary village administrator. The temporary village administrator shall have all the duties and responsibilities of the village administrator. 
(Ord. No. 84-1, § 1(1.25.4), 2-13-84; Ord. No. 94-9, § 1, 6-27-94) 
Sec. 2-125. - General duties and responsibilities. 
    It shall be the duty and responsibility of the village administrator to assist the president and board of trustees in adopting and modifying the village's zoning ordinance and securing and managing grant assistance programs. He shall administer the business licensing application procedure of the village. He shall attend all meetings of the board of trustees, zoning board of appeals and the plan commission and shall attend other public hearings involving the village and various branches and agencies thereof, which administer duties and responsibilities consistent with those hereinbefore specified, unless excused by the president. He shall investigate into the affairs of the village and into complaints in relation to matters concerning village services and administration and perform such other duties as may be required by the corporate authorities consistent with all village ordinances. The village administrator shall direct the administration and implementation of the zoning ordinance, subdivision control ordinance, comprehensive plan and other group management policies and ordinance. He shall serve as zoning administrator and as such coordinate all zoning and development, review activities and prepare reports on subdivision and zoning proposals as necessary in conjunction with the plan commission and zoning board of appeals. In addition, the village administrator shall ensure that all significant board actions are transmitted to the appropriate departments for implementation or action. He shall also be responsible for actively engaging in the pursuit of economic development opportunities that will enhance the village and act in a public relations capacity in matters relating to the village, particularly involving the business community. Finally, he shall supervise and direct all department heads to provide for a coordinated approach to the management of the village. 
(Ord. No. 84-1, § 1(1.25.5), 2-13-84; Ord. No. 85-4, § 1, 3-25-84; Ord. No. 85-6, § 1, 7-10-85; Ord. No. 94-9, § 1, 6-27-94) 
Secs. 2-126-2-135. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - VILLAGE ATTORNEY 

Sec. 2-136. - Legal advice. 
    The village attorney shall be the legal advisor of the village and shall render advice on all legal questions affecting it, whenever requested to do so by any village official. Upon request by the president or the board of trustees, he shall reduce any such opinion to writing. 
(Code 1965, § 1.6.4) 
Sec. 2-137. - Enforcement of judgments. 
    It shall be the duty of the village attorney to see to the full enforcement of all judgements or decrees entered in favor of the village, and of all similar interlocutory orders. 
(Code 1965, § 1.6.3) 
Sec. 2-138. - Handling lawsuits. 
    The village attorney shall prosecute or defend any and all suits or actions at law or equity to which the village may be a party, or in which it may be interested, or which may be brought against or by, any officer of the village on behalf of the village or in the capacity of such person as an officer of the village. 
(Code 1965, § 1.6.2) 
Sec. 2-139. - Special assessments. 
    It shall be the duty of the village attorney to see to the completion of all special assessment proceedings and condemnation proceedings. 
(Code 1965, § 1.6.5) 
Sec. 2-140. - Approval of surety bonds. 
    All bonds required by law or ordinance to be submitted to and approved by the board of trustees shall first be submitted to the village attorney, and it shall be his duty to examine said bonds, and if in his judgment the same are properly drawn and are legal and binding obligations, he shall endorse the same with his approval, and if not, he shall endorse his disapproval thereon, together with his reasons therefor. 
(Code 1965, § 1.6.6) 
Secs. 2-141-2-150. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - VILLAGE CLERK[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Licenses, permits and miscellaneous business regulations, Ch. 12; taxation, Ch. 24. 
State Law reference- Village clerk, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-15-5, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-25-90. 

Sec. 2-151. - Election, bond and salary. 
    The village clerk shall be elected for such term as may be prescribed by statute and shall take the statutory oath of office. He shall give bond with sureties to be approved by the board of trustees, conditioned upon the faithful performance of his duties. The village clerk shall be paid at an annual rate of $9,600.00. 
(Code 1965, § 1.4.1; Ord. No. 85-1, § 1, 1-28-85; Ord. No. 89-1, § 1, 1-23-89; Ord. No. 96-4, § 3, 9-9-96; Ord. No. 2004-34, § 3, 9-27-04; Ord. No. 2016-20, § 3, 10-24-16) 
Sec. 2-152. - General duties. 
    It shall be the duty of the village clerk to perform all duties and functions which may be required by him by statute or by ordinance, to attend the meetings of the board of trustees and to keep the records thereof, and to keep a record of all the officers of the village with the names of the person holding each office. 
(Code 1965, § 1.4.4) 
State Law reference- General duties of clerk, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-35-90. 
Sec. 2-153. - Records to be kept. 
    The village clerk shall keep the record of ordinances which is required to be kept by statute, and such other records as may be required by ordinance. He shall keep in a separate book a record of all licenses and permits issued by him, and of the amounts of money received by him, and he shall keep the record of accounts between his office and that of the treasurer. 
(Code 1965, § 1.4.3) 
Secs. 2-154-2-165. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - VILLAGE COLLECTOR[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference- Licenses, permits and miscellaneous business regulations, Ch. 12; taxation, Ch. 24. 

Sec. 2-166. - Office created. 
    There is hereby created the office of village collector, an executive office of the village. 
(Code 1965, § 1.5.1) 
State Law reference- Appointment of officers, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-30-5. 
Sec. 2-167. - General duties. 
    It shall be the duty of the collector to collect and receive all money due on special assessments and special taxes that are not paid directly to the treasurer or to some other village official, and to keep such records pertaining to such collections as may be required by statute or ordinance. 
(Code 1965, § 1.5.3) 
Sec. 2-168. - Reports. 
    The collector shall make such reports regarding delinquent special assessments as are required by statute, and shall make a monthly report to the board of trustees showing what money has been received, and the source thereof. The collector shall also make an annual report during the last month of the fiscal year showing all the activities of his office. 
(Code 1965, § 1.5.4) 
Secs. 2-169-2-180. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - VILLAGE TREASURER[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Cross reference- Licenses, permits and miscellaneous business regulations, Ch. 12; taxation, Ch. 24. 

Sec. 2-181. - Office created; term. 
    There is hereby created the office of village treasurer who shall be appointed for a term of one year. 
(Code 1965, § 1.8.1) 
State Law reference- Appointment of treasurer, 65 ILCS, 5/3.1-30-5. 
Sec. 2-182. - General duties. 
    The village treasurer shall perform such duties as may be prescribed for him by statute or ordinance. He shall receive all money paid into the village, either directly from the person paying the money or from the hands of such other officer or employee as may receive it, and he shall pay out money only on vouchers or orders properly signed by the president and the village clerk. 
(Code 1965, § 1.8.3) 
Sec. 2-183. - Deposit of funds. 
    The village treasurer shall deposit the village funds in such depositories as may be selected from time to time by the board of trustees; he shall keep the money belonging to the village separate and distinct from his own money, and shall not make private or personal use of any money belonging to the village. 
(Code 1965, § 1.8.4) 
State Law reference- General duties of treasurer, 65 ILCS, 5/3.1-35-40. 
Sec. 2-184. - Records. 
    The village treasurer shall keep the records showing all money received by him, showing the source from which it is received and the purpose for which it is paid; he shall keep records at all times showing the financial status of the village. 
(Code 1965, § 1.8.5) 
Sec. 2-185. - Accounts. 
    The village treasurer shall keep such books and accounts as may be required by statute or ordinance, and he shall keep them in the manner required by the board of trustees. 
(Code 1965, § 1.8.6) 
Sec. 2-186. - Register of warrants. 
    The village treasurer shall keep a register of all warrants, bonds or orders filed with him or paid by him, and all vouchers, as is required by statute. 
(Code 1965, § 1.8.7) 
Secs. 2-187-2-200. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 8. - VILLAGE ENGINEER OR SPECIAL ENGINEER 

Sec. 2-201. - Authorized. 
    The president with the consent of the board of trustees may from time to time engage a village engineer to represent or advise the village on engineering matters; he may also engage a special engineer to advise or represent the village on special matters or to assist the village engineer. 
(Code 1965, § 1.9.1) 
Sec. 2-202. - Duties. 
    The village engineer shall advise the president and board of trustees generally and specially on engineering matters as the same shall pertain to the program and problems of the village. 
(Code 1965, § 1.9.2) 
Secs. 2-203-2-215. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 9. - AUDITOR AND SPECIAL ACCOUNTS 

Sec. 2-216. - Authorized. 
    The president, with the consent of the board of trustees, may from time to time retain an auditor to advise the village on financial and fiscal matters; he may also engage special accountants to advise the village on special matters or to assist the auditor for the village. 
(Code 1965, § 1.7.1) 
Sec. 2-217. - Duties. 
    The auditor for the village shall prepare all financial statements requested by the village and required by law, and shall prepare the certified annual reports required by law. 
(Code 1965, § 1.7.2) 
State Law reference- The Illinois Municipal Auditing Law, 65 ILCS 5/8-8-1 et seq. 
Secs. 2-218-2-222. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 10. - CODE ENFORCEMENT OFFICER 

Sec. 2-223. - Position created. 
    There is hereby created the position of code enforcement officer. Code enforcement officers shall be appointed by the village president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees to serve as a full-time employees or part-time employees. 
(Ord. No. 2003-36, § 2, 10-13-03) 
Sec. 2-224. - General duties. 
    A code enforcement officer shall have authority to enforce the provisions of the property maintenance code and those provisions of the Crete Municipal Code as designated. A code enforcement officer shall exercise authority as necessary in the interest of public health, safety and general welfare to interpret and implement property maintenance code and other designated provisions, to inspect properties and to institute court proceedings. The code enforcement officer is also hereby designated as a "code official" as described in the International Codes adopted in the Crete Municipal Code. 
(Ord. No. 2003-36, § 2, 10-13-03) 
Secs. 2-225-2-230. - Reserved.

Sec. 2-261. - Generally. 
    The board of fire and police commissioners is hereby created. Such board shall be governed by the provisions of division 2.1 of article 10 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-1 et seq.), which division is hereby adopted by reference as if set out at length in this Code.

(Ord. No. 98-31, § 1, 1998)

ARTICLE VII. - RECAPTURE FEES 

Sec. 2-321. - Capital improvement fee. 
    For the purpose of funding necessary capital improvements that are not the responsibility of a single builder or land developer nor which are a general benefit to the public as a whole, there shall be required a fee for each use or any increment in the size of any established use that uses water in the amount of $1.67/gallon of an estimated daily water usage. 
(Ord. No. 86-13A, § 1, 1-5-87) 
Editor's note- Sec. 2-321 contains a capital improvement fee which the village advised had been erroneously deleted in Supplement No. 8. Such provisions, formerly § 6-27(g), have been redesignated by the editor as § 2-321 with the concurrence of the village.

(3)  Dorsetshire Drive Watermain Extension (lots fronting Dorsetshire Drive), per lineal foot of frontage ..... 31.67 
(Limited to five years from September 26, 1994) 
(Ord. No. 93-3, 2-8-93; Ord. No. 94-22, § 1, 9-26-94; Ord. No. 95-9, § 1, 2-13-95)

ARTICLE VIII. - POLITICAL ACTIVITIES AND GIFTS 

Sec. 2-801. - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this article, the following terms shall be given these definitions: 
    Campaign for elective office means any activity in furtherance of an effort to influence the selection, nomination, election, or appointment of any individual to any federal, state, or local public office or office in a political organization, or the selection, nomination, or election of presidential or vice-presidential electors, but does not include activities (i) relating to the support or opposition of any executive, legislative, or administrative action, (ii) relating to collective bargaining, or (iii) that are otherwise in furtherance of the person's official duties. 
    Candidate means a person who has filed nominating papers or petitions for nomination or election to an elected office, or who has been appointed to fill a vacancy in nomination, and who remains eligible for placement on the ballot at a regular election, as defined in section 1-3 of the Election Code (10 ILCS 5/1-3). 
    Collective bargaining has the same meaning as that term is defined in Section 3 of the Illinois Public Labor Relations Act (5 ILCS 315/3). 
    Compensated time means, with respect to an employee, any time worked by or credited to the employee that counts toward any minimum work time requirement imposed as a condition of his or her employment, but for purposes of this article, does not include any designated holidays, vacation periods, personal time, compensatory time off or any period when the employee is on a leave of absence. With respect to officers or employees whose hours are not fixed, compensated time includes any period of time when the officer is on premises under the control of the employer and any other time when the officer or employee is executing his or her official duties, regardless of location. 
    Compensatory time off means authorized time off earned by or awarded to an employee to compensate in whole or in part for time worked in excess of the minimum work time required of that employee as a condition of his or her employment. 
    Contribution has the same meaning as that term is defined in section 9-1.4 of the Election Code (10 ILCS 5/9-1.4). 
    Employee means a person employed by the Village of Crete whether on a full-time or part-time basis or pursuant to a contract, whose duties are subject to the direction and control of an employer with regard to the material details of how the work is to be performed, but does not include an independent contractor. 
    Employer means the Village of Crete. 
    Gift means any gratuity, discount, entertainment, hospitality, loan, forbearance, or other tangible or intangible item having monetary value including, but not limited to, cash, food and drink, and honoraria for speaking engagements related to or attributable to government employment or the official position of an officer or employee. 
    Leave of absence means any period during which an employee does not receive (i) compensation for employment, (ii) service credit towards pension benefits, and (iii) health insurance benefits paid for by the employer. 
    Officer means a person who holds, by election or appointment, an office created by statute or article, regardless of whether the officer is compensated for service in his or her official capacity. 
    Political activity means any activity in support of or in connection with any campaign for elective office or any political organization, but does not include activities (i) relating to the support or opposition of any executive, legislative, or administrative action, (ii) relating to collective bargaining, or (iii) that are otherwise in furtherance of the person's official duties. 
    Political organization means a party, committee, association, fund, or other organization (whether or not incorporated) that is required to file a statement of organization with the state board of elections or a county clerk under section 9-3 of the Election Code (10 ILCS 5/9-3), but only with regard to those activities that require filing with the state board of elections or a county clerk. 
    Prohibited political activity means: 
(1)  Preparing for, organizing, or participating in any political meeting, political rally, political demonstration, or other political event. 
(2)  Soliciting contributions, including but not limited to the purchase of, selling, distributing, or receiving payment for tickets for any political fundraiser, political meeting, or other political event. 
(3)  Soliciting, planning the solicitation of, or preparing any document or report regarding anything of value intended as a campaign contribution. 
(4)  Planning, conducting, or participating in a public opinion poll in connection with a campaign for elective office or on behalf of a political organization for political purposes or for or against any referendum question. 
(5)  Surveying or gathering information from potential or actual voters in an election to determine probable vote outcome in connection with a campaign for elective office or on behalf of a political organization for political purposes or for or against any referendum question. 
(6)  Assisting at the polls on election day on behalf of any political organization or candidate for elective office or for or against any referendum question. 
(7)  Soliciting votes on behalf of a candidate for elective office or a political organization or for or against any referendum question or helping in an effort to get voters to the polls. 
(8)  Initiating for circulation, preparing, circulating, reviewing, or filing any petition on behalf of a candidate for elective office or for or against any referendum question. 
(9)  Making contributions on behalf of any candidate for elective office in that capacity or in connection with a campaign for elective office. 
(10)  Preparing or reviewing responses to candidate questionnaires. 
(11)  Distributing, preparing for distribution, or mailing campaign literature, campaign signs, or other campaign material on behalf of any candidate for elective office or for or against any referendum question. 
(12)  Campaigning for any elective office or for or against any referendum question. 
(13)  Managing or working on a campaign for elective office or for or against any referendum question. 
(14)  Serving as a delegate, alternate, or proxy to a political party convention. 
(15)  Participating in any recount or challenge to the outcome of any election. 
    Prohibited source means any person or entity who: 
(1)  Is seeking official action (i) by an officer or (ii) by an employee, or by the officer or another employee directing that employee; 
(2)  Does business or seeks to do business (i) with the officer or (ii) with an employee, or with the officer or another employee directing that employee; 
(3)  Conducts activities regulated (i) by the officer or (ii) by an employee, or by the officer or another employee directing that employee; or 
(4)  Has interests that may be substantially affected by the performance or non-performance of the official duties of the officer or employee. 
(Ord. No. 2004-19, § 1, 5-11-04) 
Sec. 2-802. - Prohibited political activities. 
(a)  No officer or employee shall intentionally perform any prohibited political activity during any compensated time, as defined herein. No officer or employee shall intentionally use any property or resources of the Village of Crete in connection with any prohibited political activity. 
(b)  At no time shall any officer or employee intentionally require any other officer or employee to perform any prohibited political activity (i) as part of that officer or employee's duties, (ii) as a condition of employment, or (iii) during any compensated time off (such as holidays, vacation or personal time off). 
(c)  No officer or employee shall be required at any time to participate in any prohibited political activity in consideration for that officer or employee being awarded additional compensation or any benefit, whether in the form of a salary adjustment, bonus, compensatory time off, continued employment or otherwise, nor shall any officer or employee be awarded additional compensation or any benefit in consideration for his or her participation in any prohibited political activity. 
(d)  Nothing in this section prohibits activities that are permissible for an office or employee to engage in as part of this or her official duties, or activities that are undertaken by an officer or employee on a voluntary basis which are not prohibited by this article. 
(e)  No person either (i) in a position that is subject to recognized merit principles of public employment or (ii) in a position the salary for which is paid in whole or in part by federal funds and that is subject to the federal standards for a merit system of personnel administration applicable to grant-in-aid programs, shall be denied or deprived of employment or tenure solely because he or she is a member or an officer of a political committee, of a political party or of a political organization or club. 
(Ord. No. 2004-19, § 1, 5-11-04) 
Sec. 2-803. - Gift ban. 
    Except as permitted by this article, no officer or employee, and no spouse of or immediate family member living with any officer or employee (collectively referred to herein as "recipient"), shall intentionally solicit or accept any gift from any prohibited source, as defined herein, or which is otherwise prohibited by law or article. No prohibited source shall intentionally offer or make a gift that violates this section. 
(Ord. No. 2004-19, § 1, 5-11-04) 
Sec. 2-804. - Exceptions. 
    Section 2-803 is not applicable to the following: 
(1)  Opportunities, benefits, and services that are available on the same conditions as for the general public. 
(2)  Anything for which the officer or employee, or his or her spouse or immediate family member, pays the fair market value. 
(3)  Any (i) contribution that is lawfully made under the election code or (ii) activities associated with a fundraising event in support of a political organization or candidate. 
(4)  Educational materials and missions. 
(5)  Travel expenses for a meeting to discuss business. 
(6)  A gift from a relative, meaning those people related to the individual as father, mother, son, daughter, brother, sister, uncle, aunt, great aunt, great uncle, first cousin, nephew, niece, husband, wife, grandfather, grandmother, grandson, granddaughter, father-in-law, mother-in-law, son-in-law, daughter-in-law, brother-in-law, sister-in-law, stepfather, stepmother, stepson, stepdaughter, stepbrother, stepsister, half brother, half sister, and including the father, mother, grandfather, or grandmother of the individual's spouse and the individual's fiance or fiancee. 
(7)  Anything provided by an individual on the basis of a personal friendship unless the recipient has reason to believe that, under the circumstances, the gift was provided because of the official position or employment of the recipient or his or her spouse or immediate family member and not because of the personal friendship. In determining whether a gift is provided on the basis of personal friendship, the recipient shall consider the circumstances under which the gift was offered, such as: (i) the history of the relationship between the individual giving the gift and the recipient of the gift, including any previous exchange of gifts between those individuals; (ii) whether to the actual knowledge of the recipient the individual who gave the gift personally paid for the gift or sought a tax deduction or business reimbursement for the gift; and (iii) whether to the actual knowledge of the recipient the individual who gave the gift also at the same time gave the same or similar fits to other officers or employees, or their spouses or immediate family members. 
(8)  Food or refreshments not exceeding $75.00 per person in value on a single calendar day; provided that the food or refreshments are (i) consumed on the premises from which they were purchased or prepared or (ii) catered. For the purposes of this section, "catered" means food or refreshments that are purchased ready to consume which are delivered by any means. 
(9)  Food, refreshments, lodging, transportation, and other benefits resulting from outside business or employment activities (or outside activities that are not connected to the official duties of an officer or employee), if the benefits have not been offered or enhanced because of the official position or employment of the officer or employee, and are customarily provided to others in similar circumstances. 
(10)  Intra-governmental and inter-governmental gifts. For the purpose of this article, "intra-governmental gift" means any gift given to an officer or employee from another officer or employee, and "inter-governmental gift" means any gift given to an officer or employee by an officer or employee of another governmental entity. 
(11)  Bequests, inheritances, and other transfers at death. 
(12)  Any item or items from any one prohibited source during any calendar year having a cumulative total value of less than $100.00. 
Each of the exceptions listed in this section is mutually exclusive and independent of every other. 
(Ord. No. 2004-19, § 1, 5-11-04) 
Sec. 2-805. - Disposition of gifts. 
    An officer or employee, his or her spouse or an immediate family member living with the officer or employee, does not violate this article if the recipient promptly takes reasonable action to return a gift from a prohibited source to its source or gives the gift or an amount equal to its value to an appropriate charity that is exempt from income taxation under Section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as now or hereafter amended, renumbered, or succeeded. 
(Ord. No. 2004-19, § 1, 5-11-04) 
Sec. 2-806. - Ethics advisor. 
(a)  The village president, with the advice and consent of the board of trustees shall designate an ethics advisor for the Village of Crete. The duties of the ethics advisor may be delegated to an officer or employee of the Village of Crete and said the position shall not be considered an office by the Village of Crete. 
(b)  The ethics advisor shall provide guidance to the officers and employees of the Village of Crete concerning the interpretation of and compliance with the provisions of this article and state ethics laws. The ethics advisor shall perform such other duties as may be delegated by the corporate authorities. 
(Ord. No. 2004-19, § 1, 5-11-04) 
Sec. 2-807. - Ethics commission. 
(a)  There is hereby created a commission to be known as the ethics commission of the Village of Crete. The ethics commission shall be composed of the village president, village clerk and one member of the board of trustees that has served the greatest number of years as a member of the board of trustees. In the event any member of the ethics commission is unable to serve due to a conflict or other reason, said vacancy shall be filled by a trustee who has served the second greatest number of years on the board of trustees. Further vacancies shall be filled thereafter by the remaining trustees according to the number of years served. In the event a vacancy is not able to be filled by the above procedure, a vacancy will be filled by the chief judge of the Twelfth Judicial Circuit from a list of two or more names of Crete residents submitted by the village president. No more than two members of the commission shall belong to the same political party at the time such appointments are made. Party affiliation shall be determined by affidavit of the person appointed. 
(b)  At the first meeting of the commission, the commissioners shall choose a chairperson from their number. Meetings shall be held at the call of the chairperson or any two commissioners. A quorum shall consist two commissioners, and official action by the commission shall require the affirmative vote of two members. The commission shall be active only as required upon receipt of a complaint and until it has made a final determination. 
(c)  The commission shall have the following powers and duties: 
(1)  To promulgate procedures and rules governing the performance of its duties and the exercise of its powers. 
(2)  Upon receipt of a signed, notarized, written complaint, to investigate, conduct hearings and deliberations, issue recommendations for disciplinary actions, impose fines in accordance with section 2-810 of this article and refer violations of section 2-802 or 2-803 of this article to the appropriate attorney for prosecution. The commission shall, however, act only upon the receipt of a written complaint alleging a violation of this article and not upon its own prerogative. 
(3)  To receive information from the public pertaining to its investigations and to require additional information and documents from persons who may have violated the provisions of this article. 
(4)  To compel the attendance of witnesses and to compel the production of books and papers pertinent to an investigation. It is the obligation of all officers and employees of the Village of Crete to cooperate with the commission during the course of its investigations. Failure or refusal to cooperate with request by the commission shall constitute grounds for discipline or discharge. 
(5)  The powers and duties of the commission are limited to matters clearly within the purview of this article. 
(d)  Complaints alleging a violation of this article shall be filed with the ethics commission. 
(1)  Within three business days after the receipt of a complaint, the commission shall send by certified mail, return receipt requested, a notice to the respondent that a complaint has been filed against him or her and a copy of the complaint. The commission shall send by certified mail, return receipt requested, a confirmation of the receipt of the complaint to the complainant within three business days after receipt by the commission. The notices to the respondent and the complainant shall also advise them of the date, time, and place of the meeting to determine the sufficiency of the complaint and to establish whether probable cause exists to proceed. 
(2)  Upon not less than 48 hours' public notice, the commission shall meet to review the sufficiency of the complaint and, if the complaint is deemed sufficient to allege a violation of this article, to determine whether there is probable cause, based on the evidence presented by the complainant, to proceed. The meeting may be closed to the public to the extent authorized by the open meetings act. The commission shall issue notice to the complainant and the respondent of the commission's ruling on the sufficiency of the complaint and, if necessary, on probable cause to proceed within seven business days after receiving the complaint. 
If the complaint is deemed sufficient to allege a violation of section 2-803 of this article and there is a determination of probable cause, then the commission's notice to the parties shall include a hearing date scheduled within four weeks after the complaint's receipt. Alternatively, the commission may elect to notify in writing the attorney designated by the corporate authorities to prosecute such actions and request that the complaint be adjudicated judicially. If the complaint is deemed not sufficient to allege a violation or if there is not determination of probable cause, then the commission shall send by certified mail, return receipt requested, a notice to the parties of the decision to dismiss the complaint, and that notice shall be made public.
