If the complaint is deemed sufficient to allege a violation of section 2-802 of this article, then the commission shall notify in writing the attorney designated by the corporate authorities to prosecute such actions and shall transmit to the attorney the complaint and all additional documents in the custody of the commission concerning the alleged violation. 
(3)  On the scheduled date and upon a least 48 hours' public notice of the meeting, the commission shall conduct a hearing on the complaint and shall allow both parties the opportunity to present testimony and evidence. The hearing may be closed to the public only if authorized by the open meeting act. 
(4)  Within 30 days after the date the hearing or any recessed hearing is concluded, the commission shall either (i) dismiss the complaint or (ii) issue a recommendation for discipline to the alleged violator and to the village president or other officer having authority to discipline the officer or employee, or impose a fine upon the violator, or both. The particular findings in the case, any recommendation for discipline, and any fine imposed shall be a matter of public information. 
(5)  If the hearing was closed to the public, the respondent may file a written demand for a public hearing on the complaint within seven business days after the issuance of the recommendation for discipline or imposition of a fine, or both. The filing of the demand shall stay the enforcement of the recommendation or fine. Within 14 days after receiving the demand, the commission shall conduct a public hearing on the complaint upon at least 48 hours' public notice of the hearing and allow both parties the opportunity to present testimony and evidence. Within seven days thereafter, the commission shall publicly issue a final recommendation to the alleged violator and to the village president or other officer having authority to discipline the officer or employee or impose a fine upon the violator, or both. 
(6)  If a complaint is filed during the 60 days preceding the date of any election at which the respondent is a candidate, the commission shall render its decision as required under subsection (e) within seven days after the complaint is filed, and during the seven days preceding that election, the commission shall render such decision before the date of that election, if possible. 
(7)  The commission may fine any person who intentionally violates any provision of section 2-803 of this article in an amount of not less than $1,001.00 and not more than $5,000.00. The commission may fine any person who knowingly files a frivolous complaint alleging a violation of this article in an amount of not less than $1,001.00 and not more than $5,000.00. The commission may recommend any appropriate discipline up to and including discharge. 
(8)  A complaint alleging the violation of this article must be filed within one year after the alleged violation. 
(Ord. No. 2004-19, § 1, 5-11-04) 
Sec. 2-810. - Penalties. 
(a)  A person who intentionally violates any provision of section 2-802 of this article may be punished by a term of incarceration in a penal institution other than a penitentiary for a period of not more than 364 days, and may be fined in an amount not to exceed $2,500.00. 
(b)  A person who intentionally violates any provision of section 2-803 of this article is subject to a fine in an amount of not less than $1,001.00 and not more than $5,000.00. 
(c)  Any person who intentionally makes a false report alleging a violation of any provision of this article to the local enforcement authorities, the state's attorney or any other law enforcement official may be punished by a term of incarceration in a penal institution other than a penitentiary for a period of not more than 364 days, and may be fined in an amount not to exceed $2,500.00. 
(d)  A violation of section 2-802 of this article shall be prosecuted as a criminal offense by an attorney for the Village of Crete by filing in the circuit court an information, or sworn complaint, charging such offense. The prosecution shall be under and conform to the rules of criminal procedure. Conviction shall require the establishment of the guilt of the defendant beyond a reasonable doubt. A violation of section 2-803 of this article may be prosecuted as a quasi-criminal offense by an attorney for the Village of Crete, or, if an ethics commission has been created, by the commission through the designated administrative procedure. 
(e)  In addition to any other penalty that may be applicable, whether criminal or civil, an officer or employee who intentionally violates any provision of section 2-802 or section 2-803 of this article is subject to discipline or discharge. 
(Ord. No. 2004-19, § 1, 5-11-04) 
Chapter 3 - ALARM SYSTEMS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Fees and fines schedule, § 2-301; licenses, permits and miscellaneous business regulations, Ch. 12. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 3-1. - Alarm line fee. 
(a)  All alarm systems, whether fire, burglar, panic or other type, which is directly wired into and monitored by the dispatch center maintained, directly or pursuant to contract, for the village police and fire departments shall be charged a monthly line fee as set by the corporate authorities of the village, see section 2-301. Collection of said line fee shall be supervised by the village administrator and shall be collected as part of the monthly monitoring fee by the alarm monitoring company and forwarded to the village monthly. 
(b)  Failure to pay said alarm line fee shall constitute a petty offense and is punishable by a fine as set forth in section 2-301. Each month the line fee remains unpaid shall constitute a separate offense. Any person accused of a violation of this section may settle and compromise said claim without a court appearance by payment of one-half of the minimum required fine to the village clerk at the village hall within ten business days of the date of violation if the compromise box designation is so checked on the complaint and notice to appear form. 
(Ord. No. 98-28, § 2, 8-10-98) 
Secs. 3-2-3-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ALARMS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Section 2 of Ord. No. 2006-09, adopted March 27, 2006, retitled art. II, burglar alarms, to read as herein set out. 

Sec. 3-16. - False alarms. 
    Any person, business or corporation who has installed or operates on any premises or vehicle a burglary, fire, panic or medical emergency alert or alarm system that automatically sounds an audible alarm or notifies the Crete Police or Fire Department to respond to said alarm, when it is determined there is no valid purpose for said alarm or alert to be activated (hereinafter "false alarm") shall be made subject to a penalty as set forth in article V of chapter 2 shown immediately to the right of the reference to section 3-16, which penalty shall be imposed for each event or occasion upon which the false alarm is sounded in excess of two such false alarms in any given three-month period. 
(Ord. No. 808, (Art. 10.14), 9-10-79; Ord. No. 86-13A, § 1, 1-5-87; Ord. No. 2006-09, § 3, 3-27-06) 
Sec. 3-17. - Alarm key holders. 
    Any person, business or corporation operating any premises alarm subject to the section 3-16 regulation, shall provide and maintain accurate information to the chief of police or the premises' individual alarm service company regarding names, addresses and phone numbers of persons who have both the ability and knowledge of the operation of said alarms ("alarm key holder") who can silence audible alarms and/or deactivate repetitive alarm activations. The failure to provide and maintain accurate alarm key holder information to the chief of police or the premises' individual alarm service company shall constitute a petty offense punishable pursuant to the provisions of subsection 3-1(b) above, including compromise payment provisions. 
(Ord. No. 2006-09, § 5, 3-27-06) 
Chapter 4 - ALCOHOLIC LIQUOR[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Health and sanitation, ch. 11; licenses, permits and miscellaneous business regulations, ch. 12; food dealers, food handlers, etc., § 12-371 et seq.; consumption of intoxicating liquors in parking lots, § 12-626; public intoxication, § 13-8; liquor and drunkenness in public parks, § 17-22; taxation, ch. 24. 
State Law reference- The Liquor Control Act of 1934, 235 ILCS 5/1-1 et seq.; local liquor control powers, 235 ILCS 5/4-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 4-1. - Definitions. 
    Terms used in this chapter which are defined in The Liquor Control Act of 1934 shall have the meanings assigned to them in such Act. 
(Code 1965, §§ 9.1.1-9.1.6) 
State Law reference- Applicable definitions, 235 ILCS 5/1-3 et seq. 
Sec. 4-2. - Offenses involving underaged persons. 
(a)  No person under the age of 21 years shall consume, purchase or accept delivery of alcoholic liquor or have alcoholic liquor in his possession within the village; provided, the possession and dispensing, or consumption by a person under the age of 21 years of alcoholic liquor in the performance of a religious service or ceremony, the consumption by a person under the age of 21 years under the direct supervision and approval of the parent or guardian of such person in the privacy of the parent's or guardian's home, or the possession and delivery of alcoholic liquors in the course of a person's employment by a licensee under this chapter is not prohibited. 
(b)  No person after purchasing or otherwise obtaining alcoholic liquor shall sell, give or deliver such alcoholic liquor to another person under the age of 21 years, except as allowed under subsection (a). 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for a parent or guardian to knowingly suffer or permit any minor child of which he is the parent or guardian to violate any provision of this chapter. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any owner or occupant of any premises located within the village to knowingly allow any person under the age of 21 years to remain on such premises while in the possession of alcoholic liquor or while consuming alcoholic liquors in violation of subsection (a). 
(e)  No person to whom a license has been issued pursuant to this chapter, or any officer, associated member, representative, agent or employee of such licensee shall sell, give or deliver alcoholic liquor to any person under the age of 21 years. 
(f)  It shall be unlawful for any holder of a liquor license, or his agent or employee, to suffer or permit any person under the age of 21 years to be or remain in any room or compartment adjoining or adjacent to, or situated in the room or place where such licensed premises is located; provided, that this subsection shall not apply to any person under the age of 21 years who is accompanied by his or her parent or guardian, or to that portion of any licensed premises which derives its principal business from restaurants or the sale of service or commodities other than alcoholic liquor. 
(Code 1965, Arts. 9.18.1-9.18.4; Ord. No. 83-4, § 1, 6-13-83) 
State Law reference- Offenses involving underaged persons, 235 ILCS 5/6-16, 5/6-20. 
Sec. 4-3. - Offenses involving consumption outside of the licensee's building. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any patron of any liquor-dispensing establishment, holding a license allowing consumption on the premises, to allow consumption of liquor purchased from said establishment outside of the building in which the liquor was purchased, unless either the license specifically allows for consumption on the premises outside the building and such building has been specifically designed and approved for such outdoor consumption, or, the liquor commissioner has specifically authorized the licensee's use in this regard. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any holder of any liquor license, or his agent or employee, to knowingly allow any patron to purchase alcoholic liquor with the intent of violating subsection (a) above. 
(Ord. No. 88-1, § 1, 1-25-88) 
Sec. 4-4. - Removal of alcoholic liquor from premises. 
    No person shall remove or attempt to remove, nor shall a licensee, or his agent or employee, permit a person to remove, any alcoholic liquor in an open container or when permitted by applicable license in any packaging other than its original container or packaging from the licensed premises. The licensee shall post a sign at all exits prohibiting open liquor from being removed from the licensed premises. The licensee is prohibited from making "to go" or carry-out sales from the licensed premises unless the licensee is properly licensed for sales in closed containers. 
(Ord. No. 2010-24, § 2, 7-12-10) 
Sec. 4-5. - Persons on-premises after hours. 
    No persons, except peace officers in the performance of law enforcement duties or licensees including employees actually on duty, shall be upon the premises of any licensed building or area, excepting licensed as Class B or Class G, between the hour of closing and the hour of opening as established by section 4-48 of the Crete Municipal Code. 
(Ord. No. 2010-24, § 2, 7-12-10) 
Sec. 4-6. - Liquor on public ways and other public places. 
(a)  No person shall possess, except in an unbroken original package, or consume alcoholic liquor upon a public way, other than in an area designated as a licensed premises by the liquor commissioner as set forth in this chapter 4. 
(b)  No person shall possess, except in an unbroken original package, or consume alcoholic liquor within a park, public library or public mass transit facility unless such areas, or portions thereof, are designated as licensed premises by the liquor commissioner as set forth in this chapter 4. 
(c)  It shall be an affirmative defense to a violation under this section that the liquor commissioner, park district, public library district or public mass transit system specifically authorized the possession or consumption of alcohol liquor upon the property or area involved at such time and place of the alleged violation. 
(Ord. No. 2010-24, § 2, 7-12-10) 
Sec. 4-7. - Alcoholic beverages on any parking lot, parking garage, business property or vacant lots. 
(a)  No person shall possess any alcoholic beverage in an open or unsealed container while the person is located on: 
(1)  A parking lot or parking garage accessible to the public; 
(2)  The exterior portion of any property being used as a business that is accessible to the public or for any other use not permitted in a residential zoning district excepting cemeteries and public utilities; or 
(3)  Any vacant lot accessible to the public with or without the owner's permission. 
(b)  It shall be an affirmative defense to a violation under this section that the location has been specifically licensed by the village president as the liquor control commissioner to permit the sale, possession or consumption of alcoholic beverages. 
(c)  The terms "parking lot" and "parking garage" as used in this section shall have the same meaning as the terms "parking area, public" and "parking lot" as defined in the Crete Zoning Ordinance, as amended. 
(Ord. No. 2010-24, § 2, 7-12-10) 
Secs. 4-8-4-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LICENSE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to require, classify, etc., licenses, 235 ILCS 5/4-1. 

Sec. 4-16 - Required license. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, offer for sale at retail or give away any alcoholic liquor in the village in conjunction with a business or any nonresidential context, without having a retail liquor dealer's license. No person issued such a license shall sell, offer for sale or give away an alcoholic liquor in violation of the terms of their license. 
(Code 1965, Art. 9.2; Ord. No. 2011-06, § 2, 2-28-11) 
Sec. 4-17. - Application. 
    Application for such license shall be made to the commissioner, upon forms prepared and furnished by the village. Each application shall be signed by the applicant. If the applicant is a partnership, all partners shall sign the application. If the applicant is a corporation or club, all officers shall sign the application and indicate their official position and title. The information recited in the application form shall be verified upon the oath or affirmation of each person signing the application. Such application shall be filed with the commissioner and be accompanied by a nonrefundable application fee of $100.00. Each application shall contain at least the following information and statements: 
(1)  The name, age and address of the applicant in the case of an individual; in the case of a partnership, the names ages, and addresses of all partners; in the case of a corporation or a club, the date of incorporation, the objects for which it was organized, the names and addresses of the officers, directors, manager, and, if a majority in interest of the stock of the corporation is owned by one person or his nominees, the name, age and address of that person. 
(2)  The citizenship of the applicant, his place of birth and, if a naturalized citizen, the time and place of his naturalization. 
(3)  The nature of the business which the applicant intends to carry out on the premises along with the percentage of the applicant's gross revenues for alcoholic liquor as compared with the percentage of revenue from other sources within the proposed licensed premises. 
(4)  The nature of entertainment proposed to be offered on the proposed premises. 
(5)  The class of license for which application is made. 
(6)  The length of time that the applicant has been a resident of the state, county and village; or, if a partnership, the length of time that each partner has been a resident of the state, county and village; or if a corporation, the length of time which its proposed resident manager has been a resident of the state, county and village. 
(7)  The length of time that the applicant has been in a business of that character; or, in the case of a corporation, the date on which its charter was issued, the state of incorporation, and, if a foreign corporation, the date upon which said foreign corporation was first registered to do business within the State of Illinois. 
(8)  The address of the proposed premises, a detailed description of the proposed premises, an exterior photograph of the premises, and an interior layout plan of the proposed premises including the approximate number of seats and/or the maximum number of occupants allowed by code. 
(9)  A list of governmental entities to which the applicant has submitted an application for a liquor license, the date of such application, the disposition of such application and the dates, reason and length of suspension or revocation of such license, if any. 
(10)  A list of convictions for any violation [other than traffic violations,] of any city ordinance or state or federal statute indicating the name of the offense and date(s) of conviction. In the case of a corporation, such information must be supplied of all officers, directors, shareholders owning more than five per cent of the stock, and the manager. In the case of a partnership, such information must be supplied by all partners. 
(11)  Whether a previous license by any state or subdivision thereof or by the federal government has been revoked and the reasons therefor. 
(Code 1965, Art. 9.3; Ord. No. 88-1, § 1, 1-25-88; Ord. No. 2016-22, § 3, 11-28-16) 
Sec. 4-18. - Hearing on license application. 
(a)  Calling; notice. Upon the filing of an application for a liquor license, the commissioner shall fix a time and place for a hearing thereon. Such hearing shall be scheduled not more than 45 days following the date upon which a completed application has been submitted. Notice of such hearing shall be given in a newspaper providing general circulation within the village. Such notice shall be given not less than five business days prior to the hearing. The notice shall contain the time, place and date of the hearing, the name or names of the applicant(s) and the proposed location of the premises on which licensee's privileges will be maintained. 
(b)  Report to council. After conducting a hearing in relation to the application for a license (the hearing shall be used to afford all interested persons an opportunity to be heard in relation to matters and issues relating to the licensing application process), the commissioner shall report his findings and decision to the board of trustees of the village. Such decision shall be based on the criteria set forth in this article. 
(c)  Criteria. The commissioner shall not issue a new liquor license unless he has found that the issuance of such license is in the best interest of the people of the village. In deciding whether the issuance is in the best interest of the people of the village, the commissioner shall consider the following criteria, namely: 
(1)  The class liquor license applied for; 
(2)  The past performance of the applicant; or if a partnership, that of each of the partners; or if a corporation, that of the officer's directors, and majority stockholder, and manager, as a licensee; 
(3)  The character and reputation of the applicant; or if a partnership, that of each of the partners; or if a corporation, that of the officers, directors, majority stockholder and manager; 
(4)  The general design and layout of the proposed premises with particular attention given to the licensee's ability to control access by minors; 
(5)  The amount of the applicant's anticipated gross revenues from the sale of alcoholic liquor as compared with gross revenue from other sources within the proposed license premises; 
(6)  The nature of entertainment, if any which the applicant intends to provide; 
(7)  The compliance of the premises with all ordinances of the city and specifically health, building, property, maintenance, housing, and fire safety ordinances; 
(8)  Any monies owed to the city by the applicant which have remained unpaid for a period of more than 45 days, whether for bills, taxes, licenses or otherwise; 
(9)  The number, class and type of licensed premises within a one-mile radius of the proposed licensed premises, and within the city as a whole; 
(10)  The zoning general character of the surrounding neighborhood and the projected impact of the premises upon the surrounding neighborhood and the city as a whole; 
(11)  The law enforcement problems, if any, which would be created by the opening of the premises; 
(12)  The type of operation of the business and its relation to the sale of alcohol; 
(13)  The applicability of section 4-20 to the applicant's location. 
(d)  Post-hearing action. The commissioner shall render a decision on each application within 15 business days following the conclusion of the hearing as provided hereinbefore. The applicant shall be notified in writing of the commissioner's decision along with the reasons therefor. If the application is denied, the applicant may request a hearing before the commissioner within seven days of the receipt of such notification. Said request shall be made in writing. A hearing in response to said request shall be held within a reasonable period of time thereafter at a mutually agreeable time and place. 
(e)  Conditions. If a license is issued by the commissioner, said licensee shall be subject to the terms of this chapter and also to any additional terms or conditions as discussed and agreed upon during the hearing process, the furnishing of dram shop insurance as required by state statutes and appropriate provisions of this article and the provisions of this chapter to the extent that the same are applicable to the operation of licensed premises. 
(Code 1965, Art. 9.6; Ord. No. 770, § 1, 11-28-77; Ord. No. 785, § 1, 9-11-78; Ord. No. 821, § 1, 4-28-80; Ord. No. 84-5, § 1, 3-28-84; Ord. No. 85-11, § 1, 8-26-85; Ord. No. 86-2, § 1, 6-9-86; Ord. No. 88-1, § 1, 1-25-88; Ord. No. 2011-06, § 2, 2-28-11) 
Sec. 4-19. - Prerequisites for license issuance. 
(a)  At the time set forth herein for the renewal of a retail liquor license, and in the case of a successful new applicant, within ten days of notification of the commissioner's action in relation to the license application, the current licensee or new applicant shall present the following information and materials to the commissioner, namely: 
(1)  Evidence of dram shop liability insurance in the form of a certificate of insurance issued by an insurance company licensed to do business in the State of Illinois and providing insurance for the applicant, the owner and/or lessor of the premises in the minimum amount as required by Illinois law; and 
(2)  Payment to the village clerk in cash, or its equivalency of the license fee in the amount required for the particular class of license to be issued. 
(b)  Following the fulfillment on the part of applicant of the requirements specified in subsection (a) hereinabove, the commissioner shall issue the appropriate liquor license. 
(c)  If the requirements of subsection (a) are not fulfilled within the period of time specified therein, subject application shall be deemed withdrawn and applicant shall be required to tender a new application pursuant to the various procedures set forth in this article. 
(Ord. No. 88-1, § 1, 1-25-88) 
Sec. 4-20. - License classes generally. 
    Licenses required by this article shall be of the following classes: 
(1)  Class A. Class "A" licenses shall authorize the retail sale on the premises specified of alcoholic liquor for consumption on the premises as well as other retail sales of such liquor in their original package not for consumption on the premises. Any Class A license may be supplemented by a rider which shall authorize the retail sale on the premises of alcoholic liquor for consumption on said premises, and limited to within the building and any attached patio areas which are fenced or otherwise prohibit entry or exit directly to the outside parking areas or adjacent properties (unless by way of an emergency exit.) Said rider is not transferable to any other person or entity and may not be transferred from a particular premises and specifically do not permit any sales of liquor in any manner for consumption off the premises other than as packaged sales in their original package. 
(2)  Class B. Class "B" licenses shall authorize the retail sale on the premises for consumption on the premises as well as other retail sales in their original package not for consumption on the premises of alcoholic liquor in the form of beer or wine only. For the purposes of this section, "beer" means a beverage obtained by the alcoholic fermentation of an infusion or concoction of barley, or other grain, malt, and hops in water, and includes, among other things, beer, ale, stout, lager beer, porter and the like. For the purposes of this section, "wine" means any alcoholic beverage obtained by the fermentation of the natural contents of fruits, or vegetables, containing sugar, including such beverages when fortified by the addition of alcohol or spirits as defined in 235 ILCS 5/1-1 et seq. (as amended). 
(3)  Class C. Class "C" licenses shall authorize the retail sale of alcoholic liquor, but not for consumption on the premises where sold. 
(4)  Class E. Class "E" licenses shall authorize the retail sale and consumption of all types of alcoholic liquor on any part of the premises and grounds of a country club or golf course either public or private. This shall also allow consumption of all types of alcoholic liquor on any day of the week as early as 6:00 a.m. including Sunday and shall observe the hours of closing as referenced in section 4-48. 
(5)  Class F. Class "F" licenses shall authorize the sale and distribution of alcoholic liquor for consumption on the premises of a hotel as defined by this chapter or other ordinances of the village and the state. This shall not include areas of the hotel buildings or grounds that may be either leased or rented to another party for the purpose of establishing a retail alcoholic liquor establishment or other similar business. 
(6)  Class G. Class "G" licenses shall authorize the use of particular alcoholic liquor as ancillary to the preparation of food or drink or other business operation, including, but not limited to, the use of alcohol as a complementary beverage to customers but not holding out said business as a bar, tavern or alcoholic drinking establishment. 
(7)  Class H. Class "H" licenses shall authorize the use of particular alcoholic liquor as ancillary to the preparation of food and drink in connection with the business of catering. 
(8)  Class K-AL. Class "K-AL" licenses shall authorize the retail sale and consumption on the premises of all types of alcoholic liquor in an establishment whose principal business is one of gaming. 
(9)  Class K-B. Class "K-B" licenses shall authorize the retail sale and consumption of alcoholic liquor in the form of beer and wine, as described above in paragraph (2), in an establishment whose principal business is one of gaming. 
(10)  [Class M.] A Class "M" license shall entitle the licensee to operate a microbrewery or winery and to manufacture and store beer, cider or wine product on the licensed premises and to make sales at retail of the on-site manufactured products for consumption on or off the premises, and to store and sell at retail other alcoholic liquor, including distilled spirits or liquor purchased wholesale, for consumption on the premises. Permitted free sampling of product manufactured on the premises is allowed in accordance with the zoning regulations of the licensed premises. Additionally, a wholesale sale of product manufactured on site is permitted in accordance with the state license obtained. Nothing in the issuance of a Class "M" license pursuant to this section shall be considered to relieve the licensee of any responsibility for complying with applicable state and federal regulations relating to the manufacture and/or sale of beer products or other alcoholic beverages and applicable environmental regulations and all applicable business and other regulations of the village. 
(11)  Class R. Class "R" licenses shall authorize retail sale on the premises specified of alcoholic liquor for consumption on the premises only and shall only be granted for use in an establishment that contains a restaurant as defined in this chapter. A Class "R" license shall be co-extensive with the rights and prerogatives of a Class "A" license including the rider; provided, however, that under no circumstances shall a Class "R" license holder sell packaged or bulk liquor goods. This license shall be void and of no effect if it is not used in an establishment containing a restaurant as defined in this chapter. 
(12)  Class T. Class "T" licenses, shall authorize the sale of alcoholic liquor by civic, charitable, governmental or other not-for-pecuniary-profit organizations on specified premises or within an area specifically designated in the license for not longer than a period of 72 hours. A Class "T" license shall be available to only such organizations whose offices are located within the village, and in no event shall an organization be issued more than three such permits in any calendar year. 
(Ord. No. 88-1, § 1, 1-25-88; Ord. No. 96-04, § 2, 1-8-96; Ord. No. 97-10, § 2, 3-24-97; Ord. No. 2005-07, § 2, 3-14-05; Ord. No. 2011-06, § 2, 2-28-11; Ord. No. 2015-25, § 2, 9-28-15; Ord. No. 2016-22, § 4, 11-28-16) 
Sec. 4-21. - Persons eligible. 
    No license of any kind required by this article shall be issued to: 
(1)  A person who is not a resident of the village if the license is being requested by an individual; 
(2)  A person who is not of good character and reputation in the community in which he resides; 
(3)  A person who is not a citizen of the United States; 
(4)  A person who has been convicted of a felony under any federal or state law, if the president determines, after investigation, that such person has not been sufficiently rehabilitated to warrant the public trust; 
(5)  A person who has been convicted of being the keeper or is keeping a house of ill fame; 
(6)  A person who has been convicted of pandering or other crime or misdemeanor opposed to decency and morality; 
(7)  A person whose license issued under this the Liquor Control Act of 1934 has been revoked for cause; 
(8)  A person who at the time of application for renewal of any license issued hereunder would not be eligible for such license upon a first application; 
(9)  A copartnership, unless all of the members of such copartnership shall be qualified to obtain a license; 
(10)  A corporation, if any officer, manager or director thereof, or any stockholder or stockholders owning in the aggregate more than five percent of the stock of such corporation, would not be eligible to receive a license hereunder for any reason other than citizenship and residence within the political subdivision; 
(11)  A corporation unless it is incorporated in Illinois, or unless it is a foreign corporation which is qualified under the Illinois Business Corporation Act to transact business in Illinois; 
(12)  A person whose place of business is conducted by a manager or agent unless the manager or agent possesses the same qualifications required by the licensee; 
(13)  A person who has been convicted of a violation of any federal or state law concerning the manufacture, possession or sale of alcoholic liquor, subsequent to January 31, 1934 or has forfeited his bond to appear in court to answer charges for any such violation; 
(14)  A person who does not beneficially own the premises for which a license is sought, or does not have a lease thereon for the full period for which the license is to be issued; 
(15)  Any law enforcing public official of the village, including members of any village liquor control commission, the president of the board of trustees, any member of the board of trustees; 
(16)  A person who is not a beneficial owner of the business to be operated by the licensee; 
(17)  A person who has been convicted of a gambling offense as prescribed by any of subsections (a)(3) through (a)(10) of section 28-1 of, or as proscribed by section 28-3 of, the Criminal Code of 1961, approved July 28 1961, as heretofore or hereafter amended, [720 ILCS 5/28-1, 5/28-3] or as proscribed by a statute replaced by any of the aforesaid statutory provisions; 
(18)  A person to whom a federal wagering stamp has been issued by the federal government for the current tax period; 
(19)  A co-partnership to which a federal wagering stamp has been issued by the federal government for the current tax period, if any of the partners have been issued a federal wagering stamp by the federal government for the current tax period; 
(20)  A corporation, if any officer, manager or director thereof, or any stockholder owning in the aggregate more than 20 percent of the stock of such corporation has been issued a federal wagering stamp for the current tax period; 
(21)  Any premises for which a federal wagering stamp has been issued by the federal government for the current tax period; 
(22)  A person who intends to sell alcoholic liquors for use or consumption on his or her licensed retail premises who does not have liquor liability insurance coverage for that premises in an amount that is at least equal to the maximum liability amounts set out in 235 ILCS 5/6-21 (as amended); 
(23)  A person who knowingly has misstated a material fact under oath during the application process. 
(Code 1965, Art. 9.4; Ord. No. 88-1, § 1, 1-25-88; Ord. No. 2011-06, § 2, 2-28-11) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 235 ILCS 5/6-2. 
Sec. 4-22. - Retail sales near churches, schools, etc. 
(a)  No license required by this article shall be issued for the sale at retail of any alcoholic liquor within 100 feet of any church, school other than an institution of higher learning, hospital, home for aged or indigent persons or for veterans, their spouses or children or any military or naval station, provided, that this prohibition shall not apply to hotels offering restaurant service, regularly organized clubs, or to restaurants, food shops or other places where sale of alcoholic liquors is not the principal business carried on, if such place of business so exempted shall have been established for such purposes prior to July 1, 1934; nor to the renewal of a license for the sale at retail of alcoholic liquor on-premises within 100 feet of any church or school where such church or school has been established within such 100 feet since the issuance of the original license. In the case of a church, the distance of 100 feet shall be measured to the nearest part of any building used for worship services or educational programs and not to property boundaries. 
(b)  Nothing in this section shall prohibit the issuance of a license to a church or private school to sell at retail alcoholic liquor if any such sales are limited to periods when groups are assembled on the premises solely for the promotion of some common object other than the sale or consumption of alcoholic liquors. 
(Code 1965, Art. 9.14; Ord. No. 88-1, § 1, 1-25-88) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 235 ILCS 5/6-11. 
Sec. 4-23. - Stores selling school supplies, lunches, etc. 
    No license required by this article shall be issued to any person for the sale at retail of any alcoholic liquor at any store or other place of business where the majority of customers are minors of school age or where the principal business transacted consists of school books, school supplies, food, lunches or drinks for such minors. 
(Code 1965, Art. 9.4; Ord. No. 88-1, § 1, 1-25-88) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 235 ILCS 5/6-12. 
Sec. 4-24. - Requirements for restaurant and club licenses. 
    No person shall receive a license required by this article to sell alcoholic liquor upon any premises as a restaurant nor as a club unless it has the qualifications respectively described in sections 1-3.23 and 1-3.24 of the Liquor Control Act of 1934 [235 ILCS 5/1-3.23, 5/1-3.24]. 
(Code 1965, Art. 9.4, § 9.6.6; Ord. No. 785, § 3, 9-11-78; Ord. No. 85-11, § 1, 8-26-85; Ord. No. 88-1, § 1, 1-25-88) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 235 ILCS 5/6-25. 
Sec. 4-25. - Fees. 
(a)  The fee which shall be paid to the village prior to the issuance or renewal of a license required by this article shall be as follows: 
(1)  Class "A" ..... $800.00 
(2)  Class "B" ..... 800.00 
(3)  Class "C" ..... 800.00 
(4)  Class "E" ..... 800.00 
(5)  Class "F" ..... 800.00 
(6)  Class "G" ..... 100.00 
(7)  Class "H" ..... 100.00 
(8)  Class "K-AL" ..... 800.00 
(9)  Class "K-B" ..... 800.00 
(10)  Class "M" ..... 800.00 
(11)  Class "R" ..... 800.00 
(12)  Class "T" ..... 25.00 
(b)  The fee to be paid shall be reduced in proportion to the full calendar month which have expired in the year prior to the issuance of the license. 
(c)  All such fees shall be paid to the village collector at the time the application is approved. Such fees shall be immediately transferred to the village treasurer for deposit in the village's general corporate fund or in such other fund or funds as the president and board of trustees of the village may from time to time designate. 
(Code 1965, Arts. 9.6, 9.7; Ord. No. 770, § 1, 11-28-77; Ord. No. 785, § 1, 9-11-78; Ord. No. 821, § 1, 4-28-80; Ord. No. 84-5, § 1, 3-28-84; Ord. No. 86-13A, § 1, 1-5-87; Ord. No. 88-1, § 1, 1-25-88; Ord. No. 96-04, § 3, 1-8-96; Ord. No. 2011-06, § 2, 2-28-11; Ord. No. 2013-06, § 2, 5-13-13; Ord. No. 2015-25, § 3, 9-28-15; Ord. No. 2016-22, § 5, 11-28-16) 
Sec. 4-26. - Maximum number. 
    Licenses shall be issued in the following numbers by classes: 
(1)  Class "A": This class shall allow for six such licenses, and such number may be changed from time to time as determined by village board action. 
(2)  Class "B": No limits. 
(3)  Class "C": No limits. 
(4)  Class "E": No limits. 
(5)  Class "F": No limits. 
(6)  Class "G": No limits. 
(7)  Class "H": No limits. 
(8)  Class "K-AL": This class shall allow for two such licenses, and such number may be changed from time to time as determined by village board action. Provided, further, no such license may be issued for any premises which is located on Main Street between North Street and Cass Street. 
(9)  Class "K-B": This class shall allow for ten such licenses, and such number may be changed from time to time as determined by village board action. Provided, further, no such license may be issued for any premises which is located on Main Street between North Street and Cass Street. 
(9)  Class "M": This class shall allow for one such license, and such number may be changed from time to time as determined by village board action. 
(10)  Class "R": No limits. 
(11)  Class "T": No limits. 
(Code 1965, Art. 9.6; Ord. No. 770, § 1, 11-28-77; Ord. No. 785, § 1, 9-11-78; Ord. No. 821, § 1, 4-28-80; Ord. No. 84-5, § 1, 3-28-84; Ord. No. 88-1, § 1, 1-25-88; Ord. No. 96-04, § 4, 1-8-96; Ord. No. 2005-07, § 3, 3-14-05; Ord. No. 2011-06, § 2, 2-28-11; Ord. No. 2015-25, § 4, 9-28-15; Ord. No. 2016-22, § 6, 11-28-16; Ord. No. 2017-15, § 2, 6-12-17; Ord. No. 2018-18, § 2, 9-24-18) 
Sec. 4-27. - Term. 
(a)  All licenses issued pursuant to this chapter shall be valid from the date of issuance, or in the case of renewals, from the first day of June through the business night of May 31, including the morning hours of May 31, per the closing times as stated in the license. A new or renewed license will be required in order for the licensed establishment to commence operations on June 1 of the new [license] year. 
(b)  Any licensee who ceases to do business for whatever reason, or who closes his place of business for whatever reason for a period in excess of 45 days should notify the commissioner in writing of the same. The licensee may be required by the liquor commissioner, after receipt of notice of a hearing, to show cause why the license for such establishment should not be terminated. 
(Code 1965, Art. 9.5; Ord. No. 88-1, § 1, 1-25-88; Ord. No. 2011-06, § 2, 2-28-11) 
Sec. 4-28. - Renewal. 
(a)  Any licensee may renew his liquor license at the expiration thereof, provided he is then qualified to receive a license and the premises for which such renewal license is sought are suitable for such purpose; and, provided further, that this section shall not be construed as a vested right which shall in any case prevent the village from decreasing the number of licenses to be issued within the village. 
(b)  In the event that a liquor license is issued, the holder of such license shall bear continuing responsibility to update the original license application form so as to furnish the liquor commissioner with current information in relation to corporate shareholders, partnership members, and/or changes in management establishing local residence for the purposes of license issuance. Failure to do so shall be grounds for immediate license suspension. 
(Code 1965, Art. 9.5; Ord. No. 88-1, § 1, 1-25-88) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 235 ILCS 5/6-1. 
Sec. 4-29. - Transfer. 
(a)  A license issued pursuant to this article shall be purely a personal privilege, good for not to exceed one year after issuance unless revoked sooner and shall not constitute property, nor shall it be subject to attachment, garnishment or execution, nor shall it be alienable or transferable, voluntarily or involuntarily, or subject to being encumbered or hypothecated, subject, however, to exceptions hereinafter provided in this section. Such license shall not descend by the laws of testate or intestate devolution, but it shall cease upon the death of the licensee, provided that executors or administrators of the estate of any deceased licensee, and the trustee of any insolvent or bankrupt licensee, when such estate consists in part of alcoholic liquor, may continue the business of the sale or manufacture of alcoholic liquor under order of the appropriate court, and may exercise the privileges of the deceased, or such insolvency or bankruptcy until the expiration of such license but not longer than six months after the death, bankruptcy or insolvency of such licensee. A refund shall be made of that portion of the license fees paid for any period in which the licensee shall be prevented from operating under such license in accordance with the provisions of this subsection. 
(b)  Notwithstanding any other provisions of this article a license holder or the legal representative of a deceased or incompetent person who held such a license, may, at his option, transfer the license upon the sale of the business premises upon which the alcoholic beverages are sold, or have been sold, provided that the purchaser qualified in all respects necessary for the granting of an application for such license contained in this chapter and that the referred to qualifications have first been acknowledged and approved in writing by the village president. If a purchaser does not qualify within six months as herein provided, the license will be automatically revoked and not reissued except upon application for an original issuance of a license. 
(Code 1965, Art. 9.9; Ord. No. 88-1, § 1, 1-25-88) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 235 ILCS 5/6-1. 
Sec. 4-30. - Change of location. 
(a)  A retail liquor dealer's license shall permit the sale of alcoholic liquor only in the premises described in the application and license. Such location may be changed only upon permission from the village president. No change of location shall be permitted unless the proposed new location is a proper one for the retail sale of alcoholic liquor under law and ordinance. 
(b)  Inasmuch as businesses involving the issuance of a liquor license are subject to review and approval upon issuance of such license initially, any substantial change in business operations, including, but not by way of limitation, structural remodeling, renovation, addition or expansion, or the addition or development of entertainment or amusement facilities, shall subject such license to review for continued compliance in relation to the terms of the original issuance. 
(Code 1965, Art. 9.10; Ord. No. 88-1, § 1, 1-25-88) 
Sec. 4-31. - Records, etc. 
    The president shall keep or cause to be kept a complete record of all licenses issued by him pursuant to this article; and shall furnish the village clerk, the village treasurer, and the chief of police each with a copy thereof. Upon the issuance of any new license, or the revocation of any license, the president shall give written notice of such action to each of such officers within 48 hours of such action. 
(Code 1965, Art. 9.8; Ord. No. 88-1, § 1, 1-25-88) 
Sec. 4-32. - Revocation. 
    The president may revoke any retail liquor dealer's license for cause in the manner provided by law. 
(Code 1965, Art. 9.19; Ord. No. 88-1, § 1, 1-25-88) 
State Law reference- Revocation for cause authorized, 235 ILCS 5/4-4; revocation procedures, 235 ILCS 5/7-5. 
Sec. 4-33 - Penalties. 
    Whosoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this article shall be guilty of an offense and subject to the penalties as set forth in 235 ILCS 5/7-5 (as amended). 
(Ord. No. 2011-06, § 2, 2-28-11) 
Secs. 4-34-4-45. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - REGULATIONS FOR RETAIL ESTABLISHMENTS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- General regulatory authority of municipalities over retail sale of alcoholic liquor, 235 ILCS 5/4-1. 

Sec. 4-46. - Sanitation-Generally. 
    All premises used for the retail sale of alcoholic liquor, or for the storage of such liquor for such sale, shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition, and shall be kept in full compliance with the ordinances regulating the condition of premises used for the storage or sale of food for human consumption, and the same shall be approved by the county board of health. 
(Code 1965, Art. 9.12) 
Cross reference- Health and sanitation, ch. 11; food dealers, food handlers, etc., § 12-371 et seq. 
Sec. 4-47. - Same-Employees. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to employ in any premises used for the retail sale of alcoholic liquor any person who is afflicted with, or who is a carrier of, any contagious, infectious or venereal disease. It shall be unlawful for any person who is afflicted with or a carrier of any such disease to work in or about any premises or to engage in any way in the handling, preparation or distribution of such liquor. 
(Code 1965, Art. 9.13) 
Cross reference- Food dealers, food handlers, etc. § 12-371 et seq. 
Sec. 4-48. - Closing hours, etc. 
(a)  All classes other than Class T: 
6:00 am Sunday through Thursday until 1:00 am the following day; 
6:00 am Friday and Saturday until 2:00 am the following day; 
Hours of operation on New Year's Eve shall begin 6:00 am and conclude 5:00 am on the following day. 
Class T: 
Specifically annotated by license. 
(b)  Restaurants, clubs or hotels whose premises are licensed under this chapter, shall be permitted to remain open during periods of time differing from the hours established by subsection (a) hereinabove, provided, however, that: 
(1)  No licensee or agent or employee thereof shall sell any alcoholic liquor except during the hours permitted in subsection (a) hereinabove. 
(2)  No alcoholic liquor may be served within 20 minutes prior to the conclusion of hours of operation as permitted in subsection (a) and further all alcoholic liquor so regulated must be cleared from public areas and tables at the time of conclusion of said hours of operation. 
(3)  With regard to restaurants, no alcoholic liquor shall be consumed on the premises later than 15 minutes after the hour of closing as permitted in subsection (a) hereinabove. All businesses holding Class C licenses shall be allowed to permit persons upon their premises for the purposes of conducting business other than that of the sale and/or consumption of alcoholic beverages. 
(Code 1965, Art. 9.15, § 9.6.6; Ord. No. 576, § 1, 9-17-65; Ord. No. 785, § 3, 9-11-78; Ord. No. 857, § 1, 9-13-82; Ord. No. 85-12, § 1, 8-26-85; Ord. No. 88-1, § 1, 1-25-88; Ord. No. 96-04, § 5, 1-8-96; Ord. No. 97-10, § 3, 3-24-97; Ord. No. 2007-32, §§ 2, 3, 10-8-07) 
Sec. 4-49. - Posting of license. 
    Every person licensed in accordance with the provisions of this chapter shall immediately post the license so issued in a conspicuous place on the licensed premises and shall keep such license so posted during all of the time said license is in force. 
(Ord. No. 88-1, § 1, 1-25-88) 
Chapter 5 - ANIMALS AND FOWL[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Fees and fines schedule, § 2-301; nuisances generally, ch. 16; animals in parks, § 17-24. 
State Law reference- Animal Control Act, 510 ILCS 5/1 et seq.; general authority to regulate animals, 65 ILCS 5/11-20-9. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 5-1. - Animal warden. 
(a)  The office of animal warden is hereby created. 
(b)  The duties of the animal warden shall be as follows: 
(1)  To routinely and/or periodically patrol the public streets, alleys and public places of the village; 
(2)  To apprehend and confine dogs or other animals who may be dangerous to the public safety or health of the village; 
(3)  To provide suitable and humane facilities, care and treatment for the confinement of such animals, within the village limits or otherwise; 
(4)  To destroy vicious, diseased or poisonous animals when it appears to him that the public health or safety of the village is directly and immediately in jeopardy; 
(5)  To dispose of the remains of such animals or creatures in accordance with public health regulations; 
(6)  To assist the police department with said duties; 
(7)  To do all other acts or things necessary or requisite to effectuate and implement the meanings and interest of the subject matter of this chapter; 
(8)  To do such other acts or things as may be contracted between him and the village or such acts or things that the president and board of trustees may from time to time direct him to do. 
(c)  The animal warden shall be deputized as a special policeman for the limited purpose of exercising his duties. He shall be empowered, accordingly, to issue complaints or citations against offenders or violators of any of the provisions of this chapter. The animal warden need not be a resident of the village. 
(d)  An animal warden shall be compensated by salary by the president and board of trustees in such amount as they may determine and such salary may be in weekly, monthly, annual or such other installments as the president and board of trustees believe to be to the best interests of the village. 
(e)  The animal warden salary, equipment costs and vehicle costs shall be defrayed by a $0.55/month charge on the village services bill mailed quarterly to all residential and commercial accounts. 
(Ord. No. 723, § 1(6.2.15), 8-5-74; Ord. No. 2001-50, § 2, 12-10-01) 
Cross reference- Officers and employees generally, § 2-86 et seq. 
Sec. 5-2. - Powers of policemen. 
    Members of the police department shall have the same powers as the animal warden in the absence of the animal warden. 
(Ord. No. 723, § 1(6.2.15), 8-5-74) 
Sec. 5-3. - Use of steel jaw leghold traps. 
    No person shall use or permit the use of any leghold animal trap or similar device with spring activated jaws of the type used for the trapping of fur-bearing animals, which has a capability of inflicting cruelty upon small animals and threatening the health, safety, and welfare of small children. 
(Ord. No. 83-7, § 1(6.1.11), 7-25-83) 
Cross reference- Hunting prohibited, § 13-3. 
Sec. 5-4. - Permissible animals. 
    Except as otherwise provided in the zoning ordinance, the only animals which shall be allowed to be housed or kept in the village by any owner or resident shall be those commonly characterized as domestic pets such as dogs, cats rabbits, caged birds (not fowl), guinea pigs, hamsters and similar pets which are not confined or held for business or breeding purposes, except as the same may be incidental thereto. 
(Code 1965, § 6.1.10) 
Sec. 5-5. - Cruelty. 
    No person shall cruelly treat any animal in the village in any way. Any person who inhumanely beats, underfeeds, overload, or abandons any animal shall be guilty of an offense. 
(Code 1965, § 6.1.1) 
State Law reference- Authority to prohibit cruelty to animals, 65 ILCS 5/11-5-6; Humane Care for Animals Act, 510 ILCS 70/1 et seq. 
Sec. 5-6. - Impoundment. 
(a)  The animal warden and/or members of the police department shall impound all stray animals at the Forest South Animal Hospital, or at such other animal hospital as the chief of police shall from time to time determine, subject to the approval of the president and board of trustees. 
(b)  The animal hospital staff shall care for such impounded animals for a period of three days following their impoundment and shall provide proper sustenance and human care for them during such period. The cost for such care shall be as set forth in article V of chapter 2 immediately to the right of the reference to section 5-6, or such increased or diminished figures as the chief of police shall from time to time determine subject to the approval of the president and board of trustees. 
(c)  If the owner of an impounded animal wishes to claim such impounded animal the owner shall first obtain a release form from the police department, which department shall, upon issuance of the release, serve a complaint for the violation of this chapter. An owner, upon presentation of the release to the animal hospital and the payment of the accrued per diem cost for animal care to the hospital, shall be entitled to reclaim the animal. 
(d)  If an owner does not claim an animal during the three-day impoundment period, a suitable home will be sought for the animal by the hospital staff and if the same cannot be found, the animal will be turned over to the Humane Society, and if such organization does not have sufficient accommodations for the animal, the same shall be humanely destroyed and per diem and disposition costs paid by the village. 
(e)  In the instance of a stray animal being impounded as the result of a reported "bite" case, the animal will be impounded at the animal hospital for a period of not less than ten days and at a cost as set forth in article V of the instant ordinance immediately to the right of the reference to section 5-6(e), said cost to be borne by the village unless an owner claims such animal pursuant to the procedures contained in subsection (c). 
(Ord. No. 740, § 6.2.16, 9-22-75; Ord. No. 86-13A, § 1, 1-5-87) 
Sec. 5-7. - Reports of rabies. 
    It shall be the duty of every veterinarian or other person who discovers any animal to be suffering with rabies to report such fact immediately to the chief of police. Such report shall give the name, if known, and the place of residence of the person owning or harboring such animal, the place where the animal can be found, and any license number of the animal, if known. Such animal shall be immediately taken up and impounded in the manner provided in this chapter, and securely kept until the chief of police can make or cause to be made an examination of said dog or other animal. If upon examination, it is determined that such animal is suffering with rabies, the animal shall be immediately killed. 
(Code 1965, §§ 6.2.12, 6.2.14; Ord. No. 723, § 1, 8-5-74; Ord. No. 86-13A, § 1, 1-5-87; Ord. No. 2003-35, § 2, 9-22-03) 
State Law reference- Reports of rabies, 510 ILCS 5/12, 5/13; penalty for ordinance violations, 65 ILCS 5/1-2-1, 5/1-2-1.1. 
Sec. 5-8. - Wild or dangerous animals. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to permit any dangerous animal or vicious animal to run at large within the village. Exhibitions or parades of animals which are ferae naturae in the eyes of the law are prohibited. The members of the police department or any other person in the village are authorized to kill any dangerous animal of any kind when it is necessary for the protection of any person or property. 
(Code 1965, §§ 6.1.2, 6.1.5) 
Sec. 5-9. - Noises. 
    It shall be unlawful to harbor or keep any animal which disturbs the peace by loud noises at any time of the day or night. 
(Code 1965, § 6.1.3) 
Sec. 5-10. - Livestock. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to permit any cattle, horse, swine, sheep, goats, or poultry under his care, custody or control to run at large in the village. Any such animal running at large in any public place in the village shall be impounded in the manner provided in this chapter. It shall be unlawful for any person to picket or tie any such animal in any street or residential area of the village for the purpose of grazing or feeding. 
(Code 1965, § 6.1.4) 
Sec. 5-11. - Diseased animals. 
    No domestic animal afflicted with a contagious or infectious disease shall be allowed to run at large, or to be exposed in any public place whereby the health of man or beast may be affected, nor shall such diseased animal be shipped or removed from the premises of the owner thereof, except under the supervision of the chief of police or the health officer. The health officer shall secure such disposition of any diseased animal and such treatment of affected premises as to prevent the communication and spread of the contagion or infection except in cases where the state veterinarian is empowered to act. 
(Code 1965, § 6.1.6) 
Sec. 5-12. - Licensing and regulation of stables. 
(a)  As used in this section the phrase "the business of operating a stable" shall mean providing buildings for the shelter and feeding of horses and renting horses for hire for riding or related purposes. 
(b)  No person shall conduct the business of operating a stable without first having secured a license for same. An annual license fee shall be a charge as set forth in article V of chapter 2 immediately to the right of the reference to section 5-12, which fee shall be paid to the village in relation to such license. 
(c)  The buildings and grounds of stables shall be maintained in an orderly and sanitary manner and no manure or refuse of any kind or description shall be burned upon the premises but shall be otherwise disposed of. 
(Ord. No. 657, § 1(2.2.25B), 6-22-70; Ord. No. 820, § 1, 4-28-80; Ord. No. 86-13A, § 1, 1-5-87) 
Cross reference- Licenses, permits and miscellaneous business regulations, ch. 12. 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to locate and regulate the use and construction of stables, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-8. 
Sec. 5-13. - Licensing and regulation of small animal stores. 
(a)  As used in this section the term "small animal store" shall be construed to include any establishment for the raising, training, boarding or selling of dogs, cats, birds, mice, rats or other small animals for hire or profit, or any establishment where more than three dogs or cats are harbored or kept. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to operate a small animal store anywhere in the village without having first secured a license therefor. The annual fee to be paid to the village for such license shall be as set forth in article V of chapter 2 immediately to the right of the reference to section 5-13. 
(c)  Every place used as a small animal store shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition, and no refuse or waste material shall be allowed to remain thereon for more than 24 hours. All animals shall be humanely treated, and any animal having any disease shall be properly isolated and treated. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.25; Ord. No. 86-13A, § 1, 1-5-87) 
Cross reference- Licenses, permits and miscellaneous business regulations, ch. 12. 
State Law reference- State licensing and regulation of pet stores, 225 ILCS 605/1 et seq. 
Secs. 5-14-5-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - DOGS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 5-31. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2003-35, § 2, adopted Sept. 22, 2003, deleted § 5-31, which pertained to the penalty for violation of this article and was derived from Ord. No. 723, § 1, 8-5-74; and Ord. No. 86-13A, § 1, 1-5-87. 
Sec. 5-32. - Vaccination. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to own, possess or harbor any dog in the village unless the dog has been vaccinated against rabies as required by state law. 
(Code 1965, § 6.2.2) 
State Law reference- Rabies vaccinations, 510 ILCS 5/8. 
Sec. 5-33. - Leashes and running at large. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to cause or permit, or to fail to take reasonably necessary steps to prevent any dog under their care, custody or control, to run at large anywhere within the limits of the village. Further, no dog shall be allowed to go upon any public street, alley or sidewalk, or other public place unless it is controlled by a leash made of chain, leather or other substantial material, which leash must be of sufficient length to prevent unreasonable interference or contact with other persons or animals on said public street, alley, sidewalk or other public place. The leash must be affixed securely to the animal's collar or harness as provided in this article and the opposite end must have a suitable loop or hand grip to assure control of the animal. 
(b)  At such times as when the dog is located upon the private property where it is housed, and said private property is not suitably fenced: 
(1)  The dog must be tethered or securely connected to a fixed pole, tree, fence post or other suitable anchorage by a leash or connector made of chain, leather or other suitable material, which said leash or connector shall not exceed such length to prevent said dog from causing unreasonable interference or contact to persons on surrounding properties or public sidewalks or rights-of-way. The leash must be affixed securely to the animal's collar or harness of appropriate size for the animal as provided in this article; or 
(2)  The owner or person having care or custody of the dog must be outside within the presence of the dog and positioned such to control the dog and prevent the dog from leaving the property. Compliance with this subsection (2) shall not be a defense to the dog running at large in violation of subsection (a) above, if the dog physically leaves the property while so attended. 
(c)  Dogs which are running at large shall be taken up and impounded. 
(Code 1965, §§ 6.2.6, 6.2.7; Ord. No. 723, § 1, 8-5-74; Ord. No. 2009-09, § 2, 2-23-09) 
Sec. 5-34. - Prohibited in public places. 
(a)  No dog shall be permitted, even though on leash, to enter any public hall, restaurant, coffeehouse, ice cream parlor, soft drink parlor, office, store, market, or confectionery shop anywhere within the village, during the time that such place is open for public business. 
(b)  The provisions of subsection (a) shall not apply to dogs leading blind persons. 
(Code 1965, § 6.2.11) 
Sec. 5-35. - Dog bites. 
    Whenever any dog bites a person, the owner of the dog shall immediately notify the health officer who shall order the dog to be held on the owner's premises or shall have it impounded for a period of 15 days. The dog shall be examined immediately after it has bitten anyone and again at the end of the 15-day period. If at the end of the 15-day period a veterinarian is convinced that the dog is free from rabies, he shall order the dog released. 
(Code 1965, § 6.2.13) 
Sec. 5-36. - Removal of pet excrement. 
    No person shall appear with a pet upon the public ways or within public places or upon the property of another, absent that person's consent, without some means for the removal of excrement; nor shall any person fail to remove any excrement deposited by such pet. This section shall not apply to a blind person while walking his or her guide dog. 
(Ord. No. 88-25, § 1, 10-24-88) 
Secs. 5-37-5-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSING 

Sec. 5-51. - Generally. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to own or keep more than three dogs or three cats per each dwelling within the village. The owner or keeper of such animal(s) shall make application for such license to the village clerk, giving the animal's name, breed, color, sex and/or other identifying characteristics as required pursuant to the village's application form. The fee for such license shall be as set forth in article V of chapter 2 immediately to the right of the section number assigned to such section. The fee for each such license shall be paid to the village clerk. The license shall expire on the last day of April in each year following the issuance of such license. No license shall be issued for a sum less than the full annual fee except as provided herein, and no license shall be issued for more than the number of animals permitted herein. 
(Code 1965, § 6.2.1; Ord. No. 86-13A, § 1, 1-5-87) 
Sec. 5-52. - Rabies vaccination as prerequisite. 
    No dog license shall be issued unless the dog to be licensed is vaccinated as required by law. 
(Code 1965, § 6.2.2) 
Sec. 5-53. - Issuance and tag. 
(a)  After the payment of the license fee required by this division, and upon presentation of a certificate signed by a veterinarian that the dog has been vaccinated against rabies as required by law, the village clerk shall furnish to the person paying the same a license certificate and tag for the dog. 
(b)  The shape of dog tags issued by the village clerk shall be changed each year, and it shall have stamped thereon the year for which the fee is paid, the identifying description, and the number of the tag to correspond with the number on the license certificate. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person other than the owner to remove a license tag from a dog. 
(d)  Upon satisfactory proof to the village clerk that a license tag has been lost or worn or damaged beyond further use, the village clerk shall issue to the licensee a new tag, but of new and different number, and upon payment of a fee of $1.00 and the village clerk shall revise his records accordingly. 
(Code 1965, §§ 6.2.2, 6.2.5) 
Sec. 5-54. - Collar or harness. 
    Every dog kept within the village shall be provided by its owner or keeper with a collar or harness made of leather, metal or other substantial material to which the required license tag shall be securely fastened. 
(Code 1965, § 6.2.3) 
Sec. 5-55. - Transfer. 
    Whenever the ownership of a dog shall change, the new owner shall notify the village clerk, and pay to the village clerk, the sum of $2.00 whereupon the village clerk shall alter the records accordingly for the dog. 
(Code 1965, § 6.2.4) 
Sec. 5-56. - Records. 
    The village clerk shall keep a complete record of all licensed dogs, describing the same by name, breed, color and sex, and shall also enter in such records the name and address of the owner or keeper as given, and the number of the village license tag. 
(Code 1965, § 6.2.4) 
Secs. 5-57-5-69. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CATS 

Sec. 5-70. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2003-35, § 2, adopted Sept. 22, 2003, repealed § 5-70, which pertained to the penalty for violation of this article and was derived from Ord. No. 95-20, § 3, 4-24-95. 
Sec. 5-71. - Running at large prohibited. 
    No person shall cause or permit any cat owned or kept by them to run at large within the limits of the village. Any cat found upon the private property of another other than the owner or keeper, or upon a public street, sidewalk, alley, parkway or any enclosed place shall be deemed running at large unless under restraint. For the purposes of this section, a cat is under "restraint" if it is controlled by a leash; within a vehicle being driven or parked on the street; or within the property limits of its owner or keeper. Cats running at large shall be impounded. 
(Ord. No. 95-20, § 3, 4-24-95) 
Sec. 5-72. - Proof of rabies vaccination required. 
    All owners or keepers of cats shall be required to provide proof of current rabies vaccination upon the request of the animal warden or a police officer. 
(Ord. No. 95-20, § 3, 4-24-95) 
Secs. 5-73-5-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLES IV-IX. - RESERVED 

Secs. 5-101-5-1000. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - PENALTIES 

Sec. 5-1001. - Penalty; compromise payment. 
(a)  Whosoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of an offense and fined not less than $100.00 nor more than $750.00 and/or sentenced up to six months in the county jail. Except when fines and costs are paid by compromise payment as provided in subsection (b) below prior to court, the court clerk shall add to the fine any and all costs and fees upon an authorized disposition. 
(b)  Any person accused of a violation of this chapter may settle and compromise said claim without a court appearance by payment of one-half of the minimum required fine to the village clerk at the village hall within ten business days of the date of violation if the compromise box designation is so checked on the complaint and notice to appear form. 
(Ord. No. 2003-35, § 2, 9-22-03; Ord. No. 2006-43, § 4, 12-11-06) 
Chapter 6 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes:
