Cross reference- Village datum, § 2-3; fees and fines schedule, § 2-301; flood hazard areas, § 8-16 et seq.; erosion and sedimentation, § 8-51 et seq.; scaffolds, § 13-10; mobile home parks, ch. 14; planning and development, ch. 19; signs and billboards, ch. 21; house numbering, § 22-41 et seq.; subdivisions, ch. 23; water, sewers and sewage disposal, ch. 27; zoning, ch. 28. 
State Law reference- General authority to regulate construction, 65 ILCS 5/11-30-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 6-1-6-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - BUILDING CODE 

Sec. 6-26. - Adoption of 2003 International Building Code. 
    The 2003 International Building Code, including Appendix Chapters C, E, I and J, as published by the International Code Council, Inc., Publication Date: December 2002, is hereby adopted as the building code [of the] Village of Crete, in the State of Illinois, for the control of building and structures, and each and all of the regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and terms are hereby referred to, adopted and made a part hereof, as if fully set out in this chapter, with the additions, insertions, deletions and changes as specified in section 6-27 of this chapter. This code is intended [for] and shall establish the minimum regulations governing the conditions and maintenance of all property, buildings and structures, and shall provide the standards for supplied utilities and facilities and other physical things and conditions essential to ensure that structures are safe, sanitary and fit for occupation and use, and shall provide for the issuance of permits, collection of fees and establish the required inspections, and shall provide for the condemnation of buildings and structures unfit for human occupancy and use and the demolition of such structures, and shall provide for enforcement and penalties concerning the regulations of said building code. Three copies of such publication will be maintained on file with the village clerk. 
(Ord. No. 2003-52, § 2, 12-8-03) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2003-52, adopted Dec. 8, 2003, enacted provisions to be designated as § 6-26.1. Said provisions have been redesignated as § 6-26 at the direction of the village. 
Sec. 6-27. - Revisions to 2003 International Building Code. 
    The following sections of the 2003 International Building Code are hereby revised so as to be read with the following insertions, additions and deletions and/or changes as follows: 
    Section 101.1. Title. Insert: Village of Crete, IL. 
    Section 101.4.4. Plumbing. "International Plumbing Code" is deleted and replaced with "Illinois Plumbing Code, (02/04)." 
    Section 103.3. Deputies' is amended by adding the following paragraph to the existing language: 
Building inspectors shall be appointed by the Village President with the advise and consent of the Board of Trustees to serve as full-time employees or part-time employees. The Village President may direct full-time employees or part-time employees to perform the duties and exercise the powers of the building official. 
    Section 105.2. Work exempt from permit is amended as follows: 
Building 
1.  Existing language is deleted and replaced with following language: One-story detached accessory structures used as tool and storage sheds provided the floor area does not exceed 32 sq. ft. and no electric service is installed. 
2.  Deleted 
3.  Deleted 
4.  Deleted 
    Section 105.5. Expiration. The first sentence is deleted and the following is inserted in its place: Permits shall be valid upon issuance for a period not to exceed twelve months. 
    Section 106.1. Submitted Documents. Addition: The building official shall have the authority to require an Illinois architect seal or Illinois licensed engineer seal on any construction drawing submitted in support of an application for a building permit. All submittals shall be made in minimum 1/4" scale on paper sized a minimum of 18"×24" and maximum of 30"×42". 
    Section 108.2. Schedule of Permit Fees, the following language is added: The schedule of the various permit fees are listed in section 6-1501 of the Crete Municipal Code. 
    Section 109.1. General. The following language will be added: 
"Where panels are constructed off site and assembled on site, open panel panelized construction will be required. After inspection, panels may be enclosed." 
    Section 113.4. Violation penalties, the following language is added: Each day that a violation continues is deemed a separate offense. 
    Section 113.5. Penalties, the following language is added to Section 113, Violations, and reads as follows: 
(a)  Whosoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this Code shall be guilty of an offense and fined not less than seventy-five dollars ($75.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) and/or sentenced up to six months in the county jail excepting violations of stop work orders and occupancy without a permit. Except when fines and costs are paid by compromise payment as provided in (b) below prior to Court, the Court Clerk shall add to the fine any and all costs and fees upon an authorized disposition. 
(b)  Any person accused of a violation of this Code may settle and compromise said claim without a court appearance by payment of one-half of the minimum required fine to the Village Clerk at the Village Hall within ten business days of the date of violation if the compromise box designation is so checked on the Complaint and Notice to Appear form. 
(c)  Violations of any Stop Work Order issued by the Building Official are set at a minimum fine of Two Hundred Fifty Dollars ($250.00) nor more than Seven Hundred Fifty Dollars ($750.00) and/or sentenced up to six months in the county jail; violations of occupancy of a structure without an occupancy permit are set at a minimum fine of Two Hundred Fifty Dollars ($250.00) nor more than Seven Hundred Fifty Dollars ($750.00) and/or sentenced up to six months in the county jail. 
    Section 116. Plumbing inspector is added and reads as follows: 
(a)  Creation. There is hereby created the position of plumbing inspector, an executive position of the village. The plumbing inspector shall be selected by the president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees for a term of one (1) year. Said plumbing inspector shall be qualified pursuant to the law of the State of Illinois. 
(b)  Duties and Responsibilities. 
(1)  It shall be the duty of the plumbing inspector to enforce all village ordinances relating to the installation, care and standards of plumbing. He shall make all necessary inspections and tests, which may be needed in the performance of his duties. Whenever the plumbing inspector shall find plumbing work in violation of village ordinances, he shall have the power to order the work stopped until the ordinances are complied with. It shall be unlawful to continue any such work after such a stop order has been issued, except upon the written permission of the plumbing inspector or village president; provided, that where such stop order has been made orally it shall be followed by a written stop order within two (2) hours, which said stop order may be delivered in the same manner as the building official's stop order (or orders). 
(2)  The plumbing inspector shall have the power to enter any building or premises on or in which plumbing fixtures or pipes are being installed, altered or repaired, at all reasonable hours, to make inspections to determine compliance with the village ordinances relating to plumbing. 
    Section 117. Contractor's License, the following language is added: 
Work for which a permit is required under this code if performed by a third party shall be performed by and under the jurisdiction of a contractor licensed by the state. 
    Section 202. Definitions is amended by adding the following: 
"Building contractor" shall mean a general building contractor who undertakes to construct or erect, or repair or alter an entire building or structure or portion thereof involving the work of more than one (1) trade. 
"Building subcontractor" shall mean a subtrade contractor who undertakes to construct or erect, or repair or alter an entire building or structure or portion thereof involving the work of but one (1) trade. 
"Owner-builder" shall mean anyone who through use of his own skills or through use of skills of others, including subcontractors, shall undertake to construct or erect, or repair or alter an entire building or structure or portion thereof involving the work of one (1) or more trades. 
    Section 301.1.1. Dwelling Unit Separation. All separation walls must be freestanding and masonry construction. 
    Section 1612.3. Establishment of flood hazard areas. Insert: Village of Crete FEMA map dated November 6, 2000. 
    Section 3409.2. Applicability insert: February 1, 2002. 
    Section 3401.3. Compliance with other codes. The International Plumbing Code reference is deleted and replaced with "Illinois Plumbing Code, 1998 edition, with 2002 amendments." 
(Ord. No. 2003-52, § 2, 12-8-03; Ord. No. 2004-39, § 2, 11-22-04; Ord. No. 2007-17, § 3, 4-23-07) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2003-52, adopted Dec. 8, 2003, enacted provisions to be designated as § 6-27.1. Said provisions have been redesignated as § 6-27 at the direction of the village. 
Sec. 6-28. - General requirements. 
(a)  Work within the right-of-way. The provisions of chapter 22 entitled Streets and Sidewalks shall be adhered to and any necessary permits and bonds shall be secured prior to the start of any work within the right-of-way. If such work is known to be necessary as part of any construction activity covered under a requested building permit, then in such cases the permit required for work within the right-of-way shall be required prior to the issuance of the building permit. Such permits and bonds shall be required of the contractor or subcontractor who will actually be performing the work. 
(b)  Times when construction is prohibited. It shall be unlawful to conduct construction operations that will disturb the peace of adjoining residential properties which are within 400 feet of the construction site between 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. Such operations shall be in conformance with the performance standards governing noise so noted in section 28-311(i). 
(c)  Crete Public Library District. All applications for building permits for new construction will be accompanied by a receipt showing the appropriate cash contribution has been paid to the Crete Public Library District as required by ordinance. 
(d)  Connection to storm drainage system. In all multifamily, commercial and industrial structures, roof drains, downspouts and sump pump discharge shall be directly connected to the storm drainage system required by section 23-107 of the subdivisions chapter. 
(Ord. No. 93-7, § 1, 3-8-93; Ord. No. 95-10, § 4, 2-27-95; Ord. No. 2003-52, § 2, 12-8-03; Ord. No. 2005-38, § 1, 10-10-05; Ord. No. 2006-01, § 2, 1-9-06) 
Sec. 6-29. - Masonry fireplaces. 
    All wood burning fireplaces shall be masonry construction including fire brick constructed fire box with masonry flue. 
(Ord. No. 2003-52, § 2, 12-8-03) 
Secs. 6-30-6-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - RESIDENTIAL BUILDING CODE 

Sec. 6-51. - Adoption of 2003 International Residential Code. 
    The International Residential Code, including Appendix Chapters A, B, C, D, G, H, J, and K, as published by the International Code Council, Inc., Publication Date: January, 2003, is hereby adopted as the residential code for one- and two-family dwellings of [the] Village of Crete, for the control of building of one- and two-family dwelling structures and accessory structures, and each and all of the regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and terms are hereby referred to, adopted and made a part hereof, as if fully set out in this chapter, with the additions, insertions, deletions and changes as specified in section 6-52 of this chapter. This residential code is intended and shall establish the minimum regulations governing the design, construction, quality of materials, erection, installation, alteration, repair location, relocation, replacement, addition to, use or maintenance of one- and two-family dwellings and townhouses not more than three stories in height and further to provide for the issuance of permits and collection of fees; and shall provide the standards for supplied utilities and facilities and other physical things and conditions essential to ensure that structures are safe, sanitary and fit for occupation and each and all of the regulations, provisions, conditions and terms of such 2003 International Residential Code for One- and Two-Family Dwellings (First Printing, Publication Date: January, 2003) published by the International Code Council are hereby referred to, adopted and made a part hereof as if fully set out in this article, with additions, insertions, deletions and changes prescribed in section 6-52 of this chapter. Three copies of said residential code will be maintained on file with the village clerk. 
(Ord. No. 2003-53, § 2, 12-8-03) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2003-52, adopted Dec. 8, 2003, enacted provisions to be designated as § 6-51.1. Said provisions have been redesignated as § 6-51 at the direction of the village.

Except when fines and costs are paid by compromise payment as provided in (b) below prior to Court, the Court Clerk shall add to the fine any and all costs and fees upon an authorized disposition.

(a)  Creation. There is hereby created the position of plumbing inspector, an executive position of the village. The plumbing inspector shall be selected by the president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees for a term of one (1) year. Said plumbing inspector shall be qualified pursuant to the law of the State of Illinois. 
(b)  Duties and Responsibilities. 
(1)  It shall be the duty of the plumbing inspector to enforce all village ordinances relating to the installation, care and standards of plumbing. He shall make all necessary inspections and tests, which may be needed in the performance of his duties. Whenever the plumbing inspector shall find plumbing work in violation of village ordinances, he shall have the power to order the work stopped until the ordinances are complied with. It shall be unlawful to continue any such work after such a stop order has been issued, except upon the written permission of the plumbing inspector or village president; provided, that where such stop order has been made orally it shall be followed by a written stop order within two (2) hours, which said stop order may be delivered in the same manner as the building official's stop order (or orders). 
(2)  The plumbing inspector shall have the power to enter any building or premises on or in which plumbing fixtures or pipes are being installed, altered or repaired, at all reasonable hours, to make inspections to determine compliance with the village ordinances relating to plumbing. 
    Section R116. Contractor's License, the following language is added:

The annual fee for said license shall be Seventy-Five Dollars ($75.00). A further condition of license is proof of insurance coverage of not less than $500,000 per occurrence. Section R202. Section R304.5 Residence space requirements. 
(a)  No residential building erected or constructed within "R-E single-family residence district zoning" shall contain less than one thousand eight hundred (1,800) square feet of livable floor area. Those built in "R-1A single-family residence district zoning" shall contain no less than one thousand four hundred (1,400) square feet of livable floor area. Those built in "R-1 single-family residence district zoning" shall contain no less than one thousand two hundred fifty (1,250) square feet of livable floor area. Those built in R2 districts shall contain no less than one thousand (1,000) square feet of livable floor area per dwelling unit. For minimum livable floor areas for dwellings built in R-3 or R-4 zoning districts, please refer to Crete Zoning Code. In "R-EU' districts, the minimum livable floor area for single-story residential buildings is two thousand (2,000) square feet; for multistory residential buildings the minimal livable floor area is two thousand five hundred (2,500) square feet. 
(b)  No residential buildings erected or constructed within the village shall contain cubical livable contents less than the square feet of livable floor area multiplied by the height of the ceiling line above the floor line, excluding areas occupied by basements, porches, garages, attics, utility and/or heater rooms. 
(c)  The limitations provided in subsections (a) and (b) of this section shall constitute limitations on bulk. The ceiling heights of every room constituting livable ground floor area shall be not less than eight (8) feet from the floor line. All upper floor livable floor area ceiling heights shall be not less than seven and one-half (71/2) feet, providing that where sloping ceiling lines are employed in sleeping rooms, the ceiling height thereof shall be not less than seven and on-half (71/2) feet above floor line, which height shall be maintained over one-half of the ceiling area. 
(d)  No residence shall be erected or constructed in an "R1" residential district that does not include a living room containing at least two hundred (200) square feet of livable floor area. All residences erected or constructed in any other residential districts shall contain a living room containing at least one hundred fifty (150) square feet of livable area. All other minimum room sizes shall be governed by R304 unless amended hereinabove or hereinbelow. 
(e)  Any bedroom included in any residential building constructed or erected shall contain a minimum of one hundred twenty (120) square feet of livable floor area. 
    Section R309.2 is amended in that "fire rated 5/8 " gypsum board or equal is to be used in place of "1/2" gypsum board and the following is added: "Walls not common with the residence must be covered by a minimum of 1/2" gypsum board. Doors between the garage and residence must be self-closing and carry a one hour fire rating." 
    Section R321. Dwelling Unit Separation. Insert: All separation walls must be freestanding and masonry construction. 
    Section R326. Accessibility. Insert: Accessible dwelling units shall also comply with the Illinois Accessibility Code, as amended. See Title 71, Illinois Administrative Code. 
    Section R402. Materials. 
    Sections R402.1. Wood foundations, R402.1.1. Fasteners and R402.1.2 Wood treatment are deleted in their entirety. 
    Section 403.1 General (Footing) is changed to read as follows: 
All exterior walls shall be supported on continuous concrete footing with a 2"×4" keyway which shall be of sufficient design to accommodate all loads according to Section R301 and to transmit the resulting loads to the soil within the limitations as determined from the character of the soil. Footings shall be supported on undisturbed natural soils or engineered fill. 
    Section R403.1.1 Minimum size (footings) is changed to read as follows: 
Minimum size for concrete footings shall be 10" thickness by 20" width. The size of footing piers and columns shall be based on the tributary load and allowable soil pressure in accordance with Table R401.4.1. 
    Figures R403.1(2) and R403.1(3) are deleted. 
    Section R403.2. Footings for wood foundations is deleted. 
    Section R404.1. Concrete and masonry foundation walls. The language "and masonry" is deleted. 
    Section R404.1.1. Masonry foundation walls is deleted in its entirety. 
    Section R404.1.5. Foundation wall thickness based on walls supported is changed to: Foundation wall thickness. Foundation walls shall be a minimum of 10" thick. 
    Section R404.2. Wood foundation walls and the subsections thereto are all deleted in their entirety. 
    Section R404.3. Wood sill plates is changed to read: Wood sill plates shall be a minimum of 2 × 4 nominal lumber, provided further, sill plates shall be a width at least equal to the width of the studs. Sill plate anchorage shall be in accordance with Sections R403.1.6 and R602.11. 
    Section R404.4. Insulating concrete form foundation walls and the subsections thereto are deleted in their entirety. 
    Section R405.2. Wood foundations and the subsections thereto are deleted in their entirety. 
    Section R506.2.1. Fill is changed by adding the following sentence: 
All garage floors will have fill material composed only of clean stone aggregate to full depth. 
    Chapters 26, 27, 28, 29, 30, 31, 32 are deleted and replaced with the following language: 
All plumbing requirements are governed by the adopted State Plumbing Code of Illinois (as amended) See 225 ILCS 320/0.01 et seq. (as amended). 
(Ord. No. 2003-53, § 2, 12-8-03) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2003-52, adopted Dec. 8, 2003, enacted provisions to be designated as § 6-52.1. Said provisions have been redesignated as 6-52 at the direction of the village. 
Sec. 6-53. - Permit and inspection fees. 
    All permit and inspection fees to be charged in connection with construction undertaken pursuant to this code shall be determined in accordance with the schedule pertaining to valuation, fees and charges set forth in the form of article VI of chapter Two [section 2-311] of the Crete Municipal Code. 
(Ord. No. 90-28, § 4, 9-24-90) 
Sec. 6-54. - Certificates of occupancy. 
    For any new residential structure or room addition the person issued the building permit shall be required to obtain a certificate of occupancy. The certificate of occupancy shall be issued in the name of the builder or purchaser after the building officials have completed and approved the final inspections of the premises to ascertain compliance with this chapter and other pertinent aspects of the Crete Municipal Code. If the premises are suitable and ready for occupancy by meeting at least the minimal health and safety provisions of the Code but other items or provisions are yet unfinished or incomplete a conditional certificate of occupancy may be issued. A conditional certificate of occupancy may be issued if those provisions of the Code that are required but yet unfinished or incomplete are guaranteed to be completed by holding in escrow a sum of money sufficient to cover the costs to be incurred. The building inspector shall set a minimum amount of money to be held in escrow. Said escrow shall either be held by the village clerk or a legally binding escrow account shall be established with an independent third party involved with the construction such as a financial institution or title company. A notarized letter shall be required and placed on file with the building official stating the amount and items that are covered by the escrow account. 
(Ord. No. 91-35, § 1, 10-14-91) 
Sec. 6-55. - Grading plan requirements. 
(a)  Preliminary plat of survey. Two copies of a plat of survey, no more than six months old, shall be submitted with the building permit application and said survey shall include the following: 
(1)  Legal description, lot number, lot size and building setback line. 
(2)  All existing utility and drainage easements. 
(3)  North arrow, scale and benchmark. 
(4)  Existing elevations of: all buildings on or adjacent to the lot, property lines, roads, curbs, ditches, storm sewers, or any other feature pertinent to the grading of the lot. 
(5)  Location and size of the proposed building on the lot, tied in with dimensions to the front and side property lines. 
(6)  Proposed elevations to show positive drainage for lot grading, including the relationship to adjacent properties and buildings. 
(7)  Proposed elevations for top of foundation, including adjacent existing buildings. 
(b)  Spotted plat of survey. Two copies of a spotted plat of survey shall be submitted to the building department after the foundation walls have been completed and before any further construction and shall include the following: 
(1)  Exact location of the structure in relation to the lot lines (front and side yard) and all dimensions for the foundation. 
(2)  Plat to be signed and sealed by an Illinois professional land surveyor. 
(3)  The elevation of the top of the foundation (as constructed). 
(c)  Final plat of survey. Two copies of a final plat of survey shall be submitted prior to issuance of the certificate of occupancy and shall include the following: 
(1)  All of the information requested for the spotted survey. 
(2)  Location and measurements of any additional accessory or detached buildings. 
(3)  All concrete flatwork, i.e. driveways, patios, porches, service walks, etc. 
(4)  All easements. 
(5)  Front and side yard measurements. 
(6)  Elevation for the top of foundation and lot elevations sufficient to show the drainage of the lot relative to existing drainage facilities and adjacent property. 
(Ord. No. 92-7, § 1, 5-11-92) 
Sec. 6-56. - General requirements. 
(a)  In all multifamily and townhouse structures, roof drains, downspouts and sump pump discharge shall be directly connected to the storm drainage system required by section 23-107 of the subdivisions chapter. 
(b)  In all single-family structures, sump pump discharge shall be directly connected to the storm drainage system required by section 23-107 of the subdivisions chapter if said storm drainage system is deemed accessible via adjacent or abutting properties, as determined by the village engineer applying engineering standards. 
(Ord. No. 2006-01, § 4, 1-9-06) 
Secs. 6-57-6-75. - Reserved.

Section 104.8 Rule-making authority. 
The president and board of trustees of the village shall have the power to adopt and promulgate rules, regulations, guidelines and policy statements so as to interpret and implement provisions of this code in order to secure the intent thereof and to designate requirements uniquely applicable because of local climatic or other conditions; however, except as otherwise provided, such rule shall not have the effect of waiving working stresses or fire protection requirements specifically provided in this code.

ARTICLE V. - ELECTRICAL CODE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 90-31, §§ 1, 3, 4, adopted Sept. 24, 1990, adopted and amended an electrical code for the village and provided a penalty for violation of such code. Inasmuch as such provisions did not specify manner of codification, they have been designated by the editor as art. V, §§ 6-101-6-103. The user's attention is also directed to the editor's footnote to art. II of this chapter. 

Sec. 6-101. - Adoption of 2005 National Electrical Code. 
    The National Electrical Code (2005 Edition) and the various additions, insertions, revisions and/or changes as provided in section 6-102 are hereby adopted by reference as if each and every provision of such code were set forth verbatim herein together with the certain additions, insertions, revisions and/or changes as provided in section 6-102 hereof. In this connection, three copies of the National Electrical Code (2005 Edition) as adopted, are on file in the office of the village clerk, marked and designated as the "National Electrical Code (2005 Edition)" and may be cited hereafter as the Electrical Code of the Village of Crete. 
(Ord. No. 90-31, § 1, 9-24-90; Ord. No. 2004-39, § 1, 11-22-04) 
Sec. 6-101.1. - Adoption of 2003 International Code Council Electrical Code. 
    The 2003 International Code Council Electrical Code, Administrative Provisions (First Printing: December 2002), is adopted as the administrative provisions to enforce the National Electrical Code, 2005 Edition, both of which are the electrical code of the village subject to the additions, insertions, revisions and/or changes in the following section. 
(Ord. No. 2003-52, § 4, 12-8-03; Ord. No. 2004-39, § 1, 11-22-04) 
Sec. 6-102. - Additions, insertions, revisions and/or changes to 2005 National Electrical Code. 
    [The electrical code adopted in section 6-101 shall be revised and changed to reflect the following:] 
(1)  The use of aluminum wiring in any and all construction is prohibited. 
(2)  The use of nonmetallic-sheathed cable in any and all construction is prohibited, with the exception that the same may be used only as temporary wiring in accordance with provisions set forth in article 305 of the National Electrical Code. 
(3)  All service conductors installed above-ground and within ten feet of grade, or where subject to physical damage, shall be protected by ridged metal conduit. 
(4)  All wiring for doorbells and thermostats, where permanently concealed, shall be installed in conduit. 
(5)  Electrical services shall not enter single-family dwellings from the rear elevation. 
(6)  A one-half-inch conduit, complete with pull wire shall be installed between the water meter and its remote readout. The locations of the water meter and remote readout shall be established by the superintendent of public works or his designee. 
(7)  In commercial and industrial buildings, all switches for fire or burglar alarm systems shall be equipped with lockouts to prevent accidental turnoff. 
(8)  Fire alarms systems shall be installed in conduit. 
(9)  Electrical rooms in sprinkled buildings shall be enclosed by fire rated wall assemblies and fire rated doors (minimum one hour) with detection and being unsprinkled. 
(Ord. No. 90-31, § 3, 9-24-90; Ord. No. 2003-52, § 4, 12-8-03) 
Sec. 6-103. - Penalty for violation. 
(a)  Whosoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of the code [adopted in this article] shall be guilty of an offense and fined not less than $75.00 nor more than $750.00 and/or sentenced up to six months in the county jail excepting violations of stop work orders and occupancy without a permit. Except when fines and costs are paid by compromise payment as provided in (b) below prior to court, the court clerk shall add to the fine any and all costs and fees upon an authorized disposition. 
(b)  Any person accused of a violation of the code [adopted in this article] may settle and compromise said claim without a court appearance by payment of one-half of the minimum required fine to the village clerk at the village hall within ten business days of the date of violation if the compromise box designation is so checked on the complaint and notice to appear form. 
(c)  Violations of any stop work order issued by the building official are set at a minimum fine of $250.00 nor more than $750.00 and/or sentenced up to six months in the county jail; violations of occupancy of a structure without an occupancy permit are set at a minimum fine of $250.00 nor more than $750.00 and/or sentenced up to six months in the county jail. 
(Ord. No. 90-31, § 4, 9-24-90; Ord. No. 2003-52, § 4, 12-8-03) 
Secs. 6-104-6-125. - Reserved.

Cross reference- Health and sanitation, ch. 11. 

Sec. 6-126. - Adopted. 
    That certain document, three copies of which are on file in the office of the village clerk, each being marked and designated as the "Illinois Plumbing Code 02/04" thereto, as published under the direction of the Illinois Department of Public Health (Title 77, Chapter I, Subchapter r, Part 890), be and is hereby adopted, together with the various additions and deletions specified in section 6-127 of this article, all of which (as hereby adopted) shall be known and may be cited as the "Plumbing Code of the Village of Crete." The code (as herein adopted) shall provide the various rules, regulations, standards, designs and guidelines to be followed within the Village of Crete insofar as plumbing installations and all plumbing related equipment and paraphernalia is concerned and shall be applied so as to safeguard environmental health and consumer safety through properly designed, acceptably installed and adequately maintained plumbing systems. 
(Ord. No. 90-30, § 1, 9-24-90; Ord. No. 2003-54, § 2, 12-8-03; Ord. No. 2004-40, § 2, 11-22-04) 
Sec. 6-127. - Additions, insertions, revisions and/or deletions. 
    The Illinois Plumbing Code (02/04) thereto as adopted in section 6-126, are hereby amended and revised by the following additions, insertions, revisions and/or deletions, so that as fully adopted hereby, the plumbing code of the Village of Crete shall include the following additions, insertions, revisions and /or deletions, namely: 
    A-5, Circuit vent. All language pertaining to the phrase "circuit vent" and the definition thereof is deleted. 
    Section 890-1500, Wet vent. New phraseology is added concerning "wet vent" to read as follows: 
It shall be unlawful for any person to use a wet vent in connection with plumbing installations within the Village of Crete. All fixtures must have their own vent or back-to-back vent. 
    Authority Section 890-110. All installation shall be in accordance with applicable state and local laws, ordinances, resolutions, rules, regulations and codes as adopted by the Village Board. 
    C-1, Section 890.320, entitled "Plastic pipe, tubing and fittings for potable water piping, etc.," is deleted. 
    Page A-26, Section 890.150, is amended at subparagraph a) thereof, so that paragraph a) shall include new language after the last complete sentence thereof, which shall read as follows: 
It is the obligation of any person installing, remodeling or repairing any plumbing or plumbing fixture within the village to consult with the plumbing inspector before commencing any such work in order to verify the quality, character and type of materials, to be used in connection with the work. 
    Section 890.1130. Special fixtures and/or items designed for a particular purpose. 
(d)  Water and Drain Connections. Baptisteries, ornamental and lily ponds, aquaria, ornamental fountain basins, private swimming pools and similar type constructions requiring a special permit for their construction and/or installation (when provided with water supplied from the potable water system) shall be protected from back-siphonage as required by code. 
    Section 890.1320, paragraph (b) thereof shall read in its entirety as follows: 
Existing house drains and sewer. Existing house drains and sewer may be used in the renovation of the plumbing system of existing structures if they are in serviceable condition. Starting inside the foundation wall, cast iron or P.V.C. is required to a distance of five (5) feet outside of the building's foundation wall. At that point, a combination wye and one eight-inch bend shall be installed as a "clean out," extending up to finish grade. A six-inch by four-inch (6" × 4") mission coupling shall be installed between the 4" P.V.C. and the 6" S.D.R. 
No new building hereinafter constructed, be it primary or auxiliary structure, equipped with basement area drains shall be connected to the sanitary sewer. It shall be mandatory that all such structures shall have sump pumps and drains of overhead design. These drains shall be constructed to flow into the storm sewer, if one exists, or if the same does not, the water shall be disposed of in such manner that no part of the water will be discharged into the sanitary sewerage system. 
    J-7, Section 890.1370, (b) is amended so that such subsection d shall require floor drain traps and drains having a minimum diameter of three (3) inches as opposed to two (2) inches as specified in said subparagraph. 
    Section 890.210. 
Plastic pipe and fittings will be allowed for drain, waste or vent above foundation slab and for a maximum of three (3) stories, and shall consist of Schedule 40 polyvinylchloride (PVC). Above three (3) stories, cast iron, galvanized or copper pipe will be used for drain, waste or vent. Water service pipe under two (2) inches diameter shall be made of type "K" copper tube with flared fittings. Water service pipe above two (2) inches diameter shall be of ductile iron water main and fittings and shall be buried to a depth of not less than five (5) feet below grade from the "B" Box to the riser for water meter attachment. Water distribution piping inside of building shall be type "K" (soft) copper underground, and type "L" (hard drawn) copper above ground with sweat fittings. On change overs from septic to city sewer, additional clean outs may be required. Locations will be determined in field. 
Section 3/225 ILCS 320/3 
All plumbing contractors working within the village must furnish the plumbing inspector with a copy of his State of Illinois or City of Chicago plumbing license and an up-to-date certificate of insurance prior to the issuance of a plumbing permit. All commercial plumbing installations, repairs, alterations or replacements must be performed by a licensed plumber. The plumbing inspector will be responsible for maintaining up-to-date files of those plumbing contractors properly licensed. 
    Section 890.140 
In the case of improvements on residential, commercial or industrial buildings or property, the issuance of a plumbing permit is required to make the following repairs, replacements or changes: 
(1)  Conversion from galvanized water piping to copper; 
(2)  Addition of any plumbing fixture; 
(3)  Replacement of water heater or boiler; 
(4)  Installation or conversion to overhead sewer system or anti-flood system; 
(5)  Any plumbing changes or additions to any part of the waste, vent, water piping or sewer system. 
(Ord. No. 90-30, § 3, 9-24-90; Ord. No. 2004-40, § 2, 11-22-04) 
Sec. 6-128. - Penalty for violation. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to violate any provision of the aforementioned Plumbing Code of the Village of Crete (as hereby created and adopted), and anyone who shall violate any of the terms, provisions, rules and regulations of said plumbing code shall be guilty of an offense and fined not less than $75.00 nor more than $750.00 and/or sentenced up to six months in the county jail excepting violations of stop work orders and occupancy without a permit. Except when fines and costs are paid by compromise payment as provided in subsection (b) below prior to court, the court clerk shall add to the fine any and all costs and fees upon an authorized disposition. 
(b)  Any person accused of a violation of this code may settle and compromise said claim without a court appearance by payment of one-half of the minimum required fine to the village clerk at the village hall within ten business days of the date of violation if the compromise box designation is so checked on the complaint and notice to appear form. 
(Ord. No. 90-30, § 4, 9-24-90; Ord. No. 2003-54, § 2, 12-8-03) 
Secs. 6-129-6-215. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - SWIMMING POOLS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Formerly designated as art. IV, swimming pools, §§ 6-216-6-227, such provisions have been redesignated as art. VII by the editor in order to accommodate the inclusion of arts. IV-VI. 
Cross reference- Health and sanitation, ch. 11. 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate swimming pools, 65 ILCS 5/11-30-9; state regulation of public swimming pools, 210 ILCS 125/1 et seq. 

Sec. 6-216. - Definition. 
    As used in this article the term "swimming pool" means an artificial pool of water intended for the purpose of immersion or partial immersion therein of human beings, together with auxiliary structures, including dressing rooms and locker rooms, toilets, showers, and other areas and enclosures designed or intended for use of persons using the pool, and in any manner incident thereto. The term shall not include any swimming pool subject to the Swimming Pool and Bathing Beach Act (210 ILCS 125/1 et seq.). 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.44B.2) 
Sec. 6-217. - Inspections and authority to close. 
    The health officer of the village or others authorized by the board of trustees shall have the right and authority to inspect any pool, or to check the operations thereof, during reasonable daylight hours. If it is found on inspection that the operation of the pool does not meet the sanitary and safety requirements of any ordinance of the village, the officer making the inspection shall direct that the pool be closed until the sanitary and safety requirements are met. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.44B.12) 
Sec. 6-218. - Permit. 
    No swimming pool shall be constructed within the village unless building permits have been obtained as required by ordinance. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.44B.1) 
Sec. 6-219. - Type of construction. 
    Swimming pools shall be constructed of water-tight steel reinforced concrete poured in place, pneumatically applied concrete (gunite) with adequate steel reinforcing, dry pack concrete with adequate steel reinforcement, concrete block, brick, aluminum, fiberglass, steel, steel sunk in concrete, fiberglass sunk in concrete, vinyl lined steel, vinyl lined marine plywood treated, vinyl lined wood treated, vinyl lined concrete asbestos (transite) or other materials having equivalent or similar utilitarian value or qualities as may meet with the approval of the architectural review board. Certification of plans and specifications by a licensed architect or professional or structural engineer shall be sufficient evidence of compliance with the requirements of this section. This section shall apply to all swimming pools built on or above ground level, whether of a dismantable nature or of permanent installation, providing such pools are: 
(1)  In excess of ten feet in diameter if round (or in excess of ten feet by ten feet if of a square or of a rectangular design); 
(2)  Are of 24 inches or more in depth; and; 
(3)  Have a quantitative volume in excess of 1,200 gallons regardless of shape or figure. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.44B.3; Ord. No. 601, § 1, 5-22-67) 
Sec. 6-220. - Recirculation requirements. 
    All swimming pools with a capacity of 1,200 gallons or more shall be of the recirculation type, in which circulation of the water is maintained through the pool by pumps; the water drawn from the pool being clarified and disinfected before being returned to the pool. The equipment shall be capable of effecting one turnover of the pool volume in 24 hours or less, at a rate of filtration not exceeding three gallons per square foot per minute. At least one surface skimming device shall be provided for each 800 square foot of surface area, or fraction thereof. All skimmers shall be built into the wall and located at least 30 feet apart. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.44B.5; Ord. No. 601, § 2, 5-22-67) 
Sec. 6-221. - Water supply. 
    The source of water for a swimming pool shall be either that supplied by the village water system or a private well. If water is obtained from a private well, the water shall meet the bacteriological standards of the state department of public health for a safe drinking water. The point of discharge to the pool, whether through a hose or a pipe, shall be firmly fixed at the deep end of the pool at a point at least 6 inches above the overflow level of the pool. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.44B.6) 
Sec. 6-222. - Pool drainage. 
    Drain outlets from a swimming pool shall not be directly connected to a sanitary sewer line. Drainage shall be by gravity, by pumping, or by siphoning. Drainage must not be made into a sanitary sewer, but can be made into storm sewers or gutters or natural water courses. Pools must not be drained during periods of rain or storm. The drain outlet which connects to the recirculating system shall be permanently installed at a lowest point in the pool. It shall be ample in size with a free grating area sufficient to minimize chances of clogging, or occurrences of suction dangerous to the safety of bathers. The grating openings shall be of sufficiently small mesh and construction that bathers' fingers or toes will not be caught or injured. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.44B.7) 
Sec. 6-223. - Water disinfection. 
    Chlorine disinfectant in the form of sodium or calcium hypochloride, or bromine, shall be applied daily as frequently as needed to maintain a definite chlorine residual, not to exceed 0.5 ppm, throughout the pool volume while the pool is in use. A test kit with permanent color standards shall be provided at all pools and be used at frequent intervals to check on the adequacy of chlorine treatment. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.44B.8) 
Sec. 6-224. - Walks. 
    A walk area not less than four feet wide shall be provided to extend entirely around a swimming pool, except in the case of a portable, aboveground installation. The walk area shall be of impervious materials, shall be easily cleaned and have a definite pitch away from the pool edge. At portable aboveground pools, an area of impervious material four feet wide by eight feet long shall be constructed around the point where swimmers climb into the pool. Such walks shall be of non-skid texture. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.44B.9; Ord. No. 601, § 3, 5-22-67) 
Sec. 6-225. - Electrical equipment. 
    All metal parts of underwater electrical fixtures shall be grounded. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.44B.10) 
Sec. 6-226. - Safety equipment and fences. 
(a)  Pools shall be equipped with grab rails and approved metal ladders or steps firmly fastened to the construction. There shall be two or more means of egress by ladders or steps. 
(b)  Diving boards will not be permitted in depths less than seven feet of water. 
(c)  The slope of the bottom of the pool shall not exceed one foot of depth for each ten feet horizontal where the depth of water is less than five feet. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.44B.11; Ord. No. 601, § 4, 5-22-67) 
Sec. 6-227. - Disease control. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person having an infectious or contagious disease to use any swimming pool, and no person in charge of any pool shall knowingly permit such use. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.44B.13) 
Secs. 6-228-6-240. - Reserved.

Sec. 6-1502. - Penalties. 
(a)  Whosoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of an offense and fined not less than $100.00, nor more than $750.00 and/or sentenced up to six months in the county jail excepting violations of stop-work orders and occupancy without a permit. except when fines and costs are paid by compromise payment as provided in subsection (b) below prior to court, the court clerk shall add to the fine any and all costs and fees upon an authorized disposition. 
(b)  Any person accused of a violation of this code may settle and compromise said claim without a court appearance by payment of one-half of the minimum required fine to the village clerk at the village hall within ten business days of the date of violation if the compromise box designation is so checked on the complaint and notice to appear form. 
(c)  Violations of any stop work order issued by the building official are set at a minimum fine of $250.00, nor more than $750.00 and/or sentenced up to six months in the county jail; violations of occupancy of a structure without an occupancy permit are set at a minimum fine of $250.00, nor more than $750.00 and/or sentenced up to six months in the county jail. 
(d)  Violations of any provision of this chapter may be cited in accordance with administrative hearing procedures as set for in article XIV of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2003-52, § 10, 12-8-03; Ord. No. 2006-43, § 5, 12-11-06; Ord. No. 2009-52, § 2, 7-27-09) 
Secs. 6-1503-6-1600. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIV. - ADMINISTRATIVE HEARING AND ADJUDICATION PROCEDURES 

Sec. 6-1601. - Adoption of state statute. 
    Hereby adopted is 65 ILCS 5/11-31.1-1, et seq. as it may be amended from time to time and as allowed by said statute. 
(Ord. No. 2009-52, § 2, 7-27-09) 
Sec. 6-1602. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, unless context requires otherwise: 
    Building official means a full-time or part-time village employee whose duties include the inspection or examination of structures or property in the village to determine if zoning or other code violation exist and includes, but is not limited to, building inspectors, plumbing inspectors, electrical inspectors, code enforcement officers, patrol officers, patrol sergeants, supervisory and command police personnel, fire inspectors, firefighter and supervisory and command fire personnel and the zoning administrator; 
    Code means any Village of Crete ordinance, law, housing, building code or zoning ordinance that establishes construction, plumbing, heating, electrical, fire prevention, sanitation, property maintenance or other health and safety standards that are applicable to structures in the Village of Crete; 
    Hearing officer means a village employee or an officer or agent of the village, other than a property inspector, building official or law enforcement officer, whose duty it is to: 
(1)  Preside at an administrative hearing called to determine whether or not a code violation exists; 
(2)  Hear testimony and accept evidence from the building official, the building owner and all interested parties relevant to the existence of a code violation; 
(3)  Preserve and authenticate the record of the hearing and all exhibits and evidence introduced at the hearing; 
(4)  Issue and sign a written finding, decision and order stating whether a code violation exists. 
    Property owner means the legal or beneficial owner of a structure. 
(Ord. No. 2009-52, § 2, 7-27-09) 
Sec. 6-1603. - Code hearing department. 
(a)  There is hereby established a code hearing department, the function of which is to expedite the presentation and correction of code violations in the manner set out in 65 ILCS 5/11-31.1 et seq and this article. 
(b)  The adoption of this article does not preclude the village from using other lawful methods to enforce the provisions of its Code. 
(Ord. No. 2009-52, § 2, 7-27-09) 
Sec. 6-1604. - Code hearing procedure. 
(a)  When a building official finds a code violation while inspecting a property, he or she shall note the violation on a multiple copy violation notice and report form, indicating the name and address of the property owner, the type and nature of the violation, the date and time the violation was observed, the names of witnesses to the violation, and the address of the property where the violation is observed. A copy of the violation notice and report form may be handed directly to the property owner if present. 
(b)  The violation report form shall be forwarded by the building official to the code hearing department where a docket number shall be stamped on all copies of the report, and a hearing date noted in the blank spaces provided for that purpose on the form. The hearing date shall not be less than 30 days, nor more than 40 days after the violation is reported by the building official. 
(c)  One copy of the violation report form shall be maintained in the files of the code hearing department and shall be part of the record of hearing, one copy of the report form shall be returned to the building official so that he may prepare evidence of the code violation for presentation at the hearing on the date indicated, and one copy of the report form shall be served by first class mail on the property owner along with a summons commanding the property owner to appear at the hearing. If the name of the property owner of the structure cannot be ascertained or if service on the property owner cannot be made by mail, service may be made on the property owner by posting or nailing a copy of the violation report form on the front door of the structure where the violation is found, not less than 20 days before the hearing is scheduled. 
(Ord. No. 2009-52, § 2, 7-27-09) 
Sec. 6-1605. - Subpoenas. 
    At any time prior to the hearing date the hearing officer assigned to hear the case may, at the request of the building official or the attorney for the village, or the property owner or his attorney, issue subpoenas directing witnesses to appear and give testimony at the hearing. 
(Ord. No. 2009-52, § 2, 7-27-09) 
Sec. 6-1606. - Default. 
    If on the date set for hearing the property owner or his attorney fails to appear, the hearing officer may find the property owner in default and shall proceed with the hearing and accept evidence relevant to the existence of a code violation. 
(Ord. No. 2009-52, § 2, 7-27-09) 
Sec. 6-1607. - Continuances and representation at code hearings. 
    No continuances shall be authorized by the hearing officer in proceedings under this article except in cases where a continuance is absolutely necessary to protect the rights of the owner. Lack of preparation shall not be grounds for a continuance. Any continuance authorized by a hearing officer under this article shall not exceed 25 days. The case for the village may be presented by the building official, by any other village employee or by an attorney designated by the village. However, in no event shall the case for the village be presented by an employee of the code hearing department. The case for the property owner may be presented by the owner, his attorney, or any other agent or representative. 
(Ord. No. 2009-52, § 2, 7-27-09) 
Sec. 6-1608. - Evidence at hearing. 
    At the hearing, a hearing officer shall preside and shall hear testimony and accept any evidence relevant to the existence or no-existence of a code violation relating to a property or structure indicated. The strict rules of evidence applicable to judicial proceedings shall not apply to hearings authorized by this article. 
(Ord. No. 2009-52, § 2, 7-27-09) 
Sec. 6-1609. - Retaliatory action against occupants prohibited. 
    No action for eviction, abatement of a nuisance, forcible entry and detainer or other similar proceeding shall be threatened or instituted against an occupant of a dwelling solely because such occupant agrees to testify or testifies at a code violation hearing. 
(Ord. No. 2009-52, § 2, 7-27-09) 
Sec. 6-1610. - Defenses to code violations. 
    It shall be a defense to a code violation charge under this article if the property owner, his attorney, or any other agent or representative proves to the hearing officer's satisfaction that: 
(1)  The code violation alleged in the notice does not in fact exist, or at the time of the hearing the violation has been remedied or removed; 
(2)  The code violation has been caused by the current property occupants and that in spite of reasonable attempts by the property owner to maintain the dwelling free of such violations, the current occupants continue to cause the violations; 
(3)  An occupant or resident of the dwelling has refused entry to the property owner or his agent to all or a part of the dwelling for the purpose of correcting the code violation. 
(Ord. No. 2009-52, § 2, 7-27-09) 
Sec. 6-1611. - Findings, decision, order of hearing officer. 
(a)  At the conclusion of the hearing the hearing officer shall make a determination on the basis of the evidence presented at the hearing whether or not a code violation exists. The determination shall be in writing and shall be designated as findings, decision and order. The findings, decision and order shall include the hearing officer's finding of fact, a decision whether or not a code violation exists based upon the findings of facts, and an order ordering the property owner to correct the violation or dismissing the case in the event a violation is not proved. 
(b)  If a code violation is proved, the order may also impose the sanctions that are provided in the Code for the violation proved. A copy of the findings, decision and order shall be served on the property owner within five days after they are issued; service shall be in the same manner as the report form and summons are served pursuant to subsection 6-1604(c). Payment of any penalty or fine and the disposition of fine money shall be in the same manner as set forth in the Code. 
(Ord. No. 2009-52, § 2, 7-27-09) 
Sec. 6-1612. - Fines and sanctions. 
    Whosoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this chapter and pursuant to the findings, decision and order of the hearing officer is found to be guilty of an offense shall be as a sanction fined not less than $75.00, nor more than $750.00. Violations of any stop-work order issued by the building official are set at a minimum fine of $250.00, nor more than $750.00, violations of occupancy of a structure without an occupancy permit are set at a minimum fine of $250.00, nor more than $750.00. 
(Ord. No. 2009-52, § 2, 7-27-09) 
Sec. 6-1613. - Administrative review law to apply. 
    The findings, decision and order of the hearing officer shall be subject to review in the Twelfth Judicial Circuit, Will County, and the provisions of the administrative review law (735 ILCS 5/3-101 et seq.), and all amendments and modifications thereto, and the rules adopted pursuant thereto are adopted and shall apply to and govern every action for the judicial review of the final findings, decision and order of a hearing officer under this article. 
(Ord. No. 2009-52, § 2, 7-27-09) 
Sec. 6-1614. - Disposition of violations. 
(a)  Any fine, other sanction or costs imposed, or part of any fine, other sanction or costs imposed remaining unpaid after the exhaustion of, or the failure to exhaust, judicial review procedures under the administrative review law shall be a debt due and owing the village and, as such, may be collected in accordance with applicable law. 
(b)  After expiration of the period within judicial review under the administrative review law may be sought for a final determination of the code violation, the village may commence a proceeding in the circuit court for purposes of obtaining a judgment on the findings, decision and order. Nothing in this section shall prevent the village from consolidating multiple findings, decisions and orders against a person in such a proceeding. Upon commencement of the action, the village shall file a certified copy of the findings, decision and order, which shall be accompanied by a certification that recites facts sufficient to show that the findings, decision and order was issued in accordance with this article and applicable state law. Service of the summons and a copy of the petition may be by any method provided by Section 2-203 of the Code of Civil Procedure or by certified mail, return receipt requested, provided that the total amounts of fines, other sanctions and costs imposed by the findings, decision and order does not exceed $2,500.00. 
(Ord. No. 2009-52, § 2, 7-27-09) 
Sec. 6-1615. - Sanctions and findings to run with property. 
    The order to correct a code violation and the sanctions imposed by the village as the result of a finding of a code violation under this article shall attach to the property as well as to the property owner so that a finding of a code violation against one owner cannot be avoided by conveying or transferring the property to another owner. Any subsequent transferee or owner of property takes subject to the findings, decision and order of a hearing officer under this article. 
(Ord. No. 2009-52, § 2, 7-27-09) 
Secs. 6-1616-6-1645. - Reserved. 
Chapter 7 - CABLE COMMUNICATIONS 
ARTICLE I. - CABLE AND VIDEO CUSTOMER PROTECTION LAW 

Sec. 7-1. - Customer service and privacy protection law. 
(a)  Adoption. The regulations of 220 ILCS 5/70-501 are hereby adopted by reference and made applicable to the cable or video providers offering services within the village boundaries. 
(b)  Amendments. Any amendment to the Cable and Video Customer Protection Law that becomes effective after the effective date of this article shall be incorporated into this article by reference and shall be applicable to cable or video providers offering services within the municipality's boundaries. However, any amendment that makes its provisions optional for adoption by municipalities shall not be incorporated into this article by reference without formal action by the corporate authorities of the village. 
(Ord. No. 2007-48, § 2, 12-10-07) 
Sec. 7-2. - Enforcement. 
    The village does hereby pursuant to law declare its intent to enforce all of the customer service and privacy protection standards of the cable and video protection law with respect to complaints received from residents within the village. 
(Ord. No. 2007-48, § 2, 12-10-07) 
Sec. 7-3. - Penalties. 
    The village, pursuant to 220 ILCS 5/70-501(r)(1), does hereby provide for a schedule of penalties for any material breach of the Cable and Video Protection Law by cable or video providers in addition to the penalties provided in the law. The monetary penalties shall apply on a competitively neutral basis and shall be a minimum of $100.00 and not exceed $750.00 for each day of the material breach, and shall not exceed $25,000.00 for each occurrence of a material breach per customer. 
(1)  Material breach means any substantial failure of a cable or video provider to comply with service quality and other standards specified in any provision of the law. 
(2)  The village shall give the cable or video provider written notice of any alleged material breaches of the law and allow such provider at least 30 days from the receipt of the notice to remedy the specified material breach. 
(3)  A material breach, for the purposes of assessing penalties, shall be deemed to occur for each day that a material breach has not been remedied by the cable or video service provider after the notice in [subsection] (2). 
(Ord. No. 2007-48, § 2, 12-10-07) 
Sec. 7-4. - Customer credits. 
    The village hereby adopts the schedule of customer credits for violations. Those credits shall be as provided for in the provisions of 220 ILCS 5/70-501(s) and applied on the statement issued to the customer for the next billing cycle following the violation or following the discovery of the violation. The cable or video provider is responsible for providing the credits and the customer is under no obligation to request the credit. 
(Ord. No. 2007-48, § 2, 12-10-07) 
Secs. 7-5-7-19. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CABLE/VIDEO SERVICE PROVIDER FEE AND PEG ACCESS SUPPORT FEE 

Sec. 7-20. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, the following terms shall have the following meanings: 
    Cable service means that term as defined in 47 U.S.C. § 522(6). 
    Commission means the Illinois Commerce Commission. 
    Gross revenues means all consideration of any kind or nature, including, without limitation, cash, credits, property, and in-kind contributions received by the holder for the operation of a cable or video system to provide cable service or video service within the holder's cable service or video service area within the village. 
(1)  Gross revenues shall include the following: 
a.  Recurring charges for cable or video service. 
b.  Event-based charges for cable service or video service, including, but not limited to, pay-per-view and video-on-demand charges. 
c.  Rental of set-top boxes and other cable service or video service equipment. 
d.  Service charges related to the provision of cable service or video service, including, but not limited to, activation, installation, and repair charges. 
e.  Administrative charges related to the provision of cable service or video service including, but not limited to, service order and service termination charges. 
f.  Late payment fees or charges, insufficient funds check charges, and other charges assessed to recover the costs of collecting delinquent payments. 
g.  A pro rata portion of all revenue derived by the holder or its affiliates pursuant to compensation arrangements for advertising or for promotion or exhibition of any products or services derived from the operation of the holder's network to provide cable service or video service within the village. The allocation shall be based on the number of subscribers in the village divided by the total number of subscribers in relation to the relevant regional or national compensation arrangement. 
h.  Compensation received by the holder that is derived from the operation of the holder's network to provide cable service or video service with respect to commissions that are received by the holder as compensation for promotion or exhibition of any products or services on the holder's network, such as a "home shopping" or similar channel, subject to subsection i. 
i.  In the case of a cable service or video service that is bundled or integrated functionally with other services, capabilities, or applications, the portion of the holder's revenue attributable to the other services, capabilities, or applications shall be included in the gross revenue unless the holder can reasonably identify the division or exclusion of the revenue from its books and records that are kept in the regular course of business. 
j.  The service provider fee permitted by 220 ILCS 5/21-801(b). 
(2)  Gross revenues do not include any of the following: 
a.  Revenues not actually received, even if billed, such as bad debt, subject to 220 ILCS 5/21-801(c)(1)(vi). 
b.  Refunds, discounts, or other price adjustments that reduce the amount of gross revenues received by the holder of the state-issued authorization to the extent the refund, rebate, credit, or discount is attributable to cable service or video service. 
c.  Regardless of whether the services are bundled, packaged, or functionally integrated with cable service or video service, any revenues received from services not classified as cable service or video service, including, without limitation, revenue received from telecommunication services, information services, or the provision of directory or Internet advertising, including yellow pages, white pages, banner advertisement, and electronic publishing or any other revenues attributed by the holder to noncable service or nonvideo service in accordance with the holder's books and records and records kept in the regular course of business and any applicable laws, rules, regulations, standards, or orders. 
d.  The sale of cable services or video services for resale in which the purchaser is required to collect the service provider fee from the purchaser's subscribers to the extent the purchaser certifies in writing that it will resell the service within the village and pay the fee permitted by 220 ILCS 5/21-801(b) with respect to the service. 
e.  Any tax or fee of general applicability imposed upon the subscribers or the transaction by a city, state, federal, or any other governmental entity and collected by the holder of the state-issued authorization and required to be remitted to the taxing entity, including sales and use taxes. 
f.  Security deposits collected from subscribers. 
g.  Amounts paid by subscribers to "home shopping" or similar vendors for merchandise sold through any home shopping channel offered as part of the cable service or video service. 
(3)  Revenue of an affiliate of a holder shall be included in the calculation of gross revenues to the extent the treatment of the revenue as revenue of the affiliate rather than the holder has the effect of evading the payment of the fee permitted by 220 ILCS 5/21-801(b) which would otherwise be paid by the cable service or video service. 
    Holder means a person or entity that has received authorization to offer or provide cable or video service from the commission pursuant to 220 ILCS 5/21-401. 
    PEG means public, education and governmental. 
    PEG access support fee means the amount paid under this article and 220 ILCS 5/21-801(d) by the holder to the village for the service areas within its territorial jurisdiction. 
    Service means the provision of cable service or video service to subscribers and the interaction of subscribers with the person or entity that has received authorization to offer or provide cable or video service from the commission pursuant to 220 ILCS 5/21-401. 
    Service provider fee means the amount paid under this article and 220 ILCS 5/21-801 by the holder to a village for the service areas within its territorial jurisdiction. 
    Video service means video programming and subscriber interaction, if any, that is required for the selection or use of such video programming services, and which is provided through wireline facilities located at least in part in the public right-of-way without regard to delivery technology, including Internet protocol technology. This definition does not include any video programming provided by a commercial mobile service provider defined in 47 U.S.C. § 332(d) or any video programming provided solely as part of, and via, service that enables users to access content, information, electronic mail, or other services offered over the public Internet. 
(Ord. No. 2007-47, § 2, 12-10-07) 
Sec. 7-21. - Cable/video service provider fee imposed. 
(a)  Fee imposed. A fee is hereby imposed on any holder providing cable service or video service in the village. 
(b)  Amount of fee. The amount of the fee imposed hereby shall be five percent of the holder's gross revenues and shall be the same percentage as any incumbent cable operator. 
(c)  Notice to the village. The holder shall notify the village at least ten days prior to the date on which the holder begins to offer cable service or video service in the village. 
(d)  Holder's liability. The holder shall be liable for and pay the service provider fee to the village. The holder's liability for the fee shall commence on the first day of the calendar month following 30 days after receipt of the ordinance adopting this article by the holder. The ordinance adopting this article shall be sent by mail, postage prepaid, to the address listed on the holder's application notice sent pursuant to 220 ILCS 5/21-401(b)(6) to the village. 
(e)  Payment date. The payment of the service provider fee shall be due on a quarterly basis, 45 days after the close of the calendar quarter. If mailed, the fee is considered paid on the date it is postmarked. Each payment shall include a statement explaining the basis for the calculation of the fee. 
(f)  Exemption. The fee hereby imposed does not apply to existing cable service or video service providers that have an existing franchise agreement with the village in which a fee is paid. 
(g)  Credit for other payments. An incumbent cable operator that elects to terminate an existing agreement pursuant to 220 ILCS 5/21-301(c) with credit for prepaid franchise fees under that agreement may deduct the amount of such credit from the fees that operator owes under subsection 7-21(b). 
(Ord. No. 2007-47, § 2, 12-10-07) 
Sec. 7-22. - PEG access support fee imposed. 
(a)  PEG fee imposed. A PEG access support fee is hereby imposed on any holder providing cable service or video service in the village in addition to the fee imposed pursuant to [section] 7-21. 
(b)  Amount of fee. The amount of the PEG access support fee imposed hereby shall be one percent of the holder's gross revenues or, if greater, the percentage of gross revenues that incumbent cable operators pay to the village or its designee for PEG access support in the village. 
(c)  Payment. The holder shall pay the PEG access support fee to the village or to the entity designated by the village to manage PEG access. The holder's liability for the PEG access support fee shall commence on the date set forth in subsection 7-21(d). 
(d)  Payment due. The payment of the PEG access support fee shall be due on a quarterly basis, 45 days after the close of the calendar quarter. If mailed, the fee is considered paid on the date it is postmarked. Each payment shall include a statement explaining the basis for the calculation of the fee. 
(e)  Credit for other payments. An incumbent cable operator that elects to terminate an existing agreement pursuant to 220 ILCS 5/21-301(c) shall pay, at the time they would have been due, all monetary payments for PEG access that would have been due during the remaining term of the agreement had it not been terminated pursuant to that section. All payments made by an incumbent cable operator pursuant to the previous sentence may be credited against the fees that that operator owes under section 7-22. 
(Ord. No. 2007-47, § 2, 12-10-07) 
Sec. 7-23. - Applicable principles. 
    All determinations and calculations under this article shall be made pursuant to generally accepted accounting principles. 
(Ord. No. 2007-47, § 2, 12-10-07) 
Sec. 7-24. - No impact on other taxes due from holder. 
    Nothing contained in this article shall be construed to exempt a holder from any tax that is or may later be imposed by the village, including any tax that is or may later be required to be paid by or through the holder with respect to cable service or video service. A state-issued authorization shall not affect any requirement of the holder with respect to payment of the village's simplified municipal telecommunications tax or any other tax as it applies to any telephone service provided by the holder. A state-issued authorization shall not affect any requirement of the holder with respect to payment of the local unit of government's 911 or E911 fees, taxes or charges. 
(Ord. No. 2007-47, § 2, 12-10-07) 
Sec. 7-25. - Audits of cable/video service provider. 
(a)  Audit requirement. The village will notify the holder of the requirements it imposes on other cable service or video service providers to submit to an audit of its books and records. The holder shall comply with the same requirements the village imposes on other cable service or video service providers in its jurisdiction to audit the holder's books and records and to recompute any amounts determined to be payable under the requirements of the village. If all local franchises between the village and cable operator terminate, the audit requirements shall be those adopted by the village pursuant to the Local Government Taxpayers' Bill of Rights Act, 50 ILCS 45/1 et seq. No acceptance of amounts remitted should be construed as an accord that the amounts are correct. 
(b)  Additional payments. Any additional amount due after an audit shall be paid within 30 days after the village's submission of an invoice for the sum. 
(Ord. No. 2007-47, § 2, 12-10-07) 
Sec. 7-26. - Late fees/payments. 
    All fees due and payments which are past due shall be governed by ordinances adopted by this village pursuant to the Local Government Taxpayers' Bill of Rights Act, 50 ILCS 45/1 et seq. 
(Ord. No. 2007-47, § 2, 12-10-07)

ARTICLE II. - FLOOD HAZARD AREAS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Formerly, art. II, §§ 8-16-8-28, pertained to flood hazard areas as derived from Ord. No. 828, § 1, adopted Dec. 22, 1980, and Ord. No. 87-14, § 1, adopted Mar. 18, 1987. Subsequently, Ord. No. 89-19, § 1(200-1500), adopted July 11, 1989, enacted new provisions pertaining to the same subject matter set out herein as §§ 8-16-8-19, 8-26-8-30, and 8-36-8-40 (see the repealer in § 8-18). Sec. 1(1600) pertaining to separability was omitted from codification as being covered by § 1-9 of the Code. 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 6; subdivisions, ch. 23; zoning, ch. 28. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 8-16. - Purpose. 
    This article is enacted pursuant to the police powers granted to the village by Illinois Revised Statutes, 65 ILCS 5/1-2-1, 5/11-12-12m, and 5/11-30-8. The purpose of this article is to maintain the village's eligibility in the National Flood Insurance Program; to minimize potential losses due to periodic flooding including loss of life, loss of property, health and safety hazards, disruption of commerce and governmental services, extraordinary public expenditures for flood protection and relief, and impairment of the tax base, all of which adversely affect the public health, safety and general welfare; and to preserve and enhance the quality of surface waters, conserve economic and natural values and provide for the wise utilization of water and related land resources. This article is adopted in order to accomplish the following specified purposes: 
(1)  To meet the requirements of 615 ILCS 5/5, an act in relation to the regulation of the rivers, lakes and streams of the State of Illinois, approved June 10, 1911, as amended; 
(2)  To assure that new development does not increase the flood or drainage hazards to others, or create unstable conditions susceptible to erosion; 
(3)  To protect new buildings and major improvements to buildings from flood damage; 
(4)  To protect human life and health from the hazards of flooding; 
(5)  To lessen the burden on the taxpayer for flood control projects, repairs to flood-damaged public facilities and utilities, and flood rescue and relief operations; 
(6)  To make federally subsidized flood insurance available for property in the village by fulfilling the requirements of the National Flood Insurance Program; 
(7)  To comply with the rules and regulations of the National Flood Insurance Program codified as 44 CFR 59-79, as amended; 
(8)  To protect, conserve and promote the orderly development of land and water resources; 
(9)  To preserve the natural hydrologic and hydraulic functions of watercourses and floodplains and to protect water quality and aquatic habitats; 
(10)  To preserve the natural characteristics of stream corridors in order to moderate flood and stormwater impacts, improve water quality, reduce soil erosion, protect aquatic and riparian habitat, provide recreational opportunities, provide aesthetic benefits and enhance community and economic development. 
(Ord. No. 89-19, § 1(200), 7-11-89) 
Sec. 8-17. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this article, the following definitions are adopted: 
    Act: "An act in relation to the regulation of the rivers, lakes and streams of the State of Illinois", 615 ILCS 5/5 et seq. 
    Applicant: Any person, firm, corporation or agency which submits an application. 
    Appropriate use: Only uses of the regulatory floodway that are permitted and will be considered for permit issuance. The only uses that will be allowed are as specified in section 8-38(2). 
    Base flood: The flood having a one percent probability of being equaled or exceeded in any given year. The base flood is also known as the 100-year frequency flood event. Application of the base flood elevation at any location is as defined in section 8-28 of this article. 
    Building: A structure that is principally above ground and is enclosed by walls and a roof. The term includes a gas or liquid storage tank, a manufactured home, mobile home or a prefabricated building. This term also includes recreational vehicles and travel trailers to be installed on a site for more than 180 days. 
    Channel: Any river, stream, creek, brook, branch, natural or artificial depression, ponded area, flowage, slough, conduit, culvert, gully, ravine, wash, or natural or manmade drainageway, which has a definite bed and banks or shoreline, in or into which surface or ground water flows, either perennially or intermittently. 
    Channel modification: Alteration of a channel by changing the physical dimensions or material of its bed or banks. Channel modification includes damming, rip-rapping or other armoring, widening, deepening, straightening, relocating, lining, and significant removal of bottom or woody vegetation. Channel modification does not include the clearing of dead or dying vegetation, debris, or trash from the channel. Channelization is a severe form of channel modification involving a typical relocation of the existing channel (e.g. straightening).
