(Code 1965, §§ 2.2.4A.27-2.2.4A.30) 
Sec. 9-90. - Piping. 
    All piping used in connection with flammable liquids shall comply with the following: 
(1)  All piping shall be standard full weight wrought iron or steel for working pressures less than 100 pounds; for working pressures in excess of 100 pounds extra heavy pipe and fitting shall be used. No pipe less than one-half inch internal diameter will be permitted. 
(2)  Piping shall be run as directly as possible and proper allowance made for expansion and contraction. 
(3)  Pipes shall not be surrounded or covered by cinders or other materials of corrosive effect, but preferably should be laid in sand, and where carried in conduit, the openings of such conduit must be fully protected to prevent escape of liquid under dangerous conditions. Pipelines buried on railroad property shall be laid at a depth of not less than three feet; where they pass under tracks they shall be laid at least four feet below the bottom of the ties. Piping buried in village streets or other areas where other pipe lines are carried shall be placed in conduit. Joints of conduit shall be sealed to prevent leakage and pitch shall be toward tank yard. Underground piping shall be coated with asphaltum or corrosion resisting material. 
(4)  Joints may be welded or of the ordinary screw type; if the screw type they shall be made with litharge and glycerin, lamp black or shellac. 
(5)  Piping after installation shall be tested at a pressure of 50 percent in excess of the working pressure and shall be proven tight. Test shall continue 30 minutes. 
(6)  Each pipe attached to a tank shall be provided with a valve at the tank, with no branches or outlets between the tank and the valve. In case two or more tanks are cross-connected, there shall be a valve at each tank in each cross-connection. Tanks with different classes of liquids shall not be cross-connected. 
(7)  In addition to normal valves, there shall be an extra valve at each pipeline, installed on the inside of the tank and operated by an effective heat releasing device, which shall automatically prevent the flow of liquid from the tank in case of fire, even if pipelines are broken from the tank. 
(Code 1965, §§ 2.2.4A.20-2.2.4A.26) 
Sec. 9-91. - Pumphouses. 
(a)  Motors and pumps shall be located in a separate, noncombustible building, not less than ten feet from tanks, warehouses, garage, or property lines. 
(b)  Motors shall be of the polyphase, non-sparking or explosion-proof type, and shall be grounded to permanently moist earth. 
(c)  If a pumphouse is electrically lighted, lights shall be of the vapor-proof type, wiring shall be in a sealed conduit, and the light switch shall be of the explosion-proof type, or shall be placed outside the building. 
(d)  Motor starting switches shall be of the explosion-proof type or oil bath type. 
(e)  Screened openings of not less than 64 square inches shall be constructed in opposite corners at floor line to provide proper ventilation. 
(f)  All doors of pumphouses shall open outward. Doors shall be left open at all times when pumps are in operation. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.4A.32) 
Sec. 9-92. - Fencing. 
    The area which embraces the tank gear, including dike and all aboveground piping and pipe lines, shall be properly fenced with a metal fence. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.4A.44) 
Sec. 9-93. - Warehouses. 
(a)  Warehouses in which flammable liquids are located shall be constructed so that refuse cannot accumulate under the floor. 
(b)  The storage of class I liquids shall not be permitted in any building. The storage of class II liquids shall not be permitted except in original sealed containers and no transfer of such liquids in such containers to other circumstances shall ever be made inside the warehouse. 
(c)  All warehouses shall be kept clean, neat and orderly, and free from accumulation of grease and oil spillage. 
(d)  The National Electrical Code shall govern the electrical installations. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.4A.33) 
Sec. 9-94. - Garages. 
(a)  Floors of garage in which flammable liquids are located shall be of concrete or other noncombustible material, laid directly on the ground or on a well tamped and puddled fill. 
(b)  Adequate ventilation shall be provided to carry off any inflammable gases which may accumulate. 
(c)  No connection to any house drainage or to any sewer system shall be made from any garage waste basin, sink, floor drain or waste, unless an adequate grease trap is provided ahead of such connection. This subsection does not apply to lavatories, toilets, or wash basins, used exclusively for toilet or personal use, nor does it apply to downspouts carrying surface water from the roof. 
(d)  The National Electrical Code shall govern all electrical installations. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.4A.34) 
Sec. 9-95. - Loading docks. 
(a)  Truck loading docks and platforms shall be located not less than ten feet from storage tanks, plant buildings and property lines. 
(b)  All electric lights at loading or unloading docks shall be of vaporproof construction. Electric wiring shall be in sealed conduit at docks and switches shall be of the explosion-proof type or placed at some point remote from the docks. 
(Code 1965, §§ 2.2.4A.35, 2.2.4A.36) 
Sec. 9-96. - Pumps and pipelines. 
(a)  Gasoline and naphtha shall not be handled through the same pump and pile lines as kerosene and fuel oils. 
(b)  Pipelines shall have a definite color scheme for painting to indicate the product which is being carried by the respective lines. The color red shall be for gasoline and naphtha. Valves on lines in pumphouse shall be tagged to denote the product handled and controlled by each valve. 
(c)  Pumps delivering to or taking supply from tanks or tank car shall be provided with valves on both suction and discharge pump. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.4A.37) 
Sec. 9-97. - Grounding of tank cars. 
(a)  Before unloading operations are started and before any connection or contact is made with piping or other loading equipment, the tank car shall be electrically grounded in an effective manner. Permanent electrical connection of not less than number 0 copper cable shall be made between the rails on which tank cars stand and the piping system of the storage plant. 
(b)  The connection may be accomplished in one of the following ways: 
(1)  The rails may be bonded by means of standard rail bonds and connected to the permanent piping system with number 0 electric cable connections at each end of the loading or unloading section; or 
(2)  A similar connection may be made between each rail on which cars stand and the permanent piping system. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.4A.38) 
Sec. 9-98. - Permissible methods of unloading tank cars. 
(a)  The withdrawal of flammable liquids from tank cars through bottom outlets shall not be permitted. Tank cars shall be unloaded through dome (manhole) only. Pumps required to accomplish this shall be adequate type and securely installed. 
(b)  Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection (a), fuel oils may be unloaded by gravity. 
(c)  The use of compressed air to discharge contents of tank cars is prohibited, but this shall not be construed to prevent the use of a standard system employing an inert gas, such as carbon dioxide or nitrogen, as pressure generating medium for this purpose. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.4A.39) 
Sec. 9-99. - Unloading to portable containers. 
    Unloading flammable liquids from tank cars to tank trucks or to any portable containers shall not be permitted. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.4A.40) 
Sec. 9-100. - Dome covers for tank cars. 
    After unloading, pipe shall be inserted into dome of tank car and before any pumping is done, and the dome shall be tightly covered with wet burlap or some other type of equally effective cover. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.4A.41) 
Sec. 9-101. - Other restrictions on tank cars. 
(a)  All connections between tank cars and pipe lines shall be in good condition and shall not permit leakage. 
(b)  Tank cars shall not be left connected to pipe lines except when loading or unloading is going on, and during all such times a competent man shall be present and in charge. 
(c)  The presence of flame lanterns, flame switch lights or other exposed flame lights or fires during the process of loading or unloading is prohibited. 
(d)  Siding use in connection with tank car unloading operations shall not be common to other users, or they shall be provided with necessary derails or with warning signs in accordance with section 4, paragraph 697(b) of the Interstate Commerce Commission regulations on the transportation of explosives. 
(e)  The unloading of tank cars and all operations in connection therewith shall be in full accord with the rules and regulations of the Interstate Commerce Commission. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.4A.42) 
Sec. 9-102. - Tank trucks and wagons generally. 
(a)  Tanks, tank trucks, and wagons shall be constructed with double bulkheads. 
(b)  Each compartment or tank shall be numbered and the same number shall appear on pipeline at rear of truck or wagon connected with that compartment. 
(c)  A serviceable metal tag shall be fastened securely to each faucet, designating the contents of the compartment it controls by lettering not less than one-fourth inch high. Tags shall be painted according to the same color scheme as the pipe line, red always indicating gasoline or naphtha. 
(d)  Faucets shall be of the self-closing type. 
(e)  Heavy bumpers shall be provided across the rear, adequate to protect all faucets in case of a rear end collision. 
(f)  Tanks, chassis, axles and springs shall be attached and shall be long enough to reach the ground at all times. 
(g)  If buckets are used to deliver gasoline or naphtha, they shall be painted red and properly labeled. They shall be used for delivering gasoline and naphtha only and gasoline and naphtha shall not be delivered in any other buckets. 
(h)  No retail deliveries from tank trucks or tank wagons shall be permitted in any street or alley in the village, nor on any highway outside the village. 
(i)  Each tank truck or tank wagon shall carry an approved fire extinguisher suitable for extinguishing gasoline and oil fires, such as carbon tetrachloride, carbon dioxide, foam or powder. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.4A.48) 
Sec. 9-103. - Grounding of tank trucks. 
    Before loading operations begin, tank trucks shall be electrically bonded to pipe line by means of a bonding device at loading dock. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.4A.43) 
Sec. 9-104. - Hazardous materials handling. 
(a)  For the purposes of this section, "hazardous materials" is defined as a chemical, liquid or solid substance which are physical hazards or health hazards as defined in the International Fire Code (see chapter 9), whether the materials are in usable or waste condition. 
(b)  All businesses involved in the storage, transfer, sale, purchase or movement of hazardous materials shall establish and maintain written procedures to follow in the event of a spill. All personnel shall be trained in these procedures and the procedures shall be readily accessible in case of a spill. 
(c)  Upon observation of a hazardous material spill, all activity not related to the mitigation of the spill within the area affected or which could be affected shall cease until the spill has been removed or the hazard has been mitigated. 
(d)  Vehicular movement though the spill area shall not be permitted until the spilled material has been removed or the hazard has been mitigated. 
(e)  The fire department shall be notified of any hazardous materials spill which is considered a hazard to person(s) or property or which meet one of the following criteria: 
(1)  Any dimension of the spill is greater than ten feet. 
(2)  The spill area is greater than 50 square feet. 
(3)  The flow is continuous in nature. 
(f)  Self-closing metal can(s) or other container(s) approved by the fire chief shall be maintained on the premises to temporarily store spilled material or debris resulting from mitigation and clean-up procedures. Said items shall be properly disposed of as soon as prudent by a certified disposal business for hazardous materials. 
(g)  All time and costs expended by fire department personnel in mitigating a hazardous material response shall be charged to the responsible party or the property owner upon which the spill originated and shall be a lien against the property until paid. The delineation of equipment and personnel costs to be applied to such responses shall be adopted by the corporate authorities and maintained by the village clerk. 
(Ord. No. 2005-35, § 2, 9-12-05) 
Secs. 9-105-9-120. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - LIQUEFIED PETROLEUM GAS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal regulation of liquefied petroleum gases, 430 ILCS 5/3. 

Sec. 9-121. - Miscellaneous ordinances not affected. 
    Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect section 2.2.27 of the Revised Municipal Code of the Village of Crete of 1965 and such section hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this Code. 
Sec. 9-122. - Compliance with state laws. 
    This article shall not relieve any person from the duty of obtaining any permits relating to the storage and dispensing of liquefied petroleum gases. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.4B.9; Ord. No. 83-3, § 1, 6-13-83) 
State Law reference- State regulation of liquefied petroleum gases, 430 ILCS 5/0.01-5/4. 
Sec. 9-123. - Adoption of 2003 International Fire Code. 
(a)  The village hereby adopts by reference the 2003 International Fire Code (First Printing: December 2002) including Appendices B, D, E, F and G and excluding Section 105 Permits as the village fire prevention code subject to additions, deletions and amendments in this chapter. 
(b)  The village clerk shall keep at least three copies of the 2003 International Fire Code (First Printing: December 2002) on file in the village hall and available for public use. 
(Code 1965, §§ 2.2.4B.1, 2.2.4B.2, 2.2.4B.4; Ord. No. 83-3, § 1, 6-13-83; Ord. No. 2003-55, § 2, 12-8-03) 
State Law reference- Adoption by reference, 65 ILCS 5/1-3-1 et seq. 
Sec. 9-124. - Signs on containers. 
    All containers for liquefied petroleum gas shall be conspicuously posted with signs made of weather rigid material. The signs shall be visible on all sides of the container and shall display in white letters on a red background, the following warnings: 
(1)  Warning 
(2)  Stop engine 
(3)  No smoking 
(4)  No open flame 
(5)  Extinguish pilot light on cooking or heating unit 
The warnings contained in paragraphs (1) through (4) shall be printed in capital letters which shall be four inches high and not less than five-eighths-inch wide; the warning contained in paragraph (5) shall be printed in capital letters two inches high and not less than one-quarter-inch wide. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.4.5B; Ord. No. 83-3, § 1, 6-13-83) 
Sec. 9-125. - Placement of storage and dispensing facilities. 
    The location of equipment and facilities designed for the storage and dispensing of liquefied petroleum gas shall be determined and established by the fire chief. The placement of such facilities shall be in areas which do not endanger the residents of the village; the fire chief may, in his discretion, limit the placement of such facilities or equipment to industrial areas. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.4B.3; Ord. No. 83-3, § 1, 6-13-83) 
Sec. 9-126. - Transfer operations. 
    Transfer of liquefied petroleum gases into containers, which are mounted on vehicles, shall take place only outdoors. It shall be unlawful to store any portable containers containing liquefied petroleum gases and awaiting use or resale. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.4B.6; Ord. No. 83-3, § 1, 6-13-83) 
Sec. 9-127. - Storage limitations. 
    It shall be unlawful to store on any premises within the village more than 2,000 gallons of liquefied petroleum gases. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.4B.7; Ord. No. 83-3, § 1, 6-13-83) 
Sec. 9-128. - Site specifications. 
    Any person who shall sell, store or dispense liquefied petroleum gases within the village shall, prior to obtaining any permit so to do, submit a plot drawing, which shall set forth dimensions of any tank or tanks together with the location of the tanks with reference to lot lines; such plot drawing or plans shall indicate the nearest roads, highways, all buildings, sizes of each tank or tanks, number of tanks and all pertinent information relating to installation of any tanks. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.4B.8; Ord. No. 83-3, § 1, 6-13-83) 
Sec. 9-129. - Fire extinguishers. 
    At least one portable fire extinguisher with a minimum rating of 15 B.C. shall be mounted within a distance of 20 feet of the liquefied petroleum gas dispensing unit or point. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.4B.10; Ord. No. 83-3, § 1, 6-13-83) 
Sec. 9-130. - Guard rails. 
    Steel guard rails shall be installed on all four sides of liquefied petroleum gas dispensing pumps. The rails shall be a minimum of ten feet from the tanks and dispensing units and shall be 30 inches in height. Said guard rails shall include a minimum of two means of emergency access, each such opening not to exceed 48 inches in width. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.4B.11; Ord. No. 83-3, § 1, 6-13-83) 
Secs. 9-131-9-140. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - FIRE SUPPRESSION AND EMERGENCY REGULATIONS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note- Inasmuch as Ord. No. 87-39, §§ 3-19, adopted Oct. 5, 1987, did not specify manner of codification, such provisions have been designated herein as art. VI, §§ 9-141-9-157, by the editor. See also the editor's footnote to ch. 9 concerning the Fire Prevention Code. 
Cross reference- For additional fire department regulations, see § 9-26 et seq. 

Sec. 9-141. - Authority at fires and other emergencies. 
    The fire official or duly authorized representatives, as may be in charge at the scene of a fire or other emergency involving the protection of life and/or property, is empowered to direct such operations as may be necessary to extinguish or control any suspected or reported fires, gas leaks, or other hazardous conditions or situations or of taking any other action necessary in the reasonable performance of their duty. The fire official may prohibit any person, vehicle or object from approaching the scene and may remove or cause to be removed from the scene any person, vehicle or object which may impede or interfere with the operations of the fire department. The fire official may remove or cause to be removed any person, vehicle or object from hazardous areas. All persons ordered to leave a hazardous area shall do so immediately and shall not re-enter the area until authorized to do so by the fire official. 
(Ord. No. 87-39, § 3, 10-5-87) 
Sec. 9-142. - Interference with fire department operations. 
    It shall be unlawful to interfere with, attempt to interfere with, conspire to interfere with, obstruct or restrict the mobility of, or block the path of travel of any fire department emergency vehicle in any way, or to interfere with, attempt to interfere, conspire to interfere with, obstruct or hamper any fire department operations. 
(Ord. No. 87-39, § 4, 10-5-87) 
Sec. 9-143. - Compliance with orders. 
    A person shall not willfully fail or refuse to comply with any lawful order or direction of the fire official or to interfere with the compliance attempts of another individual. 
(Ord. No. 87-39, § 5, 10-5-87) 
Sec. 9-144. - Vehicles crossing fire hose. 
    A vehicle shall not be driven or propelled over any unprotected fire hose of the fire department when laid down on any street, alleyway, private drive or any other vehicular roadway without the consent of the fire official in command of such operation. 
(Ord. No. 87-39, § 6, 10-5-87) 
Sec. 9-145. - Definition of authorized emergency vehicle. 
    Authorized emergency vehicles shall be restricted to those which are defined and authorized under the laws of the State of Illinois. 
(Ord. No. 87-39, § 7, 10-5-87) 
Sec. 9-146. - Operation of vehicles on approach of authorized emergency vehicles. 
    Upon the approach of any authorized vehicle, giving audible and visual signal, the operator of every other vehicle shall immediately drive the same to a position as near as possible and parallel to the right-hand edge or curb of the street or roadway, clear of any intersection, and shall stop and remain in such position until the authorized emergency vehicle or vehicles shall have passed, unless otherwise directed by the fire official or a police officer. 
(Ord. No. 87-39, § 8, 10-5-87) 
Sec. 9-147. - Vehicles following fire apparatus. 
    It shall be unlawful for the operator of any vehicle, other than one on official business, to follow closer than 300 feet from any fire apparatus traveling in response to a fire alarm, or to drive any vehicle within the block or immediate area where fire apparatus has stopped in answer to a fire alarm. 
(Ord. No. 87-39, § 9, 10-5-87) 
Sec. 9-148. - Unlawful boarding or tampering with fire department emergency equipment. 
    A person shall not without proper authorization from the fire official in charge of said fire department emergency equipment, cling to, attach himself to, climb upon or into, board or swing upon any fire department emergency vehicle, whether the same is in motion or at rest, or sound the siren, horn, bell, or other sound-producing device thereon, or manipulate or tamper with, or attempt to manipulate or tamper with any levers, valves, switches, starting devices, brakes, pumps, or any equipment or protective clothing on, or a part of, any fire department emergency vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 87-39, § 10, 10-5-87) 
Sec. 9-149. - Damage, injury of fire department equipment, personnel. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to damage or deface, or attempt, or conspire to damage or deface any fire department emergency vehicle at any time, or to injure, or attempt to injure or conspire to injure fire department personnel while performing departmental duties. 
(Ord. No. 87-39, § 11, 10-5-87) 
Sec. 9-150. - Emergency vehicle operation. 
    The driver of any emergency vehicle, as defined in section 9-145, shall not sound the siren thereon or have the front red lights on or disobey any existing traffic regulation, except when said vehicle is responding to an emergency call or when responding to, but not upon returning from a fire. Tactical strategies such as, but not restricted to, "move-ups" do not constitute an emergency call. The driver of an emergency vehicle may: 
(1)  Park or stand irrespective of the provisions of existing traffic regulations. 
(2)  Proceed past a red or stop signal or other sign, but only after slowing down as may be necessary for safe operation. 
(3)  Exceed the prima facie speed limit so long as the action does not endanger life or property. 
(4)  Disregard regulations governing direction of movement or turning in specified directions. 
(5)  The exemptions herein granted to an emergency vehicle shall apply only when the driver of any such vehicle while in motion sounds audible signal by bell, siren, or exhaust whistle as may be reasonably necessary, and when the vehicle is equipped with at least one lighted lamp displaying a red light visible under normal atmospheric conditions from a distance of 500 feet to the front of such vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 87-39, § 12, 10-5-87) 
Sec. 9-151. - Blocking fire hydrants and fire department connections. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to obscure from view, damage, deface, obstruct or restrict the access to any fire hydrant or any fire department connection for the pressurization of fire suppression systems, including fire hydrants and fire department connections that are located on public or private streets and access lanes, or on private property. 
(b)  If upon the expiration of the time mentioned in a notice of violation, obstruction or encroachments are not removed, the fire official shall proceed to remove the same. Costs incurred in the performance of necessary work shall be paid from the municipal treasury on certificate of the fire official and with the approval of the chief administrative official; and the legal authority of the municipality shall institute appropriate action for the recovery of such costs. 
(Ord. No. 87-39, § 13, 10-5-87) 
Sec. 9-152. - Hydrant use approval. 
    A person shall not use or operate any fire hydrant intended for use of the fire department for fire suppression purposes unless such person first secures a permit for such use from the fire official and the water company having jurisdiction. This section shall not apply to the use of such hydrants by a person employed by, and authorized to make use by, the water company having jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 87-39, § 14, 10-5-87) 
Sec. 9-153. - Public water supply. 
    The fire official shall recommend to the chief administrative official of the municipality the location or relocation of new or existing fire hydrants and the placement or replacement of inadequate water mains located upon public property and deemed necessary to provide an adequate fire flow and distribution pattern. A fire hydrant shall not be placed into or removed from service until approved by the fire official. 
(Ord. No. 87-39, § 15, 10-5-87) 
Sec. 9-154. - Yard systems. 
    All new and existing shipyards, oil storage plants, lumberyards, amusement or exhibition parks, and educational or institutional complexes and similar occupancies and uses involving high fire or life hazards, and which are located more than 150 feet from a public street or which require quantities of water beyond the capabilities of the public water distribution system shall be provided with properly placed fire hydrants. Such fire hydrants shall be capable of supplying fire flows as required by the fire official and shall be connected to a water system in accordance with accepted engineering practices. The fire official may require the installation of sufficient fire hose and equipment housed in accordance with the approved rules and may require the establishment of a trained fire brigade when the hazard involved requires such measures. Private hydrants shall not be placed into or removed from service until approved by the fire official. 
(Ord. No. 87-39, § 16, 10-5-87) 
Sec. 9-155. - Maintenance of fire suppression equipment. 
    A person shall not obstruct, remove, tamper with or otherwise disturb any fire hydrant or fire appliance required to be installed or maintained under the provisions of the Fire Prevention Code except for the purpose of extinguishing fire, training or testing purposes, recharging, or making necessary repairs, or when permitted by the fire official. Whenever a fire appliance is removed as herein permitted, it shall be replaced or re-installed as soon as the purpose for which it was removed has been accomplished. Defective and non-approved fire appliances or equipment shall be replaced or repaired as directed by the fire official. 
(Ord. No. 87-39, § 17, 10-5-87) 
Sec. 9-156. - Sale of defective fire extinguisher. 
    A person shall not sell, trade, loan or give away any form, type or kind of fire extinguisher which is not approved by the fire official, or which is not in proper working order, or the contents of which do not meet the requirements of the fire official. The requirements of this section shall not apply to the sale, trade or exchange of obsolete or damaged equipment for junk when said units are permanently disfigured or marked with a permanent sign identifying the unit as junk. 
(Ord. No. 87-39, § 18, 10-5-87) 
Sec. 9-157. - Street obstruction. 
    A person or persons shall not erect, construct, place, or maintain any bumps, fences, gates, chains, bars, pipes, wood or metal horses or any other type of obstruction in or on any street, within the boundaries of the municipality. The word street, as used in this section shall mean any roadway accessible to the public for vehicular traffic, including, but not limited to, private streets or access lanes, as well as all public streets and highways within the boundaries of the municipality. 
(Ord. No. 87-39, § 19, 10-5-87) 
ARTICLE VII. - LOCK BOX EMERGENCY ACCESS SYSTEMS 

Sec. 9-158. - Established. 
    To aid the suppression of fire, a lock box emergency access system(s) ("LBEAS") is hereby established. 
(Ord. No. 91-31, § 1, 9-9-91) 
Sec. 9-159. - Requirements. 
    All premises equipped with an automatic fire alarm, or used for the storage of hazardous substances, or housing a business (or businesses) in which hazardous substances are stored, various multiple-family structures and all other premises determined by the fire chief, or his designated representative or agent, as requiring immediate nonforcible entry in the event of an emergency or apparent emergency shall have a lock box emergency access system. 
(Ord. No. 91-31, § 1, 9-9-91) 
Sec. 9-160. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, the following words and phrases shall have the following meanings: 
(1)  Lock box means a heavy gauge steel box fitted with a locking device requiring a key, which cannot be duplicated by a locksmith. 
(2)  Fire chief means the chief executive officer of the village's fire department. 
(Ord. No. 91-31, § 1, 9-9-91) 
Sec. 9-161. - Installation. 
    Each and every lock box system shall be installed on the front access wall of the building gate or main premises entrance at a height of not less than eight feet, nor more than 12 feet from the ground. 
(Ord. No. 91-31, § 1, 9-9-91) 
Sec. 9-162. - Authorization. 
    The location and intended utilization of any and all "LBEAS" must be approved by the village's fire chief, or his designated representative or agent, before installation or utilization thereof. The owner or occupant of the premises must provide the fire chief with a completed authorization, indemnification and waiver form, in substantially the form of that which is provided as an appendix to Ordinance No. 91-31. Said authorization must be counter-signed by village's fire chief. All forms must be properly executed and delivered to the village's fire chief prior to the issuance (by the fire chief) of the fire department's approval. 
(Ord. No. 91-31, § 1, 9-9-91) 
Editor's note- It should be noted that the form referenced in § 9-162 as an appendix to Ord. No. 91-31 is not set out at length in the Code, but is on file and available for inspection in the office of the city clerk. 
Sec. 9-163. - Contents of lock box. 
    Each lock box shall contain the following: 
(1)  Keys to locked points of ingress (whether on the interior or exterior of the premises); 
(2)  Keys to locked mechanical equipment rooms; 
(3)  Keys to locked electrical rooms; 
(4)  Keys to elevator controls; and 
(5)  Keys to other areas as determined by the fire chief. 
(Ord. No. 91-31, § 1, 9-9-91) 
Sec. 9-164. - Access to lock box. 
    It shall be the responsibility of the owner or occupant of the premises to keep the contents of the lock box and information contained therein up-to-date. 
(Ord. No. 91-31, § 1, 9-9-91) 
Sec. 9-165. - Administrative rules and regulations. 
    The fire chief of the village fire department is authorized to establish additional policies and procedures in order to implement the use of "LBEAS" (under this article) and provide and promote uniformity in the acquisition, installation and use of lock box systems. 
(Ord. No. 91-31, § 1, 9-9-91) 
Sec. 9-166. - Exemptions from lock box requirements. 
    Premises satisfying both of the following criteria shall be exempt from the requirements of lock box installation: 
(1)  Premises that remain open for business 24 hours per day, 365 days per year; and 
(2)  The premises have 24-hour security personnel or other authorized personnel available to assist the fire chief and fire department personnel. 
(Ord. No. 91-31, § 1, 9-9-91) 
Sec. 9-167. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2003-55, § 3, adopted Dec. 8, 2003, deleted § 9-167, which pertained to the penalty for violation of this article and was derived from Ord. No. 91-31, § 1, adopted Sept. 9, 1991. 
Secs. 9-168-9-190. - Reserved. 
ARTICLES VIII, IX. - RESERVED 

Secs. 9-191-9-1000. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - PENALTIES 

Sec. 9-1001. - Penalties, compromise violations. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to violate any provision of this chapter and anyone who shall violate any of the terms, provisions, rules and regulations of said fire prevention code shall be guilty of an offense and fined not less than $100.00 nor more than $750.00 and/or sentenced up to six months in the county jail. Except when fines and costs are paid by compromise payment as provided in (b) below prior to court, the court clerk shall add to the fine any and all costs and fees upon an authorized disposition. 
(b)  Any person accused of a violation of this Code may settle and compromise said claim without a court appearance by payment of one half of the minimum required fine to the village clerk at the village hall within ten business days of the date of violation if the compromise box designation is so checked on the complaint and notice to appear form. 
(Ord. No. 2003-55, § 4, 12-8-03; Ord. No. 2006-43, § 6, 12-11-06) 
Chapter 10 - GARBAGE AND TRASH[1] 
Footnotes:

II, §§ 10-11-10-18, 10-26-10-37, and former provisions, §§ 10-1, 10-16-10-20, pertaining to litter and municipal collection and disposal service, as derived from the 1965 Code, §§ 3.2.1, 5.2.2, 5.2.4, 5.2.6, 5.2.7; Ord. No. 805, §§ 1-4, adopted Sept. 24, 1979; and Ord. No. 84-11, § 1, adopted May 24, 1984, has been deleted.

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 10-1-10-10. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SOLID WASTE 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 10-11. - Short title. 
    This division shall be known as the "Crete Solid Waste Ordinance". 
(Ord. No. 86-8, § 1, 7-21-86) 
Sec. 10-12. - Applicability. 
    This division shall constitute a uniform law applicable in all geographical areas of the village. 
(Ord. No. 86-8, § 1, 7-21-86) 
Sec. 10-13. - Definitions. 
    As used in this division, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings set forth hereinafter: 
    Board shall mean the president and board of trustees of the village. 
    Dead animals shall mean dead animals not intended for use for food purposes. 
    Department of public works shall mean the supervisor of the village's department of public works and any of his authorized representatives. 
    Garbage shall mean waste products of animal or vegetable origin resulting from the growing, processing, marketing and preparation of food items including the containers in which they are packaged. 
    Hazardous waste shall mean materials which are: 
(1)  Toxic or poisonous; 
(2)  Corrosive; 
(3)  Irritating or sensitizing; 
(4)  Radioactive; 
(5)  Explosive; or 
(6)  Flammable and that present a significant hazard to human health or the environment. 
    Manure shall mean body waste of animals and fowl and cleanings from all barns, stables, corrals or pens used for stabling, caging or penning of animals or fowl. 
    Offal shall mean waste matter from butchering, slaughtering and packing operations. 
    Pathological waste shall mean: 
(1)  Equipment, instruments, utensils and fomites (any substance that may harbor or transmit pathogenic organisms) of a disposable nature from the rooms of patients who are suspected to have or have been diagnosed as having a communicable disease; 
(2)  Laboratory wastes, including pathological specimens (i.e., all tissues, specimens of blood elements, excreta and secretions obtained from patients) and disposable fomites attendant thereto; and 
(3)  Surgical operating room pathologic specimens and disposable fomites attendant thereto and similar disposable materials from outpatient areas, emergency rooms, private medical facilities and veterinary offices. 
    Person shall be construed to include any natural person, individual, public or private corporation, association, joint venture, partnership, municipality, governmental agency, political subdivision, public officer, or any other entity, whatsoever, or any combination of such, jointly or severally. 
    Police shall mean the chief of police of the village's department of police along with his deputy or auxiliary police. 
    Service, commercial shall mean the service provided through a commercial franchise to multifamily residences (except in those cases where the board has, by appropriate resolution, specifically approved such service as a residential service) using a bulk container of over one cubic yard, collected by mechanical means rather than manual means, and to business, commercial enterprises of all types licensed to do business in the village. 
    Service, residential shall mean service provided by a franchise to any single-family residence, or to any multifamily residence deemed to be suitable for residential service by board resolution, or to any trailer park where service is rendered individually to mobile home owners. 
    Trash shall mean waste material not of a putrescible nature; included are stumps and logs, car bodies, refrigerators, stoves, tires, building and road materials, tree trimmings, paper boxes and all such similar material. 
(Ord. No. 86-8, § 1, 7-21-86; Ord. No. 87-24, § 1, 6-15-87) 
Sec. 10-14. - Solid waste storage. 
    The following standard requirements are hereby established as a minimum for the sanitary accumulation and storage of solid waste pending collection and/or removal to an approved disposal facility: 
(1)  Garbage: 
a.  Garbage containers for other than bulk accumulation shall be of galvanized metal or plastic and shall be provided with tight-fitting lids, or other suitable approved container. 
b.  Individual garbage containers shall be a maximum 20-gallon capacity. All garbage cans over ten-gallon capacity shall be equipped with hand grips on opposite sides of the container. All cans of ten gallons or less capacity shall be equipped with a bail handle. Both handles and bails shall be adequate to support the weight of a full container without bending or breaking. 
c.  Containers shall be maintained in a clean and sanitary condition, free of cracks and holes, leak-proof and rodent-proof. 
d.  Areas where garbage containers are kept shall be maintained in a clean sanitary manner, free of spilled garbage, wastewater and odors. 
e.  Bulk garbage storage units such as dumpsters shall be maintained in a clean, nuisance free manner and shall be cleaned after each emptying or with such frequency as necessary to comply with the intent of this section. 
f.  All garbage shall be prewrapped in leak-proof plastic containers before being placed in any bulk storage container. 
(2)  Hazardous wastes: 
a.  Hazardous waste materials shall not be commingled with other solid waste. 
b.  Hazardous waste shall not be stored, collected, transported or disposed of in the county except as provided in current environmental protection agency regulations. 
c.  Hazardous wastes shall be properly identified and packaged according to the particular material involved. 
d.  No hazardous wastes shall be disposed of in the village. 
(3)  Pathologic wastes: 
a.  Pathologic wastes shall be packaged tightly and in a manner which will minimize the potential for accidental exposure. 
b.  All disposable needles shall have the tips removed or be otherwise broken and shall be properly wrapped prior to being stored for collection. 
(Ord. No. 86-8, § 1, 7-21-86) 
Sec. 10-15. - Disposal; exceptions. 
(a)  Garbage, offal, dead animals, or trash mixed with garbage, offal or dead animals, or any combination thereof shall be disposed of only at an approved sanitary landfill or other permitted disposal site. Such materials shall not be disposed of by being placed in any natural or artificial body of water. 
(b)  Open burning of garbage, offal, dead animals, trash and manure or trash mixed with garbage, offal, dead animals or manure is hereby prohibited as a violation of this division; provided, however, that, this subsection shall not be construed to prohibit burning of leaves, yard clippings and similar materials as provided under chapter 9 of this Code. 
(c)  It shall be prima facie evidence of a violation of this division if abandoned or dumped material disposed of in a manner other than outlined in this division can be established as having originated with a particular person and such person has allowed such material to be dumped, discarded, abandoned or disposed of in an area other than an approved disposal site, unless such person has contracted for the disposal of waste material with an approved garbage franchise. 
(d)  All garbage, offal, dead animals and trash shall be removed to an approved sanitary landfill or other permitted disposal site at sufficient frequency to prevent a sanitary nuisance. In no case shall garbage be removed less than once per week. Such removal shall be at the expense of the owner and/or occupant of the premises either by a franchised collection service or by the owner or occupant. 
(e)  All construction materials, including trash, packaging, discarded materials and debris shall be securely and properly contained on the construction site during the construction period so as not to create an unsightly condition and so as not to be scattered over other properties in the area. After completion of construction and not more than 15 days thereafter, all remaining or discarded materials, trash or debris shall be completely cleared from the construction site. 
(Ord. No. 86-8, § 1, 7-21-86) 
Sec. 10-16. - Enforcement. 
    The provisions of this division shall be enforced as set forth in sections 10-18 and 10-39 of this division. 
(Ord. No. 86-8, § 1, 7-21-86; Ord. No. 98-07, § 3, 4-27-98) 
Sec. 10-17. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Former § 10-17, Penalties, derived from Ord. No. 86-8, § 1, adopted July 21, 1986, was repealed by Ord. No. 98-07, § 4, adopted Apr. 27, 1998. See § 10-39. 
Sec. 10-18. - Remedies. 
    In addition to all other remedies available, the board shall have the power and authority to apply for an injunction to enjoin any violation of this division. In the event a court of proper jurisdiction enjoins any violation of this division, the person so enjoined shall be required to pay all costs and attorney's fees, together with reasonable expenses as necessarily incurred and associated with and required as a result of obtaining such an injunction. 
(Ord. No. 86-8, § 1, 7-21-86) 
Secs. 10-19-10-25. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - FRANCHISE REGULATIONS FOR COLLECTORS 

Sec. 10-26. - Short title. 
    This division shall be referred to as the "Solid Waste Collection Ordinance of the Village of Crete". 
(Ord. No. 86-8, § 1, 7-21-86) 
Sec. 10-27. - Intent and purpose. 
    This division is promulgated for the purpose of assuring that the storage, burning, collection, recycling, disposal and transportation of refuse within the geographical boundaries of the village is accomplished in a manner beneficial to the health, safety and welfare of the citizens of the village. 
(Ord. No. 86-8, § 1, 7-21-86) 
Sec. 10-28. - Definitions. 
    As used in this division, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings set forth hereinafter: 
    Applicant: A firm or individual who desires to obtain a franchise to transport or collect refuse for hire in the village. 
    Board shall mean the president and board of trustees of the village. 
    Commercial franchise: A nonexclusive commercial franchise granted by the board to refuse collector to provide commercial service within the village at large on a free enterprise basis. 
    Commercial service: The service provided by a commercial franchise using bulk containers of over one cubic yard, collected by mechanical means rather than manual means to multifamily residences and to business, commercial enterprises of all types licensed to do business in the village, (except where the village has by resolution approved it as a residential service). 
    Curbside service: A type of residential service rendered by a franchisee, by agreement with a customer, whereby garbage and trash will be placed within ten feet of the curb or road edge within village rights-of-way, and within private property lines along state and federally maintained roads, as safely as possible. 
    Exclusive franchise: A formal authorization by the board to a refuse collector conferring to such refuse collector an exclusive right and obligation to provide residential service within a prescribed geographical area of the village. 
    Franchise agreement or ( agreement): A binding agreement between the board and a franchisee setting forth the terms, duration and other conditions of the franchise. 
    Garbage: All putrescible wastes and all animal or vegetable refuse or residue that shall result from the preparation or care for, or treatment of, foodstuffs, intended to be used as food, or shall have resulted from the preparation or handling of food for human consumption, or any decayed or unsound meat, fish or vegetable matter. 
    Hazardous waste: The waste or a combination of waste and other discarded material including solid, liquid, semi-solid, or contained gaseous material which, because of its quantity, concentration, or physical, chemical, or infectious characteristics, may cause or significantly contribute to an increase in mortality or an increase in serious irreversible or incapacitating, or reversible illness, or may pose a substantial present or potential hazard to human health or the environment when improperly treated, stored, transported, disposed of, or otherwise managed. 
    Nonexclusive franchise: A nonexclusive franchise granted by the board to a refuse collector to provide service within the village at large on a free enterprise basis. 
    Premises: Any structure or parcel of land where refuse is created or accumulated, or any parcel on which a structure is located or under construction. 
    Rear door service: A type of residential service rendered by a franchisee, by agreement with a resident, whereby garbage will be picked up from containers placed on side or rear yards, at or near ground level, outside fences, hedges, garages, carports or other such enclosures, or in general, located so as to be easily accessible to the collector, and trash will be picked up as near to the curb or road surface as is safely possible in accordance with the applicable provisions of this division. 
    Refuse: The definition of refuse is presented for the purpose of clarification rather than regulation, and is inclusive and shall include, but not be restricted to, all putrescible and nonputrescible wastes consisting of both combustible and noncombustible wastes such as paper, cardboard, garbage, grass clippings, tree or shrub trimmings, wood, bedding, crockery, rubber tires, construction waste and similar waste materials (except sewage and sludges generated by sources or methods of treatment other than those sludges which have been treated via domestic wastewater treatment facilities, and industrial wastes of a toxic or contaminatory nature); it shall be construed to include trash and garbage as said terms are defined herein. 
    Residential franchise: An exclusive franchise granted by the board to a refuse collector to provide residential service within a set and specified area of the village. 
    Residential service: The service provided by a franchisee to any single-family residence, or to any multifamily residence or commercial use deemed to be suitable for residential service by a village board resolution or to any trailer park where service is rendered on an individual, separate basis. 
    Roll-offs: A type of service referring to the use of refuse containers having space and volume sufficient to contain refuse in excess of 15 cubic yards, whether used for the removal of commercial or residential refuse and/or garbage or in connection with the construction, rehabilitation, revitalization, demolition or cleaning of any new or existing residential, commercial or municipal structure. 
    Specialized container: Any portable, non-absorbent, enclosed container with a close-fitting cover and doors satisfactory to the health department which is used to store refuse in volumes greater than those allowed by a standard container. 
    Standard container: Any commercially made container designed for residential use, made of nonabsorbent material, and provided with a close-fitting cover designed or modified to be unopenable by animals, and provided with side handles. The use of plastic bags by themselves are not considered as being a standard container. Plastic bags must be placed within a standard container. 
    Trash: All refuse not otherwise included in the definition of garbage, including tin cans and glass containers used in the preparation of foodstuffs, grass clippings, fruit other than processed for consumption within the home, and wastes of all kinds incurred from normal maintenance of grounds. 
    Truck: Any truck, trailer, semi-trailer, conveyance or other vehicle used to collect refuse or to haul or transport refuse upon or along a public highway. 
(Ord. No. 86-8, § 1, 7-21-86; Ord. No. 87-17, § 1, 5-4-87; Ord. No. 88-18, § 1, 8-8-88; Ord. No. 93-9, § 1, 3-22-93; Ord. No. 2008-14, § 2, 2-25-08) 
Sec. 10-29. - General regulations. 
(a)  Accumulation and burning of refuse or garbage prohibited. For reasons of health and sanitation, it shall be unlawful for any person to accumulate upon private property in the village any refuse or garbage except in accordance with the provisions of this division and division 1 of this article, or to burn any refuse on such property. 
(b)  Transportation of garbage, trash and other refuse. All garbage, trash and other refuse hauled by any person over any road in the village shall be securely tied and covered during the hauling thereof so as to prevent leakage, spillage or blowing. No person shall allow garbage, trash or other refuse of any kind whatsoever to spill, blow or drop from any vehicle on any road in the village. 
(c)  Franchise required to collect refuse. It shall be unlawful for any person to collect, haul or transport refuse for hire within the village without first being granted by the village a franchise or a commercial franchise. The provisions of this section shall not apply to persons hauling household refuse from their own residences, or to farming or agricultural operations, or to municipalities or public agencies, or industrial, commercial and business establishments, or to building contractors or any persons hauling their own refuse generated by themselves, or the one-time, period or occasional use of roll-offs, irrespective of whether said roll-off is used commercially, residentially or in connection with the construction, rehabilitation, revitalization, demolition or cleaning of any new or existing residential, commercial or municipal structure. It is the intent of this subsection to prohibit any person from hauling or disposing of refuse for hire without being franchised as a refuse collector. 
(d)  Business license and permit fee in relation to the use of roll-offs. It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to place, collect, haul or transport garbage and/or refuse for consideration within the village by means of a roll-off without first obtaining a business permit in relation thereto. In this connection, the village hereby authorizes the issuance of appropriate business licenses upon the application of the provisions set forth in chapter 12 of said Crete Municipal Code. 
(Ord. No. 86-8, § 1, 7-21-86; Ord. No. 87-17, §§ 2, 3, 5-4-87) 
Sec. 10-30. - Franchise conditions. 
(a)  Commercial. Commercial franchises may be exclusive or nonexclusive in the discretion of the board; moreover, all such franchises shall be village-wide franchises. Service rates shall be as agreed upon between the franchisee and the customer. Commercial franchises shall be regulated by this division and other applicable village ordinances, by the provisions of the franchise agreement or agreements, the laws of the State of Illinois, and such other rules and regulations as may be set by the board. 
(b)  Residential. Residential franchises shall be exclusive for a prescribed geographical area of the village as set by the board. The board shall have the authority to make minor changes in boundaries in conjunction with affected collectors so as to allow for development changes and more efficient routes. Service rates shall be set or approved by the board or each respective franchise. Residential franchises shall be regulated by this division and other applicable village ordinances, by the provisions of the franchise agreement, the laws of the State of Illinois, and such other rules and regulations as may be set by the board. 
(c)  Issuance to authorized refuse collectors on effective date of this division. Upon adoption of this division, all existing franchises shall be deemed legitimate until the expiration of such franchise. 
(d)  Application. Any person desiring to obtain a franchise to provide residential or commercial garbage collection services or to provide any form of garbage disposal pursuant to this division must submit to the village an application therefor in writing. Such application shall be submitted on a form approved by the board, including, but not limited to, the following data: 
(1)  Name and address of applicant. If the application is for a corporation or other legally constituted organization, include names and mailing addresses of all officers, directors and stockholders. 
(2)  A list of all vehicles owned or leased by such firm including vehicle identification number, manufacturer of vehicle, manufacturer of body, type of body, maximum capacity of body, and model of chassis to be used in the operation of the franchise. 
(3)  Location of disposal area proposed to be used by the applicant, and written evidence of the approval of the owner of such disposal facility of the applicant's intent if a county landfill is not used. 
(4)  Number of accounts (classified as residential or commercial) applicant expects to serve. 
(5)  A complete rate schedule which the applicant intends to charge for his services. 
(6)  An application fee, a renewal fee, a franchise transfer fee, and periodic franchise fees shall be set forth by the board, and shall be paid to the office of the village clerk for the residential and commercial franchisees to adequately cover the village's administrative costs for implementing and administering this division. 
(e)  Renewal. A franchise holder shall have the right to apply for a renewal of any such franchise within 90 days prior to the expiration of such franchise; provided that, the franchise holder, in the opinion of the board, has satisfactorily performed the services herein required, and further, that the board considers with renewal to be beneficial to the health and general welfare of the residents of the village. The board shall provide a standard procedure for processing initial and renewal franchise applications, which shall include a review of financial data, operational experiences and the like. No franchisee or licensee shall use a firm name containing the words Village of Crete or Crete, or other words implying village ownership. 
(f)  Duration. Franchisees granted exclusive rights to provide residential service within prescribed geographical limits and commercial franchises will be issued for a period of time determined by the board, not to exceed five years, and renewal may be made upon application by the franchisee and approved by the board in accordance with subsection (e) of this section. 
(g)  Performance bonds. Each franchise agreement shall provide for the franchisee to supply a performance bond, acceptable letter of credit, or a cash deposit (in the event of a cash deposit, such deposit shall be allowed interest). The bond shall be in an amount equal to one full billing cycle of the franchisee, covering accounts that are paid in advance. Billing cycle for those purposes shall be defined as that period which represents 90 days' service. 
(h)  Insurance. Insurance requirements are as follows: 
(1)  The collector shall furnish to the village evidence of insurance coverage for all insurance required under the provisions of this section of this division immediately upon the execution of a permit by the parties. Failure of the collector to maintain such insurance at any time during the term of the permit shall be construed to be a material breach of this division by the collector. 
(2)  The collector shall provide and maintain during the term of the permit such workers' compensation insurance as required by law for all of its employees employed in connection with the performance of the work provided for under his permit. In the case of any work which is sublet, the collector shall require the subcontractor to provide such workers' compensation insurance as required by law for all such subcontractor's employees unless such employees are covered by the policy maintained by the collector. All subcontractors shall have the approval of the board prior to performing any work under the permit. 
(3)  The collector agrees to indemnify and hold harmless the village from any and all liability, claims, damages, losses, expenses, proceedings and causes of action of every kind and nature arising out of or connected with the performance of his duties provided for under this division. The collector further agrees to, at his own expense, defend any and all actions, suits or proceedings which may be brought against the village in connection with the performance of his duties under this division and to satisfy, pay and discharge any and all judgements that may be entered against the village in any such action or proceedings. 
(4)  The collector agrees to provide and maintain at all times during the term of his permit, without cost or expense to the village, policies of insurance generally known as "public liability and automobile policies," insuring the collector against any and all claims, demands or causes of action whatsoever for injuries received or damage to property relating to the performance of the duties of the collector under the terms and provisions of this division. Such policies of insurance shall insure the collector in an amount not less than $500,000.00 to cover any and all claims connected with any accident or occurrence that may arise or be claimed to have arisen against the collector. The collector shall also obtain property damage insurance insuring the collector in an amount not less than $500,000.00 to cover the claims of any person or persons from a single or specific act that results in alleged damage to property. Such insurance policies shall provide that the village shall be entitled to 30 days' written notice of any changes in or cancellations of such policies. A certificate of insurance indicating that the collector has coverage in accordance with the requirements of this division shall be furnished by the collector to the director at the time of application, renewal or transfer. The amount shall be set by the village and included in the agreement. 
(i)  Franchisee to defend village. The franchisee shall appear and defend all actions against the village arising out of the exercise of such franchise or license and shall indemnify and save the village, its officers, employees and agents harmless and free of all claims, demands, action or causes of action of every kind and description arising out of, and in any way connected with the exercise of such franchise. As a condition of the board issuing a franchise, the applicant agrees to the terms of this division and any regulations enacted pursuant thereto. 
(Ord. No. 86-8, § 1, 7-21-86; Ord. No. 2008-14, § 2, 2-25-08) 
Sec. 10-31. - Suspension or relinquishment of franchise. 
(a)  General. The board is empowered to deny, suspend or revoke any refuse collection franchise granted hereunder when such franchisee fails to comply with this division or other rules and regulations related thereto. Such action of revocation or suspension by the board may be taken only after 14 days' notice in writing to the franchisee of the violation charged and the failure of the franchisee to remedy the violation within such time. 
(b)  Transfer. The franchisee shall not sell, assign or transfer the franchise, nor any of the rights and privileges granted thereby, without the prior written approval of the board. Any change in management of a franchise must be approved in writing by the board. Disregard of any of the preceding is sufficient for board revocation of the franchise. The franchisee shall file a statement of ownership when renewing a franchise and at such other times as required as being true and correct under the penalty of perjury. 
(c)  Insolvency/bankruptcy. If the franchisee should at any time during the term of his permit become insolvent, or if proceedings in bankruptcy shall be instituted by or against the franchisee, or if the franchisee shall be adjudged bankrupt or insolvent by any court, or if a receiver or trustee in bankruptcy or a receiver of any property of the franchisee shall be appointed in any suit or proceedings brought by or against the franchisee, or if the franchisee shall make an assignment for the benefit of creditors, then and in each and every case, the franchise and the rights and privileges granted thereby shall immediately cease, desist and be forfeited and canceled without notice, suit or other proceedings. 
(d)  Relinquishment. The franchisee may of his own volition relinquish his franchise provided that the board is granted sufficient time, but not less than 60 days, to assure that adequate refuse collection will continue. Upon termination, suspension, revocation or relinquishment of a franchise, the department may direct another franchisee to provide temporary service to the area affected, or may otherwise provide refuse disposal service to such area. 
(e)  Records required. Upon the termination, suspension or revocation of a franchise, the franchisee shall submit to the village upon demand adequate records for the purpose of resuming or continuing service to the franchisee's customers. 
(Ord. No. 86-8, § 1, 7-21-86) 
Sec. 10-32. - Village responsibilities. 
(a)  Administration. The village shall administer and enforce the provisions of this division, and all other village ordinances, resolutions, rules and regulations that address or regard refuse collection. 
(b)  Franchise area map. There shall be maintained in the records of the board a franchise area map depicting the boundaries of all franchise areas authorized by the board. The boundaries therein depicted may be amended by the board from time to time by resolution, and as may be deemed by the board to best serve and promote the health and general welfare of the citizens of the village. Before amending any franchise boundary, the board shall notify the holder of such affected franchise. Such notice shall be made by certified mail, return receipt requested, and shall be mailed not less than 30 days prior to the adoption of such change. 
(c)  Dispute of boundaries. The director shall set a definite procedure for the review and evaluation of boundary conflicts. 
(d)  Franchise agreement. The board shall enter into a franchise agreement with each duly granted franchisee. 
(e)  Rules and regulations. The board shall establish from time to time by resolution such rules and regulations as are deemed necessary for protection of the health, safety and welfare of the village. 
(f)  Standardized accounting. The board may establish a standardized accounting method for residential service operations. Such method, if once established, shall set forth each item of equipment, depreciation schedules, allowable and unallowable costs, and the like, and shall then serve as the principal accounting tool in the evaluation of respective franchise rates. 
(g)  Rate reviews. The board may, in its discretion, impose a rate review of any franchisee at such time as it is deemed appropriate. 
(Ord. No. 86-8, § 1, 7-21-86) 
Sec. 10-33. - Residential service rates. 
(a)  Generally. Residential service rates shall be set by the board and shall be set forth in the franchise agreement or amendments thereto and shall also be as set forth in article V of chapter 2 immediately to the right of the reference to section 10-33. Rates may be uniform for the life of the franchise, or may vary under prescribed conditions, or may be reviewed for adjustment as called for in the agreement. Insofar as is practical and possible the aforesaid rates or fees shall be billed on Village of Crete Water and Sewer Department bill heads. The village collector shall employ other billing procedures where necessary at such collector's discretion. 
(b)  Basis of collection rates. Collection rates shall be based on respective geographical areas and haul distances, actual operational costs, known future costs, the recommendations called forth under subsection 10-32(g) of this division and such other factors and/or formulas as may be prescribed or deemed appropriate by the board. 
(c)  Reviews. Times or frequencies of reviews of collections rates shall be set forth in the franchise agreement. 
(d)  Rate change requests. Should events beyond the control of a franchisee occur (prior to a set or prescribed rate review time) that significantly result in a substantial change in operational costs, a franchisee may formally request a rate adjustment. Such request shall be made to the village in the prescribed manner and accompanied with all necessary records, calculations, and a full description of and justification for the rate change request. In the event the board decides such a request warrants formal consideration, a public hearing shall be held prior to any rate change. Each franchisee should have an annual audit prepared by a certified public accountant in accordance with the forms set forth by the village. The cost of the audit shall be borne by the respective franchises, and included in the rate structure. Such records shall constitute the primary base on which rates would be based. Records form and format may be established by an expert accountant paid by the village. Record systems may need to vary somewhat to take into account substantial size differences in franchise operations. In the event a model or analytical tool is developed and adopted for use in rate reviews, prescribed forms and a computer program may be developed for automated processing. Established rates shall reflect real operation costs and rates may be unique to respective franchise areas. 
(Ord. No. 86-8, § 1, 7-21-86; Ord. No. 86-13A, § 1, 1-5-87; Ord. No. 89-4, § 1, 1-13-89) 
Sec. 10-34. - Franchisee responsibilities. 
(a)  General. Each franchisee shall establish a written contract with the village. The conditions of the contract may include, but are not limited to the following: 
(1)  Base rate. The base rate shall consist of the monthly charges. 
(2)  Items to be collected. The items to be collected for the base rate shall be stated. This shall include any volume, weight, or item restrictions established and approved by the village. 
(3)  Excess charges. If there are extra charges for items over the established limit, special pickups, bulky items, etc., they shall be explained. 
(4)  Frequency of collection. The collection days shall be stated. 
(5)  Holidays. The procedure for holiday collections shall be explained. 
(6)  Billing procedure. The billing method shall be explained. 
(b)  Franchise business practices. Each franchisee shall establish and have approved the following practices: 
(1)  Office location and hours. The office and operating hours of the business office shall be such that it is accessible to the public. 
(2)  Truck parking. The overnight parking of the rolling stock of the company will be at a location that is zoned for such use. 
(3)  Billing procedure. The method and frequency of billing shall be approved by the board. 
(4)  Holidays. The franchisee may, at his discretion, operate during legal holidays. If collections are not made on legal holidays, a procedure shall be established and approved by the village for the holiday schedule. If collection days are to be changed due to holidays, announcements explaining the holiday schedule shall be sent to the customer with the preceding bill or at the time a customer is given first service. 
(5)  Service refused and reinstatement of service. At the discretion of the village or franchisee, service may be refused if the owner or operator of a premises violates this division (i.e., is delinquent on the account, allows others to share the service, has overweight or oversized containers, etc.). Once the violation has been corrected, collection service can be reinstated on the next scheduled collection day. 
(c)  Complaints. Each franchisee shall be responsible for handling complaints. Each complaint shall be responded to within five working days. Any complaint not resolved or deemed unresolvable shall be directed to the board for settlement. In this connection, the board's settlement authority shall be limited to the issuance of advisory opinions. A file of all complaints shall be maintained by the board. 
(d)  Standard reporting forms. Each franchisee shall maintain records on standard reporting forms approved by the board. These forms may include such items as financial statements, depreciation schedules, asset records, cash flow analyses, etc. An annual report in a format prescribed by the board shall be submitted to the collage within 60 days of the closing date of the franchisee's business year. 
(e)  Spills. It shall be the responsibility of the franchisee to clean up any spills that may occur from his vehicle or equipment. 
(f)  Equipment. Each truck must be equipped with a minimum five-pound extinguisher, ten-man first aid kit, Class C broom and shovel. Equipment operated by franchisees must comply with the provisions of this section. 
(1)  Type of trucks. The bodies of trucks used in the collection or transportation of refuse shall have beds of metal or other impervious material which can be cleaned and said beds must be reasonably watertight and leakproof. Such beds shall be cleaned and disinfected on a regular basis. The franchisee must provide adequate means to prevent refuse from escaping from such truck while collecting or transporting refuse. 
(2)  Condition of trucks. All trucks of the collector will be maintained in a clean and sanitary condition satisfactory to the department. Trucks shall be inspected for sanitary cleanliness at least once annually or more often by the department of public works and trustee of public health to assure compliance with this division. 
Each vehicle of the franchisee shall at all times have in the cab a facsimile of the registration of the truck and certificate of insurance and an identification card with the name of whom to phone in case of an accident. Each vehicle of any franchisee that services specialized containers shall be equipped to clean and sanitize the container after collection. 
(g)  Special pick-up collections. In addition to the regularly scheduled collection of refuse, the franchisee shall provide a special pick-up service, available to all customers receiving residential service, for the removal of excess refuse which normally accumulates in a household and could not otherwise be placed in a standard container, such as discarded furniture or appliances. 
(Ord. No. 86-8, § 1, 7-21-86; Ord. No. 2008-14, § 2, 2-25-08) 
Sec. 10-35. - Customer responsibilities. 
(a)  General. Each customer shall prepare his refuse for disposal in such a manner as to safeguard the human the health and safety of the collection crew. 
(b)  Refuse containers. Residential refuse containers shall meet the requirements as defined for standardized containers. Commercial refuse containers shall meet or exceed the requirements set forth under the definitions under standardized container or specialized container, as applicable. Any overweight, oversize, broken, rusted or otherwise unsafe container may be refused service. Such containers shall be replaced by the customer. 
(c)  Dangerous or hazardous items. Dangerous or hazardous items such as broken glass, or other materials that could possibly cause injury to the collector shall be clearly identified on the container. Acid or caustic chemicals shall be clearly identified on the refuse container, and will not be accepted at the county landfill. 
(d)  Loose refuse. No refuse shall be placed for collection that is not otherwise containerized or bundled. No refuse shall be allowed to blow away from the point of collection. Grass or leaves must be contained in appropriate recyclable paper bags or containers and appropriate fees paid for their collection. Branches and small limbs of trees of reasonable amounts will be collected by the department of public works during specified times, provided said items are properly placed at the edge of the street. Branches shall be placed all in the same direction with cut ends on the same side. Larger elements of a tree or other items not in reasonable amounts that cannot be containerized will not be considered as refuse and therefore must be collected and disposed of by a properly licensed business engaged in landscape services or tree services and the cost of such service shall be borne by the resident. The village's removal of branches and limbs, noted above, is limited only to the ordinary landscape trimmings from existing residential homes. Disposal of trees or brush that are a product of clearing a vacant lot in anticipation of building is not the responsibility of the village. "Reasonable amount" is defined as tree branches less than two inches in diameter and total bulk material less than ten cubic feet. 
(e)  House number. Each customer shall display on his residence or at the point of collection his U.S. Postal Service house number. This number shall be in plain view from the street. 
(f)  Pets. Each customer shall ensure that their pets do not bite, attack or otherwise threaten the collection crew. 
(g)  Payments. Each customer shall maintain his account in good standing. Neither the village, nor any of its officers or employees shall be liable for, or in any way responsible for, the payment of any service rates or charges due. 
(h)  Moving. Each customer shall notify the village in advance of stopping service for moving; in the case of a property sale, the customer shall provide the name and contact information of the new owner, if known or the name and contact information of the realtors involved, if any. 
(i)  Refunds. No refund will be given for a period of less than 30 days. 
(Ord. No. 86-8, § 1, 7-21-86; Ord. No. 93-4, § 2, 3-22-93; Ord. No. 2008-14, § 2, 2-25-08) 
Sec. 10-36. - Violations and proceedings to restrain violations. 
    It is hereby declared to be unlawful and an offense to violate the provisions of this division. Any person who violates any section of this division shall be prosecuted and punished in accordance with general provisions of this Code. The board may bring suit to restrain, enjoin or otherwise prevent the violation of this division. 
(Ord. No. 86-8, § 1, 7-21-86) 
Sec. 10-37. - Title to waste. 
    Title to all waste collected shall be vested with the franchisee until such time as such waste is unloaded at a bulk storage or disposal facility, at which time title shall be deemed to be transferred to the owner of such facility. 
(Ord. No. 86-8, § 1, 7-21-86) 
Sec. 10-38. - Unauthorized placement of garbage, waste or trash; nonresident, hours. 
(a)  No person shall place any garbage, waste or trash at any collection point or in a collection container unless said garbage, waste or trash is from the premises served by the container or from the premises at which the collection point is located. "Collection container" includes, but is not limited to, dumpster, can, toter, bags or recycle bin. "Collection point" includes, but is not limited to, areas abutting passable alleys adjacent to property where the person disposing of waste resides or operates a business, or where no alley abuts such property, that area abutting the street immediately in front of such property. 
(b)  For "collection points" located at that area abutting the street immediately in front of the premises served, no garbage, waste or trash collection container may be placed for collection prior to 6:00 p.m. of the evening prior to the designated pickup day. Empty collection containers remaining after waste pickup shall be removed from collection points abutting the street immediately in front of the premises served at or before 11:59 p.m. of the designated pickup day. 
(c)  Every residence or business must show evidence of proper waste disposal for the waste stream generated by said residence or business. 
(d)  Every residential structure which contains two dwelling units or less must show evidence of disposal collection via the Village of Crete residential franchise refuse collector for each individual dwelling unit. 
    For the purposes of this section, a "dwelling unit" is defined as one or more rooms designed for occupancy having its own cooking and sanitary facilities, or any portion of a structure which is leased or rented. 
(e)  Businesses not showing evidence of proper waste disposal shall not be issued an annual business license. 
(f)  No person shall place garbage, waste or trash which has been transported from another location into a municipal collection container on public property. 
(Ord. No. 98-07, § 2, 4-27-98) 
Sec. 10-39. - Penalties. 
    Whoever violates or fails to comply with this chapter shall be subject to a fine of not less than $100.00, nor more than $750.00. Violations of this chapter may be cited on a short form ordinance complaint and may be prepaid by paying 50 percent of the minimum fine to the village clerk on or before ten days after issuance of the complaint. 
(Ord. No. 98-07, § 2, 4-27-98; Ord. No. 2006-43, § 7, 12-11-06) 
Chapter 11 - HEALTH AND SANITATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Alcoholic liquor, ch. 4; sanitation in alcoholic liquor establishments, § 4-46 et seq.; rabies control, § 5-7 et seq.; vaccination of dogs against rabies, § 5-32; plumbing code, § 6-126 et seq.; swimming pools, § 6-216 et seq.; garbage and trash, ch. 10; food dealers, food handlers, etc., § 12-371 et seq.; water, sewers and sewage disposal, ch. 27. 
State Law reference- General health power of municipality, 65 ILCS 5/11-20-5. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 11-1. - Spitting. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to spit or expectorate on any public sidewalk or other public place, or on the floor or walls of any store, theater, hall, public vehicle, or other place frequented by the public or to which the public is invited. 
(Code 1965, § 5.3.12) 
Sec. 11-2. - Dense smoke. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to cause or permit the emission of dense smoke from any fire, chimney, engine, oil burner or any other agency in the village so as to cause annoyance or discomfort to the residents thereof.
