The annual fee for such permit shall be in an amount as set forth in article V of chapter 2 immediately to the right of the reference to section 12-291. 
(b)  Subsection (a) shall not apply to devices, machines or mechanism for which another license or permit is required by another ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 656, § 1(2.2.1.4(a)), 5-24-70; Ord. No. 820, § 1, 4-28-80; Ord. No. 86-13A, § 1, 1-5-87) 
Sec. 12-292. - Video gaming devices. 
    For video gaming terminals licensed and operated in accordance with the Video Gaming Act, an annual fee shall be paid in an amount as set forth in article V of chapter 2 immediately to the right of the reference to section 12-292. 
(Ord. No. 2014-16, § 2, 7-14-14) 
Secs. 12-293-12-310. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - DRUG PARAPHERNALIA DEALERS 

Sec. 12-311. - License. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to sell any items, effect, paraphernalia, accessory or thing which is designed or marketed for use with illegal cannabis or drugs, as defined by Illinois law, without obtaining a license therefor. Such licenses shall be in addition to any or all other licenses held by applicant. 
(b)  Application to sell any item, effect, paraphernalia, accessory of thing which is designed or marketed for use with illegal cannabis or drugs shall be accompanied by affidavits by applicant and each and every employee authorized to sell such items that such person has never been convicted of a drug-related offense. 
(c)  Any person required to obtain such a license shall pay an annual fee in the amount as set forth in article V of chapter 2 immediately to the right of the reference to section 12-311. 
(Ord. No. 848, § 1, (2.2.56.1, 2.2.56.2, 2.2.56.6), 5-10-82; Ord. No. 86-13A, § 1, 1-5-87) 
Sec. 12-312. - Sales to minors. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or give any item, effect, paraphernalia, accessory or thing which is designed or marketed for use with illegal cannabis or drugs in any form to any child under 18 years of age. 
(Ord. No. 848, § 1(2.2.56.3), 5-10-82) 
Sec. 12-313. - Records. 
    Every licensee under this article must keep a record of every item, effect, paraphernalia, accessory or thing which is designed or marketed for use with illegal cannabis or drugs which is sold and this record shall be open to the inspection of any police officer at any time during the hours of business. Such record shall contain the name and address of the purchaser, the name and quantity of the product, the date and time of the sale, and the licensee or agent of the licensee's signature, such records shall be retained for not less than two years. 
(Ord. No. 848, § 1(2.2.56.4), 5-10-82) 
Sec. 12-314. - Compliance with regulations. 
    A license under this article shall comply with all applicable regulations of the department of health services and police department. 
(Ord. No. 848, § 1(2.2.56.5), 5-10-82) 
Secs. 12-315-12-330. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - DRY CLEANERS 

Sec. 12-331. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Dry cleaning: The process of cleaning fabric by immersion and agitation, or by immersion only, in volatile solvents (including, but not by way of limitation, solvents of petroleum distillate type, the coal tar distillate type and the chlorinated hydrocarbon type) and processes incidental thereto (including, but without limitation, spotting, cleaning, wet cleaning and finishing). 
    Dry cleaning establishment: Any structure, store, building or other place where the service of dry cleaning, wet cleaning as a process incidental to dry cleaning, dyeing, spotting, and/or finishing any fabric is rendered for hire, or is sold, resold, or offered for sale or resale. 
    Fabric: Any article of wearing apparel, household furnishing, rugs, textiles, fur and leather. 
    Finishing: The process of pressing and/or reshaping any fabric, which is designed to restore as nearly as possible the shape, dimensions, and contour of said fabric. 
    Spotting: The process designed to remove spots or stains which remain in a fabric after it has been subjected to the other processes of dry cleaning. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.13.1) 
Sec. 12-332. - License. 
(a)  No person shall conduct, operate or maintain any dry cleaning establishment in the village without first securing a license therefor as is herein required. Applications for such licenses shall be made in writing to the village clerk and shall be referred to the chief of the fire department who shall investigate or cause to be investigated the premises intended to be used, and shall report the result of the investigation to the president and board of trustees before the issuance of a license. No such license shall be issued to any person, firm or corporation not complying with all the provisions of this article, with the provisions of the building code and all ordinances relating to flammable liquids. 
(b)  The annual license fee shall be an amount as set forth in article V of chapter 2 immediately to the right of the reference to section 12-332. 
(Code 1965, §§ 2.2.13.2, 2.2.13.3; Ord. No. 820, § 1, 4-28-80; Ord. No. 86-13A, § 1, 1-5-87) 
Sec. 12-333. - Inspections. 
    The chief of the fire department or other officials designated by the president and board of trustees shall have the right to enter any building or premises situated in the village and occupied by any dry cleaning establishment, in order to examine the same and to determine whether or not the building and premises, or any material, chemical or compound kept therein, or used thereon, or any article or fabric dry cleaned, dyed, spotted or finished, as received, used, kept, maintained or stored on the premises or building conforms to the ordinances and regulations of the village or constitutes a fire hazard within the village. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.13.6) 
Sec. 12-334. - Building and sanitation requirements. 
    No dry cleaning establishment shall be operated in a frame building. Such establishment shall be kept free from flammable wastes so far as possible, and it shall be unlawful to maintain or permit a stove or open flame of any kind in the premises. Smoking in such premises is hereby prohibited, and appropriate signs to that effect shall be posted in conspicuous places in the establishment. The premises must be kept in a clean and sanitary condition and must be kept free from rats, mice and vermin. No person afflicted with a contagious or venereal disease shall be employed in any dry cleaning establishment. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.13.4) 
Secs. 12-335-12-350. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - FLORISTS[11] 

Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to license, tax and regulate florists, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-1. 

Sec. 12-351. - Definition. 
    As used in this article the term "florist" shall mean any person engaged in the business of selling flowers, shrubs or ornamental plants at retail. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.14.1) 
Sec. 12-352. - License. 
    No person shall do business as a florist in the village without first having secured a license therefor. Application for a license to do business as a florist shall be made in writing to the village clerk and must state thereon the nature of the business and the proposed location. The license fee for doing business as a florist shall be in the amount as set forth in article V of chapter 2 immediately to the right of the reference to section 12-352. 
(Code 1965, §§ 2.2.14.1-2.2.14.3; Ord. No. 820, § 1, 4-28-80; Ord. No. 86-13A, § 1, 1-5-87) 
Sec. 12-353. - Sanitary regulations. 
    No owner or operator of a florist shop shall permit any dead or dying vegetation to remain in or upon the premises so as to cause noxious or disagreeable odors. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.14.4) 
Secs. 12-354-12-370. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XII. - FOOD DEALERS, FOOD HANDLERS, ETC.[12] 

Footnotes: 
--- (12) --- 
Cross reference- Health and sanitation, ch. 11. 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to license, tax and regulate places for eating, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-5. 

Sec. 12-371. - Food dealer's license. 
(a)  The term "food dealers" as used in this section shall be construed to mean and include every person engaged in conducting or operating any of the following businesses: 
(1)  Fruit and vegetable store or establishment for the retail sale of fresh fruits, berries and vegetables; 
(2)  Grocery store, or establishment for the sale at retail of butter, cheese, vegetables or other provisions; 
(3)  Ice cream parlor; 
(4)  Meat market, or establishment for the retail sale of fresh meat, poultry or fish; 
(5)  Retail beverage store, or establishment for the sale at retail of any malted, cereal, carbonated or vinous non-intoxicating beverages as defined by law; 
(6)  Confectionery, or establishment for the sale of candy. 
The term "food" as used in this section shall be construed to include beverages. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any food dealer to engage in or do business in the village without first having secured a license therefor. Applications for such licenses shall be made in compliance with the ordinances relating thereto, and shall state the kind of food intended to be sold or handled. All applications for a license to conduct a business connected with the storage, handling, sale or preparation of food or drink intended for human consumption shall be referred to the health officer, who shall make or cause to be made an investigation of the premises to be used, and report his finding thereon, recommending or advising against the issuance of the license. The annual fee for such a license shall be in the amount as set forth in article V of chapter 2 immediately to the right of the reference to section 12-371. Any person licensed to sell any of the foods or beverages for the sale of which a license is required by the terms of this section may conduct on the same premises and in connection with the licenses business any other business mentioned in this chapter without paying any additional fee therefor; provided that the fee paid for the licenses business is at least as great in amount as the fee required for the other business so conducted, but this section shall not be so construed as to relieve any such applicant from the regulator requirements for such business. Any food dealer's license may be revoked by the president and board of trustees for repeated violation of any ordinance relating to the conduct of the business, the condition of the premises, and the articles sold. 
(Code 1965, §§ 2.2.15.1, 2.2.15.4, 2.2.15.8, 2.2.15.9, Ord. No. 86-13A, § 1, 1-5-87) 
Sec. 12-372. - Food delivery vehicle license. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to use or permit the use of any vehicle, including wagons and motor vehicles and vehicles propelled by manpower, for the storage or carrying of any meat, poultry, fish, butter, cheese, lard, vegetables, bread or bakery goods, or any other provisions intended for human consumption, including beverages and milk, in the village for the purpose of delivery of any such foodstuffs to any place in the village for such purposes, unless a license for such vehicle is first secured. 
(b)  Applications for such licenses shall be made to the village clerk, and shall recite the names of the persons from whom such deliveries are made and the nature of the goods carried. The clerk shall issue such licenses and shall give the president of the village a list of all such licenses issued. The annual fee for such licenses shall be in an amount as set forth in article V of chapter 2 immediately to the right of the reference to section 12-372 and shall be issued for one year beginning on the first day of January of each year. Such fees shall be paid to the village clerk who shall turn them over to the village treasurer. No license fee shall be required for any vehicle used to deliver foodstuffs from any establishment which is licensed and inspected as a food dealing establishment in the village. 
(c)  Any license issued under the provisions of this section may be revoked by the village president for any violation of any law or ordinance relating to the conduct of the licensed business. 
(Code 1965, §§ 2.2.16.1-2.2.16.3, 2.2.16.6; Ord. No. 820, § 1, 4-28-80; Ord. No. 86-13A, § 1, 1-5-87) 
Sec. 12-373. - Ice dealer license. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of the retail sale of ice in the village without first having obtained a license therefor. Applications for such a license shall contain the number of vehicles or vending machines to be used for delivery of ice. Whenever the number of vehicles or vending machines licenses is increased, notice of this fact shall be given to the village clerk and the fee provided herein shall be paid. The annual fee for an ice dealer's license shall be in the amount as set forth in article V of chapter 2 immediately to the right of the reference to section 12-373. 
(Code 1965, §§ 2.2.23.1, 2.2.23.2, 2.2.23.4; Ord. No. 820, § 1, 4-28-80; Ord. No. 86-13A, § 1, 1-5-87) 
Sec. 12-374. - Restaurant. 
(a)  As used in this section, the term "restaurant" shall be construed to include any place where food or drink (other than alcoholic liquor) is prepared or served to the public for consumption on the premises, and the term "food" shall include beverages other than alcoholic liquor. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a restaurant in the village without having first obtained a license therefor. The annual fee for such licenses shall be in an amount as set forth in article V of chapter 2 immediately to the right of the reference to section 12-374. Applications for such licenses shall be made in writing to the village clerk on a form to be furnished by him, and shall comply with the provisions of all ordinances relating to licenses. All applications for a license to conduct a restaurant shall be referred to the health officer and the county health department, who shall make or cause to be made an investigation of the premises to be used, and report their finding thereon, recommending or advising against the issuance of the license. 
(c)  Any restaurant license may be revoked by the president and board of trustees for repeated violation of any ordinance relating to the conduct of the business, the condition of the premises or the articles sold. 
(Code 1965, §§ 2.2.41.1-2.2.41.3, 2.2.41.5; Ord. No. 86-13A, § 1, 1-5-87) 
Sec. 12-375. - Milk dealer's license. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the sale or distribution of milk or cream in the village without having first obtained a license therefor. Applications for such licenses shall comply with all ordinances governing such applications, and shall state, in addition to the other information required, the source of the supply of the milk to be sold, and the ownership of the cattle from which the milk is produced. The annual fee for such a license shall be in an amount as set forth in article V of chapter 2 immediately to the right of the reference to section 12-375. 
(Code 1965, §§ 2.2.30.1-2.2.30.3; Ord. No. 820, § 1, 4-28-80; Ord. No. 86-13A, § 1, 1-5-87) 
Sec. 12-376. - Food refrigeration locker plant license. 
(a)  As used in this section the term "food refrigeration locker plant" shall mean and include any establishment wherein compartments are rented, leased or made available to other than the owner of the establishment for the refrigeration of food. The term "food" shall mean and include any edible or beverage used or intended to human consumption. 
(b)  No person shall operate a food refrigeration locker plant without having first secured a license therefor. Application for such license shall conform to the provisions of all ordinances relative thereto. In addition to all other information contained in such application, it shall state the number of units maintained on the premises, and the size of each unit; each application shall also state whether a unit is maintained in which food will be stored belonging to several individuals in addition to the separate units rented to other than the owner of the premises. The annual fee for such a license shall be as set forth in article V of chapter 2 immediately to the right of the reference to section 12-376. No license shall be issued for any food refrigeration locker plant which does not comply with the laws of the state pertaining thereto. 
(Code 1965, §§ 2.2.17.1-2.2.17.3, 2.2.17.9; Ord. No. 820, § 1, 4-28-80; Ord. No. 86-13A, § 1, 1-5-87) 
State Law reference- Cold storage plants, 225 ILCS 650/1 et seq. 
Secs. 12-377-12-390. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIII. - GARAGE SALES 

Sec. 12-391. - Intent. 
    It is the intent of this article to prohibit the infringement of any business in any established residential areas and in doing so to regulate the term and frequency of personal property sales, such as garage sales, porch sales, basement sales, yard sales, and other similar types of sales so as not to disrupt the residential environment of the area. It is not the intent of this article to seek the control of sales of individuals selling a few of their household or personal items. 
(Ord. No. 765, § 1(2.2.55), 7-11-77) 
Sec. 12-392. - Permit. 
(a)  Any person desiring to hold a personal property sale, shall first obtain a permit by applying to the village clerk prior to the sale. The sale shall be personal property of the permittee only. A permittee shall not offer for sale personal property previously acquired with the intent of re-sale. 
(b)  The fee to be paid for the permit shall be in the amount as set forth in article V of chapter 2 immediately to the right of the reference to section 12-392. The permit must be posted in a conspicuous location on the premises of the permittee which shall be clearly visible from the street. 
(c)  A person shall be permitted to have up to four sales pursuant to this article XIII during each consecutive 12-month period. No permit shall be assignable. 
(d)  The permit shall be letter size (81/2 × 11 inches) of suitable weighted stock and of a bright color. The permit shall contain the name and address of the permittee, the dates of the sale, the date issued, and shall be signed by the village clerk. 
(Ord. No. 765, § 1(2.2.55.1-2.2.55.4), 7-11-77; Ord. No. 86-13A, § 1, 1-5-87; Ord. No. 2013-01, § 2, 1-14-13) 
Sec. 12-393. - Hours of sale, duration of sales, etc. 
    A sale for which a permit is required by this article shall be conducted only between 8:00 a.m. and 8:00 p.m. The sale may be for two consecutive days. If the weather should be rainy and/or inclement to the extent that such personal property sale will be impractical, the permittee shall notify the village clerk, who shall assign alternative dates without an additional permit fee. 
(Ord. No. 765, § 1(2.2.55.2), 7-11-77; Ord. No. 2013-01, § 2, 1-14-13) 
Sec. 12-394. - Signs. 
    A person issued a permit pursuant to this article may exhibit up to four signs advertising the sale and providing directions to the general public as to how to reach the sale. Such signs may be posted on parkways, provided that all such signs must be freestanding and self-supporting. Such signs may not be posted more than 24 hours prior to the sale and must be removed within one hour following the conclusion of the sale. It shall be unlawful for any person holding a personal property sale to post any sign or signs on utility poles, trees and/or street signs within the village. 
(Ord. No. 765, § 1(2.2.55.5), 7-11-77; Ord. No. 88-17, § 1, 8-8-88; Ord. No. 2013-01, § 2, 1-14-13) 
Secs. 12-395-12-410. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIV. - HANDBILLS, ETC. 

Sec. 12-411. - Litter. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to place, throw or scatter any cards, circulars, handbills, samples of merchandise or any advertising matter on any public street or sidewalk or other public place in the village. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.18.1) 
Sec. 12-412. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2006-07, § 3, adopted March 13, 2006, deleted § 12-412, which pertained to a license for house to house distribution of handbills and was derived from Code 1965, § 2.2.18.3; Ord. No. 820, § 1, adopted April 28, 1980; and Ord. No. 86-13A, § 1, adopted Jan. 5, 1987. 
Secs. 12-413-12-430. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XV. - HARDWARE STORES 

Sec. 12-431. - License. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain and operate a hardware store without first having obtained a license as herein provided. Such license shall be in an amount as set forth in article V of chapter 2 immediately to the right of the reference to section 12-431. No license shall be issued except upon payment of this fee. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.19.1; Ord. No. 820, § 1, 4-28-80; Ord. No. 86-13A, § 1, 1-5-87) 
Sec. 12-432. - Safety precautions. 
    Each hardware store licensee shall store, inventory or stock all merchandise chemicals, flammables and other potentially dangerous items, and electrical devices, whether for sale, or used in services to the public in such a manner as to properly safeguard the public from injury or unnecessary exposure and shall be subject to such safety regulations of the village as may pertain thereto. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.19.2) 
Secs. 12-433-12-450. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XVI. - HOTELS AND ROOMING HOUSES 

Sec. 12-451. - License. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to conduct or operate a hotel, or a building or part thereof used or held out to the public as a place where sleeping accommodations are furnished for 20 or more persons for a period of one day or more without first having obtained a license therefor. The annual fee for such licenses shall be in an amount as that set forth in article V of chapter 2 immediately to the right of the reference to section 12-451. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to conduct or operate a rooming house, bed and breakfast, or building, apartment or portion of a building, in which any person or persons not related to the owner or occupant of such premises by blood or marriage are furnished sleeping accommodations for hire, without first securing a license therefor. The annual fee for such license shall be in an amount as set forth in article V of chapter 2 immediately to the right of the reference to section 12-451. 
(Code 1965, §§ 2.2.21.1, 2.2.21.2; Ord. No. 820, § 1, 4-28-80; Ord. No. 86-13A, § 1, 1-5-87; Ord. No. 2002-37, § 2, 11-25-02) 
Sec. 12-452. - Inspections. 
    The chief of police is authorized to inspect or cause to be inspected, every hotel or rooming house operated in the village as frequently as may be necessary to insure compliance with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.21.7) 
Sec. 12-453. - General condition of premises. 
    All premises used for hotel or rooming house purposes shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition in all portions of such premises. Hotels that are open for use by guests or by the public shall be kept lighted at all times they are so open to use. All such premises shall be kept heated between October 1 and May 1 to a temperature of not less than 68 degrees between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 10:00 p.m. and to a temperature of not less than 55 degrees at all other hours. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.21.3) 
Sec. 12-454. - Exits. 
    No building shall be used for a hotel unless it is furnished with the number of exits and fire escapes required by the building ordinances of the village for the construction of a new hotel. No premises shall be used for a rooming house unless there are at least two exits to the outdoors from such premises. It shall be unlawful to block or permit the blocking of any exit from any premises used for a hotel or rooming house. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.21.4) 
Sec. 12-455. - Sanitary facilities. 
    Water closets and lavatories shall be available to all guests using any hotel or rooming house; and there shall be at least one bathroom equipped with water closet, shower or tub, and lavatory facilities for each ten residents on the premises. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.21.5) 
Sec. 12-456. - Miscellaneous regulations. 
    It shall be unlawful to knowingly permit any fugitive from justice to stay in any rooming house or hotel. Each hotel proprietor shall keep or cause to be kept a register of guests as required by state law, and each operator of a rooming house shall keep a list of all persons staying therein. Such registration or list shall be available for inspection by any member of the police department at any time. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.21.6) 
State Law reference- Required books and records, 35 ILCS 145/4. 
Secs. 12-457-12-470. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XVII. - JUNK DEALERS[13] 

Footnotes: 
--- (13) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to license, tax and regulate secondhand and junk stores, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-3. 

Sec. 12-471. - License. 
(a)  Required. It shall be unlawful to operate or carry on the business of junk dealer or to keep any junk shop, store, yard or place for the purpose or sale of junk, rags, old rope, paper or bagging, old iron, brass, copper or empty bottles, without having obtained a license therefor. Applications for such licenses shall be made in conformance with the provisions of all ordinances relating to licenses. The fee to be paid for such a license, which license shall be an annual license, shall be an amount as set forth in article V of chapter 2 immediately to the right of the reference to section 12-471; provided that a junk dealer not maintaining a store or yard in the village shall pay the amount as listed in such article for each vehicle so used. 
(b)  Restriction. It shall be unlawful for any junk dealer to collect, obtain, possess or "pick up" any recyclable items placed for collection in front of any business or residence as part of any recycling program sanctioned by the village. All junk dealer licenses issued within the village shall contain a statement in relation to the aforementioned restriction, together with a statement advising the licensee of the boundaries of the areas within the village in which a recycling program is being conducted. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.24.3; Ord. No. 820, § 1, 4-28-80; Ord. No. 86-13A, § 1, 1-5-87; Ord. No. 88-12, § 1, 6-13-88) 
Sec. 12-472. - Stolen goods. 
    Every keeper of a junk shop or junkyard who shall be in possession of or receive any goods, article or things of value which may have been lost or stolen, shall upon demand produce such articles or thing to any member of the police department for examination. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.24.4) 
Sec. 12-473. - Vehicles. 
    Every vehicle used by a junk dealer in the conduct of his business shall bear thereon in legible characters the name and address of the owner and proprietor thereof. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.24.5) 
Secs. 12-474-12-490. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XVIII. - LAUNDRIES[14] 

Footnotes: 
--- (14) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to locate and regulate the use and construction of laundries, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-8. 

Sec. 12-491. - License. 
    No person shall operate or conduct a laundry in the village without having first obtained a license therefor; provided that establishments licensed as dry cleaning establishments need not obtain a laundry license in addition to the dry cleaning license. Application for such licenses shall be made in writing to the clerk and shall state thereon the location intended to be occupied. The annual fee for a laundry license shall be in the amount as set forth in article V of chapter 2 immediately to the right of the reference to section 12-491, and no license shall be issued except upon the payment of the fee. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.26.2; Ord. No. 820, § 1, 4-28-80; Ord. No. 86-13A, § 1, 1-5-87) 
Sec. 12-492. - Sanitation. 
    Premises used for laundries must be kept in a clean and sanitary condition. No refuse of any kind shall be permitted to accumulate on such premises; and the premises must be kept free from rats, mice, and vermin. It shall be unlawful to employ any person with a venereal or contagious disease in a laundry. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.26.3) 
Sec. 12-493. - Inspections. 
    The chief of police, or other officials designated by the president, are authorized to inspect, or cause to be inspected every establishment licensed under this article. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.26.4) 
Secs. 12-494-12-510. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIX. - LUMBERYARDS[15] 

Footnotes: 
--- (15) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to license, tax and regulate lumberyards, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-1. 

Sec. 12-511. - Definition. 
    As used in this article the term "lumberyard" shall mean any place used for the storage of lumber, wooden containers or wood in an amount exceeding 5,000 board feet. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.28.1) 
Sec. 12-512. - License. 
    No person shall establish, conduct or maintain a lumberyard in the village without having first obtained a license therefor. Applications for such licenses shall be made to the village clerk in writing and shall state thereon the location and size of the lumberyard for which such license is intended. The annual fee for a license for a lumberyard shall be in the amount as set forth in article V of chapter 2 immediately to the right of the reference to section 12-512. No license shall be issued without payment of this fee. 
(Code 1965, §§ 2.2.28; 2.2.28.2; Ord. No. 820, § 1, 4-28-80; Ord. No. 86-13A, § 1, 1-5-87) 
Sec. 12-513. - Inspections. 
    The fire marshal is authorized to inspect or cause to be inspected every lumberyard in the village to insure compliance with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.28.6) 
Sec. 12-514. - Fire extinguishing equipment. 
    It shall be the duty of every person owning or operating a lumberyard to have the same equipped with sufficient fire apparatus to handle any small fires which may start and to prevent their spreading. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.28.4) 
Sec. 12-515. - Piling lumber. 
    It shall be unlawful to pile any lumber in a lumberyard in such a way that the lumber is hanging over or in danger of falling onto any adjoining property, street, alley or public way. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.28.5) 
Secs. 12-516-12-530. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XX. - MACHINE SHOPS[16] 

Footnotes: 
--- (16) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to locate and regulate the use and construction of machine shops, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-8. 

Sec. 12-531. - Definition. 
    The term "machine shop" as used in this article shall be construed to include every workshop in which machines are made or metal parts thereof are repaired, or where parts of machines or tools, implements, gears, dies, screws, or other metal articles are cut, filed, shaped, or repaired by means of a lathe of other machinery. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.29.1) 
Sec. 12-532. - License. 
    No person shall conduct, operate or manage a machine shop in the village without having first secured a license therefor; provided that this article shall not be construed as requiring an additional license for any class of machine shop specifically licensed under any other ordinance of the village. The annual fee for such license shall be as set forth in article V of chapter 2 immediately to the right of the reference to section 12-532. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.29.2; Ord. No. 820, § 1, 4-28-80; Ord. No. 86-13A, § 1, 1-5-87) 
Sec. 12-533. - Inspections. 
    The health inspector is authorized to make or cause to be made such inspections as may be necessary to insure compliance with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.29.5) 
Sec. 12-534. - Sanitation. 
    No building, structure or part thereof shall be used for or in connection with any machine shop in any way so as to endanger the health or property of the employees or of the public. The owner, lessee, tenant, occupant or manager of any such machine shop shall cause all floors or other surfaces around or beneath any machine or work bench to be kept in good order and repair and shall have suitable and convenient and sanitary receptacles for receiving wastes and cloths used in and about the machine shop for the purpose of cleaning machines or parts thereof or which are intended for any other use. No person suffering from any actively contagious or infectious disease shall be employed in or about any machine shop where cutting compound or fluid is used. All such cutting compound or fluid shall be kept free from infectious or harmful matter. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.29.3) 
Sec. 12-535. - Operation at night. 
    No machine shop shall be operated between the hours of 8:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. in any place in which a majority of the buildings within a radius of 400 feet are used exclusively for residence purposes. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.29.4) 
Secs. 12-536-12-550. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XXI. - MOBILE HOME SALES 

Sec. 12-551. - Definition. 
    As used in this article the term "mobile trailer home" shall have the same definition as the term "trailer coacch." 
(Ord. No. 649, § 2.2.48.16, 12-22-69) 
Sec. 12-552. - License. 
    It shall be unlawful to establish, maintain or operate the business of selling mobile trailer homes, or items incidental thereto, in the village, without first having obtained a license therefor. Application for such license shall be made in writing to the village clerk in compliance with ordinances relating to license applications. The annual fee for such a license shall be in an amount as set forth in article V of chapter 2 immediately to the right of the reference to section 12-552. No such license shall be issued to any but a person of good character, nor to any corporation if any officer thereof is not a person of good moral character. 
(Ord. No. 649, §§ 2.2.48.17-2.2.48.19, 12-22-69; Ord. No. 86-13A, § 1, 1-5-87) 
Sec. 12-553. - General regulations. 
    A licensee under this article, shall cause safe stowage and parking of mobile trailer homes and shall take all other necessary safety precautions against fire or otherwise for the public safety and well being. 
(Ord. No. 649, § 2.2.48.20, 12-22-69) 
Secs. 12-554-12-565. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XXII. - MOTELS OR AUTO COURTS[17] 

Footnotes: 
--- (17) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to locate and regulate the use and construction of cabin accommodations, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-8. 

Sec. 12-566. - Definition. 
    The terms "motel" or "auto court" used in this article shall be construed to mean any parking lot or garage for the accommodation of motor vehicles where transient sleeping accommodations are afforded or provided on the same premises for the public or for the occupants of such automobiles. A hotel which furnishes parking space or has a garage in connection with the hotel shall not be construed as an auto court. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.3.1) 
Sec. 12-567. - License. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct or operate a motel or auto court without having first obtained a license therefor. Each applicant for such a license shall file an application with the village clerk, and shall state thereon the name and address of the applicant, name and address of the owner or manager thereof, location of the auto court, and the maximum number of persons and vehicles to be accommodated. This application shall be accompanied by plans of the toilet, bath and wash basin facilities, slop sinks, water faucets, sewer connections, driveways, and other improvements. The annual license fee for such a license shall be in an amount as set forth in article V of chapter 2 immediately to the right of the reference to section 12-567. 
(Code 1965, §§ 2.2.3.1, 2.2.3.2, 2.2.3.4; Ord. No. 820, § 1, 4-28-80; Ord. No. 86-13A, § 1, 1-5-87) 
Sec. 12-568. - Inspections. 
    The chief of police is authorized to inspect, or cause to be inspected, each auto court in order to insure compliance with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.3.6) 
Sec. 12-569. - Fire walls. 
    No parking space shall be provided for motor vehicles within ten feet of any building or structure used for housing accommodation in an auto court unless the wall facing such parking space is constructed of fireproof materials and unless the windows in such wall, if any, are equipped with reinforced fire resistant glass. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.3.3) 
Sec. 12-570. - Lights. 
    Any area or premises of an auto court open to use by the public or by persons staying in or being accommodated in the court shall be kept adequately lighted at night; provided that such lights must be so shaded or otherwise regulated so as to prevent them from shining upon any adjacent premises. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.3.7) 
Sec. 12-571. - Sanitary requirements. 
    No premises shall be operated as an auto court unless they are equipped with adequate toilet and other sanitary facilities to serve the total number of persons accommodated therein. All such sanitary facilities shall be properly connected with the sanitary sewer system serving the village if the premises are located on a street served by such sewer. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.3.5) 
Sec. 12-572. - Parking of house trailers. 
    It shall be unlawful to use or permit the use of an auto court for the accommodation of house trailers unless all ordinance requirements pertaining to trailer camps are complied with; provided that where a license fee for a trailer camp has been paid, it shall not be necessary to pay an additional fee for the operation of an auto court on the same premises. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.3.8) 
Sec. 12-573. - Miscellaneous regulations. 
    It shall be unlawful to permit any violation of any ordinance or law on or in any auto court; such premises must be kept clean and sanitary at all times, and all waste material must be removed therefrom at least once every 24 hours. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.3.6) 
Secs. 12-574-12-589. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XXIII. - NURSING HOMES, ETC.[18] 

Footnotes: 
--- (18) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal licensing of nursing homes, 210 ILCS 45/3-104. 

Sec. 12-590. - Definition. 
    As used in this article, the term "nursing home" shall mean any institution, place or family used for the reception or care, for a longer period than 24 hours, of three or more children or infants apart from their parents. A nursing home is further defined to mean any institution used for the reception or care of persons who are dependent or not capable of properly caring for themselves, and shall be understood to include homes for aged or infirm, orphan asylums, refuges and shelters and also boarding homes caring for three or more women with their children when such children are less than 14 years of age. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.32.1) 
Sec. 12-591. - License. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person other than the regularly constituted authorities of the United States, the county, the village, or of the state, or any association or institution for the care of children which has been accredited, certified or licensed by the state pursuant to an act of the legislature, to regulate the treatment and control of dependent, neglected and delinquent children, to open, conduct, manage or maintain any nursing home without first obtaining a license therefor. Any person desiring such license shall make application in writing to the village clerk. Such applications shall conform to all ordinances relating to applications for licenses and shall state the location or proposed location of the home, the purpose for which it is to be opened, conducted or maintained, the accommodations for the inmates thereof, the nature and kind of care, instruction or benefits given or proposed to be given therein, the name and address of the officials and/or board of officials conducting, managing or maintaining such home, the name and address of the chief physician, surgeon, or attending physicians, or surgeons attending therein. The license fee for nursing homes shall be in an amount as set forth in article V of chapter 2 immediately to the right of the reference to section 12-591. 
(Code 1965, §§ 2.2.32.2, 2.2.32.3, 2.2.32.5; Ord. No. 820, § 1, 4-28-80; Ord. No. 86-13A, § 1, 1-5-87) 
Secs. 12-592-12-605. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XXIV. - PAINT STORES 

Sec. 12-606. - License. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain and operate a paint store without first having obtained a license therefor. The fee for such a license shall be in an amount as set forth in article V of chapter 2 immediately to the right of the reference to section 12-606. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.34.1; Ord. No. 820, § 1, 4-28-80; Ord. No. 86-13A, § 1, 1-5-87) 
Sec. 12-607. - Safety regulations. 
    Each licensee under this article shall store, inventory or stock all merchandise, chemicals, flammables and other potentially dangerous items, and electrical devices, whether for sale, or used in services to the public, in such a manner as to properly safeguard the public from injury or unnecessary exposure and shall be subject to such safety regulations of the village as may pertain thereto. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.34.2) 
Secs. 12-608-12-620. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XXV. - PARKING LOTS[19] 

Footnotes: 
--- (19) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to locate and regulate the use and construction of parking lots, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-8. 

Sec. 12-621. - Definition. 
    The term "parking lot" as used in this article shall be construed to mean and include any place maintained for the outdoor parking of cars, excepting on a street, alley or other public place, where such parking is permitted upon the payment of compensation. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.35.1; Ord. No. 607, § 1, 7-17-67) 
Sec. 12-622. - License. 
    It shall be unlawful for, any person to operate a parking lot without having first obtained a license therefor. Applications for such licenses shall be made in writing to the village clerk and shall contain all necessary information to insure compliance with the provisions of this article, including a description of the location, size, number of cars, to be accommodated, and a statement of any services other than parking, or of any article or commodities for sale, offered to patrons of the parking lot. In addition, the applicant shall furnish a plot plan showing streets and alleys affected. The annual fee for such license shall be in an amount set forth in article V of chapter 2 immediately to the right of the reference to section 12-622. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.35.2; Ord. No. 820, § 1, 4-28-80; Ord. No. 86-13A, § 1, 1-5-87) 
Sec. 12-623. - Fire protection. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any parking lot unless there are available on the premises adequate fire extinguishers and personnel competent to use the same. There shall be maintained on each parking lot at least one hand chemical fire extinguisher having a capacity of one quart of liquid or two and one-half pounds of carbon dioxide for each ten cars for which accommodations are offered, which extinguishers shall always be maintained in good order and in accessible places. Where accommodations are provided for more than 100 cars, there shall be maintained in addition to the hand extinguishers required, at least one portable chemical fire extinguisher having a capacity of two and one-half gallons of liquid or 15 pounds of carbon dioxide. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.35.4) 
Sec. 12-624. - Driveways. 
    No driveway for a parking lot shall be constructed excepting in full compliance with the ordinances relative to the issuance of permits for driveways; it shall be the duty of the operator of each parking lot to maintain the sidewalk and parkway over which such driveway passes in good condition. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.35.5) 
Sec. 12-625. - Operation of other businesses. 
    If any business other than that of operating a parking lot is conducted on the same premises with a parking lot, such business shall be conducted in full compliance with all ordinances pertinent thereto, and any license required for the operation of such business must be procured and the fee required therefor must be paid. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.35.6) 
Sec. 12-626. - Intoxicating liquors. 
    It shall be unlawful to serve intoxicating liquor for consumption in any car parked in a parking lot or to drink any intoxicating liquor while therein. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.35.8) 
Sec. 12-627. - Pavement and litter control. 
    It shall be unlawful to operate a parking lot unless the surface thereof is covered with concrete, asphalt, macadam or similar paving. Such parking lot shall at all times be kept clean and free from dust and refuse. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.35.9) 
Sec. 12-628. - Buildings. 
    Any buildings constructed on a parking lot shall be constructed in full compliance with the ordinances pertaining thereto, and shall have exterior walls of nonflammable material; provided, that any structure used or to be used for office purposes only may have less than the minimum area requirements prescribed for residences or commercial buildings. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.35.10) 
Sec. 12-629. - Condition of vehicles. 
    It shall be unlawful to park or store, in any parking lot, any vehicle which is not in a condition ready for use, or to permit the parking of any abandoned, junked or partially disabled vehicle in any such lot. It shall be unlawful to use any parking lot for storage or parking of any vehicle for the purpose of displaying the same for sale, or to use any parking lot or portion thereof as an automobile repair shop. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.35.11) 
Sec. 12-630. - Miscellaneous regulations. 
(a)  At the entrance of each parking lot there shall be posted in words and figures large enough to be read by prospective patrons, a statement of the rates to be charged and the closing hours. There shall be at least one attendant on the premises at all times during which the parking lot is open for business. 
(b)  If a parking lot is maintained in connection with an establishment serving food for consumption on the premises, and food or drinks are served to the occupants of cars, sufficient adequate containers must be maintained for all trash and refuse, and the refuse must be removed and the premises must be kept thoroughly clean by the proprietor. 
(c)  No parking lot shall be established or operated in any place where such establishment or operation would be in violation of the zoning or any other ordinance. Not more than one car for each 200 square feet of area shall be accepted for parking in any such place. Each parking lot shall be so marked as to show the parking space allotted for each car, and shall have sufficient entrances and exits to permit the entrance and egress of cars without obstruction to traffic. 
(Code 1965, §§ 2.2.35.3, 2.2.35.7) 
Secs. 12-631-12-645. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XXVI. - PAWNBROKERS[20] 

Footnotes: 
--- (20) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to license, tax and regulate pawnbrokers, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-5. 

Sec. 12-646. - License. 
    No person shall conduct or operate the business of pawnbroker without having first obtained a license therefor. An application for a pawnbroker's license shall be made to the village clerk and shall state thereon the name of the applicant; the place of business; and the number of employees intended to be engaged. The chief of police or any other officer of the village designated by the board of trustees shall investigate each applicant for such license and shall report back to the board of trustees whether or not such applicant is a person of good character; no license shall be issued to a person who has been convicted of the offense of receiving stolen goods or of burglary or robbery. No such license shall be issued to any person who is not 18 years of age or older. The annual fee for a pawnbroker's license shall be as set forth in article V of chapter 2 immediately to the right of the reference to section 12-646. 
(Code 1965, §§ 2.2.36.1-2.2.36.3; Ord. No. 820, § 1, 4-28-80; Ord. No. 86-13A, § 1, 1-5-87) 
Sec. 12-647. - Records. 
    Every pawnbroker doing business in the village shall keep a record of every transaction as required by state statute. Every pawnbroker doing business in the village shall comply with the identification procedures as required by state statute and in addition obtain the individual's thumbprint which shall be maintained in the record book as a part of the entry. Said records shall be open to inspection of any police officer at any time during the hours of business. It shall be the duty of every pawnbroker to complete and make available for inspection by any police officer before the hour of 12:00 noon, each and every business day, the records required to be kept pursuant to this article, reflecting the completed transaction of the previous day. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.36.4; Ord. No. 2011-10, § 3, 5-9-11) 
Sec. 12-648. - Weapons. 
    No pawnbroker shall receive as a pledge or purchase any revolver, pistol, blackjack or sawed-off shotgun and no pawnbroker shall display in his window or shop any such weapons for sale. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.36.5) 
Sec. 12-649. - Minors. 
    No pawnbroker shall have any business dealings as a pawnbroker with any person less than 18 years of age without the written consent of the parent or guardian of the minor for each particular transaction. No pawnbroker shall employ a person who is less than 18 years of age to assist him in his business. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.36.6) 
Sec. 12-650. - Stolen goods. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of every pawnbroker to report to the police any article pledged with him, or which it is sought to be pledged with him, if he shall have reason to believe that the article was stolen or lost and found by the person attempting to pledge it in the case of a lost article. 
(b)  In any event that stolen property is identified pursuant to this notice, or during an inspection of records by any police officer, the police department shall seize said stolen property and provide the pawnbroker with a receipt identifying all items seized within 72 hours. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.36.7; Ord. No. 2011-10, § 3, 5-9-11) 
Sec. 12-651. - Acting as secondhand dealers. 
    No pawnbroker shall conduct the business of a secondhand dealer without having obtained the license required for such dealer in addition to his pawnbroker's license. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.36.8) 
Secs. 12-652-12-670. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XXVII. - PHOTOGRAPHY STUDIOS 

Sec. 12-671. - License. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain and operate a photographer's studio without having first obtained a license therefor. The fee for such a license shall be in the amount as set forth in article V of chapter 2 immediately to the right of the reference to section 12-671. No license shall be issued except upon payment of this fee. Applications for such licenses shall conform to all applicable ordinances. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.37.1; Ord. No. 820, § 1, 4-28-80; Ord. No. 86-13A, § 1, 1-5-87) 
Sec. 12-672. - General safety regulations. 
    Each licensee under this article shall store, inventory or stock all merchandise, chemicals, flammables and other potentially dangerous items, and electrical devices, whether for sale, or used in services to the public, in such a manner as to properly safeguard the public from injury or unnecessary exposure and shall be subject to such safety regulations of the village as may pertain thereto. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.37.2) 
Secs. 12-673-12-690. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XXVIII. - PUBLIC GARAGES[21] 

Footnotes: 
--- (21) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to locate and regulate the use and construction of parking lots, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-8. 

Sec. 12-691. - License. 
    No person shall operate or maintain a public garage in the village without having first obtained a license therefor. Applications for such a license shall be made in writing to the village clerk, and shall state the location of the garage and the number of cars which can be accommodated therein. The annual fee for such license shall be an amount as set forth in article V of chapter 2 immediately to the right of the reference to section 12-691, and no license shall be issued until the fee is paid; provided that any required maintenance fee for a commercial driveway need not be paid where the driveway is for a licensed garage. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.39.2; Ord. No. 820, § 1, 4-28-80; Ord. No. 86-13A, § 1, 1-5-87) 
Sec. 12-692. - Inspections. 
    The chief of police and the fire marshal are authorized to make or cause to be made such inspection of public garages as may be necessary to insure compliance with the provisions of this article. Any police officer shall be permitted at any reasonable time to view every car stored or kept in any public garage, and it shall be unlawful to hinder any such inspection or to conceal any motor car or motor vehicle from such inspection. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.39.7) 
Sec. 12-693. - Location restrictions. 
    It shall be unlawful to operate, maintain or conduct a public garage within 300 feet of any church, school or hospital in the village. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.39.5) 
Sec. 12-694. - Smoking. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to smoke or light a cigarette, pipe or cigar in any public garage. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.39.3) 
Sec. 12-695. - Buildings. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain or operate any public garage in a frame building, or in any building or structure used for school, church or theater purposes, or in any building which does not conform to the requirements of the building ordinances. The premises of every garage must be kept clean and free from flammable waste material. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.39.4) 
Sec. 12-696. - Changing identification marks, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to change the identification marks on the engine of any car or automobile in any public garage, and it shall be unlawful to change the license tags on such cars excepting in accordance with the register of motor vehicles kept by the Secretary of the State. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.39.6) 
Secs. 12-697-12-710. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XXIX. - SCAVENGERS[22] 

Footnotes: 
--- (22) --- 
Cross reference- Garbage and trash, ch. 10. 

Sec. 12-711. - Definition. 
    As used in this article the term "private scavenger" shall mean a person who collects the garbage and refuse of another for removal pursuant to a contract with the person being served. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.54.1) 
Sec. 12-712. - License. 
(a)  Required. It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business or activity of a private scavenger without first having obtained a license as herein provided. The annual fee for such license shall be in an amount as listed in article V of chapter 2 immediately to the right of the reference to section 12-712. No license shall be issued except on payment of this fee. 
(b)  Restriction. It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation engaging in the business or activity of private scavenger to collect, obtain, possess or "pick up" any recyclable items placed for collection in front of any business or residence as part of any recycling program sanctioned by the village. All scavenger licenses issued within the village shall contain a statement in relation to the aforementioned restriction, together with a statement advising the licensee of the boundaries of the areas within the village in which a recycling program is being conducted. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.54.1; Ord. No. 820, § 1, 4-28-80; Ord. No. 86-13A, § 1, 1-5-87; Ord. No. 88-12, § 1, 6-13-88) 
Sec. 12-713. - Safety precautions. 
    Private scavengers shall utilize and operate safe and effective equipment and shall undertake all reasonable precautions to prevent any injury to property or persons in this village. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.54.3) 
Sec. 12-714. - Vehicles. 
    Any vehicle used by a private scavenger in his business shall be watertight, and equipped with airtight covers for such portions as are used for the transportation of refuse. It shall be unlawful for any such vehicle to be driven through or over any street during or on a Sunday. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.42.4) 
Sec. 12-715. - Disposal. 
    It shall be unlawful for any private scavenger to dispose of or store any refuse in any place within the village limits. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.42.5) 
Secs. 12-716-12-730. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XXX. - SECONDHAND STORES[23] 

Footnotes: 
--- (23) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to license, tax and regulate secondhand dealers, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-3. 

Sec. 12-731. - License. 
    No person shall operate or conduct a secondhand store in the village without having first obtained a license therefor. The annual license fee for a secondhand store shall be in an amount as set forth in article V of chapter 2 immediately to the right of the reference to section 12-731. Applications for such licenses shall be made to the village clerk in writing, and shall state the location intended to be used. Upon receipt of any such application, the clerk or any person authorized by him or by the president and board of trustees to do so shall investigate the character of the applicant and shall report to the board of trustees the result of such investigation. 
(Code 1965, §§ 2.2.43.1, 2.2.43.2; Ord. No. 820, § 1, 4-28-80; Ord. No. 86-13A, § 1, 1-5-87) 
Sec. 12-732. - Records. 
    Every person operating a secondhand store shall keep a record of all articles purchased, which records shall be, together with the articles themselves, open to inspection of any member of the police department at all reasonable hours. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.43.3) 
Sec. 12-733. - Operation as pawnbroker. 
    No person operating a secondhand store shall do business as a pawnbroker without also securing a pawnbroker's license. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.43.4) 
Secs. 12-734-12-750. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XXXI. - SELF-SERVICE GASOLINE STATIONS[24] 

Footnotes: 
--- (24) --- 
Cross reference- Gasoline pumps on streets, § 9-7; flammable liquids, § 9-71 et seq. 

Sec. 12-751. - Definition. 
    For the purpose of this article the term "self-service gasoline station" shall mean that portion of the property where flammable or combustible liquids used as motor fuel are stored and subsequently dispensed, from fixed approved dispensing equipment into fuel tanks of motor vehicles by persons other than the station attendant. 
(Ord. No. 849, § 1(2.2.4C.2), 5-10-82) 
Sec. 12-752. - Compliance with state law. 
    The provisions of this article shall be in addition to any rules and regulations relating to the operation, storage, transportation, sale and uses of gasoline and volatile oils promulgated by the state. 
(Ord. No. 849, § 1(2.2.4C.4, 2.2.4C.6), 5-10-82) 
State Law reference- State regulation of gasoline stations authorized, 430 ILCS 15/2. 
Sec. 12-753. - License. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct or operate a self-service gasoline station in the village without first having obtained a business license for same. The annual fee to be paid to the village for such license shall be in the amount as set forth in article V of chapter 2 immediately to the right of the reference to section 12-753. No such license shall be issued unless the station and equipment to be used therein fully complies with the ordinances of the village and unless approved by the chief of the fire department. 
(b)  The chief of the fire department may, for failure to comply with this article, or for other good and just causes, refuse to issue or renew, suspend or revoke a self-service gasoline station license. The fire chief shall serve notice of such refusal, suspension or revocation upon the applicant for, or the holder of such license, by personal service or by certified or registered mail, if the applicant for or the holder of such license, within ten days after the notice of such refusal, suspension or revocation is served, files in the office of the chief of the fire department or in the office of the village clerk, a petition for reconsideration, the fire chief shall grant a hearing with regard to the petition. Any order of the fire chief may be appealed to the president and board of trustees within ten days of its entry. Such order shall not prevent the imposition of any fines or penalties otherwise imposed for violation of this article. 
(c)  No license shall be issued under this section to any self-service gasoline station unless a state permit has been issued for such station. In the event the state shall have suspended or revoked its permit, the village license shall automatically be suspended or revoked for the concurrent period. 
(Ord. No. 849, § 1(2.2.4C.1, 2.2.4C.5, 2.2.4C.6), 5-10-82; Ord. No. 86-13A, § 1, 1-5-87) 
Sec. 12-754. - Live-in facilities prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful to provide for the use of the live-in facilities or combinations for the benefit of any owner, operator, or employee of a self-service gasoline station on the premises of such station. 
(Ord. No. 849, § 1(2.2.4C.3(a)), 5-20-82) 
Sec. 12-755. - Attendants. 
(a)  All self-service gasoline stations shall have at least one attendant who is at least 18 years old on duty while the station is open to the public. The attendant's primary function shall be to supervise, observe and control the dispensing of flammable liquids while such liquids are actually being dispensed; this shall not be interpreted as prohibiting the "split-island" type of operation. 
(b)  The attendant shall have immediate access to emergency cut-off switches provided at a location remote from the dispensing devices, which location shall be subject to approval by the department of public safety or chief of the fire department. 
(c)  The attendant shall supervise the dispensing of motor fuels. The attendant shall refuse service to any person who is smoking or who appears, for any reason, to be unable to dispense the motor fuel safely and shall shut off the dispensing unit if a patron fails to follow instructions in compliance with this article. 
(d)  All attendants and other employees shall be thoroughly instructed in the operation and use of the communication system, the control station, the fire extinguishing equipment, the operation of the dispensing units and safety regulations for the dispensing of motor fuels. 
(Ord. No. 849, § 1(2.2.4C.3(b)-(f)), 5-10-82) 
Sec. 12-756. - Minimum age of persons operating pumps. 
    No person under the age of 16 years shall be permitted to operate pumps at a self-service gasoline station and a sign shall be prominently displayed indicating this prohibition. 
(Ord. No. 849, § 1(2.2.4C.3(g)), 5-10-82) 
Sec. 12-757. - Access, etc., to dispensing area. 
    The dispensing area of a self-service gasoline station shall at all times be in clear view of the attendant and the placing or allowing of any obstacle to come between the dispensing area and the attendant control area shall be prohibited. The attendant shall at all times be able to communicate with persons in the dispensing area. 
(Ord. No. 849, § 1(2.2.4C.3(c)), 5-10-82) 
Sec. 12-758. - Dispensing units and devices generally. 
(a)  Approved "self-service" dispensing devices are permitted at gasoline stations when available and open to the public, provided that all dispensing of motor fuels, except low pressure gas (lpg), by a person other than the service station attendant is under the supervision and control of a qualified attendant and the dispensing nozzle is a listed automatic closing type without a latch-opening device. 
(b)  Gasoline or other dispensing nozzles at a self-service gasoline station shall not be of the "latch-open" type. 
(Ord. No. 849, § 1(2.2.4C.2(c), 2.2.4C.3(i)), 5-10-82) 
Sec. 12-759. - Location of gasoline dispensing units. 
    Dispensing pumps at a self-service gasoline station shall be located at least 13 feet inside station property lines and no more than ten feet from any building opening. 
(Ord. No. 849, § 1(2.2.4C.3(h)), 5-10-82) 
Sec. 12-760. - Protection of dispensing units. 
    Dispensing units at a self-service gasoline station shall be mounted either on a concrete island or protected against collision damage by suitable means in a manner approved by the fire chief and the building inspector. 
(Ord. No. 849, § 1(2.2.4C.3(l)), 5-10-82) 
Sec. 12-761. - Fire extinguishers. 
    At least one type ABC fire extinguisher, with a capacity of ten pounds, shall be at the attendant's control station at a self-service gasoline station. 
(Ord. No. 849, § 1(2.2.4C.3(j)), 5-10-82) 
Sec. 12-762. - Pump operating instructions. 
    Signs giving instructions for the operation of gasoline or other fuel dispensing equipment, in block letters at least one-half-inch in height shall be conspicuously posted at each self-service gasoline station and a sign bearing the following words in block letters at least two inches in height shall be conspicuously posted on each gasoline or other pump island where self-service is offered: 
    "STOP ENGINE" 
    "NO SMOKING" 
    "WARNING-IT IS UNLAWFUL TO DISPENSE GASOLINE INTO UNAPPROVED CONTAINERS" 
    All signs required by this section shall be constructed of weather-resistant material. 
(Ord. No. 849, § 1(2.2.4C.3(k)), 5-10-82) 
Sec. 12-763. - Portable containers. 
    No portable containers of more than six gallons shall be filled with gasoline, at a self-service gasoline station except as dispensed directly into the fuel tanks attached to a motor vehicle. All portable receptacles for gasoline shall be red and shall be labeled in letters of a contrasting color and a height of not less than one-half-inch, and it shall be unlawful to put any other liquids or oils except gasoline in such receptacles theretofore used for gasoline so long as such receptacles are so painted red and labeled "gasoline." In all circumstances, the container shall be of material approved by the state division of fire protection. 
(Ord. No. 849, § 1(2.2.4C.3(m)), 5-10-82) 
State Law reference- "Red can" law, 430 ILCS 20/1. 
Secs. 12-764-12-775. - Reserved.

No license shall be issued except upon payment of this fee.

(Code 1965, § 2.2.46.2)
