ARTICLE XXXIII. - TOBACCO DEALERS 

Sec. 12-791. - License. 
    No person shall engage in the business of selling at retail of cigars or tobacco including selling by automatic vending devices, without obtaining a license therefor. Applications for such license shall be made in writing to the village clerk, and he shall cause an inspection to be made of the character of the applicant. No such license shall be issued to any person who is not a person of good character. The annual fee for such a license shall be an amount as set forth in article V of chapter 2 immediately to the right of the reference to section 12-791. The annual fee for each cigarette vending machine shall be an amount as listed in such article V, chapter 2. Any license issued under this section may be revoked for a violation of any provision of this article or of any ordinance relating to tobacco dealers or the premises used. 
(Code 1965, §§ 2.2.47.1, 2.2.47.2, 2.2.47.5; Ord. No. 820, § 1, 4-28-80; Ord. No. 86-13A, § 1, 1-5-87) 
Sec. 12-792. - Inspections. 
    The chief of police is authorized to inspect premises licensed pursuant to this article in order to insure compliance with this article. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.47.3) 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to inspect tobacco, 65 ILCS 5/11-20-3. 
Sec. 12-793. - Sanitation. 
    Premises and buildings used for the sale of cigars and tobacco in any form must be kept in a clean and sanitary condition. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.47.3) 
Sec. 12-794. - Minors. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or give cigars or tobacco in any form to any male or female child under 18 years of age, except on written order of any adult known to the dealer. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.47.4) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 720 ILCS 685/4. 
Secs. 12-795-12-810. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XXXIV. - UNDERTAKERS 

Sec. 12-811. - License. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain an undertaking establishment or to operate as an undertaker or mortician in the village without first having obtained a license as herein provided. Such license shall be an annual license and shall be issued upon payment of a fee in the amount as set forth in article V of chapter 2 immediately to the right of the reference to section 12-811. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.49.1; Ord. No. 820, § 1, 4-28-80; Ord. No. 86-13A, § 1, 1-5-87) 
Secs. 12-812-12-825. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XXXV. - MOTOR VEHICLE DEALERS[25] 

Footnotes: 
--- (25) --- 
Editor's note- Section 3 of Ord. No. 2006-7, adopted March 13, 2006, retitled art. XXXV, used car dealers, to read as herein set out. 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to license, tax and regulate dealers in used goods, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-3. 

Sec. 12-826. - Definition. 
    As used in this article the term "motor vehicle dealer" shall mean a person, dealing in the sale, purchase or trade, at wholesale or retail, of used or current model automobiles, motor bikes or motorcycles which are merchantable and operable and are equipped in accordance with regulations provided by the Secretary of State of Illinois, in accordance with statues made and provided therefor. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.50.1(a); Ord. No. 618, § 1, 2-26-68; Ord. No. 2006-07, § 3, 3-13-06) 
Sec. 12-827. - License. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in, carry on, maintain or conduct the business of being a motor vehicle dealer without a license therefor for each location. 
(b)  Any person desiring to obtain such a license shall make application therefor, in writing, to the village clerk. All application forms shall be prescribed and furnished by the village clerk and shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The name and post office address of the applicant; 
(2)  Whether the applicant is a person, or persons, firm, partnership or corporation; 
(3)  The street number of the building, structure, or place in which the applicant intends to carry on, maintain, conduct or engage in such business; and 
(4)  Such other information as the village clerk shall require. 
The application shall be signed by the applicant or its proper officers. 
(c)  The application of no person or partnership shall be considered until such person or members of said partnership have become bona fide residents of the state. 
(d)  The annual fee for such a license shall be in the amount as set forth in article V of chapter 2 immediately to the right of the reference to section 12-827. 
(e)  In the event any person issued a license under the provisions of this section has such license revoked, no license shall be granted to such person to conduct or carry on such business, within six months after such revocation. 
(f)  Any licensee who discontinues business for a period exceeding 30 days, will automatically relinquish all rights or interest in the license, and the license shall be automatically revoked. 
(g)  Each licensee shall display the license in a conspicuous place in his place of business. 
(Code 1965, §§ 2.2.50.1-2.2.50.6, 2.2.50.12, 2.2.50.16, 2.2.50.18; Ord. No. 820, § 1, 4-28-80; Ord. No. 86-13A, § 1, 1-5-87; Ord. No. 2006-07, § 3, 3-13-06) 
Sec. 12-828. - Police to investigate dealers. 
    It shall be the duty of the chief of police to make an investigation of any motor vehicle dealer whom he might have reason to believe is not conforming to this article or any other ordinance or law pertaining to the possession and sale of used automobiles. Such officer shall investigate any used automobile dealer for violation of this article on information given him of such violations. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.50.27; Ord. No. 2006-07, § 3, 3-13-06) 
Sec. 12-829. - Storage of abandoned vehicles, etc. 
    A motor vehicle dealer shall not keep upon his premises any wrecked, disabled, partially dismantled, dilapidated, inoperable or other motor vehicles retained by such dealer for the sale of parts, or store any automobile parts or equipment for sale or other disposal either at wholesale or retail. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.50.1(a); Ord. No. 618, § 1, 2-26-68; Ord. No. 2006-07, § 3, 3-13-06) 
Sec. 12-830. - General duty of licensee. 
    Every person licensed pursuant to the provisions of this article shall be strictly responsible for the conduct of his employees insofar as the sales or purchases of automobiles or motor vehicles are concerned; it shall be his duty to see that no automobiles or motor vehicles are sold or purchased by his agents or any other person in and upon his premises, other than his own automobiles or motor vehicles, unless such person has a license as provided for in this article. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.51.20) 
Sec. 12-831. - Records. 
    Each licensee under this article shall keep a book or other suitable record which shall contain an accurate description of any motor vehicle purchased, taken or received by such licensee. Every such entry shall be made at the time when such motor vehicle is purchased, taken or received. Such book or record in which such entries are made shall be kept and preserved in and at the place of business of such licensee in the village. In the case of used motor vehicles, the description shall include the engine number, if any, the maker's number, if any, and any other information that shall be required by the committee or the village clerk. The book or record provided for herein shall at all reasonable times be open to the inspection of any member of said committee, or any member of the village police force or any member of the state police. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.50.13; Ord. No. 2006-07, § 3, 3-13-06) 
Secs. 12-832-12-845. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XXXVI. - VARIETY STORES 

Sec. 12-846. - License. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain and operate a variety store without first having obtained a license as herein provided. The fee for such license shall be in an amount as set forth in article V of chapter 2 immediately to the right of the reference to section 12-846. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.51.1; Ord. No. 820, § 1, 4-28-80; Ord. No. 86-13A, § 1, 1-5-87) 
Sec. 12-847. - Safety regulations. 
    Each licensee under this article shall store, inventory or stock all merchandise, chemicals, flammables and other potentially dangerous items, and electrical devices, whether for sale, or used in services to the public, in such a manner as to properly safeguard the public from injury or unnecessary exposure and shall be subject to such safety regulations of the village as may pertain thereto. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.51.2) 
Secs. 12-848-12-854. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XXXVII. - LANDSCAPERS AND LANDSCAPING BUSINESSES 

Sec. 12-855. - License. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, firm (whether a partnership, joint venture or other form of business entity) or corporation to conduct or operate a landscaping business, or to do any landscaping work, without first having obtained a license. For the purposes of this section, the terms "landscaping" and "landscaping work" shall synonymously mean any work involving the removal and/or relocation of dirt and/or the addition of dirt, shrubbery, flowering plants and the like by any person, firm or corporation holding himself or itself out as having professional qualifications so to do for the purposes of aesthetically improving the appearance of any lot, parcel or tract of land or beautifying any structure or building located thereon. The fee for such license shall be in an amount as set forth in article V of chapter 2 immediately to the right of the reference to section 12-855. License applicants shall submit a copy of insurance coverages at the time of application. 
(Ord. No. 88-7, § 1; Ord. No. 2006-07, § 3, 3-13-06) 
Sec. 12-856. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2006-07, § 3, adopted March 13, 2006, deleted § 12-856, which pertained to landscaping permits and was derived from Ord. No. 88-7, § 1. 
ARTICLE XXXVIII. - ANTENNA TOWER AND SATELLITE DISH INSTALLERS 

Sec. 12-857. - License. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, firm (whether a partnership, joint venture or other form of business entity) or corporation to conduct or operate a satellite dish installation business or antenna tower installation business or to perform any satellite dish installation or antenna tower installation without first having obtained a building permit or business or contractor's license. Prior to the beginning of any such satellite installation or antenna tower installation work the person, firm or corporation intending to perform such work shall register with the village administrative offices and pay the appropriate building permit fee or show proof of business license or contractor's license. The business license fee shall be in the amount as set forth in article V of chapter 2 immediately to the right of the reference to section 12-13. 
(Ord. No. 95-23, § 3, 5-22-95) 
Secs. 12-858-12-870. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XXXIX. - ADULT USE OWNER/OPERATOR/MANAGER[26] 

Footnotes: 
--- (26) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 99-17, § 2, adopted June 14, 1999, enacted provisions which pertained to adult use owner, operator, manager. Such provisions, §§ 12-771-12-774, were redesignated as 12-871-12-874 in order to conform to the numbering system established for this Code. 

Sec. 12-871. - Definitions. 
    [As used in this article, the following words and terms shall have the meaning ascribed thereto:] 
    Adult bookstore: An establishment having as a substantial or significant portion of its sales or stock in trade, books, magazines, films for sale, rental or for viewing on premises by use of motion picture devices or by coin-operated means, and periodicals which are distinguished or characterized by their emphasis on matter depicting, describing or relating to "specified sexual activities," or "specified anatomical areas;" or an establishment that holds itself out to the public as a purveyor of such materials based upon its signage, advertising, displays, actual sales, presence of video preview or coin-operated booths, exclusion of minors from the establishment's premises or any other factors showing the establishment's primary purpose is to purvey such material. 
    Adult entertainment cabaret: A public or private establishment which: (i) features or permits topless dancers, strippers, "go-go" dancers, male or female impersonators; (ii) features or permits entertainers or exhibitors who display "specified anatomical areas"; or (iii) features or permits entertainers or exhibitors who by reason of their appearance or conduct perform in a manner which is designed primarily to appeal to the prurient interest of the patron or features entertainers who engage in, or are engaged in explicit simulations of, "specified sexual activities". 
    Adult motion picture theater: A building or area used for presenting materials distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on matter depicting, describing or relating to "specified sexual activities" or "specified anatomical areas" for observation by patrons therein. 
    Adult novelty store: An establishment having a substantial or significant portion of its sales or stock in trade consisting of toys, devices, clothing "novelties", lotions and other items distinguished or characterized by their emphasis on or use for "specialized sexual activities" or "specified anatomical areas" or an establishment that holds itself out to the public as a purveyor of such materials based upon its signage, advertising, displays, actual sales, exclusion of minors from the establishment's premises or any other factors showing the establishment's primary purpose is to purvey such material. 
    Adult use: Adult bookstores, adult motion picture theaters, adult entertainment cabarets, adult novelty stores and other similar uses. 
    Specified sexual activities: For the purpose of this article "specified sexual activities" means: (i) human genitals in the state of sexual stimulation or arousal; (ii) acts of human masturbation, sexual intercourse or sodomy; and (iii) fondling or other erotic touching of human genitals, pubic region, buttock or female breasts. 
    Specified anatomical areas: For the purpose of this article, "specified anatomical areas" means: less than completely and opaquely covered: (i) human genitals, (ii) pubic region, (iii) buttock; (iv) female breasts below a point immediately above the top of the areola. 
(Ord. No. 99-17, § 2, 6-14-99) 
Sec. 12-872. - Registration. 
    The owner of a building or premises in which adult uses, in whole or part, operate and the owner of any business in which adult use are in whole or a part of said operation shall register the following information with the village clerk: 
(1)  Legal name. In the case of any business entity other than an individual, individuals or a sole proprietorship, a copy of the legal incorporation or declaration of partnership papers shall also be filed with the village clerk. In case of a land trust, the names of the beneficial owners and/or a copy of the land trust agreement and declaration of trust shall also be filed; 
(2)  Address of the premises; 
(3)  The name of the business or establishment; 
(4)  The name(s) and address(es) of all business operators, beneficial owners and/or the major stockholders of the business or establishment if different than that provided above; 
(5)  The date of initiation of the adult use; 
(6)  The nature of the adult use; 
(7)  If the building or premises are leased, a copy of said lease. 
(Ord. No. 99-17, § 2, 6-14-99) 
Sec. 12-873. - License. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to conduct or operate any business which includes in whole or in part an adult use without first having obtained a business license for same. The annual fee to be paid to the village for such a license shall be $750.00. Prior to issuance, a background check shall be conducted by the chief of police or other officer appointed by him on the applicant. No license shall be issued to a person who has been convicted of any felony or misdemeanor involving any sex offense, any offenses involving exploitation or injury to minors, or contributing to the delinquency of a minor. 
(b)  The license issued subject to the conditions of subsection (a) above, may be suspended or revoked by the corporate authorities based upon reasonable cause including, but not limited to, any ordinance violation or any violation of state statute, county ordinance or federal law being committed on said premises by the owner or operator of said business. Further, the license issued subject to the conditions of subsection (a) above, may be suspended by the corporate authorities based upon reasonable cause including, but not limited to, any ordinance violation or any violation of state statute, county ordinance or federal law being committed repeatedly by patrons on said premises. "Being committed repeatedly" for the purposes of this section shall mean four violations or more within any 30-day period. Interim emergency suspensions up to five days may be issued by the president with the concurrence of three trustees in case of any situation involving the danger of fire, safe patron evacuation or other public health and safety without a formal hearing. For all other suspensions or for a revocation of the license issued pursuant to subsection (a) above, the licensee has a right to a hearing before the corporate authorities. 
(Ord. No. 99-17, § 2, 6-14-99) 
Sec. 12-874. - Compliance with other ordinances. 
    The provisions of this article shall be in addition to any rules, regulations or ordinances as applicable to adult uses or other business or activities occurring on the premises. 
(Ord. No. 99-17, § 2, 6-14-99) 
Secs. 12-875-12-879. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XL. - PRECIOUS METALS AND GEMS BROKER 

Sec. 12-880. - Records. 
(a)  Every broker, broker's agent or broker's employee, shall keep a record of all transactions involving the purchase, sale, barter, exchange or other conveyance or receipt of any precious metal or gem as defined in section 12-883 below. Such record shall be hand written or legibly printed, or may be maintained in a computer database. All entries into the record shall be in the English language. 
(b)  The record maintained as stated above shall be made at the time of the transaction and shall set forth the following information: 
(1)  Name, age, date of birth, gender, place of residence, general description of the individual with whom the transaction is had and the signature of the individual and their thumbprint on the receipt of the permanent record. The record shall also include the date and time of the transaction and the signature of the broker, agent or employee who consummated said transaction. 
(2)  A photocopy of a valid state-issued driver's license or state-issued identification card bearing the photograph of the customer with whom the transaction was consummated. If the customer does not have a valid state-issued photo identification or driver's license, broker, broker's agent or employee shall photograph customer with said photo depicting a clear and visible view of the customers face and head. Customers name shall be inscribed on the back of said photo, and the photo shall be maintained with the other record of said transaction. 
If the customer does not have a valid state-issued driver's license or identification card containing a photograph, name and address of the customer, two kinds of identification must be shown, and one of the two forms of identification must include the customer's residence address. These forms of identification shall include, but not be limited to the following: Social Security card, utility bill, employee or student identification card, credit card, or a civic, union or professional association membership card. 
(3)  A description of every article received, purchased, sold or exchanged by giving the manufacturer's name and other marks of identification appearing on the article including, but not limited to, the serial number and engravings, if any, on the article, and a complete description of all components or pieces of each article, including any stone, gems and the weight and composition of the metal comprising the article. 
(4)  The price or consideration received, and the name and address of the receiving party in the case of sale, and the sales price in the case of a purchase, and the method of payment. 
(c)  All entries in the record shall be signed and dated by the broker, his agent or employee making the entry. 
(d)  Such records shall be retained for a period of one year from the date of the transaction. 
(Ord. No. 2011-09, § 3, 5-9-11) 
Sec. 12-881. - Daily report. 
    It shall be the duty of the broker to complete and make available for the inspection by the chief of police or his designee before the hour of 12:00 noon, each and every business day, a copy of the records required to be kept under this article, reflecting the completed transactions of the previous day. 
(Ord. No. 2011-09, § 3, 5-9-11) 
Sec. 12-882. - Inspections. 
    The record as required above, the goods, articles, metals, stones or other things purchased, received or kept for sale or exchange, shall be open to inspection by any member of the police department of the village at all reasonable business times, or any person duly authorized in writing for such purpose by the chief of police as his or her designee. In any event that stolen property is identified during any inspection, the police department shall seize said stolen property and provide the precious metal and/or gem broker with a receipt identifying all items seized within 72 hours. 
(Ord. No. 2011-09, § 3, 5-9-11) 
Sec. 12-883. - Definitions. 
    Gems. Include, but are not limited to: Diamonds, opals, citrine, garnet, sapphire, ruby, emerald, tourmaline, quartz, turquoise, morganite, kunzite, topaz, aquamarine, zircon, tanzanite, alexandrite, coral, pearl, amethyst, apalite, jade, peridot, moonstone, lapis, malachite, iolite, diopside, tiger's eye, onyx, ivory, or any composition or jewelry containing any amount of said gems. 
    Precious metals. Include, but are not limited to: Any metal or alloy thereof containing any amount of gold, silver, sterling silver, platinum, copper, brass, nickel, palladium, rhodium, iridium, osmium, rhenium, mercury, indium, bismuth, or gallium, and includes U.S. minted currency containing any of the above metals. 
    Precious metals and/or gem broker. Any person having an interest in or employed by or acting as an agent of or on behalf of any person having an interest in a business whose undertakings involve the purchase or sale of precious metals or gems as defined herein in section 12-883, but excluding those persons or businesses licensed by the State of Illinois under the "Pawnbroker Regulation Act, 205 ILCS 510 et seq. 
(Ord. No. 2011-09, § 3, 5-9-11) 
Sec. 12-884. - Precious metals or gem brokers license required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in business within the corporate limits of the Village of Crete as a precious metals or gem broker, as defined hereinabove, without having first secured a license therefore from the Crete Village Clerk. 
(Ord. No. 2011-09, § 3, 5-9-11) 
Sec. 12-885. - Precious metals or gems brokers license application. 
(a)  Application for a precious metals or gems brokers license to the village clerk shall be made upon a form provided by the office of the village clerk. The applicant shall truthfully state in full the information requested on the application: 
(1)  Name; place of residence and length of residence at such address; Social Security Number; and date of birth. 
(2)  Identification: Copy of current state photo identification or driver's license. 
(3)  Date of previous application: The date, or approximate date, of the latest previous application for certificate under this chapter, if any. 
(4)  Revocation history: Whether a license issued to the applicant under this chapter has ever been revoked. 
(5)  Conviction of a violation; history: Whether the applicant has ever been convicted of a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter or the ordinance of any other Illinois municipality regulating the activities of a precious metals or gems broker license or similar such ordinances or laws of other jurisdictions otherwise named. 
(6)  Convictions history: Whether the applicant has ever been convicted of the commission of a felony under the laws of the State of Illinois or any other state or federal law of the United States, or had a legal disposition of a sentence for a crime involving theft or dishonesty. 
(b)  All statements made by the applicant upon the application or in connection therewith shall be under oath. 
(c)  Every applicant may be required to submit to fingerprinting by the police department in connection with the application for a precious metals or gem brokers license. The applicant shall pay the fee as set by the Illinois State Police for fingerprint submissions. 
(d)  The office of the village clerk shall cause to be kept an accurate record of every application received and acted upon together with all other information and data pertaining thereto and all brokers licenses issued under the provisions of this chapter and of the denial of applications. The clerk shall forward a copy of said record to the chief of police on a quarterly basis. 
(e)  No brokers license or broker's employee permit, shall be issued to any person who has been convicted of the commission of a felony under the law of the State of Illinois or federal law of the United States within five years of the date of the application; nor to any person who has been convicted of a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter, nor to any person who has been convicted of any criminal offense involving theft, possession of stolen property or dishonesty, or whose broker's license issued hereunder has previously been revoked as herein provided. 
(Ord. No. 2011-09, § 3, 5-9-11) 
Sec. 12-886. - License fee. 
    Each broker's license applicant shall pay a $375.00 application fee for the original application fee, and $250.00 for each annual renewal license application fee. Except, a person or business licensed by the village and State of Illinois to do business as a pawnbroker pursuant to 205 ILCS 510 et seq., shall not also be required to obtain a precious metals or gems broker's license. However, those licensed by the village and State of Illinois to transact business as pawnbrokers shall otherwise comply with all the rules and regulations established herein in sections 12-880 through 12-890 inclusive. Should there be any conflict between the terms of this article and the Pawnbroker's Regulation Act cited above, the provisions of the more restrictive law shall apply. 
(Ord. No. 2011-09, § 3, 5-9-11) 
Sec. 12-887. - Issuance of license for precious metals or gems broker's license. 
    The village clerk, after consideration of the application and all information obtained relative thereto, and after the return of the fingerprint check by the state police shall, within 30 business days, approve or deny the application. If the person does not possess the qualifications for a license, as herein required, and the issuance of a license to the applicant would not be in accord with the intent and purpose of this chapter, then the village clerk shall deny the application. If the applicant is found to be fully qualified, the license shall be issued so long as the application fees have been fully paid. 
(Ord. No. 2011-09, § 3, 5-9-11) 
Sec. 12-888. - Prohibitions. 
(a)  No broker licensed hereunder shall operate or allow its business to operate before the hour of 9:00 a.m. or after the hour of 9:00 p.m. 
(b)  No broker, broker's agent or employee shall accept any precious metal or gem as defined herein, from a minor under the age of 18, or person known to be under the influence of drugs or alcohol, or any person known to him/her to have been convicted of a felony, theft or crime of dishonesty. 
(c)  No broker, broker's agent or employee shall sell, transfer, exchange, or dispose of, or melt, transfigure or transform from the design and form in which it was received any precious metal or gem as defined herein within seven days of the date it was received. 
(Ord. No. 2011-09, § 3, 5-9-11) 
Sec. 12-889. - Employee permit. 
    No broker shall allow an agent, employee or other person to act on his behalf transacting any purchase, sale, exchange or other transfer of any precious metal or gem as defined herein in section 12-883, until such agent, employee, or person has applied for and been approved by the village of a broker's employee permit. A broker's employee permit application shall be provided by the village clerk. The employee permit applicant shall be subject to the same processing regulations, rules and prohibitions as established herein and imposed upon a broker license applicant by section 12-885. The cost of fingerprinting shall be borne by the employee permit applicant or broker, and paid at the time the permit application is made. The fee for an employee permit shall be $50.00 to be paid to the village clerk at the time application is made. 
(Ord. No. 2011-09, § 3, 5-9-11) 
Sec. 12-890. - Penalties and enforcement. 
(a)  Violations of this article shall be civil in nature and prosecuted under the terms of the Village of Crete Administrative Adjudication Ordinance and the rules and regulations contained therein. Fines for violations may be imposed up to $750.00 per incident. 
(b)  A broker's license or employee permit may be suspended or revoked in the sole discretion of the village president, if after properly written notice to the licensee and hearing by the village president, or his/her designee, it is determined by a preponderance of the evidence that said broker, broker's agent or employee committed a criminal offense in the operation of the licensed business, and especially, any criminal offense involving, dishonesty, theft, or the transfer or possession of stolen property. 
(Ord. No. 2011-09, § 3, 5-9-11) 
Secs. 12-891-12-1000. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XLI. - PENALTIES[27] 

Footnotes: 
--- (27) --- 
Editor's note- Section 2 of Ordinance No. 2011-09, adopted May 9, 2011 renumbered existing art. XL "Penalties" to art. XLI, as set out herein. 

Sec. 12-1001. - Penalty; compromise payment. 
(a)  Whosoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of an offense and fined not less than $100.00, nor more than $750.00. Except when fines and costs are paid by compromise payment as provided in subsection (b) below prior to court, the court clerk shall add to the fine any and all costs and fees upon an authorized disposition. 
(b)  Any person accused of a violation of this chapter may settle and compromise said claim without a court appearance by payment of one half of the minimum required fine to the village clerk at the village hall within ten business days of the date of violation if the compromise box designation is so checked on the complaint and notice to appear form. 
(Ord. No. 2003-35, § 2, 9-22-03; Ord. No. 2006-43, § 9, 12-11-06)
