Sec. 13-2. - Disturbing assemblages. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to disturb any lawful assemblage or gathering in the village. 
(Ord. No. 583, § 10.12.3.8, 1-10-66) 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to prevent disorderly conduct, 65 ILCS 5/11-5-3. 
Sec. 13-3. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2001-01, § 2, adopted Jan. 8. 2001, repealed § 13-3, Hunting, derived from Ord. No. 5-83, § 10.12.3.9, 1-10-66. 
Sec. 13-4. - Advertising unlawful business. 
    It shall be unlawful to advertise any unlawful business or article in the village. It shall be unlawful to advertise any gambling house or gambling resort in any street, alley or public place within the village. 
(Ord. No. 583, §§ 10.12.1.4, 10.12.3.13, 1-10-66) 
Sec. 13-5. - Discharge of firearms. 
    It shall be unlawful to discharge any firearms or airgun in the village. This section shall not be construed to prohibit any officer of the law to discharge a firearm in the performance of his duty, nor to prohibit any citizen from discharging a firearm when lawfully defending his person or property. 
(Ord. No. 583, § 10.12.3.16, 1-10-66) 
Sec. 13-6. - Fireworks. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to give any pyrotechnic display in the village, except in connection with public exhibitions as is herein provided. 
(b)  No public exhibition of fireworks or pyrotechnics shall be given unless a permit therefor is first secured from the president and board of trustees. All such public displays shall be under the supervision of a competent person, and shall be superintended by the chief of police or some other member of the police department assigned to this duty by him. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, store, offer for sale or keep for the purpose of selling any fireworks. 
(Code 1965, § 10.1.1) 
Sec. 13-7. - Vandalism. 
(a)  Acts of vandalism resulting in damage to real or personal property within this village have increased, posing a threat to the value of property and the welfare of residents. It is in the best interest of the village that such acts be prosecuted by the village as a local offense; that penalties therefor be imposed which are related to the nature of the act and the type of offender; and that parents or legal guardians of minors found guilty of such acts be held responsible for any monetary penalty or order of restitution or reparation imposed. The diligent pursuit of such interest will tend to increase parental supervision of minors and reduce the incidence of juvenile vandalism, thus advancing the welfare of residents of the village. 
(b)  For the purposes of this section, the following definitions shall apply: 
(1)  Legal guardian shall include a person appointed guardian, or given custody, of a minor by a circuit court of this state, but does not include a person appointed guardian, or given custody of a minor under the Juvenile Court Act. 
(2)  Minor shall mean a person who has attained 11 years of age but who has not yet reached 18 years of age. 
(3)  Marking graffiti is defined as placing any letter, word, symbol, drawing, name or any mark whatsoever upon public property or in the public way or upon private property, real or personal, without the permission of the owner, using paint, marker or any fluid or solid, or by etching. 
(c)  No person shall: 
(1)  Knowingly or recklessly damage any property of another person without his consent; or 
(2)  Knowingly and without authority enter into or obtain control over any motor vehicle, bicycle, aircraft or watercraft or any part thereof of another person without his consent. 
(3)  Performing marking of graffiti or assisting another in the marking of graffiti. 
(d)  Every person found guilty of violating subsection (c) shall be subject to either or both of the following penalties: 
(1)  A fine not in excess of an amount listed in article V of chapter 2 immediately to the right of the reference to section 13-7. 
(2)  A period of conditional discharge not to exceed one year. 
(e)  The conditions of a conditional discharge shall include that the defendant: 
(1)  Not violate any criminal statute or quasicriminal ordinance of any jurisdiction; and 
(2)  Report to and appear in person before such person or agency as directed by the court. 
(f)  The conditions of conditional discharge may, in addition, require that the defendant: 
(1)  Work or pursue a course of study or vocational training; 
(2)  Undergo medical or psychiatric treatment for drug addiction or alcoholism; 
(3)  Make restitution or reparation in an amount not to exceed actual loss or damage to property and pecuniary loss; and 
(4)  If a minor, to reside with his parent or in a foster home; attend school; attend a nonresidential program for youth; or contribute to his own support at home or in a foster home. 
(g)  When a court orders restitution or reparation as a condition for conditional discharge the court shall determine the amount and conditions of payment. When the conditions of payment have not been satisfied, the court, at any time prior to the expiration or termination of the period of conditional discharge may impose an additional period of not more than two years. Only the conditions of payment shall continue to apply during such additional period. The court shall retain all of the incidents of the original sentence, including the authority to modify or enlarge the original conditions and to revoke the penalty of conditional discharge if the conditions of payment are violated during such additional period. 
(h)  When a petition is filed charging a violation of a condition imposed for conditional discharge, the court: 
(1)  May order summons to the offender to appear; or order a warrant for the offender's arrest where there is danger of his fleeing the jurisdiction or causing serious harm to others or when the offender fails to answer a summons. The issuance of such warrant or summons shall stay the sentence of conditional discharge until the final determination of the charge, and the term of conditional discharge shall not run so long as the offender has not answered the summons or warrant. 
(2)  Shall conduct a hearing of the alleged violation. The court may admit the offender to bail pending the hearing. 
(3)  Shall receive evidence in open court with the right of confrontation, cross examination and representation by counsel. The village has the burden of going forward with the evidence and proving the violation by the preponderance of the evidence. 
(4)  Shall not revoke a conditional discharge for failure to comply with conditions of a sentence which imposes financial obligations upon the offender unless such failure is due to his wilful refusal to pay. 
(5)  May modify the conditions of a conditional discharge on motion of the village or on its own motion or at the request of the offender after notice to all parties and a hearing. 
(i)  If the court finds that the offender has violated a condition at any time prior to the expiration or termination of the period, it may continue the offender on the existing period, with or without modifying or enlarging the conditions, or may impose any other penalty that was available at the time of the initial penalty. 
(j)  A judgment revoking probation or conditional discharge is a final appealable order. 
(k)  The parent or legal guardian of a minor defendant who resides with such parent or legal guardian shall be liable for any fine or condition of restitution or reparation imposed by a court upon a minor for violation of this section, provided that the minor has not paid said fine or made restitution or reparation within the time ordered by the court, and further provided that the parent or legal guardian has been served with summons or notice to appear in the original cause and all proceedings thereafter as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 761, § 1(10.13), 6-27-77; Ord. No. 86-13A, § 1, 1-5-87; Ord. No. 94-19, § 6, 9-26-94) 
State Law reference- Penalty for ordinance violations, 65 ILCS 5/1-2-1, 5/1-2-1.1. 
Sec. 13-8. - Public intoxication. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to be in an intoxicated condition on or in any street, alley or public place of the village. 
(Ord. No. 583, § 10.12.3.2, 1-10-66) 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to prohibit intoxication, 65 ILCS 5/11-5-3. 
Sec. 13-9. - Public bathing. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to bathe at any public place or in any place open to public view unless such person is adequately garbed in a bathing suit. 
(Ord. No. 583, § 10.12.3.17, 1-10-66) 
Sec. 13-10. - Scaffolds. 
    Any scaffolds or ladders placed in such a position that they overhang or can fall onto any public street, alley or other public way in the village shall be firmly and properly constructed and safeguarded; it shall be unlawful to place or leave any tools or articles on any such place in such a manner that the same can fall onto such street, sidewalk or other public way from a greater height than four feet. 
(Ord. No. 583, § 10.12.3.19, 1-10-66) 
Sec. 13-11. - Articles on windows. 
    It shall be unlawful to place any moveable article on any window ledge, or other place abutting on a public street, alley or other public place at a height above four feet from the ground, in such a manner that the same can or is in danger of falling onto such street, sidewalk or other public place. 
(Ord. No. 583, § 10.12.3.20, 1-10-66) 
Sec. 13-12. - Posting bills. 
    It shall be unlawful to post any bills or advertisements on any public property without the authority of the board of trustees. It shall be unlawful to post any bill or advertisement on any property without the written consent of the owner thereof. 
(Ord. No. 583, § 10.12.3.18, 1.10-66) 
Sec. 13-13. - Water pollution or obstruction of water-supply. 
    It shall be unlawful and a nuisance for any person to obstruct or pollute any watercourse or source of water supply in the village. 
(Code 1965, § 5.3.3) 
Sec. 13-14. - Throwing missiles. 
    It shall be unlawful to cast, throw, or propel any missile on any street, alley or public place. 
(Code 1965, § 10.12.3.12; Ord. No. 583, 1-10-66) 
Sec. 13-15. - Public gatherings. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to hold, manage or conduct any meeting or entertainment of any kind in the village, in any premises other than a building constructed in full compliance with the ordinances and laws pertaining thereto for auditorium, theater or lodge room purposes, except in compliance with the following provisions: 
(1)  Inspections. No such gathering or entertainment shall be held or presented in any premises other than a building as described above unless such premises have been examined by the fire marshal or building inspector not more than three days before the date of such gathering and found to be free from any fire hazard and found to be suitable for the purpose. No structure enclosed by a roof shall be used for such purpose unless the same is constructed of nonflammable materials. Provided that tents or structures covered by canvas or similar materials may be so used if such canvas or other material has been properly treated so as to be rendered fire-resistive. 
(2)  Exits. Adequate unobstructed exits shall be provided in all premises used for such purposes to permit rapid egress of all persons attending, and there shall be at least two separate exits located at least 30 feet from each other. There shall be two lineal feet of doorway or exit space for each 100 people accommodated. 
(3)  Seats. Any stands or rows of seats used in such premises shall be so constructed as to be safe for the use designated, and shall be sufficiently strong to carry the same weight and stress as is required for the construction of the auditorium floors of theater buildings, not less than 100 pounds per square foot. It shall be unlawful to admit to any such premises a number of persons to exceed the number of actual seats maintained for their accommodation. 
(4)  Doors. All doors or gates on exits from premises used for such purposes shall open outward and no such exit shall be so constructed or locked that egress from inside the premises is blocked. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of any person conducting, calling for or managing any gathering in any premises other than a theater, lodge room or auditorium building constructed as provided in subsection (a), to notify the village clerk of the date of such intended use at least ten days before such meeting is to take place; upon such notice the fire marshal and/or the building inspector are authorized to inspect the premises to determine whether or not they comply with the provisions hereof. Any permit issued for any such gathering shall be subject to the condition that this section be fully complied with, whether or not such condition is embodied in the permit. 
(Code 1965, §§ 10.4.1-10.4.6) 
Cross reference- Public buildings, § 9-51 et seq. 
Sec. 13-16. - Curfew for minors; parental responsibility. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of 18 years to be in any street or alley or other public place in the village at the following times: 
(1)  For persons less than 13 years of age, between 9:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. the following day on any day of the week. 
(2)  For persons at least 13 years of age, but not yet 18 years of age: 
a.  Between 11:00 p.m. on Sunday through Thursday, inclusive, and 6:00 a.m. the following day. 
b.  Between 12:01 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. on Saturday or Sunday. 
(b)  It is a defense to a violation under this chapter that the child engaged in the prohibited conduct while: 
(1)  Accompanied by the child's parent, legal guardian, custodian or sibling, stepbrother or stepsister at least 18 years of age; 
(2)  Accompanied by an adult at least 21 years of age approved by the child's parent, guardian, or custodian; 
(3)  Participating in, going directly to, or returning directly from said event: 
a.  Employment which the laws of this state authorize a person less than 18 years of age to perform; 
b.  A school recreational activity; 
c.  A religious event; 
d.  An emergency involving the protection of a person or property from an imminent threat of serious bodily injury or substantial damage; 
e.  An activity involving the exercise of the child's rights protected under the First Amendment to the United States Constitution or Article 1, Sections 3, 4 and 5 of the Constitution of the State of Illinois, or both; 
f.  An activity conducted by a nonprofit or governmental entity that provides recreation, education, training, or other care under the supervision of one or more adult. 
A citation for violation of subsection (a) of this section may be issued by a police officer only if he reasonably believes that a violation has occurred and none of the defenses enumerated in subsection (b) apply. 
(c)  It is unlawful for a parent, legal guardian, custodian, or other person to knowingly permit a person in his custody or control to violate the provisions of subsection (a) of this section. It shall be a rebuttable presumption that a person has violated this section if someone under 17 years of age of whom such person has custody or control is present upon any public assembly, building, business, street or highway or other public place or public way in violation of subsection (a) of this section, and none of the defenses enumerated in subsection (b) hereof apply. 
(d)  Any person convicted of a violation of this section shall be fined an amount [from] $75.00 to $500.00. 
(Code 1965, §§ 10.7.1-10.7.4; Ord. No. 600, § 1, 5-8-67; Ord. No. 2004-15, § 1, 4-26-04) 
State Law reference- Curfew authorized, 65 ILCS 5/11-1-5. 
Sec. 13-17. - Interference with village officers or employees. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to interfere with or hinder any officer or employee of the village engaged in the duties of his office. 
(Code 1965, § 1.18.10) 
Sec. 13-18. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2001-01, § 3, adopted Jan. 8. 2001, repealed § 13-18, Escape from village jail, derived from the 1965 Code, § 1.19.5. 
Sec. 13-19. - Communications with prisoners in village jail. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to communicate with any prisoner held in the village jail without the permission of the keeper of the jail. 
(Code 1965, § 1.19.6) 
Sec. 13-20. - Display of sexually explicit materials to minors. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person having custody, control or supervision of any commercial establishment, open to persons under the age of 18 to display a book, pamphlet, newspaper, magazine, posted, image, record, recording tape, video tape, or motion picture film, the cover of which depicts, in whole or in part, any of the following: 
(1)  Human sexual intercourse, masturbation, sodomy or bestiality; 
(2)  Fondling or other erotic touching of human genitals, pubic region, buttocks, or female breasts; 
(3)  Less than completely and opaquely covered human genitals, buttocks, or that portion of the female breast below the top of the areola; 
(4)  Human male genitals in a discernibly turgid state, whether covered or uncovered; 
(5)  Sado-masochistic conduct; 
(6)  Human excretory function; or 
(7)  Any device or covering which is intended to give the appearance of or simulate any human body part or activity listed in subsections (1) through (6) above. 
(b)  As used in this section, the term "display" means to locate an item in such a manner that, without obtaining assistance from an employee of the commercial establishment, such item is available to the general public for handling and inspection, or, the cover or outside packaging of such item is visible to members of the general public. 
(c)  Any item regulated by this section shall not be deemed to be "available to the general public" if such item is located in a separate room in relation to which persons under the age of 18 are prohibited access and the items contained in such room are not visible by the general public from a position outside of such separate room. In this connection, it shall be the duty of the person having custody, control or supervision of such separate room to post in a conspicuous place a sign which prohibits the entry of persons under the age of 18 to such separate room. Also, it shall be the duty of the person having custody, control or supervision of such commercial establishment to actively enforce the age restriction imposed herein and to make a reasonable attempt to ascertain the true age of any person desiring access to the separate room by requiring production of driver's license, birth certificate, or other governmental or educational identification card or paper. 
(d)  It shall be an affirmative defense to any prosecution under this section that the material involved in such charge or complaint was displayed or disseminated by a person or persons under the age of 18 years of age while such person or persons were employed by a person having custody, control or supervision of such materials as defined as sexually explicit in this section for appropriate commercial purposes, or displayed, presented or disseminated to a person at a recognized and established school, church, museum, medical clinic, hospital, public library, governmental agency, and persons acting in their capacity as employees or agents of such persons or organizations, provided that such display, presentation or dissemination is in aid of a legitimate scientific, governmental, or education purpose. 
(Ord. No. 87-42, § 2, 12-28-87) 
Sec. 13-21. - Nudity and seminudity prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person or entity having a liquor license under any provision of the Crete Municipal Code, or any agent, officer or employee of any such person or entity, to knowingly allow or otherwise participate in any kind of agreement or arrangement by virtue of which any person is allowed or required to appear before or amidst the public, in attendance at an establishment to which said license has been issued, in the nude or in any kind of apparel, which as worn or by virtue of its design, fit or material, makes visible or tends to make visible all or any portion of such person's: (1) genitalia; (2) pubic hair or pubic hair region; (3) anus and/or anal crevice; and (4) if such person is a female, her breast at, below and including the areola. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to appear or enter into any kind of agreement or arrangement which allows or requires such person (or persons) to appear before or amidst the public, in attendance at an establishment licensed under any provisions of the Crete Municipal Code, in the nude or in apparel permitting visibility of all or any portion of such person's anatomy as described in subsection (a) hereof. 
(c)  Any person or entity having a liquor license under any provision of the Crete Municipal Code, or any agent, officer or employee of any such person or entity, who is convicted of a violation of this section shall be fined and/or sanctioned in accordance with the general penalties provision of the Municipal Code of the Village of Crete, as provided in section 1-10. 
(Ord. No. 90-33, § 1, 9-24-90) 
Sec. 13-22. - Unlawful possession of paint, marking instruments or etching equipment. 
(a)  For the purposes of this section, the following definitions shall apply: 
(1)  Etching equipment means any tool, device, equipment, acid or material that can be used to make permanent marks on metal, glass, plastic, concrete or stone. 
(2)  Prohibited marking instrument means any marker or device which can be used to mark which contains a fluid which is not water soluble and has a point, brush, applicator or other writing surface of three-eighths of an inch or greater. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of 18 years to possess paint in a spray can or any prohibited marking instrument unless under the direct supervision of a parent or legal guardian, or while as a student under the direct supervision of their teacher, or while as an employee under the direct supervision of their employer or adult representative of their employer. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to possess paint in a spray can, liquid paint in any type of container or any prohibited marking instrument on the property of another, or on public property or in or on any public building, structure or facility. It shall be a defense to any action for violation of this subsection (c) that the owner, manager or other person having control of the property, building, structure or facility consented to the presence of the paint or prohibited marking instrument. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to possess paint in a spray can, liquid paint in any type of container, any prohibited marking instrument, or etching equipment while on the public way, or on any public property with intent to utilize to deface, paint, mark or etch any building, structure or property. 
(e)  Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be fined an amount as set forth in article V of chapter 2 under the designation of section 13-22. 
(Ord. No. 94-19, § 7, 9-26-94) 
Sec. 13-23. - Possession of drug paraphernalia. 
(a)  The following provisions of the Drug Paraphernalia Control Act (720 ILCS 600/1 et seq.), as amended, are hereby adopted by reference as if set out at length herein: 
Section 600/2 Definitions; 
Section 600/3.5 Possession of drug paraphernalia; 
Section 600/4 Exempt items-Determinations; 
Section 600/5 Forfeiture and seizure of property; 
Section 600/6 Legislative intent-Inference of legitimacy. 
(Ord. No. 2001-01, § 4, 1-8-01) 
Sec. 13-24. - Underage possession of a tobacco product. 
(a)  For the purpose of this section, the following definitions shall apply: 
    Tobacco products shall mean any substance containing tobacco leaf, including, but not limited to, cigarettes, cigars, pipe tobacco, snuff, chewing tobacco or dipping tobacco. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of 18 years to purchase or possess any tobacco product; provided, that the possession by a person under the age of 18 years under the direct supervision of the parent or guardian of such person or in the minor's or parent or guardian's home shall not be prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 2001-01, § 5, 1-8-01) 
Sec. 13-25. - Littering prohibited. 
(a)  The following provisions of the Litter Control Act (415 ILCS 105/1 et seq.), as amended, are hereby adopted by reference as if set out at length herein: 
Section 105/2 Legislative findings and determination; 
Section 105/3 Definitions; 
Section 105/4 Dumping, deposit, etc. of litter prohibited; exemptions; 
Section 105/5 Dumping, deposit, etc. from motor vehicle prohibited; deposit of garbage or refuse in receptacles along public highways; 
Section 105/6 Accumulation of litter prohibited; 
Section 105/7 Abandonment of motor vehicle; presumption; 
Section 105/9 Presumption of violation by operator-throwing, deposit, etc., of litter from motor vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 2001-01, § 6, 1-8-01) 
Sec. 13-26. - Truancy prohibited. 
(a)  The following provisions of the School Code Article 26, Pupils -Compulsory Attendance Statute (105 ILCS 5/26-1 et seq.), as amended, are hereby adopted by reference as if set out at length herein: 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of 18 years who is enrolled in any public, private or parochial school to be present in any public place, building, street or assembly in the village other than school, during any hours when school is in session during the regular school term unless he or she is: 
(1)  Traveling to or from school by the most direct route; or 
(2)  Accompanied by a parent, legal guardian or school official; or 
(3)  Engaged in school-related activities with written approval of school authorities; or 
(4)  Engaged in personal business, including but not limited to employment, medical care or religious activities, with prior notice from a parent or legal guardian to school authorities. 
(c)  A police officer may stop and detain a person whom the officer reasonably suspects to be violating this section for the purpose of verifying the person's identity, age, school enrollment, and authority to be absent from school. The police officer shall immediately inform the person of the reason of the detention and they will be released upon verification of the authorization to be absent from school. The person shall not be removed from the scene of the investigatory detention unless he refused to provide the officer with the necessary information. 
(d)  A person violating this section shall be issued a notice to appear in the municipal court and, if practical, shall be taken to school authorities or a parent or legal guardian. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for a parent, legal guardian or other person having custody or control of any person subject to this section to knowingly permit such person to violate this section. 
(Ord. No. 20011-01, § 7, 1-8-01) 
Sec. 13-27. - Fighting, noise, riot and other breaches of peace. 
    No person shall: 
(1)  Engage in, cause or provoke any fight, brawl or riotous conduct; or 
(2)  Make, aid, countenance or assist in making, any improper noise, riot, disturbance, diversion or other breach of the peace, or use threatening, abusive or profane language or obscene gestures toward any person, leading to a breach of the peace, in the streets or elsewhere in the village; or 
(3)  Jostle or roughly crowd another person unnecessarily in a public place or on school grounds or elsewhere in the village. 
(Ord. No. 2005-06, § 2, 2-28-05) 
Sec. 13-28. - Defacing exterior building wall murals. 
    No person shall mark, paint, injure or in any other manner deface, whether or not permanent damage is caused, any exterior wall mural created pursuant to chapter 19, article III of the Crete Municipal Code. 
(Ord. No. 2007-38, § 3, 11-26-07) 
Sec. 13-29. - Unlawful possession of weapon on school grounds by persons under 21 years of age. 
(a)  A person commits the offense of unlawful possession of a weapon on school grounds when he or she, while under the age of 21 years: 
(1)  Carries or possesses any knife, razor or device containing an edge that can be used for cutting, including but not limited to, folding, antique, household and commerative knives; or 
(2)  Carries or possesses a club, bat, bludgeon, black-jack, slung-shot or sand-club; or 
(3)  Carries or possesses any firearm ammunition or cartridge; or 
(4)  Carries or possesses any tear gas gun projector or bomb or any object containing noxious liquid gas or substance; or 
(5)  Carries or possesses any stun gun or taser or any other dangerous or deadly weapon or instrument of like character which uses electricity to give a shock to another individual while protecting the possessor by design from receiving a simultaneous shock; or 
(6)  Carries or possesses any firearm which emits a projectile using air, gas or a spring device; or 
(7)  Carries or possesses a look-a-like device described in sections (a)(1) through (6) above or a look-a-like firearm. 
(b)  Defined terms. For the purposes of this section: 
    Firearm ammunition or cartridge means a tubular metal or plastic case having a projectile affixed at the front thereof and a cap or primer at the rear end thereof, with the propellant contained in such tube between the projectile and the cap. 
    Look-a-like device means any object which is designed, fashioned or held in such manner that a reasonable person in seeing the object or outline of the object would believe the object to be one of the items described herein, which the ordinance from which this section derives makes unlawful to carry or possess. 
    Person means any person under the age of 21 years who is not an employee of the school where the act of carrying or possession occurs. 
    School grounds means the real or improved property of any public or private elementary or secondary school and any administration building or grounds regardless of the time of day or the time of year and any public way within 500 feet of said real property. 
    Stun gun or taser means: (i) any device which is powered by electrical charging units, such as, batteries, and which fires one or several barbs attached to a length of wire and which, upon hitting a human, can send out a current capable of disrupting the person's nervous system in such a manner as to render him incapable of normal functioning; or (ii) any device which is powered by electrical charging units, such as batteries and which, upon contact with a human or clothing worn by a human, can send out current capable of disrupting the person's nervous system in such a manner as to render him incapable of normal functioning. 
(c)  Exemption. It is not a violation of subsection (a) for any enrolled student to utilize an object described in subsection (a)(1) while participating in shop class or any school authorized and supervised activity, e.g., homecoming float preparation, dance decoration, etc., if said object is approved by school officials. It is not a violation of subsection (a) for any person to utilize an object described in subsection (a)(1) while engaged in consuming foods in an authorized dining or eating area at a school authorized time if said object is approved by school officials. It is not a violation of subsection (a) for any enrolled student or enrolled student from another school to utilize authorized sporting equipment while engaged in school sponsored or authorized sport activities. 
(d)  If any person has previously been convicted of a felony or an unlawful use of weapon charge under any state statute and is in violation of both this section and 720 ILCS Article 24, Deadly Weapons, said person shall be charged under the applicable state statute. 
(Ord. No. 2008-36, § 2, 9-8-08) 
Secs. 13-30-13-59. - Reserved. 
Sec. 13-60. - Statutes adopted by reference as ordinance violations. 
    Those certain portions of the Illinois Compiled Statutes adopted by reference in this chapter shall be subject to all applicable definitions, defenses and presumptions provided for by state law; provided, however, that guilt need only be established by a preponderance of the evidence. 
(Ord. No. 2001-01, § 8, 1-8-01) 
Secs. 13-61-13-69. - Reserved. 
Sec. 13-70. - Penalties. 
(a)  Whosoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of a petty offense and fined not less than $100.00 or more than $750.00. Except when fines and costs paid by compromise payment are prepaid prior to court or the violator fails to appear in court, or at the administrative hearing, the court, court clerk or hearing officer shall add to the mandatory minimum fine any and all costs and fees upon an authorized disposition. 
(b)  Any person accused of a violation of an ordinance section listed herein in subsection (c) below may settle and compromise said claim without a court appearance by payment of one-half of the minimum required fine to the village clerk at the village hall within ten business days of the date of violation if the compromise box designation is so checked on the complaint and notice to appear form. 
(c)  Those ordinance sections subject to compromise payment from this chapter are as follows: 
16B Protection of library materials; 
5/26-3 Use of a facsimile machine in unsolicited advertising or fundraising; 
505/1 Abandonment of refrigerators, ice boxes, or ice chests prohibited; 
535/3 Carrying or discharging on public streets (Air Rifle Act); 
13-24 Underage possession of a tobacco product; 
13-25 Littering; 
410 ILCS 82/1 et seq. Smoke Free Illinois Act. 
(Ord. No. 2001-01, § 9, 1-8-01; Ord. No. 2006-43, § 10, 12-11-06; Ord. No. 2008-04, § 5, 1-14-08; Ord. No. 2010-02, § 2, 2-8-10) 
Chapter 14 - MOBILE HOME PARKS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Fees and fines schedule, § 2-301; mobile home sales lots, § 12-551 et seq., parking of house trailers at motels, § 12-572; planning and development, ch. 19; zoning, ch. 28; special use permits for mobile home parks, § 28-166. 
State Law reference- Mobile Home Park Act, 210 ILCS 115/1 et seq. 

Sec. 14-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Mobile home: A structure designed for permanent habitation and so constructed as to permit its transport on wheels, temporarily or permanently attached to its frame, from the place of its construction to the location, or subsequent locations, at which it is intended to be a permanent habitation and designed to permit the occupancy thereof as a dwelling place for one or more persons, provided that any such structure served by individual utilities and resting on a permanent foundation, with wheels, tongue and hitch permanently removed, shall not be construed as a "mobile home." 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 210 ILCS 115/2.1. 
    Mobile home park: A tract of land or two or more contiguous tracts of lands upon which five or more independent mobile homes are located for permanent habitation either free of charge or for revenue purposes, and shall include any building, structure, tent, vehicle, or enclosure used or intended for use as a part of the equipment of such mobile home park. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.48.1) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 210 ILCS 115/2.5. 
Sec. 14-2. - License. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to establish, maintain or operate any mobile home park in the village without first having obtained a license therefor. Application for such license shall be made in writing to the clerk in compliance with the ordinances relating to license applications, and shall contain the name of the applicant, the location of the proposed park, and the number of trailers to be accommodated. Each such application shall be accompanied by a plat or sketch showing the size and location of all buildings and structures. 
(b)  The annual fee for such a license shall be in an amount as set forth in article V of chapter 2 immediately to the right of the reference to section 14-2. 
(c)  No such license shall be issued to any but a person of good character, nor to any corporation if any officer thereof is not a person of good character. 
(Code 1965, §§ 2.2.48.2, 2.2.48.4, 2.2.48.5; Ord. No. 820, § 1, 4-28-80; Ord. No. 86-13A, § 1, 1-5-87) 
State Law reference- Municipal licensing of mobile home parks, 210 ILCS 115/18. 
Sec. 14-3. - Supervision. 
    A mobile home park shall be in the charge of a responsible attendant or caretaker at all times, who shall be responsible, with the licensee hereunder, for the compliance with the provisions of this article relating to the conduct of such parks. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.48.6) 
Sec. 14-4. - Moral character of employees. 
    It shall be unlawful to hire or keep as manager, superintendent or person in charge of a trailer camp any person who is not a person of good character, or any person who has been convicted of a felony. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.48.6) 
Sec. 14-5. - Mobile home spaces. 
    Each mobile home in a mobile home park shall be allotted a site of not less than 1,000 square feet. No mobile home shall be parked closer than five feet to the side lot lines of the park, if the abutting property is improved property, or closer than ten feet to a public street, alley or building. Each individual mobile home site shall abut or face on a driveway or clear unoccupied space of not less than 20 feet in width, which space shall have unobstructed access to a public highway or alley. There shall be an open space of at least ten feet between the sides of every mobile home and at least five feet between the ends of every mobile home. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.48.7) 
Sec. 14-6. - Water supply. 
(a)  An adequate supply of pure water for drinking and domestic purposes from the village water supply system shall be supplied to meet the requirements of the mobile home park. The water shall be obtained only from faucets, conveniently located in said camp. No common drinking cups shall be permitted. A water meter shall be installed in each mobile home park. 
(b)  If obtained from private wells, the water shall meet the bacteriological standards of the state for a safe drinking water. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.48.8) 
Sec. 14-7. - Sanitary facilities. 
    Each mobile home park shall provide toilets, baths or showers which shall comply with the provisions of the ordinances relating thereto, with separate accommodations for men and women. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.48.9) 
Sec. 14-8. - Garbage. 
    It shall be the duty of the owner, his agent or caretaker to provide for the collection and removal of garbage and other waste material and to otherwise maintain the mobile home park in a clean and sanitary condition. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.48.10) 
Sec. 14-9. - Lights. 
    The park shall be kept properly and adequately lighted at all times so that the grounds shall be safe for occupants and visitors. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.48.11) 
Chapter 15 - NOISE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Fees and fines schedule, § 2-301; nuisances, ch. 16; noise at go cart tracks, § 12-162. 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to suppress noise, 65 ILCS 5/11-5-2. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 15-1-15-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SOUND AMPLIFIERS 

Sec. 15-16. - License. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to maintain or operate any loudspeaker or amplifier connected with any radio, phonograph, microphone, or other device by which sounds are magnified and made heard over any public street or public place without first having secured a license therefor. Any person desiring a license for the use or operation of such devices, shall file an application therefor with the village clerk, upon a form provided by him, setting forth the name and address of the applicant, the name of the owner of such device, the date upon which it is intended to be used, and such other information as may be prescribed. The fee to be paid for such a license shall be in the amount as set forth in article V of chapter 2 immediately to the right of the reference to section 15-16. Such license shall be issued upon the payment of the license fee to the village clerk, and shall permit the use of any such device subject to the terms and conditions of this article, only upon the date specified on such license and no other. 
(b)  Subsection (a) shall not apply to radios in homes or in private pleasure vehicles, when the same are operated in such a manner as not to be audible at a distance of 50 feet from such vehicle, nor to noisy devices, bands or other musical devices used in any public parade in accordance with the ordinances of the village. 
(Code 1965, §§ 10.6.1-10.6.5; Ord. No. 86-13A, § 1, 1-5-87) 
Sec. 15-17. - Time and location restrictions. 
(a)  No person shall use or generate or employ any device licensed pursuant to the provisions of this article within the village limits at any time other than: 
Sunday through Thursday 8:00 a.m.-10:00 p.m. Friday through Saturday 8:00 a.m.-10:30 p.m.  
(b)  No person shall use, operate or employ any device licensed pursuant to the provisions of this article within a radius of two blocks from any hospital or within the radius of two blocks from any church or other place of public worship while services are being held there. 
(Code 1965, § 10.6.5; Ord. No. 2004-36, § 2, 10-11-04) 
Sec. 15-18. - Prohibited noise. 
    No person shall cause or permit to be emanated or emitted from any device for which a license is required by this article any noise which can be reasonably expected to provoke a breach of the peace, or any false representation of any matter, product, or project advertised thereby, the sale of which is prohibited by any law, ordinance or statute. 
(Code 1965, § 10.6.5) 
Chapter 16 - NUISANCES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Animals and fowl, ch. 5; buildings which are unsafe under building code, § 6-35; noise, ch. 15. 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to define, prevent and abate nuisances, 65 ILCS 5/11-60-2. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 16-1. - Prohibited generally. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to commit or do any act which endangers the public health or results in annoyance or discomfort to the public. It shall be unlawful for any person to permit or maintain the existence of any nuisance on any property under his control. 
(b)  For the purposes of this subsection the term "public nuisance" shall be defined as any activity, inactivity, neglect, omission, commission, abandonment, inadvertent or otherwise, or the like, which does, or tends to, permits, or results in a condition or conditions or circumstances which deleteriously affects the public health, public safety, public welfare, public morals, public sensibilities, public rights and enjoyment of residence or property, panders to vicious tastes, creates attractive nuisances for minors, results in dilapidated, abandoned and dangerous buildings or improvements or unfinished or uncompleted improvements on real property, permits the growth of noxious or poisonous weeds or growth and accumulation of trash dumps or the like. Any person who shall be responsible for the maintenance of a public nuisance shall be guilty of an offense. 
(c)  For the purposes of this section, public nuisance shall also include any refusal, failure, inactivity, inattention or neglect by the property owner, or person having control or possession of the property, whether inadvertent or not, concerning the removal or covering of graffiti, or letters, words, symbols, drawing, names or marks placed upon private property, real or personal, occurring 48 hours after notification by the village to remove or cover said graffiti or marks. Any person who shall create or maintain a public nuisance involving graffiti shall be guilty of an offense. Any person violating the provisions of this subsection (c) shall be fined at least $50.00, but not more than $500.00. Each day a public nuisance involving graffiti exists shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1965, §§ 5.3.8, 5.3.11; Ord. No. 612, §§ 1, 2, 10-12-67; Ord. No. 94-19, § 9, 9-26-94) 
Sec. 16-2. - Abatement. 
    The chief of police and the health officer are each hereby authorized to abate any nuisance existing in the village, whether such nuisance is specifically recognized by ordinance or not. 
(Code 1965, § 5.3.11) 
Sec. 16-3. - Stagnant water. 
    Any stagnant pool of water in the village is hereby declared to be a nuisance. It shall be unlawful for any person to permit any such nuisance to remain or exist on any property under his or its control. 
(Code 1965, § 5.3.4) 
Sec. 16-4. - Refuse. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to deposit anywhere in the village any uncovered piles of refuse, garbage, offal or carcasses of dead animals. Such refuse must be buried at least two feet below the surface of the ground or burned in properly constructed incinerators or otherwise properly disposed of. Any uncovered pile of refuse is hereby declared to be a nuisance. 
(Code 1965, § 5.3.5) 
Sec. 16-5. - Premises. 
    It shall be unlawful to permit any building structure or place, to remain in such a condition as to be dangerous to the public health in any way. Any such structure, building or place is hereby declared to be a nuisance. 
Sec. 16-6. - Motor vehicles. 
(a)  Nuisance declared. Any motor vehicle used in connection with the following list of offenses, whether charged by state statute or by local ordinance adopting state statute by reference, is hereby declared a public nuisance and is subject to impoundment, imposition of an administrative fee and release in accordance with this section and where applicable in accordance with 625 ILCS 5/11-208.7 of the Illinois Vehicle Code: 
(1)  Operation or use of a motor vehicle in the commission of, or in the attempt to commit, an offense for which a motor vehicle may be seized and forfeited pursuant to section 36-1 of the Criminal Code of 1961; or 
(2)  Driving under the influence of alcohol, another drug or drugs, an intoxicating compound or compounds, or any combination thereof, in violation of section 11-501 of the Illinois Vehicle Code; or 
(3)  Operation or use of a motor vehicle in the commission of, or in the attempt to commit, a felony or in violation of the Cannabis Control Act; provided further, possession of cannabis is limited to cases involving 2.5 grams or greater; or 
(4)  Operation or use of a motor vehicle in the commission of, or in the attempt to commit, an offence in violation of the Illinois Controlled Substances Act; or 
(5)  Operation or use of a motor vehicle in the commission of, or in the attempt to commit an offense in violation of sections 24-1, 24-1.5, or 24-3.1 of the Criminal Code of 1961; or 
(6)  Driving while a driver's license, permit, or privilege to operate a motor vehicle is suspended or revoked pursuant to section 6-303 of the Illinois Vehicle Code; except that vehicles shall not be subjected to seizure or impoundment if the suspension is for an unpaid citation (parking or moving) or due to failure to comply with emission testing; or 
(7)  Operation or use of a motor vehicle while soliciting, possessing, or attempting to solicit or possess cannabis or a controlled substance, as defined by and in violation of the Cannabis Control Act, or the Illinois Controlled Substances Act; provided further, illegal possession of cannabis is limited to cases involving 2.5 grams or greater; or 
(8)  Operation or use of a motor vehicle with an expired driver's license, in violation of section 6-101 of the Illinois Vehicle Code, if the period of expiration is greater than one year; or 
(9)  Operation or use of a motor vehicle without ever having been issued a driver's license or permit, in violation of section 6-101 of the Illinois Vehicle Code, or operating a motor vehicle without ever having issued a driver's license or permit due to a person's age; or 
(10)  Operation or use of a motor vehicle by a person against whom a warrant has been issued by a circuit clerk in Illinois for failing to answer charges that the driver violated sections 6-101, 6-303, or 11-501 of the Illinois Vehicle Code; or 
(11)  Operation or use of a motor vehicle in the commission of, or in the attempt to commit any offense in violation of article 16, or an offense in violation of article 16A where the value exceeds $150.00, said articles being of the Criminal Code of 1961; or 
(12)  Operation or use of a motor vehicle in the commission of, or in the attempt to commit a violation of 720 ILCS 5/11-6, indecent solicitation of a child; 720 ILCS 5/12-2, aggravated assault; 720 ILCS 5/12-4, aggravated battery; 720 ILCS 5/12-4.2, aggravated battery with a firearm; 720 ILCS 5/12-4.3, aggravated battery of a child; 720 ILCS 5/12-4.6, aggravated battery of a senior citizen; 720 ILCS 5/18-1, robbery; 720 ILCS 5/18-2, armed robbery; 720 ILCS 5/19-1, burglary; 720 ILCS 5/19-3, residential burglary; 720 ILCS 5/20-1, arson; 720 ILCS 5/20-1.1, aggravated arson; 720 ILCS 5/20-2, possession of explosives or explosive or incendiary devices; 720 ILCS 5/21-1, criminal damage to property; or 720 ILCS 5/25-1, mob action; of the Illinois Criminal Code, or similar provision of local ordinance; or 
(13)  Operation or use of a motor vehicle in the commission of, or in the attempt to commit a violation of 720 ILCS 600/3.5, possession of drug paraphernalia of the Drug Paraphernalia Control Act, or similar provision of local ordinance; or 
(14)  Operation or use of a motor vehicle in the commission of fleeing or attempting to elude a peace officer in violation of 625 ILCS 5/11-204 or aggravated fleeing or attempting to elude a peace officer in violation of 625 ILCS 5/11-204.1 of the Illinois Vehicle Code. 
(b)  Whenever a police officer has probable cause to believe that a motor vehicle is subject to seizure and impoundment pursuant to this article, the police officer shall provide for the towing of the motor vehicle according to police department procedure. When the motor vehicle is towed, the police department shall notify or make a reasonable attempt to notify the owner, lessee, or person identifying himself or herself as the owner or lessee of the vehicle or any person who is found to be in control of the vehicle at the time of the alleged offense, of the fact of the seizure and of the motor vehicle owner's or lessee's right to request an administrative hearing. The police department shall also provide notice that the motor vehicle will remain impounded pending the completion of the administrative hearing provided for in this article, unless the owner or lessee of the motor vehicle or a lienholder posts with the village a cash bond equal to the administrative fee as provided by ordinance and pays for towing and storage charges. 
(c)  Administrative fee. The owner of record of such motor vehicle subject to seizure and impoundment shall be liable to the village of an administrative fee of $450.00 in addition to any towing and storage charges. This article is in addition to and shall not replace or otherwise abrogate, any existing state or federal laws or any ordinance that relates to the seizure and/or impoundment of motor vehicles, and any fee in this article shall be in addition to any and all penalties that may be assessed or imposed by a court for any criminal charges. This article shall not apply: 
(1)  If the motor vehicle used in the violation was stolen at that time and the theft was reported to the appropriate police authorities within 24 hours after the theft was discovered; 
(2)  If the motor vehicle is operating as a common carrier and the violation occurs without the knowledge of the person in control of the motor vehicle; or 
(3)  If the motor vehicle is subject to successful forfeiture proceedings under 725 ILCS 150/1 et seq., the Drug Asset Forfeiture Procedure Act; 720 ILCS 5/36-1 et seq., the Seizure and Forfeiture of Vessels, Vehicles and Aircraft Act; or state or federal forfeiture laws. For purposes of this article, the "owner of record" or "owner" of a motor vehicle is the record title holders as registered with the Secretary of State of the licensing or title issuing state. 
(d)  Vehicle possession. 
(1)  Except as provided otherwise in this article, a motor vehicle shall continue to be impounded until: 
a.  The administrative fee, plus any applicable towing and storage charges, are paid, in which case possession of the motor vehicle shall be given to the person who is legally entitled to possess the motor vehicle; or 
b.  The motor vehicle is sold or otherwise disposed of to satisfy judgment to enforce a lien as provided by law. 
(2)  Except as otherwise specifically provided by law, no owner, lien holder or other person shall be entitled to take possession of a motor vehicle impounded under this article until the administrative fees applicable under this section have been paid. 
(3)  The owner, lessee, or a lienholder may post a bond in cash equal to the administrative fee provided herein and pay for all towing and storage charges whereupon the motor vehicle will be released in advance of the administrative hearing. 
(e)  Preliminary hearing. Whenever the owner of a motor vehicle seized pursuant to this article requests a preliminary hearing, said owner must make a request for said preliminary hearing within 48 hours of the seizure and impoundment. Said request shall be made in person and in writing at the police department administrative offices, Monday-Friday, excluding holidays, 8:30 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., using the tow hearing request form. If the request for a preliminary hearing is timely filed, the chief of police or his designee shall conduct such preliminary hearing within 24 hours after the request, or by a date mutually agreeable to the parties, Monday-Friday, excluding holidays, 8:30 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. All interested persons shall be given a reasonable opportunity to be heard at the preliminary hearing. The formal rules of evidence will not apply and hearsay evidence shall be admissible. If, after the preliminary hearing, the chief of police or his designee determines there is probable cause to believe that the motor vehicle is subject to seizure and impoundment pursuant to this article, the chief of police or his designee shall order the continued impoundment of the motor vehicle, as provided in this article, unless the owner of the motor vehicle posts with the village a cash bond as set forth in subsection (d). The chief of police or his designee will then set the matter for a hearing as set forth in subsections (f) and (g), unless the owner affirmatively waives the right to a hearing. However, if the chief of police or his designee finds that no such violation occurred, the chief of police or his designee shall order the return of the motor vehicle or cash bond, but the owner shall be responsible for any towing and storage charges. 
(f)  Notice of hearing. The registered owner or lessee of any impounded vehicle and any lienholder of record shall be provided a notice of hearing. The notice shall: 
(1)  Be served upon the owner, lessee, and any lienholder of record either by personal service or by first class mail to the interested party's address as registered with the Secretary of State; 
(2)  Be served upon interested parties within ten days after a vehicle is impounded by the municipality; and 
(3)  Contain the date, time, and location of the administrative hearing. An initial hearing shall be scheduled and convened no later than 45 days after the date of the mailing of the notice of hearing. 
(g)  In addition to the requirements contained in subdivision (b)(4) of section 11-208.3 of the Illinois Vehicle Code relating to administrative hearings, the following requirements will be followed concerning administrative hearings: 
(1)  Administrative hearings shall be conducted by a hearing officer who is an attorney licensed to practice law in this state for a minimum of three years; 
(2)  The notice of violation and reports of police officers shall be records kept in the ordinary course of business and shall be prima facie correct and shall be prima facie evidence of the correctness of the facts shown on the notice and shall be admissible in any hearing or legal proceeding; 
(3)  At the conclusion of the administrative hearing, the hearing officer shall issue a written decision either sustaining or overruling the vehicle impoundment; 
(4)  If the basis for the vehicle impoundment is sustained by the administrative hearing officer, any administrative fee posted to secure the release of the vehicle shall be forfeited to the municipality; 
(5)  All final decisions of the administrative hearing officer shall be subject to review under the provisions of the administrative review law; and 
(6)  Unless the administrative hearing officer overturns the basis for the vehicle impoundment, no vehicle shall be released to the owner, lessee, or lienholder of the record until all administrative fees and towing and storage charges are paid. 
(h)  Vehicles not retrieved from the towing facility or storage facility within 35 days after the administrative hearing officer issues a written decision shall be deemed abandoned and disposed of in accordance with the provisions of article II of chapter 4 of the Illinois Vehicle Code. 
(i)  Unless stayed by a court of competent jurisdiction, any fine, penalty, or administrative fee imposed under this section which remains unpaid in whole or in part after the expiration of the deadline for seeking judicial review under the administrative review law may be enforced in the same manner as a judgment entered by a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(j)  Whether or not a preliminary hearing is requested and held in accordance with subsection (e) above, the administrative hearing may be waived in writing by the person paying the administrative fee. 
(Ord. No. 2009-17, § 3, 3-3-09; Ord. No. 2012-21, § 3, 7-9-12) 
Sec. 16-7. - Firearm inventory secured storage. 
(a)  The failure of any person, business or corporation who offers for retail sale or repair firearms (hereinafter "inventory") and fails to secure said inventory in accordance with the specifications contained in paragraph (b) below and operate a central station intrusion alarm monitoring system during hours when the location is closed or is otherwise unattended is hereby deemed to be maintaining a public nuisance and is guilty of an offense. 
(b)  Definitions: 
    Central station alarm monitoring means employing alarm intrusion system monitoring by either a local or national control station; reliance solely on an exterior alert sound dependent on third persons hearing the alert and calling the police is not adequate. 
    Firearm means the same definition as contained in 430 ILCS 65/0.01 et seq., the Firearms Owners Identification Act (as amended). 
    Secure means: If referring to a room that the doors, walls, ceiling and floor satisfy the UL Standard for Safety Burglary Resistant Vault Doors and Modular Panels UL Standard 608 - Class M; and if referring to a container, the container satisfies the UL Standard for Burglary Resistant Safes UL Standard 687 Class TL-15. 
(c)  As a condition of a business license, the person, business owner or corporation officer shall produce for inspection to the chief of police, or his designee, the proposed secure manner in which the inventory shall be maintained during closed business hours or when unattended and also provide proof of an alarm system which employs central station alarm monitoring. Proof of the "secure" manner shall be by producing evidence of a ul standard certificate equal to or greater than described herein for construction materials or container to be used, or by presenting the room or container to the village building inspector and chief of police, or their designees, for inspection who shall make a determination whether said materials or container satisfy or exceed the UL standards described herein. Appeals from adverse determinations concerning adherence to the 'secure' standards herein or alternative central station alarm monitoring shall be filed with the village clerk and considered by the village president and board of trustees within 28 days. A written decision shall be filed with ten days thereafter. 
(Ord. No. 2016-14, § 3, 7-25-16) 
Secs. 16-8-16-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PLANTS AND WEEDS 

Sec. 16-21. - Abatement. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the chief of police to serve or cause to be served a notice upon the owner or occupant of any such premises on which weeds or plants are permitted to grow in violation of the provisions of this article, and to demand the abatement of the nuisance within five days. 
(b)  If the person so served does not abate the nuisance within five days after such notice the superintendent of public works may proceed to abate such nuisance, keeping an account of the expense thereof, and such expense shall be charged to and paid by the owner or occupant of the premises concerned, and the same shall constitute a lien on said property until fully discharged. 
(Code 1965, §§ 10.2.5, 10.2.6) 
Sec. 16-22. - Prohibited weeds. 
    Any weeds such as jimson, burdock, ragweed, thistle, cockleburr, or other weeds of a similar kind, found growing in the village are hereby declared to be nuisances, and it shall be unlawful to permit any such weeds to grow or remain in the village. 
(Code 1965, § 10.2.1) 
Sec. 16-23. - Prohibited heights. 
    It shall be unlawful for anyone to permit any weeds, grass or plants, other than trees, bushes, flowers, agricultural crops, or other ornamental plants to grow to a height exceeding eight inches on improved lots or 12 inches on unimproved lots; any such plants or weeds exceeding such height are declared to be a nuisance. Open areas containing such growth in excess of these heights shall not be considered a nuisance provided such open areas are a minimum of 100 feet from the property of a complainant or the public right-of-way. 
(Code 1965, § 10.2.2; Ord. No. 89-18, § 1, 7-11-89; Ord. No. 2005-20, § 2, 6-27-05) 
Sec. 16-24. - Barberry bushes. 
    It shall be unlawful and a nuisance to plant or permit the growth of the bush of the species of tall, common or European barberry, further known as Barberis Vulgaris , or its horticultural varieties within the village. 
(Code 1965, § 10.2.3) 
Sec. 16-25. - Poison ivy, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful and a nuisance for any person to knowingly permit, allow or maintain any poison ivy or other noxious weed or plant on any lot owned, controlled or leased by him in the village. 
(Code 1965, § 10.2.4) 
Secs. 16-26-16-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLES III-IX. - RESERVED 

Secs. 16-51-16-1000. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - PENALTIES 

Sec. 16-1001. - Penalty; compromise payment. 
(a)  Whosoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of an offense and fined not less than $100.00, nor more than $750.00 and/or sentenced up to six months in the county jail. Except when fines and costs are paid by compromise payment as provided in subsection (b) below prior to court, the court clerk shall add to the fine any and all costs and fees upon an authorized disposition. 
(b)  Any person accused of a violation of this chapter may settle and compromise said claim without a court appearance by payment of one half of the minimum required fine to the village clerk at the village hall within ten business days of the date of violation if the compromise box designation is so checked on the complaint and notice to appear form. 
(Ord. No. 2003-35, § 2, 9-22-03; Ord. No. 2006-43, § 11, 12-11-06) 
Chapter 17 - PARKS AND RECREATION 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 17-1-17-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PARK RULES 

Sec. 17-16. - Scope. 
    The provisions of this article shall apply to parks and playgrounds within the village. 
Sec. 17-17. - Authority to remove violators from parks and playgrounds. 
    Any police officer of the village is hereby authorized to remove, or cause to be removed, from any park or playground in the village any violator of any provision of this article. 
(Ord. No. 763, § 4, 6-27-77) 
Sec. 17-18. - Park hours. 
    No person shall be in or upon any park or playground during any hours in which such park or playground is closed pursuant to ordinance of the Crete Park District, provided such hours are posted for public notice. 
(Ord. No. 763, § 1, 6-27-77) 
Sec. 17-19. - Firearms and fireworks. 
    No person shall carry or discharge firearms, pellet guns, air pistols, slingshots, BB guns, explosives, rockets, fireworks or any other item containing any substance of an explosive nature, unless authorized by the Crete Board of Park Commissioners. 
(Ord. No. 763, § 2(B), 6-27-77) 
Sec. 17-20. - Throwing stones or other missiles. 
    No person shall throw or cast any stone, rock, or other missile, other than athletic equipment while engaged in the athletic activity. 
(Ord. No. 763, § 2(C), 6-27-77) 
Sec. 17-21. - Fires. 
    No person shall light or make use of any fire or burn any combustible item, except in containers or fire pits specifically provided therefor and except as may be authorized specifically by the board of park commissioners of the Crete Park District or the recreation director of superintendent of maintenance of the Crete Park District. 
(Ord. No. 763, § 2(D), 6-27-77) 
Sec. 17-22. - Liquor and drunkenness. 
    No person shall bring into, sell, give away or drink any intoxicating liquors in parks or playgrounds. No intoxicated person shall enter, be or remain within the parks or playgrounds. 
(Ord. No. 763, § 2(E), 6-27-77) 
Sec. 17-23. - Littering. 
    No person shall deposit, dump, throw or place any garbage, refuse, paper, trash or rubbish of any kind in or upon any part of any park or playground. All refuse or garbage created by lawful activities within the parks shall be deposited in receptacles provided for that purpose. 
(Ord. No. 763, § 2(F), 6-27-77) 
Sec. 17-24. - Animals. 
    No person shall take into or allow upon any park or playground any animal, including dogs and other pets. No person shall trap, catch, wound, kill, or treat cruelly any bird or animal, nor attempt to do any of the aforesaid, within the parks and playgrounds. No person shall molest or rob any nest of any bird or animals, or attempt to do so, within the parks or playgrounds. 
(Ord. No. 763, § 2(A), (G), 6-27-77) 
Cross reference- Animals and fowl, ch. 5. 
Sec. 17-25. - Damage to park property. 
    No person shall break, cut, injure, deface, climb upon or in any way destroy any tree, shrub, plant, grass, turf, building, fence, bridge, lamp, post or other structure or property within the parks or playgrounds. 
(Ord. No. 763, § 2(H), 6-27-77) 
Sec. 17-26. - Breach of peace and disorderly conduct. 
    No person shall knowingly engage in any act in such an unreasonable manner as to alarm or disturb another person and as to provoke a breach of the peace. No person shall conduct, or gather with other persons in bodies or crowds, for unlawful purposes or for any purpose which results in annoyance, obstruction or disturbance of other users of the parks and playgrounds. 
(Ord. No. 763, § 2(I), 6-27-77) 
Sec. 17-27. - Use of areas for unintended purposes; use of restricted areas. 
    No person shall engage in any sport, game or amusement in the parks or playgrounds except in areas or playing fields provided therefor as may be designated by the board of park commissioners of the Crete Park District or the recreation director of the Crete Park District and then only under such rules and regulations as may be prescribed. Nor shall any person enter upon any portion of any park or playground where persons are prohibited by signs from going by direction of the board of park commissioners of the Crete Park District or maintenance superintendent. 
(Ord. No. 763, § 2(K), 6-27-77) 
Sec. 17-28. - Traffic. 
    No person shall bring or use any motor vehicle, bicycle, motorcycle or mini-bike, upon any park or playground. This section shall not apply to licensed motor vehicles which are located in parking areas or upon marked driveways or roadways. 
(Ord. No. 763, § 2(L), 6-27-77) 
Sec. 17-29. - Resisting or interfering with officers. 
(a)  No person shall resist, interfere with, hinder or prevent any police officer, park district commissioner or park district employee in the discharge of his duty or fail or refuse to obey any lawful command of any such police officer, commissioner or employee. No person shall in any manner assist or give aid to any person in custody of a police officer to escape or attempt to escape from custody. 
(b)  No person shall interfere with or in any manner hinder any employee of the Crete Park District while engaged in construction, repairing, or maintenance of any park property. 
(Ord. No. 763, § 2(J), (M), 6-27-77) 
Sec. 17-30. - Improper speech and conduct. 
    No person shall use any abusive, threatening, insulting, indecent, profane or obscene language, or language calculated to occasion a breach of the peace, nor be guilty of any indecent act or behavior in the parks or playgrounds. 
(Ord. No. 763, § 2(N), 6-27-77) 
Sec. 17-31. - Use of playground equipment by adults. 
    No adult shall in any manner use any of the playground apparatus, equipment or devices made exclusively for the use of children. 
(Ord. No. 763, § 2(O), 6-27-77) 
Sec. 17-32. - Obstruction of travel. 
    No person shall place, or cause to be placed any item, goods, or property of any kind so as to obstruct travel in the parks or playgrounds. 
(Ord. No. 763, § 2(P), 6-27-77) 
Sec. 17-33. - Commercial activities. 
    No person shall offer any article or item for sale or exchange, buy or offer to buy any item or article, take up any collection or solicit or receive contributions of money or items of value in parks or playgrounds without a permit from the board of park commissioners of the Crete Park District. 
(Ord. No. 763, § 2(Q), 6-27-77) 
Sec. 17-34. - Public meetings. 
    No person shall call or hold any public meeting or give any concert or public entertainment of any kind in the parks or playgrounds without the express consent of the board of park commissioners of the Crete Park District. 
(Ord. No. 763, § 2(R), 6-27-77) 
Sec. 17-35. - Advertisements and signs. 
    No person shall: 
(1)  Display any placard, sign or advertisement in the parks or playgrounds; 
(2)  Distribute, cast or place any handbills, pamphlets, circulars, advertisements or notices of any kind in the parks or playgrounds; 
(3)  Post, stencil or otherwise affix any notice or bills of advertisement or other papers upon any structure or thing in or upon the parks or playgrounds; 
without the express consent of the board of park commissioners of the Crete Park District. 
(Ord. No. 763, § 2(S), 6-27-77) 
Sec. 17-36. - Gambling. 
    No person shall engage in any game of chance, gambling or use of any gambling devices in the parks and playgrounds. 
(Ord. No. 763, § 2(T), 6-27-77) 
Sec. 17-37. - Sleeping in parks. 
    No person shall sleep overnight or camp overnight in any park or playground, without a written permit issued by the board of park commissioners of the Crete Park District. 
(Ord. No. 763, § 2(U), 6-27-77) 
Sec. 17-38. - Drugs. 
    No person shall bring into, sell, give away, possess, use or be under the influence of any cannabis as defined in the Cannabis Control Act (720 ILCS 550/3) or any controlled substance as defined in the Illinois Controlled Substances Act (720 ILCS 570/100 et seq.), in any park or playground, other than such controlled substances which has been legally prescribed for the individual by a licensed physician. 
(Ord. No. 763, § 2(V), 6-27-77) 
Secs. 17-39-17-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLES III-IX. - RESERVED 

Secs. 17-71-17-1000. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - PENALTIES 

Sec. 17-1001 - Penalty; compromise payment. 
(a)  Whosoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of an offense and fined not less than $100.00 nor more than $750.00 and/or sentenced up to six months in the county jail. Except when fines and costs are paid by compromise payment as provided in subsection (b) below prior to court, the court clerk shall add to the fine any and all costs and fees upon an authorized disposition. 
(b)  Any person accused of a violation of this chapter may settle and compromise said claim without a court appearance by payment of one half of the minimum required fine to the village clerk at the village hall within ten business days of the date of violation if the compromise box designation is so checked on the complaint and notice to appear form. 
(Ord. No. 2003-35, § 2, 9-22-03; Ord. No. 2006-43, § 12, 12-11-06) 
Chapter 18 - PEDDLERS, SOLICITORS, ETC.[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Licenses, permits and miscellaneous business regulations, ch. 12. 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to license, tax and regulate peddlers, hawkers, etc., 65 ILCS 5/11-42-5. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 18-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Hawker: Every peddler who seeks for purchasers either by outcry, or by means of horn, whistle, rattle, bell, drum or other signal, or by actual exhibition or exposure of his goods, wares or merchandise, or by placards, shall be deemed a hawker. 
    Peddler: Every person who, without outcry, blowing of horn, or by otherwise in a similar manner attracting attention of his goods, wares or merchandise, shall sell or offer for sale, barter or exchange, any goods, wares, merchandise, fruits or vegetables, traveling from place to place, on, along or upon the streets, alleys or sidewalks of the village, or at the doors of houses, apartments or stores, or from a wagon, pushcart or other vehicle. 
    Political/religious solicitor: Every person who shall solicit funds or support for religious or political organizations or causes. 
    Solicitor: Every person whether a hawker, peddler, transient vendor, itinerant merchant or other, who goes upon any premises for the purpose of securing an audience with the occupant thereof to sell items, to solicit orders or seek support for a cause, other than religious or political, and further excepting for official government purposes including canvass or census. 
    Transient vendor or itinerant merchant: Every person, transiently or temporarily engaged in the business of selling, bartering, or exchanging, or offering for sale, barter or exchange, any goods, wares or merchandise. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.20.1; Ord. No. 2005-08, § 1, 3-14-05) 
Sec. 18-2. - Reports of renting premises to transient vendors. 
    The owner, proprietor, manager or agent of any store, loft, warehouse, yard, office space, dwelling, house or show sales room space which shall be rented or engaged by a transient vendor or itinerant merchant shall report to the chief of police, within six hours after such renting, or engaging, the name of any itinerant merchant or transient vendor as aforesaid who shall so rent or engage, giving the location of the store, loft, warehouse, yard, office, office space, dwelling, house or show or sales room or space so rented or engaged. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.20.12) 
Sec. 18-3. - Harassing public. 
    No person acting as a solicitor, or political/religious solicitor, shall harass any person by continuing to engage said person to look at his goods, wares, or any object or to support a cause or listen to a position after being requested to cease. This includes requests for money for personal or other purposes. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.20.8; Ord. No. 2005-08, § 1, 3-14-05) 
Sec. 18-4. - Solicitation from roadway. 
(a)  No solicitation from a roadway in accordance with state statute is permitted within the village limits excepting: 
(1)  At the intersection of Main Street (IL Route 1) and Exchange Street. 
(b)  Further, solicitation from the roadway at the above-listed intersection(s) is permitted only if: 
(1)  The participants are 16 years of age or older; and 
(2)  The participants are wearing high visibility vests; and 
(3)  The activity occurs within the time period and on the dates authorized by the chief of police, having taken into consideration the safety of the solicitors, safety of motorists, the orderly flow of traffic, road construction in the area, weather conditions, adult supervision and natural light as per time of year. 
(c)  No person soliciting in accordance with state statute and authorized by this section shall obstruct or interfere with the traffic or travel of any vehicle on the public streets or highways within the village. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.20.8; Ord. No. 2005-08, § 1, 3-14-05; Ord. No. 2009-68, § 2, 11-23-09) 
Note- Former entitled, "Obstructing traffic". 
Sec. 18-5. - Fraud. 
    Any solicitor or political/religious solicitor who shall be guilty of any fraud or misrepresentation or imposition shall be guilty of an offense. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.20.9; Ord. No. 2005-08, § 1, 3-14-05) 
Secs. 18-6-18-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - RESERVED[2] 

Footnotes:

II, which consisted of §§ 18-21-18-26, pertained to a license for peddlers, solicitors, etc., and was derived from Code 1965, §§ 2.2.20.2-2.2.20.6, 2.2.20.8, 2.2.20.11; Ord. No. 820, § 1, adopted Apr. 28, 1980; and Ord. No. 86-13A, § 1, adopted Jan. 5, 1987.

ARTICLE III. - SOLICITORS 

Sec. 18-31. - Village policy on soliciting. 
    It is hereby declared to be the policy of the corporate authorities of the village that the occupant or occupants of the residences or other buildings in the village shall make the determination of whether solicitors shall be, or shall not be, invited to their respective residence. 
(Ord. No. 2005-08, § 3, 3-14-05) 
Sec. 18-32. - Notice to solicitors. 
(a)  Every person desiring to secure the protection intended to be provided by the regulations pertaining to soliciting contained in this chapter, shall comply with the directions set forth in this section. 
(b)  Notice of the determination by the occupant or the refusal of invitations to solicitors, to any residence or nonresidential building, shall be given in the manner following: 
(1)  A card, decal or written notice, at least three inches by four inches (3" × 4") (8cm. × 10cm.) in size, shall be exhibited upon or near the main entranceway or door to the residence, indicating the determination by the occupant, containing the applicable words, as follows: 
"NO SOLICITORS INVITED" 
or 
"NO SOLICITORS" 
(2)  The letters shall be at least one-third inch ( 1/3 ") (8mm.) in height. 
(c)  Such card so exhibited shall constitute sufficient notice to any solicitor of the determination by the occupant of the residence that no solicitation is permitted at that building. 
(Ord. No. 2005-08, § 3, 3-14-05) 
Sec. 18-33. - Duty of solicitors.
