    The village clerk shall keep a chart showing the proper street number of every lot in the village which chart shall be open to public inspection. 
(Code 1965, § 3.4.2) 
Sec. 22-43. - Numbers on houses. 
    It shall be the duty of the owner and occupant of every house in the village to have placed thereon, in a place visible from the street, figures at least two and one-half inches high, showing the number of the house. Any person failing to so number any house owned or occupied by him after receiving notice to do so from the village clerk shall be guilty of an offense. 
(Code 1965, § 3.4.3) 
Secs. 22-44-22-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLES IV-IX. - RESERVED 

Secs. 22-71-2-1000. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - PENALTIES 

Sec. 22-1001. - Penalty; compromise payment. 
(a)  Whosoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of an offense and fined not less than $100.00 nor more than $750.00. Except when fines and costs are paid by compromise payment as provided in subsection (b) below prior to court, the court clerk shall add to the fine any and all costs and fees upon an authorized disposition. 
(b)  Any person accused of a violation of this chapter may settle and compromise said claim without a court appearance by payment of one half of the minimum required fine to the village clerk at the village hall within ten business days of the date of violation if the compromise box designation is so checked on the complaint and notice to appear form. 
(Ord. No. 2003-35, § 2, 9-22-03; Ord. No. 2006-43, § 15, 12-11-06) 
Chapter 23 - SUBDIVISIONS[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 23-1. - Short title. 
    This chapter shall be known and may be cited as "The Crete Subdivision Regulations." 
(Ord. No. 571, Art. 1, § A, 5-24-65) 
Sec. 23-2. - Purpose. 
    This chapter is adopted for the following purposes: 
(1)  To promote the public health, safety, morals, comfort, convenience, prosperity, and general welfare; 
(2)  To conserve, protect, and enhance property and property values; 
(3)  To secure the most appropriate use of land; and to facilitate the adequate but economical provision of public improvements; 
(4)  To provide for orderly growth and development; to afford adequate facilities for the safe, convenient, and efficient means for the traffic circulation of its population; and to safeguard the public against flood damage; 
(5)  To prescribe reasonable rules and regulations governing the subdivision and platting of land; the preparation of plats; the location, width, and course of streets and highways; the installation of utilities, street pavements, and other essential improvements; and the necessary public grounds for schools, parks, playgrounds, and other public open spaces; 
(6)  To establish procedures for the submission, approval, and recording of plats; and to provide the means for enforcement and to provide penalties for violations. 
(Ord. No. 571, Art. 1, § B, 5-24-65) 
Sec. 23-3. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Alley: A minor way which is used primarily for vehicular access to the back or side of properties abutting upon and having access to a street. 
    Collector street: A street which carries traffic from minor streets to an arterial street, including the principal entrance streets of residential developments, and the principal streets for circulation within such a development. 
    Cul-de-sac: A short minor street ending in a turn-around designed and intended as a permanent terminus. 
    Dead-end street: Any street, other than a cul-de-sac, which has only one outlet. 
    Development: The act of building structures or installing site improvements. 
    Easement: A grant or reservation of specific rights in land conveyed by the land owner to the public or to person for a particular purpose or purposes. 
    Engineer: A professional engineer registered as such in the state. 
    Expressway: A street or highway to which access is limited or controlled, designed to move vehicular traffic between communities or other large areas. Included in this definition are the terms "tollway," "freeway, " and "turnpike." 
    Half-street: When a proposed street has as its center line, or within its right-of-way, the boundaries of one or more tracts, that portion of the street on either side of such tract boundary shall be known as a "half-street." 
    Local street: A street used primarily for access to the abutting properties. 
    Major street plan: The so designated portion of the official plan as adopted and amended by the village. 
    Marginal access street: A minor street which is approximately parallel and adjacent to an arterial street or expressway, and which provides access to abutting properties and protection from through traffic. 
    Official map: The official map, or any part thereof, as adopted by the board of trustees. 
    Official plan: The official comprehensive plan, or any part thereof, as adopted by the board of trustees. 
    Owner: Any person having sufficient proprietary interest in the land sought to be subdivided to commence and maintain proceedings to subdivide the same under this chapter. 
    Pedestrian way: A right-of-way, however designated, across or within a block for use by pedestrian traffic. Included in this term are sidewalks and crosswalks. 
    Right-of-way: A strip of land conveyed or dedicated for street use; or, where appropriate, for other special uses such as a crosswalk, railroad, pipeline, utility main or electric transmission line. 
    Resubdivision: The relocation of property boundaries, or the reallocation of property in a plat of record; however, the dissolution of property lines, not accompanied by the creation of new property lines, shall not constitute resubdivision. 
    Street: A way for vehicular traffic, whether designated as a street, highway, thoroughfare, freeway, road, avenue, boulevard, land, place, or however otherwise indicated. 
    Street width: The shortest distance between the lines delineating the right-of-way of a street. 
    Subdivider: Any person commencing proceedings under this chapter effect a subdivision of land hereunder for himself or for another. 
    Subdivision: The division of land into two or more lots, parcels or areas. The term shall include resubdivision and shall, when appropriate to the context, relate the procession of subdividing or to the land being subdivided. 
    Surveyor: A land surveyor registered as such in the state. 
    Zoning ordinance: The zoning ordinance of the village and all maps pertaining thereto for subdivisions located within the corporate limits. The term shall mean the zoning ordinance of the appropriate county having jurisdiction for subdivisions located in unincorporated areas within one and one-half miles of the village. 
(Ord. No. 571, Art. 2, 5-24-65) 
Sec. 23-4. - Interpretation. 
(a)  In interpreting and applying the provisions of this chapter they shall be held to be the minimum requirements for the promotion and effectuation of the purposes of this chapter. 
(b)  Nothing herein shall repeal, abrogate, annul, or in any way interfere with, any provisions of law, or any rules or regulations other than subdivision regulations adopted or issued pursuant to law relating to the subdivision or development of land. Where this chapter imposes greater restrictions or requirements than are imposed or required by other provisions of law, regulations, rules, covenants or agreements, the provisions of this chapter shall control, but nothing herein shall interfere with, abrogate, or annul any easements, covenants, deed restrictions or agreements between parties which impose restrictions greater than those imposed by this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 571, Art. 1, § C, 5-24-65) 
Sec. 23-5. - Exemptions. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to the following: 
(1)  Divisions of land which may be ordered or approved by a court or effected by testamentary or intestate procedures or provisions; 
(2)  A division of land for agricultural purposes into lots or parcels of five acres or more and not involving any new streets or easements of access; 
(3)  Conveyances of land for use as right-of-way for highway, railroad, or other public utilities not involving any new streets or easements or access; 
(4)  Such other subdivision as may be specifically exempted herefrom by state law. 
(Ord. No. 571, Art. 2, § 5, 5-24-65) 
Sec. 23-6. - Amendments. 
    The plan commission shall from time to time prepare and recommend in writing to the board of trustees such changes or additions to the provisions and regulations herein contained for subdivision control, as the plan commission may deem necessary or advisable. Such changes or additions shall become effective after their adoption by the board of trustees. Any previously approved preliminary plat shall remain effective for a period of one year following its approval, the fact of any intervening amendment(s), notwithstanding. Thereafter, any preliminary plat or portion of any subdivision proposal (not under construction and/or appropriately bonded) must be resubmitted to the village's plan commission for reapproval and compliance with all the then current provisions and regulations. 
(Ord. No. 571, Art. 1, § I, 5-24-65; Ord. No. 91-17, § 1, 6-10-91) 
Sec. 23-7. - Modifications. 
(a)  When the plan commission, in interpreting this chapter, finds that extraordinary hardship or injustice will result from strict compliance with this chapter, the terms thereof may be varied to the extent deemed necessary and proper to grant relief, provided that the modification: 
(1)  Is due to physical features of the site, 
(2)  Is the least deviation from this chapter which will mitigate the hardship, and 
(3)  Is not detrimental to the public interest, and is in keeping with the general spirit and intent of this chapter. 
(b)  Application for any such modification shall be made in writing by the subdivider at the time the preliminary plat is filed for consideration, stating fully and clearly all facts relied upon by the petitioner, and shall be supplemented with maps, plans, or other additional data which may aid the plan commission in the analysis of the proposed project. The plans for such development shall include such covenants, restrictions or other legal provisions necessary to guarantee the full achievement of the plan. Once the terms of any modification have been agreed upon, the review of the subdivision shall proceed as prescribed in article II of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 571, Art. 9, §§ A, B, 5-24-65) 
Sec. 23-8. - Scope and required compliance. 
(a)  This chapter shall apply to all subdivisions made within the corporate limits of the village and to all unincorporated areas located within the jurisdiction of the plan commission. All subdivisions shall comply with the applicable requirements set forth in this chapter and on the official map. 
(b)  Whoever shall sell or offer for sale, or lease for any time exceeding five years, any lot or block in any subdivision before complying with all the requirements of this chapter and the state statutes governing plats, shall be guilty of an offense for each lot or block or part thereof, so disposed of, offered for sale, or leased. 
(Ord. No. 571, Art. 1, §§ D, E, 5-24-65) 
Sec. 23-9. - Platting required. 
    No lot or tract of land located within the village or within the area of jurisdiction of the plan commission which contains an area of more than one-half acre, shall be divided or re-divided in any manner into two or more lesser tracts for building site purposes, without subdividing or resubdividing and platting such tract in the manner provided by the law. 
(Ord. No. 571, Art. 1, § J, 5-24-65) 
Sec. 23-10. - Buildings within proposed major street extensions. 
    No permanent building or structure shall be erected within the extended street lines of proposed extensions of major streets shown on the major street plan adopted as part of the official plan of the village. 
(Ord. No. 571, Art. 1, § K, 5-24-65) 
Sec. 23-11. - Building permits and certificates of occupancy. 
    Within the corporate limits: 
(1)  Building permits shall not be issued until the building inspector and board of trustees have been notified that the final plat has been approved. 
(2)  Certificates of occupancy shall not be issued until the building inspector has been notified by the plan commission that the required improvements have been completed and operational approval has been granted by the village engineer. 
(Ord. No. 571, Art. 4, § F, 5-24-65) 
Secs. 23-12-23-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PLAT REVIEW PROCEDURES 

Sec. 23-36. - Duties of subdividers and of the plan commission. 
    The prospective subdivider is urged to consult informally with the plan commission and, where pertinent, county officials, state agencies, and public utility people, on the availability of services and public facilities in the area to be subdivided. He is also encouraged to study the pertinent rules and regulations including the zoning ordinance, and especially this chapter. The plan commission is responsible for discouraging not only premature development, but also development in unsuitable areas that are inaccessible or hazardous or lack services. The plan commission is also charged with encouraging replatting of inadequate subdivisions and coordinating the platting of small parcels of adjacent land. 
(Ord. No. 571, Art. 3, § A, 5-24-65) 
Sec. 23-37. - Classes of subdivisions. 
    Subdivisions are, for the purposes of this article, divided into the following classes: 
(1)  Class 1 subdivision: Any subdivision containing not more than ten lots, fronting on an existing, improved, public, minor street, not involving any new street or road or the extension of municipal facilities, not adversely affecting the development of the remainder of the parcel or adjoining property, and not in conflict with the official plan, zoning ordinance, or this chapter. 
(2)  Class 2 subdivision: Any subdivision which does not meet the specifications for a class 1 subdivision. 
(Ord. No. 571, Art. 3, § B, 5-24-65) 
Sec. 23-38. - Stages of approval generally. 
    All subdivision plats shall be processed in four stages leading to approval for recording, except that in specified instances as specified by this chapter, certain stages may be waived or combined. The four stages are: 
(1)  The sketch plan; 
(2)  The preliminary plat; 
(3)  Engineering plans; and 
(4)  The final plat. 
(Ord. No. 571, Art. 3, § C, 5-24-65) 
Sec. 23-39. - Development in stages. 
(a)  The applicant for plat approval may elect to have final approval on a geographic part or parts of the plat that received preliminary approval, and may delay application for approval of other parts until a later date or dates beyond one year with the approval of the board of trustees; provided, all facilities required to serve the part or parts for which final approval is sought have been provided. In such case only such part or parts of the plat as have received final approval shall be recorded. 
(b)  In no case, except for the final section, shall any section filed for approval under this provision contain less than 50 residential lots. 
(Ord. No. 571, Art. 4, § C(5), 5-24-65) 
Sec. 23-40. - Fee. 
(a)  At the time of application for approval of a preliminary plat, the subdivider shall pay processing fee to the village of an amount as set forth in article V of chapter 2 immediately to the right of the reference to section 23-40. 
(b)  At the time of application for approval of the engineering plans, the subdivider shall pay a fee sufficient to compensate the village engineer for an examination of the engineering plans and the estimated construction cost of improvements. 
(c)  After the engineering plans and the construction cost estimate of improvements have been approved by the village engineer and the plan commission, the applicant shall deposit money in escrow payable to the village in accordance with the schedule then in effect between the village and the village engineer to cover the costs of engineering supervision and inspection. 
(d)  At the time of receiving approval of a final plat the subdivider shall pay a fee sufficient to cover the cost of recording. 
(Ord. No. 571, Art. 4, § C, 5-24-65; Ord. No. 86-13A, § 1, 1-5-87) 
Sec. 23-41. - Sketch plan stage. 
(a)  The sketch plan is a sketch proposal, complying with the provisions of subsection (b), submitted informally by the developer to the plan commission. The purposes of same conference are: 
(1)  To develop cooperation and confidence; 
(2)  To familiarize the developer with requirements; 
(3)  To do away with major revisions of the Preliminary Plats; 
(4)  To save the developer time and money; 
(5)  To provide assistance to small scale subdividers; 
(6)  To classify the subdivision as Class 1, or Class 2; sketch plans of subdivisions classified by the plan commission at this stage as Class 1 subdivisions may proceed directly to the fourth or final plat stage. Sketch plans of subdivisions classified as Class 2 subdivisions shall proceed to the preliminary plat stage. 
(b)  The subdivider shall meet with the plan commission in a preliminary conference which shall be scheduled by appointment. Prior to the conference he shall submit to the plan commission the following: 
(1)  A rough site sketch showing: 
a.  The boundaries and dimensions of the property to be subdivided; 
b.  Land characteristics such as natural drainage, swamp areas, wooded areas, and ridges, on and adjacent to the tract; 
c.  Existing easements and their location, width and purpose; 
d.  Streets on and adjacent to the tract; their name and right-of-way width and location, their type, width and approximate elevation of surfacing; 
e.  Existing utilities on and adjacent to the tract, location and size of water mains, fire hydrants, gas mains, street lights, storm and sanitary sewers, including invert elevations of sewers to which connections are to be made; 
f.  Other conditions on the tract and adjacent land, including approximate directions and gradient of ground slope, any embankments or retaining walls; character and locations of buildings and other structures, railroads, power lines, towers, and other nearby non-residential land uses of adverse influence; owners of adjacent unplatted land; 
g.  Zoning on and adjacent to the tract; 
h.  Proposed public improvements; highways or other major improvements planned by public authorities for future construction on or near the tract; 
i.  The proposed layout of streets, blocks and lots; 
j.  The proposed location of business, park, and other nonresidential areas; 
k.  Existing covenants affecting the property. 
(Ord. No. 571, Art. 3, § C(1), Art. 4, § A, 5-24-65) 
Sec. 23-42. - Preliminary plat stage. 
(a)  The preliminary plat is a drawing which shall be prepared subsequent to and in accordance with the agreements reached in the sketch plan conference. It shall be prepared in accordance with subsection (e) and all other applicable ordinances and four copies shall be filed with the village clerk, together with an application form in duplicate. 
(b)  The plan commission shall approve or disapprove the application for preliminary approval within 90 days from the date of the application or the filing by the applicant of the last item of required supporting data, whichever date is later, unless such time is extended by mutual consent. If such plat is disapproved, then within said 90 days the plan commission shall furnish to applicant in writing a statement setting forth the reason for disapproval and specifying with particularity the aspects in which the proposed plat fails to conform to the ordinances, including the official map. If such plat is approved, the board of trustees shall accept or reject said plat within 30 days after its next regular stated meeting following the action of the plan commission. Preliminary approval shall not qualify a plat for recording. 
(c)  If the plat is approved, the village clerk shall attach a certified copy of the order or resolution of approval to a copy of the plat. If the proposed plat is disapproved, the order or resolution shall state the reasons for the disapproval, specifying with particularity the aspects in which the proposed plat fails to conform to the official map. A copy of the order or resolution shall be filed in the office of the village clerk. 
(d)  In the case of a class 2 subdivision approval of the preliminary plat as returned to the subdivider shall be construed to be an expression of approval of the general layout, and shall authorize the subdivider to proceed with the preparation of the final plat. 
(e)  The preliminary plat shall be prepared by an engineer or surveyor and shall be drawn or printed on paper at a scale of 100 feet to one inch, unless a different scale was approved at the sketch plan conference. This plat shall show or be accompanied by the following information: 
(1)  Name under which the proposed subdivision is to be recorded, location and position by quarter-quarter section, section, township, range, meridian, county, and state; names and addresses of subdividers; notation stating scale, north arrow; and the following certificate: 
    "State of Illinois, County of Will, Village of Crete. Approved by _____ , Crete Plan Commission. This _____ day of _______, 19___ A.D." 
(2)  The following description of existing conditions: 
a.  Complete survey data such as angles, bearings, dimensions, curve data, etc., shall be shown for the exterior lines of the subdivision. The error of linear closure of said boundary survey shall not be greater than one in 5,000. 
b.  Location, width, and purpose of easements and other existing restrictions, reservations, or covenants. 
c.  Name, location, right-of-way width of streets, also all curbs, gutters, culverts, sidewalks, and building setbacks. 
d.  Location and size of sanitary and storm sewers; fire hydrants, and location and size of water mains; location of gas lines, electric and telephone lines. If water mains and sewers are not on or adjacent to the tract, the distance and direction to, and the size of, the nearest ones. 
e.  Watercourses, marshes and bogs, areas subject to inundation; wooded areas; and isolated preservable trees one foot or more in diameter. 
f.  All houses, barns and other structures, and other constructed features. 
g.  All of the requirements of plat preparation shall apply equally to the site being subdivided and to all land within 200 feet of its boundaries, waiving accuracy requirements as to scale of features, but not as to boundary lines. 
h.  Highways or other major improvements planned by public authorities for future construction on or near the tract, according to the information received from the plan commission at the sketch plan conference. 
i.  Depth of groundwater unless test pits are dry at a depth of eight feet, and the location and results of any tests made to ascertain subsurface soil and rock conditions. 
j.  Percolation test data shall be submitted for all subdivisions of three or more lots to be served by individual sewage disposal systems. 
(3)  All proposals of the subdivider, including: 
a.  The name of the subdivision, which must be original and not duplicate or be substantially similar to any existing subdivision located in the Townships of Crete and Monee in the county. 
b.  Streets which must have unduplicated names; right-of-way and roadway widths; radius of curvatures; length of curve and tangent sections; and similar data for alleys, if any. 
c.  Easement rights-of-way, their location, width, and purpose. 
d.  Lot lines and approximate dimensions. 
e.  Sites, if any, to be used for the following: industrial, commercial, public or semi-public, multi-family or other than single-family residential. 
f.  Sites to be reserved or dedicated for any public or semi-public use. 
g.  Minimum building setback lines. 
h.  A tabulation of gross area, street area, other dedicated area, not subdivided area, number of lots, average lot size, typical lot dimensions, and lineal feet of street. 
i.  Proposed contours of the finished subdivision. 
(f)  Before a preliminary plat may be considered for approval by the plan commission it shall be accompanied by a written statement bearing the signature of an authorized employee of the utility company attesting to the suitability of the easements for the purpose shown if the plat contains utility easements. 
(Ord. No. 571, Art. 3, § C(2), Art. 4, §§ B, D, 5-24-65) 
Sec. 23-43. - Final plat stage. 
(a)  The final plat is a record of the subdivision as surveyed in the field. It shows property lines and other dimensions important to the subdivider in selling lots, and to the public in keeping records of street lines, easements, and utility locations. Application for approval of a final plat shall be made not later than one year after approval of a preliminary plat has been granted. This application must be supported by such drawings, specifications and bond as may be necessary to demonstrate compliance with all requirements of this chapter. 
(b)  The final plat shall be prepared in accordance with this section and all other applicable ordinances and the original and three copies shall be filed with the village clerk, together with four copies of all required supporting materials and an application form in duplicate. 
(c)  It is intended that approval be automatic if the final plat conforms closely to the approved preliminary plat and approved engineering plans. Disapproval is warranted, however, if: 
(1)  There are more than minor deviations from the preliminary plat; 
(2)  More than one year has elapsed since the approval of engineering plans; 
(3)  A new highway, pipeline or other major feature has been constructed or has directly affected the site by virtue of such improvement being included in the official map. 
(d)  When a person submitting a plat of subdivision or resubdivision for final approval has supplied all drawings, maps and other documents required by this chapter to be furnished in support thereof, and if all such material meets all requirements, the board of trustees shall approve the proposed plat within 60 days from the date of filing the last required document or other paper or within 60 days from the date of filing application for final approval of the plat, whichever date is later. The applicant and the board of trustees may mutually agree to extend the 60-day period. 
(e)  If the plat is approved, the village clerk shall attach a certified copy of the order or resolution of approval to a copy of the plat. If the proposed plat is disapproved, the order or resolution shall state the reasons for the disapproval, specifying with particularity the aspects in which the proposed plat fails to conform to the official map. A copy of the order or resolution shall be filed in the office of the village clerk. 
(f)  Final plats shall comply with the following specifications: 
(1)  The final plat shall be drawn in waterproof black (India) ink on tracing cloth, or their equivalents. The scale shall be 100 feet to one inch or larger. Variation in scale may be allowed when determined by the plan commission to be necessary for a proper exhibit of the subdivision. When more than one sheet is used for any plat, they shall be numbered consecutively and each sheet shall contain a notation showing the whole number of sheets in the plat, and its relation to the other sheets ( e.g., sheet 1 of 3 sheets). Linear dimensions shall be given in feet and decimals of a foot. The final plat shall show on the face thereof: 
a.  The name of plat. 
b.  The location and position of the subdivision indicated in each of the following ways: 
1.  By quarter-quarter section, section, township, range, meridian, county and state. 
2.  By distances and bearings from true north or angles with reference to a corner or corners established in the United States public land survey. 
3.  By a written legal description of the exterior boundaries of the land as surveyed and divided. 
c.  The top of the plat shall be oriented north and the plat shall contain a north arrow. 
d.  A graphic scale. 
e.  The date of preparation. 
f.  The description and location of all survey monuments. 
g.  Survey data sufficient to reproduce any line or re-establish any monument in the subdivision. 
h.  A graphic presentation of all streets, alleys, blocks, parcels, and public grounds into which the land is divided and of all easements and rights-of-way. 
i.  The length of boundary lines of all streets, alleys, blocks, lots, parcels, public grounds, easements, and rights-of-way, or enough information so that the length of these lines can be derived by simple calculation. Where a boundary line is an arc of a circle, the length of the chord shall be shown. 
j.  The widths of all streets, alleys, easements and right-of-way. 
k.  A graphic presentation of the minimum building setback lines on all lots and parcels, and a notation of the distance between such lines and the street right-of-way line. In no case shall the setback line be less than that required by the zoning ordinance or major street plan, and official map. 
l.  The area of each lot or parcel containing an area of one acre or more. 
m.  Consecutive letters or numbers on all blocks and consecutive numbers on all lots throughout the plat. 
n.  The name of each street, printed on the graphic representation of each street, and an appropriate label designating all other easements, rights-of-way, setback lines, dedications and reservations ( e.g., "Dedicated for Park Purposes" or "Reserved for Public School site"). 
o.  Abutting street lines and adjoining lakes or streams at the date of survey and a graphic presentation, as well as a notation of, the high water marks of such lakes or streams. If any portion of the land within a subdivision shown on any final map is subject to inundation or flood hazard by storm waters, such fact and portion shall be clearly shown on the final plat by a prominent note on each sheet or such plat whereon any such portion shall be shown. 
(2)  The final plat shall include the following final plat certificates, in black (India) ink, or other reproducible ink. 
State of Illinois, Will County, Village of Crete 
Approved _____ Crete Plan Commission 
This _____ day of _______, 19___ A.D. 
Approved by _____
President, Village of Crete 
This _____ day of _______, 19___ A.D. 
(Ord. No. 571, Art. 3, § C(3), Art. 4, § D, 5-24-65) 
Sec. 23-44. - Engineering plans. 
(a)  Engineering plans are drawings, specifications, and construction cost estimates for all new construction of facilities in the development, and shall comply with the provisions of this section. Such engineering plans may be submitted at the same time as the preliminary plat or at any time up to and including the date of filing the final plat for village approval. 
(b)  Whenever new construction is required in the development of a subdivision, an engineer shall prepare all plans, specifications and construction cost estimates. Such engineer shall be approved by the board of trustees. If he so elects, and when so allowed by the board of trustees, the subdivider may contract with the village for the preparation of the engineering plans, specifications and cost estimates. These services will then be performed by the village engineer as directed by the board of trustees, provided that a deposit is placed in escrow payable to the village in accordance with the schedule then in effect between the village and the village engineer to cover the cost of engineering design services. All engineering plans are subject to the approval of the plan commission and the board of trustees. 
(c)  The engineer shall submit to the plan commission triplicate copies of the following plans, specifications, and cost estimates bearing his signature and the imprint of his seal: 
(1)  Plans and specifications for street construction, including centerline profile and grade line of each street with a typical cross section of the roadway. The street plan shall show the location of drainage structures and their sizes. The profile at grade lines shall be shown to a scale of one inch to 100 feet horizontal and one inch to ten feet vertical. Standard federal aid sheets are preferred. 
(2)  Plans, details, and specifications of proposed storm drainage improvements. 
(3)  Plans, details, and specifications of proposed community water distribution systems and of proposed community water supply facilities. 
(4)  Plans, details, and specifications of community sewerage systems and of community sewage treatment plants. 
(5)  Plans, details, and specifications of proposed street lighting systems, street signs and sidewalks. 
(d)  When unusual site conditions exists, the plan commission may require such additional plans, specifications, and drawings as are found necessary for an adequate review of the plat. The plan commission shall request this additional material from the subdivider by letter, stating therein the information requested and the particular or unusual site conditions which make this information necessary. 
(Ord. No. 571, Art. 3, § C, Art. 4, § C, 5-24-65) 
Sec. 23-45. - Recording. 
    Within seven days of receiving the approved final plat from the president and the recording fee from the subdivider, the village clerk shall submit the plat to the county recorder for recording and the final plat shall become the property of the county. Recording of the final plat authorizes the issuance of building permits, but does not constitute acceptance of proffered or required dedications. 
(Ord. No. 571, Art. 4, § E, 5-24-65) 
Secs. 23-46-23-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - DESIGN STANDARDS 

Sec. 23-61. - Generally. 
(a)  All subdivisions shall conform to the official plan, to the zoning ordinance and to this chapter, and to all other pertinent ordinances, resolutions, and plans. 
(b)  In order to promote the best possible development and use of land, the plan commission shall interpret the standards, provisions, and specifications contained in this chapter liberally and in favor of the community interest. Exceptions from these standards, provisions, and specifications may be granted when shown conclusively and to the satisfaction of the plan commission that such exceptions will bring about a more logical and desirable results than would be obtained by strict compliance. 
(c)  Each subdivision shall be appropriate to the topography, the drainage, and other natural features of the site. Developments shall be so laid out that they will tend to preserve, enhance, and promote the public benefit from natural scenic beauty. 
(d)  Land subject to flooding and land deemed by the reviewing authorities to be uninhabitable shall not be platted for residential occupancy, nor for such other uses as may increase danger to health, life, or aggravate the flood hazard, but such land within the plat shall be set aside for such uses as shall not be endangered by periodic or occasional inundation, shall not produce unsatisfactory living conditions, and shall not reduce the ability of the floodplain to retain floodwaters. 
(Ord. No. 571, Art. 5, § A, 5-24-65) 
Sec. 23-62. - Streets. 
(a)  The layout of streets in a subdivision plan shall conform to existing regulations and policies and shall be based on thorough consideration of: 
(1)  Topographic considerations and drainage. 
(2)  Public convenience and safety. 
(3)  The existing street pattern. 
(4)  The future circulation needs of nearby lands. 
(5)  The proposed uses of land to be served. 
(b)  Street rights-of-way in subdivisions shall be as designated on the official map, in all other instances, the following table shall apply: 
Width
(feet)
Major arterials (width as necessary) ..... 80 to 100 
Collector streets and minor arterials ..... 70 
Local streets ..... 66 
Marginal access street ..... 50 
Alleys: 
Residential ..... 20 
Business ..... 24 
Residential street widths shall be no less than 30 feet. Commercially zoned business street widths shall be no less than 54 feet. Greater right-of-way widths may be required where indicated by physical features and/or sound principles of highway design. Alleys shall be provided at the rear of all lots or tracts intended for business, commercial or industrial use, and multiple-family building use, but shall not be provided in residential blocks except where the subdivider produces evidence satisfactory to the plan commission of the need for alleys. 
(c)  Local streets in subdivisions shall be so designed as to discourage high-speed or through traffic. 
(d)  Streets shall not be laid out on the boundary of a subdivision. Exceptions may be permitted where streets are desirable for further expansion or where streets shall conform to the existing street system. 
(e)  Subdivision street intersections with major arterials shall be limited to not more than one per quarter mile unless topographic and physical conditions require a lesser distance. Street intersections shall be at right angles. Where unusual conditions exist, the plan commission may permit intersections of less than 90 degrees but not less than 60 degrees. In all cases street intersections and junctions shall be laid out so as to facilitate the safe flow of traffic. In no case shall two junctions be offset less than 125 feet. 
(f)  A cul-de-sac in a subdivision shall be not more than 500 feet in length measured along the centerline from the centerline of the street of origin to the center of the turn-around, and each shall have a terminus generally circular in shape, with a diameter of 120 feet and a center on, or within 30 feet of the cul-de-sac centerline. 
(g)  Whenever a subdivision borders on or contains the right-of-way of a limited access street, a railroad or a utility, a street may be required approximately parallel to and on either side of such uses as front thereon. 
(h)  Half-streets in subdivisions shall not be permitted except to complete an existing half-street which is dedicated and accepted, or to conform to the major street plan. 
(i)  Reserve strips controlling access to streets shall not be permitted. Streets roughly parallelling the subdivision boundary shall be located not less than one lot depth from the boundary. All streets intended to provide the subdivision with future means of ingress and egress shall extend to the subdivision boundary. 
(Ord. No. 571, Art. 5, § B, 5-24-65; Ord. No. 582, 1-10-66) 
Cross reference- Streets and sidewalks, ch. 22. 
Sec. 23-63. - Blocks. 
(a)  The length, width and shape of blocks in subdivisions shall be determined with due regard for the following: 
(1)  Provision of adequate building sites suitable to the special needs of the types of use contemplated. 
(2)  Zoning requirements as to lot size and dimension. 
(3)  Needs for convenient access, circulation, control and safety of street traffic. 
(4)  Limitations and opportunities of topography. 
(b)  Blocks shall not be less than 400 feet nor more than 800 feet in length, except as the plan commission considers necessary to secure efficient use of land or desired features of the street pattern. 
(c)  Where blocks exceed 600 feet in length or where orientation or pedestrian circulation requirements indicate, crosswalks may be required. Such crosswalks shall consist of public right-of-way or easement not less than ten feet in width. 
(Ord. No. 571, Art. 5, § C, 5-24-65) 
Sec. 23-64. - Lots. 
(a)  Residential lots served by a public sewerage system and public water supply system, shall not be less than 75 feet in width at the building setback line, nor less than 9,000 square feet in area; and in no case shall contain less area than the requirements of the zoning ordinance. In subdivisions not providing full community sewer and water facilities, increased area will be required as specified in sections 23-115 and 23-134 of this Code. 
(b)  All lots in subdivisions shall front directly on an improved public street. Lots adjoining state highways shall be provided with marginal access streets or shall front on an interior street. The same requirements shall apply with respect to major arterials. 
(c)  Side lot lines in subdivisions shall be at right angles or radial to the street line or substantially so, and along curvilinear street lines side lot lines so formed shall form a lot having a minimum frontage at the street right-of-way line and at the rear property line equal to the combined width of the two side yards required in the zone in which the lot is located or 25 feet which ever is the greater. 
(d)  Lots in subdivisions abutting an expressway or major arterial, a railroad right-of-way or other inharmonious use shall have a depth of 20 feet in excess of the typical interior lot in the same subdivision. A planting screen easement, across which there shall be no right or access, shall be required on such lots. 
(e)  Corner lots for residential use in subdivisions shall have sufficient extra width to permit appropriate building setback from and orientation to both streets but in no case shall be under 15 feet. A minimum side yard restriction of ten feet shall be shown on all lots adjoining a pedestrian crosswalk. 
(f)  Every lot in a subdivision shall contain a suitable building site. 
(Ord. No. 571, Art. 5, § D, 5-24-65) 
Sec. 23-65. - Easements. 
(a)  Easements in subdivisions shall be provided for any overhead or underground utility service. They shall have a minimum width of ten feet. Where it is intended that both overhead and underground utilities shall share the same easement, additional width sufficient to avoid conflict shall be provided. Easements shall be established along rear lot lines and such other lot lines as are required to provide continuity of alignment throughout the area to be served. 
(b)  When a subdivision is traversed by a water course, established drainage way, channel or stream, there shall be provided a storm water easement or drainage right-of-way conforming substantially with the lines of such water courses, and such further width or construction or both, as will be adequate, for proper drainage. It shall include additional area at least 15 feet in width adjoining each edge of the established water course as certified by the subdivider or his engineer. Where a ditch drainage is used in conjunction with storm sewers the easement shall be of sufficient width to allow future construction of a storm sewer main adequate to carry the ultimate run-off of the watershed. 
(Ord. No. 571, Art. 5, § E, 5-24-65) 
Secs. 23-66-23-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - IMPROVEMENTS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 23-81. - Scope. 
    The provisions of this article shall apply to subdivision improvements. 
Sec. 23-82. - Purpose. 
    It is deemed necessary and essential to require and control the provision and installation of improvements when property is subdivided and developed, in order to: 
(1)  Ensure conformity to the statutes governing the subdivision of land in the state; 
(2)  Cause the installation of the utilities and public service facilities necessary to serve the property developed; 
(3)  Provide for the current financing of said facilities; 
(4)  Spread the cost of required improvements upon the property benefitted; 
(5)  Prevent the dissipation or the improper use of public funds in providing these improvements or maintaining faulty installation; and 
(6)  Protect the living standards, public safety, and the common welfare of residents within and without the subdivision. 
(Ord. No. 571, Art. 6, § A(1), 5-24-65) 
Sec. 23-83. - Qualification of contractors. 
    The developer shall file with the plan commission a list of all contractors and subcontractors who are to participate in the construction of public improvements. Such contractors and subcontractors shall be subject to disqualification by reason of faulty performance of prior construction work done in the county. 
(Ord. No. 571, Art. 6, § (A)(2), 5-24-65) 
Sec. 23-84. - Time of construction. 
    All improvements required herein shall be completely installed before submittal of the final plat, the subdivider shall post surety bond guaranteeing the installation of these improvements within the time limits established by this chapter. The installation or bonding of required improvements shall be necessary prerequisites to final plat approval. 
(Ord. No. 571, Art. 6, § (A)(3), 5-24-65) 
Sec. 23-85. - Sequence of construction. 
    All underground utilities, sanitary sewers, and storm sewers installed in streets, alleys, service roads, or highways, shall be constructed or installed prior to the surfacing of such streets. Service connections to such underground utilities and sewers shall be extended to the property line of each lot so as to obviate disturbing the surface improvements in such public ways when service connections are later made. Where underground utilities are located in the parkway adjacent to the paved roadway service connections to properties across such roadway shall only be made by drilling under the pavement in such a way that surfacing is not disturbed or weakened. 
    The final surface coating for streets and all storm water drainage and detention facilities will be required to be completed by a date certain determined at the time of preliminary plat approval. 
(Ord. No. 571, Art. 6, § (A)(4), 5-24-65; Ord. No. 2000-34, § 2, 9-25-00) 
Sec. 23-86. - Debris removal. 
    The subdivider shall clean and maintain all public ways, sewers, and drains free from debris and trash or other extraneous material prior to acceptance and at such other times during construction as may be deemed necessary to prevent the creation of a public nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 571, Art. 6, § (A)(5), 5-24-65) 
Sec. 23-87. - Modification of design during construction. 
    After completion of all public improvements and prior to final acceptance of said improvements, the subdivider shall make or cause to be made, a map showing the actual location of all valves, manholes, stubs, sewer and water mains, and other improvements. This plan shall be in black (India) ink on tracing cloth, or materials of equal permanence and durability, and shall bear the seal and signature of the engineer. The presentation of this plan shall be a condition of final acceptance of the improvements and release of the surety bond assuring their completion. This plan or a reproduced (intermediate) copy, shall become the property of the village. 
(Ord. No. 571, Art. 6, § B, 5-24-65) 
Sec. 23-88. - Oversize improvements. 
    Whenever necessary, to conform to an overall plan or otherwise to protect or promote the public interest, oversize improvements may be required of the subdivider. 
(Ord. No. 571, Art. 6, § C, 5-24-65) 
Sec. 23-89. - Monuments. 
(a)  All U.S., state, county or other official bench marks, monuments, or triangulation stations in or adjacent to the subdivision shall be preserved. When a proposed improvement in a subdivision makes necessary the moving of bench marks, monuments, or stations, the authority having jurisdiction shall be notified and given sufficient time to take appropriate action. 
(b)  Permanent monuments shall be erected at all street corners and all points where street lines intersect the exterior lines of the subdivision and at all lot corners, block corners, angles in the streets or lot lines, and points of beginning or ends or curves. 
(c)  Permanent monuments shall be of either galvanized iron pipe not less than three-quarter inch in diameter and not less than 24 inches in length; or of stone or concrete not less than four inches in diameter and not less than 24 inches in length. In no case shall thin-wall pipe or electrical conduit be permitted. 
(Ord. No. 571, Art. 6, § D, 5-24-65) 
Sec. 23-90. - Grading. 
    Where it is proposed to alter ground elevations more than two feet, proposed as well as existing contours shall be shown on the contour map. Top soil removed during the course of grading or construction shall be redistributed evenly to a depth of at least four inches. All exposed areas shall be reseeded or sodded to prevent erosion. Seeding and sodding shall conform to the specifications set forth in article V of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 571, Art. 6, § E, 5-24-65) 
Sec. 23-91. - Inspection. 
(a)  All required land improvements to be installed under provisions of this chapter shall be inspected at the subdivider's expense. The engineer, as agent for the subdivider, shall provide an inspector on the job during the process of construction. When the work has been completed, the engineer shall certify that the improvements comply in all respects with the approved plans and specifications, and with the requirements of this chapter. All work shall also be at all times subject to inspection by the village engineer, where applicable by the superintendent of highways, the county health officer, the township highway commissioner and other public officials and their representatives. 
(b)  Before starting the construction of any improvements, the subdivider shall ascertain, from the village engineer, where applicable from the superintendent of highways county health officer, or township highway commissioner, what inspections are required and the amount of notification desired in each case, and shall comply with all their rules, regulations, and instructions, pertaining to such required inspections. 
(c)  Any inspection which requires that the superintendent of highways, the village engineer, or township highway commissioner be present shall be made by the official or his agent and reported in written form, and one copy shall be furnished to the engineer or other agent of the subdivider. 
(d)  Regardless of contract agreements, or inspections performed, final responsibility for the installation of all improvements, in accordance with the applicable standards, rests with the subdivider. 
(Ord. No. 571, Art. 6, § H(1)-(4), 5-24-65) 
Sec. 23-92. - Approval and acceptance. 
(a)  When street and drainage improvements in subdivisions and all appurtenances thereto, based on approval plans, have been constructed or installed and passed all inspections, the village engineer, or for areas outside the village the appropriate county or township officials, shall provide the developers with a letter of approval, completion, and acceptance by the public. 
(b)  When health and sanitary facilities, based on approval plans have been constructed or installed and have passed all inspections, the village engineer shall provide the developers with a letter of approval and completion. Such letter shall not constitute acceptance by the public; it shall be the responsibility of the agency intending to maintain and operate the facility to provide the developer with a letter of acceptance. 
(c)  When any required sewer or water improvement is not intended for public ownership, the appropriate inspecting agency shall provide the developer with a letter of approval and completion. Such letter shall not constitute acceptance by the public but shall permit the owner to operate and maintain the facility. 
(Ord. No. 571, Art. § H(5), 5-24-65) 
Sec. 23-93. - Guarantees of performance. 
    Final plat approval shall not be considered by the village unless and until the subdivider has guaranteed the completion of all required improvements in accordance with the standards and specifications required by ordinance. This guarantee shall consist of such sureties, either performance bond or cash, as shall be satisfactory to the village. The amount of the bond shall be equal to the village engineer's estimate of the cost of such public improvements and as certified by the village attorney. 
(Ord. No. 571, Art. 6, § G, 5-24-65) 
Secs. 23-94-23-105. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - IMPROVEMENTS REQUIRED 

Sec. 23-106. - Streets. 
    All subdivisions shall have streets which shall comply with the following: 
(1)  Unless otherwise specified, the type, design and construction of streets shall be in accordance with the provisions of article V of this chapter. 
(2)  Where the proposed subdivision fronts lots on only one side of a public street the subdivider shall be responsible for half of such street to be improved as described above. Whenever land adjacent to an existing public street is subdivided with lots facing thereon, and said street is not improved to a standard as high as that required for an interior street of similar character, the subdivider may be required to improve said public street but in no case shall the required expenditure for such improvement exceed that required for a similar interior street. Any improvement of an existing public street shall be subject to the approval of the public authority having jurisdiction. 
(3)  Street profile plans and cross sections for all subdivision streets shall be prepared by an engineer in accordance with the requirements of article V of this chapter, and the engineer, as agent for the subdivider, or his contractor, shall be responsible for establishing the proper lines and grades for all earthwork and drainage. 
(4)  Not less than one street of full width shall be provided to furnish the subdivision with access to an existing improved public street. The access street shall be improved by the subdivider in accordance with the standards appropriate to its function, whether or not it lies partly or entirely outside the subdivision. 
(Ord. No. 571, Art. 6, § F(1), 5-24-65) 
Cross reference- Streets and sidewalks, ch. 22. 
Sec. 23-107. - Storm drainage. 
    All subdivisions shall have storm drainage which shall comply with following: 
(1)  The storm drainage improvements shall conform to the system designed and established by the engineer and approved by the plan commission. Computations may be required for the entire watershed or drainage basin of which the subdivision is a part. The design and construction of such structures shall be in accordance with the specifications of article V of this chapter. 
(2)  In all residential subdivisions, and in all business and industrial subdivisions, underground storm sewer systems shall be constructed where required and installation shall be completed prior to the placement of any surfacing material. 
(3)  Special consideration shall be given to the avoidance of problems which may arise from concentration of stormwater runoff onto adjacent properties. All storm drainage shall be conducted and/or connected to an approved outfall. 
(4)  Adequate drainage structures shall be provided. The design installation, and construction of drainage structures shall comply with specification of article V of this chapter. 
(5)  In all subdivisions, storm drainage improvement plans shall include storm sewers having a sufficient number of inlets to effectively handle storm drainage. A sufficient number of inlets shall be provided (as mentioned) so as to allow the future connection of points of discharge of sump pumps and/or other water discharge flowing from individual buildings or natural drainage courses. All subdivision plats must include a statement to the effect that all future building within said subdivision shall be required to make appropriate connections to the village's storm drainage system. 
(Ord. No. 571, Art. 6, § F(2), (3), 5-24-65; Ord. No. 91-13, § 1, 4-22-91) 
Sec. 23-108. - Curb and gutter. 
    Curbs and gutters shall be provided in all subdivisions. 
(Ord. No. 571, Art. 6, § F(4), 5-24-65) 
Sec. 23-109. - Sidewalks. 
(a)  Sidewalks shall be required on both sides of all streets in subdivisions containing a majority of lots of less than 10,000 square feet in size. 
(b)  In subdivisions containing a majority of lots with 10,000 square feet or more, sidewalks may be required in accordance with the following standards: 
(1)  To provide a reasonable extension of an existing sidewalk system. 
(2)  To provide continuity between existing systems of sidewalks. 
(3)  To provide adequate pedestrian circulation in the vicinity of schools, shopping centers or other community facilities. 
(c)  In subdivisions where sidewalks are required, pedestrian ways bisecting blocks shall also be improved with sidewalks constructed to the same standards. 
(Ord. No. 571, Art. 6, § F(5), 5-24-65) 
Sec. 23-110. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2006-12, § 2, adopted March 27, 2006, deleted § 23-110, which pertained to street trees and was derived from Ord. No. 571, Art. 6, § F(6), adopted May 24, 1965. 
Sec. 23-111. - Street signs and names. 
(a)  Signs giving names of streets in subdivisions shall be created at all street intersections. Signs shall meet the minimum requirements for similar signs and posts as shall be specified by the village. 
(b)  Proposed streets in subdivisions which are obviously in alignment or continuation of existing streets already named shall bear the name of such existing streets. In no case shall the name for proposed streets duplicate existing street names irrespective of the use of the suffix street, avenue, road, boulevard, drive, place or court or an abbreviation thereof. 
(Ord. No. 571, Art. 6, § F(7), 5-24-65) 
Sec. 23-112. - Street lights. 
(a)  In residential subdivisions, street lighting shall be provided at all street intersections within or abutting the subdivision and at midblock intervals not exceeding 300 feet in length. 
(b)  Business area street lighting shall be of the high-level high-intensity type, and standards shall be placed every 150 feet on alternate sides of the street. 
(c)  The height, type, and degree of light shall be in accordance with the American Standard Practice for Street and Highway Lighting as approved by the American Standards Association on February 27, 1953, and as amended. In no event shall any light source be of less than 4,000 lumens in intensity. 
(Ord. No. 571, Art. 6, § F(8), 5-24-65) 
Sec. 23-113. - Water supply facilities. 
(a)  Central water supply, treatment and distribution systems shall be required in all subdivisions in which individual private water supply systems would in the opinion of the health officer or the village engineer, tend to create health problems. 
(b)  A water supply system shall be installed in all residential subdivisions with an average lot size of less than one-half acre located within the present or proposed service area of the village. 
(c)  All community water distribution systems shall be designed and constructed in accordance with the standards set forth by the state and the village. 
(Ord. No. 571, Art. 6, § F(a), 5-24-65) 
Sec. 23-114. - Fire hydrants. 
    Every water supply system in a subdivision shall have adequate pipe sizes, water pressure, and supply, and sufficient fire hydrants to provide fire protection to meet local neighborhood needs in accordance with standards of the village. Fire hydrants shall be installed such that no interval between hydrants exceeds 300 feet. 
(Ord. No. 571, Art. 6, § F(10), 5-24-65; Ord. No. 2003-56, § 2, 12-8-03) 
Sec. 23-115. - Sanitary sewage facilities. 
(a)  Residential lots located in a subdivision which are not served by a public sewerage system shall not be less than 75 feet wide at the building setback line, nor less than one-half acre in area; provided, a greater area may be required for such lots if, in the opinion of the county health department there are factors of drainage, soil condition or other conditions which cause potential health problems. The plan commission may require that data from percolation and other tests be submitted as a basis for passing upon proposed subdivisions dependent upon septic tanks as a means of sewage disposal. 
(b)  All central sanitary sewage facilities shall meet the design and performance specification set forth in article V of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 571, Art. 6, § F(11), 5-24-65) 
Sec. 23-116. - Planting screens, etc. 
    The subdivider shall plant, install, construct or otherwise provide all required fences, planting strips, or other required buffers along lot lines of houses within any development backing up to or adjoining any existing or future: 
(1)  Expressway; 
(2)  Railroad; 
(3)  Commercial area; 
The subdivision shall enclose any hazard which in the opinion of the plat-approving authorities might create a public nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 571, Art. 6, § F(12), 5-24-65) 
Sec. 23-117. - Landscaping and screening requirements. 
(a)  Purpose. Landscaping and screening requirements are designed to minimize the adverse impacts of adjoining land uses by visually separating adjoining uses from one another. The phraseology "adverse impacts" refers to such things as dust, dirt, litter, glare of lights, signs, unsightly advertisements and/or buildings and structures, parking areas or other impacts created in the form of vibration, erosion, odor, air pollution and water pollution. 
(b)  Requirements. Unless otherwise provided in the Crete Municipal Code, all yards shall be landscaped and continually maintained with green grass. And except for single-family or two-family structures, every permitted use requiring a parking lot, waste material storage, outdoor storage and the like shall be designed to include a planting screen for such parking areas, waste material storage facilities or outdoor storage areas. The planting screen shall be of sufficient length and width to achieve a visual separation of the adjoining uses and thereby mitigate the adverse impacts of each adjoining use. Subject to review and approval pursuant to the provisions of section 28-254 (of the zoning ordinance), alternative plans and requirements may be allowed. 
(c)  Planting screens. All planting screens shall consist of a combination of plant materials of which 50 percent shall be low-growing plants maturing to a height of not more than five feet, 25 percent of which mature to a height of not more than 15 feet, and the remaining 25 percent of which shall mature to a height of at least 25 feet. At least 30 percent of each height category (listed above) shall consist of evergreen plantings. Earthen berms, masonry walls, fences or a combination of such may be used in part as a partial substitute for the planting screens required above, provided, however, that any substitute must be reviewed and approved in accordance with the provisions of section 28-254 of the Crete Municipal Code. 
(d)  Placement of materials. The plant material used to satisfy the requirements of screening shall be so spaced that at maturity, each specimen will (when viewed in combination with surrounding specimens) form a tangential line. This requirement shall not govern those plant materials that mature to a height of at least 25 feet. Where berms, walls or fences are not used, the plant materials maturing to a height of less than five feet shall be planted at a density equivalent to three rows deep. If a berm, wall or fence is used, the required density of plant material may be reduced by 60 percent. 
(e)  Landscaping requirements. 
(1)  Commercial districts: In every commercial district, the required front, side and rear yards shall be landscaped in accordance with the following: 
a.  Front yards: For every 100 lineal feet of front yard there shall be provided one canopy tree; two understory trees; three shrubs. 
b.  Side yards: For every 100 lineal feet of side yard there shall be provided two canopy trees, four understory trees and six shrubs. 
c.  Rear yards: For every 100 lineal feet of rear yard there shall be provided three canopy trees, six understory trees, nine shrubs. 
d.  The requirements as set forth in subsections (1)a-c hereinabove may be reduced by 50 percent when used in combination with any installation of any fence, wall, berm or any combination thereof. 
(2)  Residential districts: In every residential district, the required front, side and rear yards shall be landscaped in accordance with the following and parkway trees shall be required as follows: 
a.  Canopy trees shall be planted in the right-of-way at locations identified by village staff at maximum distances of 50 feet from one another. If applicable, subdivision covenants requiring trees be located on private property may affect the placement of right-of-way trees if said private property trees are planted at time of construction. Right-of-way canopy trees must be maintained for a minimum of one growing season to ensure healthy development. 
b.  To ensure all yards are landscaped with grass as required by subsection (b) above, an acceptable performance bond or cash in the amount set annually by the village board is required to be posted with the village prior to the issuance of a provisional occupancy permit by the village in all instances where no grass seed or sod has been installed due to weather related delays. In all instances where a performance bond or cash has been posted, grass seed or sod will be installed within 180 days of issuance of the provisional occupancy permit. A permanent occupancy permit and bond or cash release will be issued upon establishment of healthy, growing grass. Bond or cash will be used for installation of sod upon 21-day notice to the homeowners in accordance with appropriate weather pattern. For the purpose of this section, appropriate weather pattern under normal circumstances will refer to April, May, September, October and November. Owners of record are still subject to property maintenance requirements concerning their property including weed control until grass seed or sod is installed. 
(f)  Plant types defined. For the purpose of this section, plants maturing to a height of not more than five feet shall be construed as low-growing plants, and shall include such plants as shrubs and shrubberies, but shall not include grasses or other forms of ground cover. Plants maturing to a minimum height of 15 feet shall be construed as understory trees. Plants maturing to heights exceeding 25 feet shall be construed as canopy trees. 
(g)  Landscaping of large parking lots. Where off-street parking for 50 or more vehicles is required, in addition to the required planting screen, a minimum of 25 square feet (for each parking space) shall be dedicated to open space within the perimeter of the whole of the parking area. Such area shall be landscaped. Each such landscaped area, in addition to satisfying the 25-square-foot requirement aforementioned, shall not be less than 100 square feet in area, nor less than ten feet wide, and shall be located so that no parking space shall be more than eight parking spaces in distance therefrom. The landscaping of such areas shall include a minimum of three canopy trees, two understory trees, and six shrubs for every 500 square feet of required landscaping area. All required plant material shall be maintained (pruned) so as to maximum public safety visibility. 
(h)  Minimum plant size. Unless as otherwise provided to the contrary (in the village's Municipal Code), all plant materials shall meet the following minimum size standards at the time of their planting:
