Secs. 23-118-23-130. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - ENGINEERING SPECIFICATIONS 

Sec. 23-131. - Generally. 
    The construction of improvements required in subdivisions by this chapter shall be in accordance with and to the requirements of this article. Unforeseen construction or improvements as may be required by unusual topographic, soil or other conditions shall be subject to the approval of the village engineer, and in such special cases, prior to actual construction, drawings, reports, data and work sheets may be requested. Unless otherwise specified, all street and storm drainage construction work shall be in accordance with the provisions of the Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction adopted January 2, 1958, by the Department of Public Works and Buildings, Division of Highways of the State of Illinois. Specifications and plans for all construction shall be subject to the approval of the village engineer. 
(Ord. No. 571, Art. 7, § A, 5-24-65) 
Sec. 23-132. - Streets. 
    The following specifications for the design, grading and surfacing of new and existing streets shall be adhered to: 
(1)  Design: 
a.  The maximum grades for collector and larger streets shall not exceed six percent. The maximum grades for other streets shall not exceed eight percent. In no case shall the grade of any street be less than three-tenths percent. 
b.  Vertical curves shall be provided at all changes in street grade. Length of vertical curves shall be determined by a good engineering judgement and in no case shall be less than 150 feet in length except at intersections with streets. In no case shall the vertical curve at a street intersection be less than 50 feet. 
c.  The minimum radius of center line horizontal curvature shall be as follows: 
Feet 
Arterial streets ..... 500 
Collector streets ..... 300 
Other streets ..... 100 
Angles on the center line of a street are not permitted. 
d.  Stopping sight distance shall be based on a line of sight, one end of which is four and one-half feet above the pavement and the other end four inches above the pavement. In flat topography sight distance of not less than 400 feet is desirable. In rolling topography sight distance shall be not less than 200 feet. 
(2)  Grading. All excavations, embankment and sub-grading work shall conform to the Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction. In general, back slopes of all ditches on street right-of-way shall be as flat as topography will permit. In no instance shall the back slopes of cut sections or ditches be less than two to one (two horizontal to one vertical). 
(3)  Surfacing. All streets within the subdivision shall be improved with a durable hard surface roadway. The pavement shall be equal to or superior to a pavement designed in accordance with the Illinois Department of Transportation Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction and the Design Manual. As a minimum, the road pavement shall consist of a base course of crushed stone or gravel with a prime coat for a total thickness of not less than ten inches when thoroughly compacted. The pavement shall have a bituminous binder course of a total thickness of not less then two inches when thoroughly compacted and a bituminous surface course of a total thickness of one inch when thoroughly compacted. The binder course shall be flush after compaction with the gutter flag and be installed prior to the issuance of any building permits for property fronting on the road. The surface course must be installed within a two-year period following the installation of the binder course. The pavement shall be designed to withstand the traffic [to which] the roadways will presumably be subjected and also be designed in accordance with local soil conditions and other factors which may affect the performance of the pavement. Other pavement construction may be used subject to the approval of the village engineer that meets or exceeds a minimum structural number of D(t) equals two point five as defined in the Design Manual of the Illinois Department of Transportation. The paved width of all streets shall not be less than 30 feet from face to face of curb. 
All alleys shall be improved with a roadway consisting of not less than five inches of crushed stone or gravel when thoroughly compacted and not less than 12 feet wide through residential blocks and 16 feet wide through business areas. 
(4)  Curbs and gutters. Concrete curb and gutter will be required for all streets in all subdivisions; the combination mountable type M-612 as specified in the state of Illinois Book of Standards No. 2130 or at least an equivalent curb and gutter as determined by the village engineer. 
(5)  Sidewalks. Sidewalks shall be located one foot inside the right-of-way line and shall be not less than four feet in width and five inches in thickness of the same width, if wider, of a connecting sidewalk. Construction shall be in accordance with section 89 of the Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction entitled, "Portland Cement Concrete Sidewalks." 
(6)  Erosion control. All road way ditches and slopes and all other slopes subject to erosion by runoff waters shall be properly protected by riprap, sod, seeding with rapid-growing grass or vegetation, and ditch checks. All such work shall conform to the applicable provisions of the Standard Specification for Road and Bridge Construction, State of Illinois. 
(7)  Streetlights. All streetlights shall be installed on approved poles and arms. Luminaries shall conform to the following Line Material Industry types or approved equals. 
a.  At intersections: Line 2B or 3C, 1ES Type V Distribution. No light source shall be less than 4,000 lumens. 
(Ord. No. 571, Art. 7, § B, 5-24-65; Ord. No. 89-14, § 1, 6-12-89) 
Cross reference- Streets and sidewalks, ch. 22. 
Sec. 23-133. - Storm drainage structures. 
(a)  The size and capacity of all drainage structures shall be computed using "Talbot's Formula" for run-off. Wherever practical, pipe culverts shall be used. The minimum length of culverts shall be at least equal to the distance from edge of shoulder to edge of shoulder, plus six times the vertical distance from the edge of shoulder to the flow line of the culvert. No culvert shall have a diameter of less than 12 inches. In no case shall entrance culverts be less than 20 feet in length. 
(b)  All bridges and culverts having a span of more than ten feet shall be approved by the village engineer. 
(c)  The storm sewer system shall be designed by the "Rational Method" with self-cleaning velocities as follows: 
(1)  The part of the system which serves as main or terminal collectors shall be of sufficient capacity to carry the maximum storm water flows which may occur in a ten-year period. 
(2)  That part of the system which serves as lateral collectors, and which can readily be augmented by future additions, shall be of sufficient capacity to carry maximum storm water flows which may occur in a five-year period. 
(3)  The coefficients of run-off shall be based on the types of development anticipated in all parts of the watershed affecting the drainage structure and shall be subject to approval of the village engineer. 
(4)  The system shall include all necessary appurtenances such as inlets, catch basins and manholes as may be required for proper operation and maintenance. 
(5)  Where the main storm sewer serving a subdivision can be expected to carry a substantial amount of storm water from adjoining land higher in the drainage area, and where the runoff from these lands can be expected to increase in the future because of more intense development, the developer may be permitted to substitute for such a storm sewer an open ditch. Such ditch shall comply with grading, seeding, and sodding specifications of this chapter, and such ditch shall be located on a drainage easement of sufficient width to permit its proper maintenance and to allow the eventual construction of an underground storm sewer adequate to serve the entire drainage area above the subdivision. 
(6)  No sewer line shall be less than ten inches in diameter. 
(7)  All materials for the construction of bridges, culverts, storm sewers, catch basins, manholes, inlets and other facilities shall conform to the Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction and Manual of Instructions for Field Engineers, published by the Bureau of Construction, Department of Public Works and Buildings, Division of Highways, State of Illinois. 
(d)  Effective July 1, 2004, wherever the Will County Stormwater Ordinance, adopted by reference as the Stormwater Management Ordinance of the Village of Crete in section 8-20, is more restrictive, then said Will County Stormwater Ordinance shall be applied. 
(Ord. No. 571, Art. 7, § C, 5-24-65; Ord. No. 2004-22, § 2, 6-28-04; Ord. No. 2019-03, 1-28-19) 
Sec. 23-134. - Water supply facilities. 
(a)  Individual private wells shall be located at least 25 feet from property lines, 50 feet from septic tanks, 75 feet from soil absorption fields of trench type construction, 100 feet from seepage pits, 25 feet from all cast iron sewer lines with mechanical or leaded joints, and 50 feet from cast iron sewer lines with unleaded joints, vitrified tile lines with water-tight lines or watertight sewers or other approved materials. Wells shall not be located within any area subject to flooding, unless proper protection is provided. Individual wells shall be constructed in accordance with the minimum requirements of the county. 
(b)  Public water supplies and distribution systems shall meet the requirements of the Illinois Department of Public Health and the village engineer. Plans and specifications shall be approved by the Illinois Department of Public Health. 
(Ord. No. 571, Art. 7, § D, 5-24-65) 
Sec. 23-135. - Sewage disposal facilities. 
(a)  Individual sewage disposal facilities shall be designed and constructed in accordance with the minimum standards as specified in the rules and regulations of the county health department. In addition, septic tanks shall be located so as to permit necessary cleaning and maintenance: where individual sewage disposal systems are located in rear yards, one of the side yards shall have a minimum width of ten feet to provide vehicular access to the rear yard. 
(b)  Community sewerage and sewage treatment facilities shall be designed in accordance with the rules and regulations of the state. Plans, specifications and construction work shall be subject to the approval and inspection of both the state and the village engineer. The village engineer shall be given not less than two days' notice in writing when construction is to be started. Effluent requirements for sewage treatment plants shall be based on the flow character, and use of the receiving stream. The village engineer in conjunction with the state shall establish the quality of effluent required in each particular case. 
(Ord. No. 571, Art. 7, § E, 5-24-65) 
Sec. 23-136. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2019-03, adopted Jan. 28, 2019, stated that the language previously included herein has been to be no longer operative effective February 1, 2019. Therefore, § 23-136, which pertained to the Will County Stormwater Management Ordinance, and derived from Ord. No. 2004-22, adopted June 28, 2004, has been deleted. Floodplain and stormwater regulations are found in chapter 8 of this Code. 
Secs. 23-137-23-150. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - DEDICATIONS, EASEMENTS AND RESERVATIONS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 23-151. - Right of refusal. 
    The number, size and location of dedications, reservations, and easements in subdivisions shall be subject to approval, and the plan commission shall ascertain that the proposed sites are suitable for the proposed uses. The public retains the right to refuse any and all dedications. 
(Ord. No. 571, Art. 8, § C, 5-24-65) 
Sec. 23-152. - Dedications. 
(a)  The following provisions shall apply to areas required to be dedicated in subdivisions: 
(1)  All new streets created by subdivision and shown on plats submitted for approval and recording shall be dedicated outright to the public. 
(2)  Additional street widths shall be dedicated along existing major streets where a width greater than that existing is called for by the major street plan and official map. 
(3)  Pedestrian ways bisecting long blocks, or where ever else located, shall be dedicated. 
(b)  Areas to be dedicated in a subdivision shall be clearly identified on the plat as dedicated to the public. 
(Ord. No. 571, Art. 8, § A, 5-24-65) 
Sec. 23-153. - Easements. 
(a)  The following shall apply to areas to be shown as easements in subdivisions: 
(1)  Public utilities, storm water facilities, and installations shall be located on suitable easements as specified in article IV of this chapter. 
(2)  Planting strips or other buffer zones, located between reverse frontage lots and a major street, or between incompatible uses, or wherever required. 
(b)  Easements shall be clearly identified on all plats. 
(Ord. No. 571, Art. 8, § B, 5-24-65) 
Sec. 23-154. - Reservations. 
(a)  Whenever the reasonable requirements provided by this chapter, including the official map, shall indicate the necessity for providing for a school site, park site, or other public lands within any proposed subdivision for which approval has been requested, and no such provision has been made therefor the board of trustees shall require that lands be designated for such public purpose before approving such plat. Whenever a final plat of subdivision, or part thereof, has been approved by the board of trustees as complying with the official map and there is designated therein a school having jurisdiction of such use, be it a school board, park board or other authority, such authority shall acquire the land so designated by purchase or commence proceedings to acquire such land by condemnation within one year from the date of approval of such plat; if it does not do so within such period of one year, the land so designated may then be used by the owners thereof in any other manner consistent with all ordinances including the official map and the zoning ordinance. 
(b)  Minimum reservations shall consist of the following: 
(1)  Elementary school sites (for combined school-park use) one acre per 30 dwelling units, with a minimum site size of ten acres. 
(2)  Park and playfield sites, one acre per 80 dwelling units, with a minimum site size of one-half acre. 
(3)  Fire, police, utility services, as required. 
(4)  High school and junior high school sites, as required. 
(c)  Areas reserved shall be clearly identified on the preliminary plat as reserved in accordance with this article. The preliminary plat shall also contain the proposals of the subdivider, as they might otherwise be platted, for the areas under reservation, to be applied in the event the land is not acquired by the public within the period of reservation. Upon completion of the period of reservation, the preliminary plat shall remain a valid preliminary plat for the formerly reserved areas for a period of one year. 
(d)  Where practicable, final plats shall not include areas reserved; the final plats should affect only that portion of the subdivider's land which is unrestricted by the reservations. Where final plats must include areas reserved, such areas shall be clearly identified as reserved in accordance with this chapter and shall not contain any proposals of the developer. Final plats may be submitted for reserved land unacquired by the public at the close of the reservation period. Such plats will be considered additional units of the subdivisions for which initial final plats were recorded. 
(e)  If the appropriate public agency having jurisdiction has not, within the reservation period, acquired the site reserved for a public use by the subdivider, he shall regain full and unencumbered title to the same, and may use it in any way and any purpose permitted by the pertinent regulations then in effect. 
(Ord. No. 571, Art. 8, § C, 5-24-65) 
Secs. 23-155-23-160. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - DEDICATION OF PARK LANDS OR FEES 

Secs. 23-161-23-170. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 95-26, § 2, adopted June 12, 1995, repealed Ord. No. 90-10, §§ 1-10, adopted Mar. 26, 1990, set out in this Code as Div. 2, §§ 23-161-23-170, and such repealed ordinance pertained to similar subject matter. 
Sec. 23-171. - Definitions. 
    Whenever the following words are used in this division, such words shall be deemed to have the following meanings: 
    Improved land means land located within a development which has been improved by installation of the required land improvements. 
    Demographic study means a study of the estimated ultimate population expected to be generated by a proposed development, based upon empirical historical data from similar developments. Such a study shall take into consideration demographic changes over time, dwelling types, number of bedrooms, and the number of preschool children, school age (grades K-12) children, and adults. 
    Park district means the Crete Park District, Will County, Illinois, or any public district within which a development or part of a development is located. 
    Public land is defined as real estate to be conveyed pursuant to the provisions hereof and to be utilized by the city, school district, and/or park district for uses including, but not limited to, parks, recreational sites, lakes, stormwater retention and detention areas, public forest areas, municipal service areas, public utility substations, storage areas and well sites, public natural resource areas, public golf course areas, school building sites, playgrounds and other similar uses. 
(Ord. No. 95-26, § 3, 6-12-95) 
Sec. 23-172. - Dedication of park lands or payment of cash in lieu thereof. 
    As a condition of approval of a final plat of a residential subdivision, a final plat for a residential planned unit development, a final plat of other residential development or, approval of a new residential structure building permit, each subdivider or developer or builder will be required to dedicate land for park and recreational purposes to serve the immediate and future needs of the residents of the development or new residential structure or make cash contribution in lieu of actual land dedication, or a combination of both, at the option of the village. The calculations for land to be dedicated or cash contributions in lieu thereof shall be established by determining the population of the development or new residential structure and the amount of land required to serve said population, determined as follows: 
(1)  Calculation of estimated population. The current "Table of Estimated Ultimate Population Per Dwelling Unit," as maintained by the Crete Park District, shall be used to calculate the amount of required park site land and cash contributions in lieu thereof. A written objection to use of the said table may be filed by the subdivider prior to village board approval of the preliminary plan. Such objection shall include a demographic study showing the estimated ultimate population to be generated by the subdivision. Final determination of the estimated ultimate population shall be made by the village board at the time of preliminary plan approval. It is recognized that population density, age distribution, and local conditions change over time, and that, therefore, the said table of estimated ultimate population per dwelling unit is subject to periodic review and amendment as necessary by the Crete Park District. 
(2)  Calculation of park land requirement. The estimated ultimate population of a proposed residential development shall bear directly upon the amount of land required to be dedicated for park purposes. The minimum requirement shall be five and five tenths acres of land per 1,000 of ultimate population in accordance with the standards hereinafter set forth, to wit: 
    Park site size and location standards:

(4)  Site approval requirements: The size, location and shape of the park land to be dedicated shall be subject to the approval of the village as part of the preliminary plan. The subdivider shall supply the park district with plats or other documents and information with regard to proposed park sites as soon as received or developed. Prior to village approval of the preliminary plan, the village shall have received a resolution of the park district governing board approving the location and acreage of any park land to be dedicated. The suitability of land to be dedicated for park sites shall be evaluated by the plan commission and village board according to the following standards: 
a.  The site should be essentially regular in shape to facilitate maintenance and to provide the optimum opportunity for recreational use. 
b.  The site should not be located on a major road when such a location would present a traffic hazard to park users. 
c.  The site should not be subject to frequent flooding. 
d.  The site should have soil and topographic conditions suitable to accommodate the anticipated facilities, including but not limited to parking areas, play fields, tennis courts, playground equipment, or other recreational facilities. 
e.  The site should be located in the approximate center of the residential area to be served wherever possible, and adjacent to a school site where consistent with the school site requirements hereof. 
(Ord. No. 95-26, § 4, 6-12-95; Ord. No. 98-13, § 1, 6-22-98) 
Sec. 23-173. - Criteria for requiring a cash contribution in lieu of park land. 
(a)  When cash contribution required. When the subdivision is small and the resulting site is too small to be practical, or when available land is inappropriate for park sites, or when park sites have already been provided, the village board may require the payment of cash contributions in lieu of the required land. The village board shall determine whether land or cash will be required when it approves the preliminary plan and may consider the recommendation of the Crete Park District in making such determination. When the Crete Park District has refused to accept a land contribution, the village board may require a cash contribution. 
(b)  Payment of park contribution. The cash contribution in lieu of park land shall be paid directly to the Crete Park District and held in trust to be spent solely in accordance with subsection (c) below, after approval of the final plat by the village board but prior to its execution and recording. The final plat shall not be executed by the mayor or recorded until the village receives an original receipt executed by the treasurer of the park district involved for payment of the amount required. In cases of new residential structure building permits, payment shall be made directly to the Crete Park District prior to issuance of the building permit or as negotiated with the Crete Park District as evidenced by written agreement. 
(c)  Use of contribution by park district. 
(1)  The cash contribution in lieu of park land shall be used solely for the acquisition of park land which will serve the immediate or future needs of the residents of the subdivision for which the contribution was received, or the improvement of existing park land which will serve such needs; provided, however, any expenditure of funds for land or improvements shall satisfy all applicable statutory criteria. Annexation agreements entered by the village pursuant to 65 ILCS 5/11-15.1-1 et seq. as amended with respect to land to be zoned to include residential uses shall include a provision that all cash received for the park district may be used by the park district for land acquisition, building construction, site improvements, capital improvements, equipment, operations, or any other purpose which will serve the immediate or future needs of the residents of the subdivision for which the contribution was received. 
(2)  Further, the park district shall spend a minimum of 50 percent of the contribution (a) within the subdivision from which it was received, or if no park land exists within said subdivision, (b) within park district real estate nearest said subdivision or for the purchase of park land within one and one-half miles of said subdivision. For subdivisions platted within the village limits, the park district shall spend 100 percent of the contribution within the village limits; for subdivision platted outside the village limits but within the planning jurisdiction of the village, the park district shall spend 100 percent of the contribution within the planning jurisdiction of the village. The village board may vary the requirements of this subsection (c)(2) if it finds that, based upon facts presented by the park district, such variance will result in park facilities which will serve the immediate or future needs of the residents of the subdivision from which the contribution was received. 
(d)  Return of contribution if not expended. If any portion of a cash contribution in lieu of park site land is not expended for the purposes set forth herein within ten years from the date of receipt, it shall be refunded, together with accrued interest thereon, to the owners of record of all lots, except public land, in the subdivision for which such contribution is made. The refund shall be paid to the person who is the owner of record on the day which is the tenth anniversary of the receipt of such contribution. The amount of the refund due to each lot owner shall be equal to the amount of the original contribution, divided by the total number of lots in the subdivision (excluding public land) for which the contribution was made. The village may permit one-year extensions of the ten-year restriction if the park district demonstrates that such funds have been allocated for an acquisition or improvement allowed herein, but have not been spent due to additional funds being necessary to complete such acquisition or improvement. 
(Ord. No. 95-26, § 5, 6-12-95; Ord. No. 98-13, § 2, 6-22-98) 
Sec. 23-174. - Amount of cash contribution. 
    The cash contribution in lieu of land shall be based on the fair market value of improved land within the subdivision. The fair market value of improved land in and near the village is hereby determined to be $40,000.00 per acre, which shall be used in the calculation of the required cash contributions, except as follows: 
(1)  If the village board determines that the specifics of the subdivision so warrant, it may require a formal appraisal; 
(2)  If the subdivider files a written objection to the use of the $40,000.00-per-acre value, he shall submit a formal appraisal. 
    Such appraisal shall show the fair market value of improved land in the area of the subdivision. Final determination of the fair market value per acre of land shall be made by the village board, based upon the appraisal or appraisals, and upon other information which may be submitted by the park district, school district, or others. The subdivider shall pay all appraisal fees. 
    Cash contributions for new residential building permits, not being calculated as part of a subdivision plat, shall be calculated according to the Crete Park District table of estimated ultimate population per dwelling unit, the minimum park acres of land per 1,000 population determination as set forth above in 23-172(2) and the village board determination of the fair market value of improved land in and near the village as provided above in this section. 
(Ord. No. 95-26, § 6, 6-12-95; Ord. No. 98-13, § 3, 6-22-98) 
Sec. 23-175. - Criteria for requiring land dedication and cash contribution. 
    There may be situations when a combination of land and cash in lieu of land are both necessary. At the time of preliminary plan approval, the village board may require a combination of land and cash in any of the following situations: 
(1)  When a previously designated park site lies partly within and partly outside of a proposed subdivision and the acreage of the designated park site within the subdivision is less than the park site acreage required herein, the subdivider shall contribute all of the designated park site lying within the proposed subdivision, and cash in lieu of the additional acreage needed to fulfill the requirements hereof. 
(2)  When part of a designated park site has already been acquired, and the land needed to complete it is less than the land required from the subdivision, then the subdivider shall contribute the amount of land needed from the subdivision to complete the park site and cash in lieu of the additional acreage needed to fulfill the requirements hereof. 
(3)  When the subdivider will be contributing certain park sites, and the balance of the required park site acreage would be too small or otherwise unsuitable for park sites, then the subdivider shall contribute cash in lieu of the balance of the required park site acreage. 
(Ord. No. 95-26, § 7, 6-12-95) 
Sec. 23-176. - Reservation of additional land. 
    Whenever the Crete Comprehensive Plan, or the standards of the village, or Crete Park District call for a park site within a subdivision larger than the required land contribution, the land needed in addition to the required contribution shall be reserved on the final plat for subsequent purchase by the park district. The park district shall acquire the land so designated by purchase or commence proceedings to acquire such land by condemnation within one year from the date of recording of the final plat; if the land is not so acquired or condemnation proceedings are not so commenced within said one-year period, the land so designated may then be used by the owners thereof in any other manner consistent with the Crete Municipal Code and compatible with said subdivision. 
(Ord. No. 95-26, § 8, 6-12-95) 
Sec. 23-177. - Condition of park sites. 
    Land improvements within the subdivision adjoining park sites shall be provided and paid for by the subdivider. In addition, park sites shall be fine graded, provided with a minimum of six inches of topsoil, and seeded as part of the required land improvements. Prior to commencing such work or any land improvements within a park or school site, the subdivider shall furnish a policy or policies of insurance insuring both village and the Crete Park District with coverages as approved by the village board and park district governing body. The subdivider shall provide certificates to village and the Crete Park District showing village and the Crete Park District as additional insureds. Such certificates shall provide for at least 30 days' notice to village and the Crete Park District prior to cancellation or modification in any respect. The failure to provide or maintain the insurance coverages or certificates as mentioned above shall be cause to stop construction and shall be cause for the refusal of issuance of construction and building permits or certificates of occupancy. 
(Ord. No. 95-26, § 9, 6-12-95) 
Sec. 23-178. - Time of conveyance. 
    The park sites required herein shall be conveyed to the appropriate park district grantee, as designated by the village, after village board approval of the final plat, which plat shall not be executed by the mayor or recorded until the governing body of the park district executes a written acceptance of the conveyance. Such acceptance of the conveyance shall not be deemed to constitute acceptance for purposes of maintenance. The subdivider shall be responsible for maintaining the park sites until the land improvements upon and adjoining such sites are officially accepted by the village board. 
(Ord. No. 95-26, § 10, 6-12-95) 
Sec. 23-179. - Payment of general real estate taxes and agricultural rollback taxes. 
    General real estate taxes and agricultural rollback taxes levied or which become due because of any conveyance against the park site which is conveyed, shall be the responsibility and obligation of the grantor. Grantor shall furnish evidence of payment of these taxes or deposit the amount of those taxes in escrow with the title company furnishing the preliminary report of title, requiring payment of the taxes when they become due. After payment of the taxes, evidence of such payment shall be furnished to the Crete Park District. The amount of any general real estate taxes and/or agricultural rollback taxes for the year of conveyance shall be pro-rated to the date of the delivery of deed. The amount of the general real estate and agricultural rollback taxes shall be based on the assessor's latest known rate, value, and equalizer, if any, for the land being conveyed. 
(Ord. No. 23-180, § 11, 6-12-95) 
Sec. 23-180. - Real estate conveyance requirements. 
    All real estate conveyed to the park district pursuant to the provisions of this division is hereby designated "public land." The subdivider shall furnish the village and the Crete Park District with a survey of the public land to be conveyed and a commitment, for title insurance issued by a licensed Illinois title insurance company, in a dollar amount equal to the value of the acreage conveyed as determined by the value per acre established in section 23-174 herein. If the village or park district objects in writing to defects in the title, the subdivider shall have 30 days from the date of delivery of such written objections to cure such defects. All deeds of conveyance pursuant to this division shall be recorded, at the subdivider's sole expense, in the office of the recorder of deeds of the county in which the property is located. All conveyances pursuant to this division shall be by warranty or trustee's deed subject only to the following: 
(1)  Acts done or suffered by, or judgments against the grantee, its successors and assigns; 
(2)  General taxes for the year of conveyance, and subsequent years; 
(3)  Zoning and building laws and/or ordinances; 
(4)  Public and utility easements of record which are reasonably acceptable to village and grantee; 
(5)  Conditions and covenants of record as contained only in plats of subdivision approved by the village; 
(6)  Rights-of-way for drainage ditches, feeders, laterals, and underground tile, pipe or other conduit; 
(7)  Such other exceptions to title that village and grantee shall find acceptable. 
    Each conveyance shall be accompanied by an appropriate affidavit of title. 
(Ord. No. 95-26, § 12, 6-12-95) 
Sec. 23-181. - Private recreational areas in lieu of dedicated park land. 
(a)  Private recreation areas and facilities may reduce the demand for local public recreational services. At the option of the village board, a portion of the public park site requirement may be provided in the form of private recreation areas. The extent of same shall be determined by the village, based upon the needs of the projected residents, the extent to which the private recreation areas are available for use by the residents of the subdivision, and available park land in the general area. 
(b)  In general, a substitution of private recreational areas for public park sites will require a substantially higher degree of improvement, such as the installation of recreational facilities and equipment by the subdivider. Detailed plans of facilities to be installed shall be submitted with the preliminary plan and shall be subject to review and approval of the village board. Before any credit is given for private recreation areas, the subdivider shall provide such guarantee that the private recreation areas will be permanently maintained for such use by the execution of such legal documents and the provisions of such sureties as village shall request. 
(c)  When an adjustment for private recreation area is warranted, it will be necessary to compute the total park land dedication that would have been required from the subdivision or planned unit development and then subtract the credit to be given. 
(Ord. No. 95-26, § 13, 6-12-95) 
Sec. 23-182. - Applicability. 
    If any subdivision subject to the terms hereof is located outside of the corporate limits of the village, and if the county in which the property is located has an ordinance which is more restrictive, or which would require a greater dedication or contribution than this division, as determined by the village, the ordinance of the county which the property is located shall prevail where inconsistent with the less restrictive provisions hereof. 
(Ord. No. 95-26, § 14, 6-12-95) 
Sec. 23-183. - Amendments to preliminary plan. 
    When a preliminary plan of a subdivision is amended, the required contribution of land or cash shall be recalculated for that portion of the subdivision which is amended based on the estimated ultimate population thereof. 
(Ord. No. 95-26, § 15, 6-12-95) 
Chapter 24 - TAXATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Village clerk, § 2-151 et seq.; village collector, § 2-166 et seq.; village treasurer, § 2-181 et seq.; licenses, permits and miscellaneous business regulations, ch. 12. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 24-1. - Retailers' occupation tax. 
(a)  A tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in the business of selling tangible personal property at retail in this village at the rate of one percent of the gross receipts from such sales made in the course of such business while this ordinance is in effect, in accordance with the provisions of section 8-11-1 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-11-1); provided, however, that the exclusions provided pursuant to P.A. 80-1292 effective August 2, 1978, contained in section 8-11-1 of the Illinois Municipal Code not apply to such tax. 
(b)  Every such person engaged in such business in the village shall file on or before the last day of each calendar month, the report to the State Department of Revenue required by section 3 of "An Act in Relation to a Tax upon Persons Engaged in the Business of Selling Tangible Personal Property to Purchasers for Use or Consumption" approved June 28, 1933, as amended (35 ILCS 120/3). 
(c)  At the time such report is filed, there shall be paid to the state department of revenue the amount of tax hereby imposed on account of the receipts from sales of tangible personal property during the preceding month. 
(Ord. No. 647, §§ 1-3, 9-10-69; Ord. No. 791, § 1, 12-18-78) 
Sec. 24-2. - Service occupation tax. 
(a)  A tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in this village in the business of making sales of service at the rate of three-quarters of one percent of the cost price of all tangible personal property transferred by said servicemen either in the form of tangible personal property or in the form of real estate as an incident to a sale of service, in accordance with the provisions of section 8-11-5 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-11-15); provided, however, that the exclusions provided by P.A.80-1292, effective August 2, 1978, contained in section 8-11-5 of the Illinois Municipal Code shall not apply to such tax. 
(b)  Every supplier or serviceman required to account for municipal service occupation tax for the benefit of this village shall file, on or before the last day of each calendar month, the report to the state department of revenue required by section 9 of the Service Occupation Tax Act (Ill Rev. Stat. ch. 120, par. 439.109). 
(c)  At the time such report is filed, there shall be paid to the state department of revenue the amount of tax hereby imposed. 
(Ord. No. 622, §§ 1-3, 5-13-68; Ord. No. 791, § 1, 12-18-78) 
Sec. 24-3. - Use tax. 
(a)  A tax is hereby imposed in accordance with the provisions of section 8-11-6 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-11-6) upon the privilege of using in the village any item of tangible personal property which is purchased outside the state at retail from a retailer, and which is titled or registered with an agency of state government. The tax shall be at a rate of one percent of the selling price of such tangible property. The term "selling price" shall have the meaning as defined in the Use Tax Act (35 ILCS 105/1 et seq.). 
(b)  Such tax shall be collected by the state department of revenue and shall be paid before the title or certificate of registration for the personal property is issued. 
(Ord. No. 724, §§ 1, 2, 11-11-74) 
Sec. 24-4. - Automobile renting occupation tax. 
(a)  A tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in the business of renting automobiles in this village at the rate of one percent of the gross receipts from such sales made in the course of such business in accordance with the provisions of section 8-11-7 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-11-7). 
(b)  Every such person engaged in such business in the village shall file on or before the last day of each calendar month, the report to the state department of revenue required by sections 2 and 3 of "An Act in Relation to a Tax upon Persons Engaged in the Business of Selling Tangible Personal Property to Purchasers for Use or Consumption" approved June 29, 1933, as amended (35 ILCS 120/2, 120/3). 
(c)  At the time such report is filed, there shall be paid to the state department of revenue the amount of tax hereby imposed on account of the renting of automobiles during the preceding month. 
(Ord. No. 844, §§ 1-3, 1-11-82) 
Sec. 24-5. - Automobile renting use tax. 
(a)  A tax is hereby imposed upon the privilege of using in the village an automobile which is rented from a renter outside the state and which is titled or registered with an agency of this state's government in the village at the rate of one percent of the rental price of such automobile, in accordance with the provisions of section 8-11-8 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-11-8). 
(b)  Every such person engaged in such business in the village shall file on or before the last day of each calendar month, the report to the state department of revenue required by sections 2 and 3 of "An Act in Relation to a Tax upon Persons Engaged in the Business of Selling Tangible Personal Property to Purchasers for Use or Consumption" approved June 29, 1933, as amended (35 ILCS 120/2, 120/3). 
(c)  The tax provided for in this section shall be collected from the persons whose state address for titling or registration purposes is given as being in this village. 
(d)  At the time such report is filed, there shall be paid to the state department of revenue the amount of tax hereby imposed on account of the renting of automobiles during the preceding month. 
(Ord. No. 845, §§ 1-4, 1-11-82) 
Secs. 24-6-24-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - VEHICLE LICENSE TAX[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Licenses, permits and miscellaneous business regulations, ch. 12. 
State Law reference- Vehicle license tax authorized, 65 ILCS 5/8-11-4, 625 ILCS 5/2-121. 

Sec. 24-21. - Definitions. 
(a)  Whenever the term "motor vehicle(s)" is used in this article II it shall be construed to include any vehicle which is self-propelled and licensed by this state or any other state as a passenger vehicle (including buses, motorhomes and recreational vehicles) or commercial vehicle which is principally designed to carry freight or cargo, and excludes motorcycles or motorized pedal cycles having three or less wheels in contact with the ground. 
(b)  Whenever the term "owner" is used in this section, besides the actual registered owner the word "owner" means and includes a lessee, licensee, bailee, or possessor of a motor vehicle having the use thereof with the consent of the registered owner or under a lease or other similar contractual agreement. It also means any person who has possession of a non-owned motor vehicle who resides within the village and regularly parks or keeps said vehicle within the village. Provided, however, motor vehicles owned and licensed by any state, county, federal or any taxing body and licensed with a State of Illinois "M" or "U" designated plate, state police district plate, county police plate or other state or federal government plate designating government ownership on its face or vehicles owned by charitable or not-for-profit organizations and bearing a plate designating such ownership are exempt from village vehicle license tax sticker requirement. 
(c)  The term "residing within the village" means and includes living within, residing within or cohabiting with a resident within the village or the owning, leasing, or otherwise controlling of property or a place of business wherein motor vehicles, trailers, or semi-trailers are stored, repaired, serviced, loaded, or unloaded within the city in connection with such business. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.52.1; Ord. No. 91-33, § 1, 9-9-91; Ord. No. 94-30, § 1, 11-28-94; Ord. No. 2005-04, § 2, 2-14-05; Ord. No. 2010-14, § 2, 3-22-10) 
Sec. 24-22. - Use of funds. 
    All taxes collected pursuant to this article shall, after deduction of the cost of issuing the licenses and collecting the fees, be kept as a separate fund and used only for paying the cost of street and alley repairs and improvements. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.52.8) 
Sec. 24-23. - License required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any motor vehicle owner or operator residing within the village to use, or to cause or permit any of his agents, employees, lessees, licensees, or bailees to use, any motor vehicle or any other vehicle upon the public ways of the city, unless such vehicle be licensed as hereinafter provided. Any motor vehicle which is registered with the Office of the Secretary of State of Illinois to an address within the village, shall be deemed prima facie evidence that such vehicle shall require a village vehicle license. Motor vehicles owned by the village shall be exempt from the provisions of this chapter. 
(b)  No person shall operate a motor vehicle as set forth in this chapter without said vehicle being duly licensed as prescribed herein. The operator of any such motor vehicle shall be subject to the same penalties as the owner for the violation of any of the terms of this article. 
(c)  The owner or operator of a motor vehicle or any other vehicle who resides in the village but maintains a situs or base of such vehicle located outside of the village shall not be exempt from the provisions of this section even if the motor vehicle is registered in another municipality and a similar license fee or tax is in the same or like manner imposed. 
(d)  Every such owner or operator as described above shall pay the tax or license fee according to the schedule provided in section 24-24. Such tax or license must be purchased within 30 calendar days of the acquisition of such vehicle. New residents of the village shall pay such tax within 30 days from the date of establishing residence in the village. 
(e)  Such village sticker emblem shall be affixed, in accordance with the instructions printed thereon which are made a part hereof, and without the use of supplemental adhesives, at the lower right-hand corner on the inside of the glass portion of the windshield of such motor vehicle, approximately one inch from the right and lower sections of the frame of such windshield. 
(f)  Whosoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this section shall be guilty of an offense and fined not less than $100.00, nor more than $750.00. Except when fines and costs are paid by compromise payment as provided in subsection (g) below prior to court, the court clerk shall add to the fine any and all costs and fees upon an authorized disposition. 
(g)  Any person accused of a violation of this section may settle and compromise said claim without a court appearance by payment of one half of the minimum required fine to the village clerk at the village hall within ten business days of the date of violation if the compromise box designation is so checked on the complaint and notice to appear form. 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.52.2; Ord. No. 705, § 1, 8-27-83; Ord. No. 812, Art. III, §§ 2, 3, 11-26-79; Ord. No. 91-33, § 2, 9-9-91; Ord. No. 92-6, § 1, 4-27-92; Ord. No. 2003-35, § 2, 9-22-03; Ord. No. 2010-14, § 2, 3-22-10) 
Sec. 24-24. - Amount. 
(a)  The tax referred to in section 24-23 shall be $50.00. All annual vehicle licenses shall expire on the last day of the fiscal year of the village for which they are issued. Licenses are considered delinquent and subject to citation if not purchased before June 1st. Effective 5/1/2014, the tax to be paid for all license stickers purchased after July 1 of each fiscal year thereafter shall be $100.00; provided further, the tax to be paid for all license stickers in accordance with subsection 24-23(d) shall be two times the amount applicable had it been purchased within the 30-day time period as provided. 
(b)  The village clerk shall mail to all known motor vehicle owners residing in the village a statement of the time of expiration of a current license prior to the date of such expiration or a statement of requirement for a license if none currently held. Failure to send out such notice, or the failure of the licensee to receive it, shall not excuse the licensee from a failure to obtain or renew a license, nor shall it be a defense in an action for operating or housing a motor vehicle subject to licensing under this article. 
(c)  The tax shall be reduced to $25.00 for all persons who become liable for the payment of said tax after October 31 of each year. Persons requesting the reduced rate shall submit proof of the purchase or acquisition date in the form of a bill of sale or equivalent; provided, however, such reduction is not available for replacement vehicles for vehicles owned prior to October 31 of said year. 
(d)  Notwithstanding the above scheduled fees, if the owner of a vehicle has attained the age of 65 years on or before June 1, of the year for which the license is to be issued, and as limited to one vehicle per household, the tax shall be at the rate of $25.00. Proof of ownership shall be established by the presentation of a state registration certificate and the owner's age shall be established by presentation of his driver's license. For license stickers purchased after July 1 the tax shall be two times the amount provided for in this subsection; provided further that this doubled amount shall not be applicable to vehicles subject to the provisions of subsection 24-23(d). 
(Code 1965, § 2.2.52.2; Ord. No. 705, § 1, 8-27-83; Ord. No. 812, Art. III, §§ 2, 3, 11-26-79; Ord. No. 91-33, § 2, 9-9-91; Ord. No. 92-6, § 1, 4-27-92; Ord. No. 2003-35, § 2, 9-22-03; Ord. No. 2010-14, § 2, 3-22-10; Ord. No. 2010-21, § 2, 4-26-10; Ord. No. 2013-12, § 2, 6-24-13; Ord. No. 2013-13, § 2, 6-24-13; Ord. No. 2014-12, § 2, 6-23-14) 
Sec. 24-25. - License. 
(a)  Every owner or operator of a motor vehicle required to pay a tax by the provisions of this article shall file an application with the village clerk, setting forth the name and address of the applicant and a description of the vehicle for which the tax is to be paid. Upon payment of the required tax the village clerk shall issue or cause to be issued a license which shall be attested by him, authorizing the use of such vehicle within the village during the fiscal year for which the tax is paid. Such license shall be in the form of a vehicle license tax sticker. The licenses issued to dealers in motor vehicles held for sale and used only for demonstration may be transferred to any other vehicle so held and used by the same dealer; provided that such dealers shall procure one license for each motor vehicle so held by him at any one time during the year. 
(b)  The fee which shall be paid to the village upon transfer of a license to another vehicle or replacement of a license shall be $3.00. 
(c)  As to motor vehicles, the vehicle tax license sticker shall be affixed to the inside of the lower right-hand corner of the front windshield in a space that is clearly visible from the outside. This provision is not intended to, nor shall it conflict with statutes, with respect to certain classifications of vehicles, prohibiting the same. In such instances, the president and board of trustees shall direct alternative placement of vehicle tax license stickers. 
(Code 1965, §§ 2.2.52.2, 2.2.52.5, 2.2.52.7; Ord. No. 629, § 1, 10-28-68; Ord. No. 705, § 1, 8-27-73; Ord. No. 812, Art. III, §§ 2, 5, 11-26-79; Ord. No. 90-11, § 2, 3-26-90; Ord. No. 2005-04, § 4, 2-14-05) 
Secs. 24-26-24-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - MUNICIPAL UTILITY TAX 
DIVISION 1. - GAS 

Sec. 24-51. - Tax imposed. 
(a)  A tax is imposed on all persons engaged in the following occupations or privileges: 
(1)  Persons engaged in the business of distributing, supplying, furnishing, or selling gas for use or consumption within the corporate limits of the Village of Crete, and not for resale, at the rate of five percent of the gross receipts therefrom. 
(b)  No tax is imposed by this division with respect to any transaction in interstate commerce or otherwise to the extent to which such business may not, under the constitution and statutes of the United States, be made subject to taxation by this state or any political subdivision thereof; nor shall any persons engaged in the business of distributing, supplying, furnishing or selling gas be subject to taxation under the provisions of this division for such transactions as are, or may become, subject to taxation under the provisions of the "Municipal Retailers' Occupation Tax Act," authorized by section 8-11-1 of the Illinois Municipal Code. 
(c)  Such tax shall be in addition to the payment of money, or value of products or services furnished to this municipality by the taxpayer as compensation for the use of its streets, alleys, or other public places, or installation and maintenance therein, thereon or thereunder of poles, wires, pipes or other equipment used in the operation of the taxpayer's business. 
(Ord. No. 2010-11, §§ 1-3, 3-22-10) 
Sec. 24-52. - Definitions. 
    Gross receipts means the consideration received for distributing, supplying, furnishing or selling gas for use or consumption and not for resale, as the case may be; and for all services rendered in connection therewith valued in money, whether received in money or otherwise, including cash, credit, services and property of every kind and material and for all services rendered therewith; and shall be determined without any deduction on account of the cost of the service, product or commodity supplied, the cost of materials used, labor or service cost, or any other expenses whatsoever; provided, however that "gross receipts" shall not include any amounts specifically excluded from the definition of gross receipts in subsection 8-11(2)(d) of the Illinois Municipal Code. 
    Persons means any natural individual, firm, trust, estate, partnership, association, joint stock company, joint adventure, corporation, limited liability company, municipal corporation, the state or any of its political subdivisions, any state university created by statute, or a receiver, trustee, guardian or other representative appointed by order of any court. 
(Ord. No. 2010-11, § 4, 3-22-10) 
Sec. 24-53. - Effective date. 
    This division shall take effect after publication and the tax provided for herein shall be based on the gross receipts, as herein defined, actually paid to the taxpayer for services billed on or after the 1st day of May, 2010. 
(Ord. No. 2010-11, § 5, 3-22-10) 
Sec. 24-54. - Making a return. 
(a)  On or before the last day of June, 2010 each taxpayer shall make a return to the village treasurer for the month of May, 2010 stating: 
(1)  His name; 
(2)  His principal place of business; 
(3)  His gross receipts during those months upon the basis of which the tax is imposed; 
(4)  Amount of tax; 
(5)  Such other reasonable and related information as the corporate authorities may require. 
(b)  On or before the last day of every month thereafter, each taxpayer shall make a like return to the village treasurer for a corresponding one-month period. 
(c)  The taxpayer making the return herein provided for shall, at the time of making such return, pay to the village treasurer, the amount of tax herein imposed; provided that in connection with any return the taxpayer may, if he so elects, report and pay an amount based upon his total billings of business subject to the tax during the period for which the return is made (exclusive of any amounts previously billed) with prompt adjustments of later payments based upon any differences between such billings and the taxable gross receipts. 
(Ord. No. 2010-11, § 6, 3-22-10) 
Sec. 24-55. - Erroneous payments. 
    If it shall appear that an amount of tax has been paid which was not due under the provisions of this division, whether as the result of a mistake of fact or an error of law, then such amount shall be credited against any tax due, or to become due, under this division from the taxpayer who made the erroneous payment; provided that no amounts erroneously paid more than three years prior to the filing of a claim therefore shall be so credited. 
(Ord. No. 2010-11, § 7, 3-22-10) 
Sec. 24-56. - Time limitation to recover tax due. 
    No action to recover any amount of tax due under the provisions of this division shall be commenced more than three years after the due date of such amount. 
(Ord. No. 2010-11, § 8, 3-22-10) 
Sec. 24-57. - Failure to make a return. 
    Any taxpayer who fails to make a return or who makes a fraudulent return or who willfully violates any other provision of this division is guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined not less than $100.00, nor more than $750.00 and in addition shall be liable in a civil action for the amount of tax due. 
(Ord. No. 2010-11, § 9, 3-22-10) 
Sec. 24-58. - Account maintenance. 
    The village clerk is hereby directed to send a certified copy of the ordinance from which this division derives to each utility company affected by this division. 
(Ord. No. 2010-11, § 10, 3-22-10) 
Secs. 24-59-24-80. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ELECTRIC 

Sec. 24-81. - Tax imposed on the using or consuming electricity. 
    A tax is imposed on all persons within the village limits on the privilege of using or consuming electricity in accordance with 65 ILCS 5/8-11-2, as follows in the following provisions of this division. 
(Ord. No. 2010-12, § 1, 3-22-10) 
Sec. 24-82. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this division, the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning: 
    Exempt purchaser: A purchaser who has applied for and received a resale number for the resale of electricity from the village administrator. 
    Gross receipts: The consideration received for distributing, supplying, furnishing or selling electricity for use or consumption and not for resale, as the case may be; and for all services rendered in connection therewith valued in money, whether received in money or otherwise, including cash, credit, services and property of every kind and material and for all services rendered therewith; and shall be determined without any deduction on account of the cost of transmitting the electricity, without any deduction on account of the costs of materials used, labor or service costs or any other expenses. 
    Person: Any natural individual, firm, trust, estate, partnership, association, joint stock company, joint venture, corporation, limited liability company, municipal corporation, the state or any of its political subdivisions, any state university created by statute, or a receiver, trustee, conservator or other representative appointed by order of any court. 
    Person maintaining a place of business in this state: Any person having or maintaining within this state, directly or by a subsidiary or other affiliate, an office, generation, facility, distribution facility, transmission facility, sales office or other place of business, or any employee, agent, or other representative operating within this state under the authority of the person or its subsidiary or other affiliate, irrespective of whether such place of business or agent or other representative is located in this state permanently or temporarily, or whether such person, subsidiary or other affiliate is licensed or qualified to do business in this state. 
    Purchase at retail: Any acquisition of electricity by a purchaser for purposes of use or consumption, and not for resale, but shall not include the use of electricity by a public utility, as defined in subsection 8-11(2) of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-11-2), directly in the generation, production, transmission, delivery or sale of electricity. 
    Purchaser: Any person who uses or consumes, within the corporate limits of the village, electricity acquired in a purchase at retail, other than an exempt purchaser. 
    Tax collector: The person delivering electricity to the purchaser. 
(Ord. No. 2010-12, § 1, 3-22-10) 
Sec. 24-83. - Rates for the consumption of electricity. 
(a)  Pursuant to subsection 8-11(2) of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-11-2) and any and all other applicable authority, a tax is imposed upon the privilege of using or consuming electricity acquired in a purchase at retail and used or consumed within the corporate limits of the village at the following rates, calculated on a monthly basis for each purchaser: 
(1)  For the first 2,000 kilowatt-hours used or consumed in a month; 0.61 cents per kilowatt-hour; 
(2)  For the next 48,000 kilowatt-hours used or consumed in a month; 0.40 cents per kilowatt-hour; 
(3)  For the next 50,000 kilowatt-hours used or consumed in a month; 0.36 cents per kilowatt-hour; 
(4)  For the next 400,000 kilowatt-hours used or consumed in a month; 0.35 cents per kilowatt-hour; 
(5)  For the next 500,000 kilowatt-hours used or consumed in a month; 0.34 cents per kilowatt-hour; 
(6)  For the next 2,000,000 kilowatt-hours used or consumed in a month; 0.32 cents per kilowatt-hour; 
(7)  For the next 2,000,000 kilowatt-hours used or consumed in a month; 0.315 cents per kilowatt-hour; 
(8)  For the next 5,000,000 kilowatt-hours used or consumed in a month; 0.31 cents per kilowatt-hour; 
(9)  For the next 10,000,000 kilowatt-hours used or consumed in a month; 0.305 cents per kilowatt-hour; 
(10)  For all electricity used or consumed in excess of 20,000,000 kilowatt-hours in a month; 0.30 per kilowatt-hour. 
(b)  The tax imposed is in addition to all taxes, fees and other revenue measures imposed by the village, the State of Illinois or any other political subdivision of the state. 
(c)  Notwithstanding any other provision of this divisions the tax shall not be imposed if and to the extent that imposition or collection of the tax would violate the Constitution or Statutes of the United States or the Constitution of the State of Illinois. 
(Ord. No. 2010-12, § 2, 3-22-10) 
Sec. 24-84. - Tax in addition to other payments. 
    The tax authorized by this division shall be in addition to the payment of money or value of products or services furnished to this village by the taxpayer as compensation for the use of its streets, alleys, or other public places or installation and maintenance therein, thereon or thereunder of poles, wires, pipes or other equipment used in the operation of the taxpayer's business. 
(Ord. No. 2010-12, § 3, 3-22-10) 
Sec. 24-85. - Collection. 
(a)  The tax authorized by this division shall be collected from the purchaser by the person maintaining a place of business in this state who delivers the electricity to the purchaser. This tax shall constitute a debt of the purchaser to the person who delivers the electricity to the purchaser and if unpaid, is recoverable in the same manner as the original charge for delivering the electricity. Any tax required to be collected pursuant to this division and any such tax collected by a person delivering electricity shall constitute a debt owed to the municipality by such person delivering the electricity provided that the person delivering electricity shall be allowed a credit for such tax related to deliveries of electricity the charges for which are written off as uncollectible and provided further, that if such charges are thereafter collected the delivering supplier shall be obligated to remit such tax. Persons delivering electricity shall also be authorized to add to such gross charge an amount equal to three percent of the tax to reimburse the person delivering electricity for the expense incurred in keeping records, billing customers, preparing and filing returns, remitting the tax and supplying data to the municipality upon request. If the person delivering electricity fails to collect the tax from the purchaser, then the purchaser shall be required to pay the tax directly to the municipality in the manner prescribed by the municipality. Persons delivering electricity who file returns pursuant to this section shall, at the time of filing such return, pay the municipality the amount of the tax collected pursuant to this division. In the event a purchaser shall make only a partial payment of any bill supplied to him, her or it by the supplier, any such partial payment not specifically identified by the purchaser to be applied to the tax imposed by this division shall be deemed to be for the delivery of electricity. 
(b)  On or before the last day of June, 2010 each tax collector shall make a return to the village treasurer for the month of May, 2010 stating: 
(1)  His name; 
(2)  His principal place of business; 
(3)  His gross receipts during those months upon the basis of which the tax is imposed; 
(4)  Amount of tax; 
(5)  Such other reasonable and related information as the corporate authorities may require. 
(c)  On or before the last day of every month thereafter, each tax collector shall make a like return to the village treasurer for a corresponding one-month period. The tax collector making the return herein provided for shall, at the time of making such return, pay to the village treasurer, the amount of tax herein imposed; provided that in connection with any return the tax collector may, if he so elects, report and pay an amount based upon his total billings of business subject to the tax during the period for which the return is made (exclusive of any amounts previously billed) with prompt adjustments of later payments based upon any differences between such billings and the taxable gross receipts. 
(d)  If it shall appear than an amount of tax has been paid which was not due under the provisions of this section, whether as the result of a mistake of fact or an error of law, then such amount shall be credited against any tax due, or to become due, under this section from the taxpayer or tax collector who made the erroneous payment; provided that no amounts erroneously paid more than three years prior to the filing of a claim therefore shall so be credited. 
(e)  No action to recover any amount of tax due under the provisions of this section shall be commenced more than three years after the due date of such amount. 
(Ord. No. 2010-12,§ 4, 3-22-10) 
Sec. 24-86. - Account maintenance. 
    The village clerk is hereby directed to send copies of the ordinance from which this division derives to all utility companies affected by this division and to provide to all utility companies affected by this division the names and addresses of all owners of properties subject to the tax within the corporate limits of the village, and to keep the list so provided as current as practicable so that the collection of the taxes is accomplished fairly and equitably toward all property owners and taxpayers. 
(Ord. No. 2010-12,§ 5, 3-22-10) 
Sec. 24-87. - Penalties. 
    Any taxpayer who fails to make a return or who makes a fraudulent return, or who willfully violates any other provision of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined not less than $100.00, nor more than $750.00 and in addition shall be liable in a civil action for the amount of tax due, together with all attorney's fees and costs of collection thereof. 
(Ord. No. 2010-12,§ 6, 3-22-10) 
Secs. 24-88-24-115. - Reserved. 
Chapter 25 - TRAFFIC[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 25-1. - Short title. 
    This chapter shall be known and may be referred to and cited as the "Village Traffic Code." 
(Ord. No. 858, § 1(Art. 4.1), 9-27-82) 
Sec. 25-2. - Definitions. 
(a)  Except as provided in subsection (b) hereof, and as otherwise provided in this chapter words and phrases used in this chapter shall have the same meaning as that which is given to them in The Illinois Vehicle Code (Illinois Revised Statute, Chapter 951/2). 
State Law reference- Applicable definitions, 625 ILCS 5/1-100 et seq., 625 ILCS 5/11-100. 
(b)  As used in this chapter: 
(1)  Property line shall mean the line marking the boundary between any street and the real property abutting thereon; 
(2)  Public building shall mean a building used by the village, the county, the school district or any other district authority, the state or the Government of the United States of America; 
(3)  Toy vehicle shall mean any nonmotorized vehicle propelled by the use of pedals or similar devices; 
(4)  Loading zone shall mean the space adjacent to a curb reserved for the exclusive use of vehicles during the loading or unloading of passengers or materials. 
(Ord. No. 858, § 1, 9-27-82) 
Sec. 25-3. - The Illinois Vehicle Code adopted. 
(a)  Pursuant to section 5/20-204 of the Illinois Vehicle Code (625 ILCS 5/20-204), the following portions of the 2000 Illinois Vehicle Code, including any subsequent amendment thereto, or revision thereof, are hereby adopted by references as if set out at length herein:
