Cross reference- Fees and fines schedule, § 2-301; buildings and building regulations, ch. 6; plumbing code, § 6-126 et seq.; health and sanitation, ch. 11; water pollution or obstruction of water supply, § 13-13; water supply and sewage disposal in subdivisions, §§ 23-113 et seq., 23-134 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 27-1. - Waterworks and sewerage system combined; department of public works established. 
(a)  [Combined waterworks and sewerage system; department of public works.] 
(1)  The existing waterworks system of the village and the existing sanitary sewerage system of the village are combined into a single utility known and designed as the combined waterworks and sewerage system of the village. Except as otherwise hereinafter provided to the contrary, all property comprising the existing waterworks system and sanitary sewerage system of the village shall constitute the properties of the combined waterworks and sewerage system of the village. 
(2)  There is also established a department of public works to operate and maintain said combined system together with other assigned duties regarding public buildings and infrastructure. The superintendent of public works shall be appointed annually by the village president with the consent of the board of trustees and shall be responsible for the combined waterworks and sewerage system of the village. The superintendent of public works shall have all powers to hire and terminate employees of the public works department, have responsibility for the preparation and implementation of the public works department budget and be responsible for the efficient operation of the public works department within budgetary constraints. The superintendent of public works shall further oversee all public works including construction and maintenance of roads, sanitary and storm sewers, public owned storm detention and retention, and construction and maintenance of public buildings, structures and facilities. 
(b)  Except as otherwise hereinafter provided to the contrary, the existing waterworks system and sanitary sewerage system are owned and operated by the village as a combined utility, known as the combined waterworks and sewerage system of the village, and all improvements and extensions to such waterworks or sewerage system, either or both, shall be considered as improvements and extensions to the combined utility; all the properties, assets, obligations and liabilities, of all kinds, of said waterworks system and of the sanitary sewerage system, existing, outstanding and accruing or to accrue, except as otherwise hereinafter provided to the contrary (please refer to subparagraph (c) hereinafter), shall be held, used, confessed and acknowledged as the properties, assets, obligations and liabilities of the combined utility. 
(c)  The cost of all periodic repair and maintenance of each and every water and sewerage system connection or "tap-in" shall be borne solely and exclusively by the "connecting party" or "property owner," as the case may be. The duty of payment for all repair and maintenance costs shall extend to the whole of each water and or sewerage extension as provided hereinafter without exception for either the reason or cause of repair or the fact that all or any portion of the user's extension may be within village property or property deemed to be within an easement or right-of-way belonging to the village. As used in this subparagraph, the phraseology "user's extension" shall, in the case of water connection or "tap-in", refer to the whole of the extension from the village's interceptor or "buffalo box" to the connecting party's or property owner's house or other end use exclusive of the village's "water meter," or metering device. In the case of a sewerage connection or "tap-in," the phraseology "user's extension" shall refer to the whole of the extension from the village's lateral or "trunk line" to the connecting party's or property owner's house or other end use. 
(Code 1965, §§ 7.1.1-7.1.3; Ord. No. 89-25, § 1, 9-11-89; Ord. No. 2003-30, § 2, 8-25-03) 
Sec. 27-2. - Inspections. 
    Employees of the waterworks and sewerage system of the village shall have the right at all times of access to any premises served by the system. Any person refusing to permit any employees of the waterworks and sewerage system to inspect his premises shall be guilty of an offense. 
(Code 1965, § 7.2.13) 
Sec. 27-3. - Connections generally. 
(a)  No connection shall be made with the combined waterworks and sewerage system without a permit from the village clerk. Any connection or opening made with the waterworks and sewerage system which is in any manner different from the mode prescribed for such opening or connection shall be unlawful. 
(b)  The village clerk is hereby authorized to grant such permits as he may deem proper, allowing persons to connect to the village's waterworks and sewage systems. The charge for tapping the village's waterwork mains and connecting therewith shall be an amount as set forth in article V of chapter 2 immediately to the right of the reference to section 27-3 for each "tap-in" and connection. For such charge, the village shall furnish the meter and "readout" meter. All costs and fees incurred as and for labor and materials required as part of the construction and installation of the "tap" and connection shall be at the expense of the property owner. All such "tap-ins" and connections shall be provided and constructed in a manner prescribed by the president and board of trustees as administered by the department of public works of the village. The permit fee for connection to the village's sewer system shall be an amount as set forth in article V of chapter 2 immediately to the right of the reference to section 27-3. The property owner and/or applicant involved in each such connection shall pay any and all fees and costs for labor and materials required in connection with the installation of sewer service from the village's sewer main to the property line. All such labor and materials shall be performed and sewer services shall be constructed in the manner prescribed by the president and board of trustees as administered by the department of public works of the village. All such construction and installation work must be inspected and approved by the department of public works. The connection charge and permit fee described hereinbefore shall be paid into the village's waterworks and sewage fund. 
(Code 1965, §§ 7.2.10, 7.2.11; Ord. No. 85-14, § 1, 10-14-85; Ord. No. 86-13A, § 1, 1-5-87) 
Sec. 27-4. - Special charges for extensions. 
(a)  When the village pays the cost of constructing new water main extensions or sewer main extension to furnish new service or when it is expressly understood by a separate special agreement that the costs of such water or sewer main construction are to be assumed by another person, there shall be imposed on all users connecting to the water or sewer main extension an additional charge equivalent to the pro-rata share of the cost of installing said extension. Such charge shall be computed by dividing the actual cost of all pipes, fittings, and other material used, the cost of all labor in and about constructing the extension, including engineering costs allocable to the extension by the total number of front feet abutting the extension. 
(Code 1965, § 7.2.15) 
(b)  In circumstances not contemplated by subsection (a) in which potential users will be limited, and/or where the extension of water lines will affect an expansion of the water system as a whole, or where larger piping than the normally used piping is utilized, or where a new water storage tank is constructed to serve areas not, or which were only partially served prior to the installation of the improvements, or for other good and valid purposes or reasons which, if not considered, would result in unrealistic or inequitable additional charges, or where any combination of the above factors shall exist, the president and board of trustees may by resolution adopt additional charges contrary to the provisions of subsection (a). 
(c)  In order to implement subsection (b), the president shall appoint a committee consisting of two village trustees and the village engineer to consider such special circumstances as may obtain and to report its findings and recommendations within 60 days of its appointment to the board of trustees, which report shall be in writing. A resolution shall then be presented to determine whether or not the report and the recommendations contained therein shall be adopted. If the resolution shall be approved, the schedule of fees on the described area shall become immediately in full force and effect. 
(d)  All such special charges shall be placed in a special bank account and shall be recorded in a special book of account to be set up and maintained by the village, which book of accounts shall be open to inspection at all reasonable times. Funds so collected and deposited shall be disbursed on November 1 each year until the village or such person constructing the extension under special agreement has been reimbursed for 85 percent of the entire cost paid by it for such extension, or until ten years has elapsed, whichever shall occur first. All rights, title and interest for such extensions within the corporate limits of the village, including easements and rights-of-way, shall remain vested in the village. 
(Code 1965, §§ 7.2.15, 7.2.16; Ord. No. 746, § 7.2.15a, 5-10-76) 
Sec. 27-5. - Read-out meters. 
    Water service connections shall not be authorized, nor a certificate of occupancy delivered to the owner or user of any premises which will utilize the village's water service unless such premises shall have installed a read-out meter. This provision shall also apply to subdivisions and parcels of land outside the corporate limits which, pursuant to agreement between the owner or developer of same and the village, will receive water service from the village. As used in this section the term "readout meter" shall mean a relay meter, relaying for outside vision or inspection by a water meter reader employee of the village for billing purposes, the readings of the principal water meter of the premises upon which it is installed. The cost to the user for the installation of a read-out meter shall be established at $20.00 if such installation is requested by a user. 
(Code 1965, §§ 7.2.1, 7.2.12; Ord. No. 614, § 1, 10-17-67; Ord. No. 83-11, § 1, 8-22-83) 
Sec. 27-6. - Rules and regulations. 
    The president and board of trustees are hereby authorized to make such rules and regulations consistent with this chapter for the connections to the waterworks and sewerage system, specifying the types and size of pipes and all the other appurtenances and extensions thereto, and amend the same from time to time as may be deemed necessary. All service pipes and connections to the combined waterworks and sewerage system shall comply with the said specifications and rules. Any person, firm or corporation not complying with the specifications and rules for connections to the waterworks and sewerage system shall be guilty of an offense. 
(Code 1965, § 7.2.12) 
Sec. 27-7. - Collection and handling of funds. 
(a)  The village collector shall render bills for service from the combined water and sewerage system and all other charges in connection therewith and collect all moneys due thereon. 
(b)  All moneys derived from the operation of the combined waterworks and sewerage system shall be held by the collector separate and apart from all other funds of the village and shall be delivered to the village treasurer not more than ten days after receipt of the same or at such more frequent intervals as may from time to time be directed by the president and board of trustees. 
(c)  The village treasurer shall receive all such moneys and deposit the same in a separate fund designated as the "waterworks and sewerage fund" of the village. The treasurer shall administer such fund in every respect in the manner provided by law. 
(d)  The village clerk shall establish a proper system of accounts and shall keep proper books, records and accounts in which complete and correct entries shall be made of all transactions relative to the combined waterworks and sewerage system, and at regular annual intervals he shall cause to be made by an independent auditing concern an audit of the books, to show the receipts and disbursements of the combined waterworks and sewerage system. 
(Code 1965, §§ 7.2.6-7.2.9) 
Sec. 27-8. - Altering water lines so as to prevent metering of water; tampering, etc., with meters, pipes, etc. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person or anyone acting at the instance of or in collusion with any person to dismantle, alter or change in any way whatsoever, the water line, or any portion thereof, used in connecting any facility served by village water services when it is reasonably foreseeable that such act may prevent the metering of water services relating to the facility. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any person or anyone acting at the instance of or in collusion with any person to alter, change, tamper, turn on or turn off or operate a water control valve (buffalo box) without written authorization by either the director of public works or the building inspector. The owner and/or resident of a property benefited by an unlawful act committed in violation of this subsection (a)(1) shall be subject to penalties for violations of this subsection as if the violation had been committed by the owner and/or resident personally. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person or anyone acting at the instance of or in collusion with any person to disconnect a water line or lines from any water metering device or to damage, destroy or remove any water metering device or to damage, destroy or remove any water metering device or "readout" meter providing metering of water services to any facility served by the village water services. 
(c)  Whosoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this section shall be guilty of an offense and fined not less than $75.00 nor more than $750.00. Except when fines and costs are paid by compromise payment as provided in subsection (d) below prior to court, the court clerk shall add to the fine any and all costs and fees upon an authorized disposition. 
(d)  Any person accused of a violation of this section may settle and compromise said claim without a court appearance by payment of one half of the minimum required fine to the village clerk at the village hall within ten business days of the date of violation if the compromise box designation is so checked on the complaint and notice to appear form. 
(Ord. No. 84-22, § 1(7.2.21), 11-26-84; Ord. No. 86-13A, § 1, 1-5-87; Ord. No. 2003-35, § 2, 9-22-03; Ord. No. 2012-08, § 2, 4-23-12) 
Sec. 27-9. - Smoke testing of sewer system. 
(a)  The village public works department is hereby authorized and directed to smoke test all or various portions of the village's sanitary sewer system following the issuance of notice as provided in subsection (b). The costs and expenses of the smoke testing shall be passed through to and charged against each sewer user in the form of an additional quarterly charge as shown in chapter 2, article V, to the right of the reference to section 27-9. 
(b)  The village clerk is hereby authorized and directed to publish and mail notices in substantially the following form: 
Notice of Smoke Testing 
of Public Sewer 
Within the Village of Crete 
    Notice is hereby given that ten days after the date of this notice, the village's public works department will conduct a smoke test of all or various portions of the village's public sewer system by introducing into said system a pungent, thick smoke produced by one or more smoke machines. The public is hereby notified that smoke used in said tests may appear from various residential connections. The appearance of smoke in residential connections may denote an illegal connection, which will require ordinance compliance on the part of the particular property owner. The public is requested to fully cooperate with various officials and employees of the village's public works department so as to minimize the village's cost while achieving the overall purposes of this particular test. 
    By authority of the president and board of trustees of the Village of Crete, Will County, Illinois. 
Dated: This _______ day of _______, 1990. 
/s/   
      Village Clerk 
      of Village of Crete   Such notice shall be given (by publication) in the Crete Record once, not less than ten days prior to the beginning of all or any portion of the testing and (by mail) to each person owning a lot or parcel within any particular affected area not less than ten days prior to the testing of the particular area of sanitary sewer. 
(c)  The village public works departments is further hereby authorized and directed to perform any and all additional inspections, repairs, and tests, including, but not limited to videotaping, relining and dye testing to determine points of unlawful connections or infiltration or inadequate, misfunctioning or unauthorized connections or infiltration to the sanitary sewer system. Costs and expenses shall be funded pursuant to the charge described in subsection (a) above. 
(Ord. No. 90-24, §§ 1, 2, 8-27-90; Ord. No. 2005-30, § 3, 7-25-05) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 90-24, §§ 1, 2, adopted Aug. 27, 1990, enacted provisions pertaining to smoke testing of the village sewer system. Such provisions, previously and inadvertently omitted, have been included by the editor and designated as § 27-9. 
Secs. 27-10-27-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - RATES AND CHARGES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Waste water service charges, § 27-51 et. seq., billing and collection of sewage service charges, § 21-61 et seq. 

Sec. 27-21. - Free service prohibited. 
    No free service shall be furnished by the village's combined water and sewerage system. 
(Code 1965, § 7.2.3) 
Sec. 27-22. - Within corporate limits. 
(a)  The following shall be the rates and charges for water and/or sewer service supplied by the village for premises located within the corporate limits based upon the amount of water consumed as shown by water meters: 
(1)  For users of combined water and sewerage service, the rate to be charged is as shown in article V of chapter 2 immediately to the right of the reference to section 27-22. 
(2)  For users of water only, the rate to be charged is as shown in article V of chapter 2 immediately to the right of the reference to section 27-22. 
(3)  For users of only sewerage system: 
a.  Each single-family unit or single residential premises shall pay an amount as listed in article V of chapter 2 immediately to the right of the reference to section 27-22. 
b.  Commercial and industrial users shall contract individually with the village based on rates to be established based on the volume and nature of the effluent or other pertinent considerations or an amount as set forth in article V of chapter 2 immediately to the right of the reference to section 27-22. 
(b)  Further, notwithstanding the provisions of subsection (a) providing for water usage rates, each water account will be charged a flat fee of $4.00 per month for the purpose of construction and maintenance of iron removal processing. Where water is supplied through a common meter serving multiple residential units, including, but not limited to, apartments, house trailers, mobile homes in trailer parks, multifamily structures of four units or more, nursing homes, hotels, motels, hospitals, senior assisted living units, and the like, the flat fee shall be calculated per said units and billed to said account. 
(c)  The rate for water imposed for various uses within the corporate limits during construction periods shall be in the amount as set forth in article V of chapter 2 immediately to the right of the reference to section 27-22. 
(Code 1965, § 7.2.1; Ord. No. 645, § 1(7.2.1(a)), 6-28-69; Ord. No. 756, § 1(7.2.1(b)-7.2.1(d)), 1-10-77; Ord. No. 83-11, § 1, 8-22-83; Ord. No. 85-10, 8-26-85; Ord. No. 86-13A, § 1, 1-5-87; Ord. No. 2016-16, § 3, 8-22-16) 
Sec. 27-23. - Outside corporate limits. 
    The president and board of trustees reserve the right to impose special rates and charges for users of the combined waterworks and sewerage system outside the corporate limits which shall be no less than the rates and charges imposed for users within the corporate limits. No such special charges or rates shall, however, operate to reduce the revenues of the combined water and sewerage system so that they shall be insufficient to provide ample funds to meet all requirements of any ordinance authorizing the issue of waterworks and sewerage revenue bonds as long as any of the revenue bonds remain outstanding and unpaid. 
(Code 1965, § 7.2.2) 
Sec. 27-24. - Persons liable. 
    The owner of the premises, the occupant thereof and the user of the service shall be jointly and severally liable to pay for the village water and/or sewerage service on such premises and the service is furnished to the premises by the village only upon the condition that the owner of the premises, occupant and user of the service are jointly and severally liable therefor to the village. 
(Code 1965, § 7.2.3) 
Sec. 27-25. - Reading of meters by customers. 
    If a customer of the village's water service is not at the premises served at the time of meter reading, thus preventing the reading of the meter, the village shall cause a self-addressed, postage paid card to be left with the consumer. The consumer in such event shall read the meter himself and forward the same to the municipal building without delay. Should the card not be returned within five days, the village shall bill the consumer in the form of an average billing, taking into account the two previous billings experienced by the consumer and prorating the same to secure an average figure. At the next billing period an adjustment will be effected. 
(Code 1965, § 7.2.1; Ord. No. 83-11, § 1, 8-22-83) 
Sec. 27-26. - Billing, due date, etc. 
    All bills for the village's water and sewer service shall be rendered quarterly as of the first day of the month succeeding the period for which the service is billed. All bills are payable not later than the close of business on the fifteenth day of the month the bill is received. A penalty of five percent is added to all bills not timely paid. Notice of disconnection as provided in section 27-28 shall be mailed for all bills not timely paid. When the fifteenth day of the month is a Saturday, Sunday or legal holiday, bills may be paid on the next following day. 
(Code 1965, §§ 7.2.1, 7.2.3; Ord. No. 83-11, § 1, 8-22-83; Ord. No. 2003-58, § 1, 12-8-03) 
Sec. 27-27. - Lien for unpaid bills. 
    The charges for service from the village's combined water and sewerage system are not paid within 25 days after rendition of the bill for such service, such charges shall be delinquent, and thereafter such delinquencies shall constitute liens upon the real estate for which service is supplied. The village clerk shall file from time to time as directed by the president and board of trustees, sworn, detailed statements showing such delinquencies in the office of the county recorder of deeds, and the filing of such statements shall be deemed notice of the lien for payment of the service rendered. 
(Code 1965, § 7.2.4) 
Sec. 27-28. - Termination of service for nonpayment. 
    If the rates or charges for service from the village's combined water and sewerage system are not paid within 15 days after rendition of the bill for such services, the village clerk shall notify in writing the owner of the premises, the occupant thereof, and the user of the service that such delinquency exists and that services shall be discontinued without further notice. Upon the disconnection of any service, a charge in the amount as set forth in article V of chapter 2 immediately to the right of the reference to section 27-28 shall be made for reconnecting the same after settlement of the delinquent account. 
(Code 1965, § 7.2.5; Ord. No. 86-13A, § 1, 1-5-87; Ord. No. 2003-58, § 1, 12-8-03) 
Secs. 27-29-27-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SEWERS[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- With the concurrence of the village, Ord. No. 817, Arts. I-VII, adopted Feb. 25, 1980, and Ord. No. 818, Arts. I, III, adopted May 10, 1980, together with Appendix I thereto, have been included herein as art. III, Sewers, §§ 27-36, 27-41-27-47, 27-51-27-55, 27-61-27-69. Appendix 2 to Ord. No. 817, containing permit forms, has been omitted from codification, but is on file and available for inspection in the offices of the village clerk and the superintendent of the department of public works. 
Cross reference- Ordinances specifically saved from repeal, see the adopting ordinance, page vii, the fifth paragraph, subsection (a), and § 1-3(14), of this Code. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 27-36. - Definitions. 
    Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the meaning of terms used in this article shall be as follows: 
    Administrator means the administrator of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency. 
    Approving authority means the _______ of the _______. 
    BOD (denoting biochemical oxygen demand) shall mean the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure in five days at 20 degrees Centigrade, expressed in milligrams per liter. 
    Building drain shall mean that part of the lowest piping of a drainage system which receives the discharge from soil, waste, and other drainage pipes inside the walls of the building and conveys it to the building sewer or other approved point of discharge, beginning five feet (1.5 meters) outside the inner face of the building wall. 
    Building sewer shall mean the extension from the building drain to the public sewer or other place of disposal. 
    Combined sewer shall mean a sewer which is designed and intended to receive wastewater, storm, surface and ground-water drainage. 
    Director means the director of the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency. 
    Easement shall mean an acquired legal right for the specific use of land owned by others. 
    Effluent criteria are [as] defined in any applicable NPDES permit. 
    Federal act means the Federal Water Pollution Control Act (33 U.S.C. 1251 et seq.) as amended by the Federal Water Pollution Control Act of Amendments of 1972 (P.L. 92-500) and P.L. 93-243). 
    Federal grant shall mean the U.S. government participation in the financing of the construction of treatment works as provided for by Title II-Grants for Construction of Treatment Works of the act and implementing regulations. 
    Floatable oil is oil, fat, or grease in a physical state such that it will separate by gravity from wastewater by treatment in an approved pretreatment facility. A wastewater shall be considered free of floatable fat if it is properly pretreated and the wastewater does not interfere with the collection system. 
    Garbage shall mean solid wastes from the domestic and commercial preparation, cooking, and dispensing of food, and from the handling, storage and sale of produce. 
    Industrial waste shall mean any solid, liquid or gaseous substance discharged, permitted to flow or escaping from any industrial, manufacturing, commercial or business establishment or process or from the development, recovery or processing of any natural resource as distinct from sanitary sewage. 
    Major contributing industry shall mean an industrial user of the publicly owned treatment works that: 
(1)  Has a flow of 50,000 gallons or more per average workday; or 
(2)  Has a flow greater than ten percent of the flow carried by the municipal system receiving the waste; or 
(3)  Has in its waste, a toxic pollutant in toxic amounts as defined in standards issued under section 307(a) of the federal act; or 
(4)  Is found by the permit issuance authority, in connection with the issuance of the NPDES permit to the publicly owned treatment works receiving the waste, to have significant impact, either singly or in combination with other contributing industries, on that treatment works or upon the quality of effluent from that treatment works. 
    May is permissive (see "shall"). 
    Milligrams per liter (mg/l) shall mean a unit of the concentration of water or wastewater constituent. It is 0.001 gram of the constituent in 1,000 milliliters of water. It has replaced the unit formerly used commonly, parts per million, to which it is approximately equivalent, in reporting the results of water and wastewater analyses. 
    Natural outlet shall mean any outlet into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake, or other body of surface or groundwater. 
    NPDES permit means any permit or equivalent document or requirements issued by the administrator, or, where appropriated by the director, after enactment of the Federal Water Pollution Control Amendments of 1972, to regulate the discharge of pollutants pursuant to Section 402 of the federal act. 
    Person shall mean any and all persons, natural or artificial including any individual, firm, company, municipal, or private corporation, association, society, institution, enterprise, governmental agency or other entity. 
    pH shall mean the logarithm (base 10) of the reciprocal of the hydrogen-ion concentration expressed by one of the procedures outlined in "Standard Methods". 
    Population equivalent is a term used to evaluate the impact of industrial or other waste on a treatment works or stream. One population equivalent is 100 gallons of sewage per day, containing 0.17 pound of BOD and 2.2 pounds of suspended solids. 
    ppm shall mean parts per million by weight. 
    Pretreatment shall mean the treatment of wastewaters from sources before introduction into the wastewater treatment works. 
    Properly shredded garbage shall mean the wastes from the preparation, cooking, and dispensing of food that have been shredded to such a degree that all particles will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public sewers, with no particle greater than one-half inch (1.27 centimeters) in any dimension. 
    Public sewer shall mean a sewer provided by or subject to the jurisdiction of the Village of Crete, Will County, Illinois. It shall also include sewers within or outside the village boundaries that serve one or more persons and ultimately discharge into the village sanitary (or combined sewer system), even though those sewers may not have been constructed with village funds. 
    Sanitary sewer shall mean a sewer that conveys sewage or industrial wastes or a combination of both, and into which storm, surface, and groundwaters or unpolluted industrial wastes are not intentionally admitted. 
    Sewage is used interchangeably with "wastewater". 
    Sewer shall mean a pipe or conduit for conveying sewage or any other waste liquids, including storm, surface and groundwater drainage. 
    Sewerage shall mean the system of sewers and appurtenances for the collection, transportation and pumping of sewage. 
    Shall is mandatory (see "may"). 
    Slug shall mean any discharge of water, sewage or industrial waste which in concentration of any given constituent or in quantity of flow exceeds for any period of duration longer than 15 minutes more than five times the average 24-hour concentration or flows during normal operation. 
    Standard methods shall mean the examination and analytical procedures set forth in the most recent edition of "Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater" published jointly by the American Public Health Association, the American Water Works Association and the Water Pollution Control Federation. 
    State act means the Illinois Anti-Pollution Bond Act of 1970. 
    State grant shall mean the State of Illinois participation in the financing of the construction of treatment works as provided for by the Illinois Anti-Pollution Bond Act and for making such grants as filed with the Secretary of State of the State of Illinois. 
    Storm sewer shall mean a sewer that carries storm, surface and groundwater drainage but excludes sewage and industrial wastes other than unpolluted cooling water. 
    Stormwater runoff shall mean that portion of the precipitation that is drained into the sewers. 
    Suspended solids shall mean solids that either float on the surface of, or are in suspension in water, sewage, or industrial waste, and which are removable by a laboratory filtration device. Quantitative determination of suspended solids shall be made in accordance with procedures set forth in "Standard Methods". 
    Unpolluted water is water of quality equal to or better than the effluent criteria in effect or water that would not cause violation of receiving water quality standards and would not be benefitted by discharge to the sanitary sewers and wastewater treatment facilities provided. 
    User class shall mean the type of user either residential or commercial (nonindustrial) or industrial as defined herein. 
    Industrial user shall mean any nongovernmental user of publicly owned treatment works identified in the Standard Industrial Classification Manual, 1972, Office of Management and Budget, as amended and supplemented, under the following divisions: 
(1)  Division A-Agriculture, forestry, and fishing. 
(2)  Division B-Mining. 
(3)  Division D-Manufacturing. 
(4)  Division E-Transportation, communications, electric, gas and sanitary services. 
(5)  Division I-Services. 
    Residential or commercial or nonindustrial user, shall mean any user of the treatment works not classified as an industrial user or excluded as an industrial user. 
    Village means the Village of Crete, Will County, Illinois. 
    Wastewater shall mean the spent water of a community. From this standpoint of course, it may be a combination of the liquid and water-carried wastes from residences, commercial buildings, industrial plants, and institutions, together with any groundwater, surface water, and stormwater that may be present. 
    Wastewater facilities shall mean the structures, equipment, and processes required to collect, carry away, and treat domestic and industrial wastes and transport effluent to a watercourse. 
    Wastewater treatment works shall mean an arrangement of devices and structures for treating wastewater, industrial wastes, and sludge. Sometimes used as synonymous with "waste treatment plant" or "wastewater treatment plant" or pollution control plant". 
    Water quality standards are [as] defined in the Water Pollution Regulations of Illinois. 
    Watercourse shall mean a channel in which a flow of water occurs, either continuously or intermittently. 
(Ord. No. 817, App. 1, 2-25-80; Ord. No. 818, App. 1, 3-10-80) 
Secs. 27-37-27-40. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - WASTEWATER DISPOSAL 

Sec. 27-41. - Use of public sewers required. 
(a)  Unlawful deposits on property. It shall be unlawful for any person to place, deposit or permit to be deposited in any unsanitary manner on public or private property within the village, or in any area under the jurisdiction of the village, any human or animal excrement, garbage or other objectionable waste. 
(b)  Unlawful discharges into natural outlets. It shall be unlawful to discharge to any natural outlet within the village, or in any area under the jurisdiction of the village, any sewage or other polluted waters, except where suitable treatment has been provided in accordance with subsequent provisions of this division. 
(c)  Septic tanks, cesspools, etc. Except as hereinafter provided, it shall be unlawful to construct or maintain any privy, privy vault, septic tank, cesspool, or other facility intended or used for the disposal of sewage. 
(d)  Connection to public sewers. The owner of all houses, buildings, or properties used for human occupancy, employment, recreation, or other purposes situated within the village and abutting on any street, alley, or right-of-way in which there is now located or may in the future be located any public sanitary for combined sewer of the village is hereby required at his expense to install suitable toilet facilities therein, and to connect such facilities directly with the proper public sewer in accordance with the provisions of this division, within 90 days after date of official notice to do so. 
(Ord. No. 817, Art. I (§§ 1-4), 2-25-80) 
Sec. 27-42. - Private sewage disposal systems. 
(a)  When use allowed. Where a public sanitary (or combined) sewer is not available under the provisions of section 27-41(d), the building sewer shall be connected to a private sewage disposal system complying with the provisions of this section. 
(b)  Permit required, application, fee. Before commencement of construction of a private sewage disposal system, the owner shall first obtain a written permit signed by the county health department and the village. The application for such permit shall be made on a form furnished by the village and the Will County Health Department, which the applicant shall supplement by any plans, specifications and other information deemed necessary by the village or the county health department. A permit inspection fee of $15.00 shall be paid to the village at the time the application if filed. 
(c)  When permit effective; inspections. A permit for a private sewage disposal system shall not become effective until the installation is completed to the satisfaction of the village and the county health department. They shall be allowed to inspect the work at any stage of construction and, in any event, the applicant for the permit shall notify the Village of Crete and the Will County Health Department when the work is ready for final inspection, and before any underground portions are covered. The inspection shall be made within 48 hours of the receipt of written notice by the Village of Crete and the Will County Health Department. 
(d)  Compliance with all regulations required. The type, capacities, location, and layout of a private sewage disposal system shall comply with all recommendations of the State of Illinois Private Sewage Disposal Licensing Act and Code and with the State of Illinois Environmental Protection Agency. No permit shall be issued for any private sewage disposal system not in compliance with the Will County Sewage Treatment and Disposal Ordinance. No septic tank or cesspool shall be permitted to discharge to any natural outlet. 
(e)  Abandonment of system upon availability of public sewer. At such time as a public sewer becomes available to a property served by a private sewage disposal system, as provided in section 27-41(d), a direct connection shall be made to the public sewer in compliance with this division, and any septic tanks, cesspools, and similar private sewage disposal facilities shall be abandoned and filled with suitable material. 
(f)  Operation and maintenance. The owner shall operate and maintain the private sewage disposal facilities in a sanitary manner at all times, and at no expense to the village. 
(g)  Additional requirements. No statement contained in this section shall be construed to interfere with any additional requirements that may be imposed by the Will County Health Department. 
(h)  Connection to public sewer; closed private system. When a public sewer becomes available, the building sewer shall be connected to such sewer within 60 days, and the private sewage disposal system shall be cleaned of sludge and filled with clean bank-run gravel or dirt. 
(Ord. No. 817, Art. II(§§ 1-8), 2-25-80) 
Sec. 27-43. - Building sewers and connections. 
(a)  Permit required. No unauthorized person shall uncover, make any connections with, or opening into; use, alter; or disturb any public sewer or appurtenance thereof without first obtaining a written permit from the village. 
(b)  Compliance with discharge standards. All disposal by any person into the sewer system is unlawful except those discharges in compliance with federal standards promulgated pursuant to the federal act and more stringent state and local standards. 
(c)  Classes of permits; application, fee. There shall be two classes of building sewer permits: 
(1)  For residential and commercial service; and 
(2)  For service to establishments producing industrial wastes. 
In either case, the owner or his agent shall make application on a special form furnished by the village. The permit application shall be supplemented by any plans, specifications, or other information considered pertinent in the judgment of the village building department. A permit and inspection fee of $15.00 for a residential or commercial building sewer permit shall be paid to the village at the time the application is filed. The industry, as a condition of permit authorization, must provide information describing its wastewater constituents, characteristics, and type of activity. 
(d)  Permit issuance. A building sewer permit will only be issued and a sewer connection shall only be allowed if it can be demonstrated that the downstream sewerage facilities, including sewers, pump stations and wastewater treatment facilities, have sufficient reserve capacity to adequately and efficiently handle the additional anticipated waste load. 
(e)  Owner's costs. All costs and expenses incident to the installation and connection of the building sewer shall be borne by the owner. The owner shall indemnify the village from any loss or damage that may directly or indirectly be occasioned by the installation of the building sewer. 
(f)  Separate building sewers required, exception. A separate and independent building sewer shall be provided for every building, except that where one building stands at the rear of another on an interior lot and no private sewer is available or can be constructed to the rear building through an adjoining alley, court, yard, or driveway, the building sewer from the front building may be extended to the rear building and the whole considered as one building sewer. 
(g)  Connecting new buildings to old sewers. Old buildings sewers may be used in connection with new buildings only when they are found, on examination and test by the village to meet all requirements of this division. 
(h)  Specifications for construction. The size, slope, alignment, materials of construction of a building sewer, and the methods to be used in excavating, placing of the pipe, jointing, testing and backfilling the trench, shall all conform to the requirements of the building and plumbing code or other applicable rules and regulations of the village. In the absence of code provisions or in amplification thereof, the materials and procedures set forth in appropriate specifications of the American Society of Testing Materials, Water Pollution Control Federation Manual of Practice No. 9, and Standard Specifications for Water and Sewer Main Construction in Illinois shall apply. 
(i)  Elevation and lifts. Whenever possible, the building sewer shall be brought to the building at an elevation below the basement floor. In all buildings in which any building drain is too low to permit gravity flow to the public sewer, sanitary sewage carried by such building drain shall be lifted by a means which is approved in accordance with paragraph (b) of this section, and discharged to the building sewer. 
(j)  Specific drainage connections prohibited. No person(s) shall make connection of roof downspouts, exterior foundation drains, areaway drains, or other sources of surface runoff or groundwater to a building sewer or building drain which in turn is connected directly or indirectly to a public sanitary sewer. 
(k)  Specifications for connection. The connection of the building sewer into the public sewer shall conform to the requirements of the building and plumbing code, or other applicable rules and regulations of the village, or the procedures set forth in appropriate specifications of the American Society of Testing Materials, Water Pollution Control Federation Manual of Practice No. 9, and Standard Specifications for Water and Sewer Main Construction in Illinois. All such connections shall be made gastight and watertight. Any deviation from the prescribed procedures and materials must be approved by the superintendent of public works of the village before installation. 
(l)  Supervision of connection required. The applicant for the building sewer permit shall notify the superintendent of public works of the village when the building sewer is ready for inspection and connection to the public sewer. The connection shall be made under the supervision of the superintendent of public works of the village. 
(m)  Protection and restoration of excavations. All excavations for building sewer installation shall be adequately guarded with barricades and lights so as to protect the public from hazard. Streets, sidewalks, parkways and other public property disturbed in the course of the work shall be restored in a manner satisfactory to the village. 
(Ord. No. 817, Art. III(§§ 1-13), 2-25-80) 
Sec. 27-44. - Regulation of discharges into public sewers. 
(a)  Drainage and process waters prohibited. No person shall discharge, or cause to be discharged, any stormwater, surface water, groundwater, roof runoff, subsurface drainage, uncontaminated cooling water, or unpolluted industrial process waters to any sanitary sewer. 
(b)  Discharge of unpolluted waters. Stormwater and all other unpolluted drainage shall be discharged to such sewers as are specifically designated as combined sewers or storm sewers, or to a natural outlet approved by the engineer of the village. 
(c)  Prohibited discharges. No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any of the following described waters or wastes to any public sewers: 
(1)  Any gasoline, benzene, naphtha, fuel oil, or other flammable or explosive liquid, solid, or gas; 
(2)  Any waters or wastes containing toxic or poisonous solids, liquids, or gases in sufficient quantity, either singly or by interaction with other wastes, to injure or interfere with any sewage treatment process, constitute a hazard to humans or animals, create a public nuisance, or create any hazard in the receiving waters of the sewage treatment plant; 
(3)  Any waters or wastes having a pH lower than five point five or having any other corrosive property capable of causing damage or hazard to structures, equipment, and personnel of the sewage works; 
(4)  Solid or viscous substances in quantities or of such size capable of causing obstruction to the flow in sewers, or other interference with the proper operation of the sewage works such as, but not limited to, ashes, cinders, sand, mud, straw, shavings, metal, glass, rags, feathers, tar, plastics, wood, unground garbage, whole blood, paunch manure, hair and fleshings, entrails and paper dishes, cups, milk containers, etc., either whole or ground by garbage grinders. 
(d)  Industrial cost recovery system required. No industrial user may discharge sewage into any public sewer until the village has adopted an industrial cost recovery system which: 
(1)  Meets the requirements of Section 204(b)(1)(B) of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act as amended and applicable federal regulations; and 
(2)  Has been approved by the agency in accordance with the conditions of any grant made to the village or the Thorn Creek Basin Sanitary District by the United States Environmental Protection Agency or by the State of Illinois for the construction of any part of the sewer system or sewage treatment works of the village or the Thorn Creek Basin Sanitary District. 
(e)  Harmful discharges limited or prohibited. No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged the following described substances, materials, waters, or wastes if it appears likely in the opinion of the engineer of the village and the superintendent of public works of the village that such wastes can harm either the sewers, sewage treatment process or equipment; have an adverse effect on the receiving stream; or can otherwise endanger life, limb, public property, or constitute a nuisance. In forming his opinion as to the acceptability of these wastes, the engineer of the village and the superintendent of public works of the village will give consideration to such factors as the quantities of subject waste in relation to flows and velocities in the sewers, materials or construction of the sewers, nature of the sewage treatment process, capacity of the sewage treatment plant, and maximum limits established by regulatory agencies. The substances prohibited are: 
(1)  Any liquid or vapor having a temperature higher than 150 degrees Fahrenheit (65° (C)); 
(2)  Any waters or wastes containing toxic or poisonous materials; or oils, whether emulsified or not, in excess of 100 mg/l or containing substances which may solidify or become viscous at temperatures between 32 and 150 degrees Fahrenheit (0 and 65° C); 
(3)  Any garbage that has not been properly shredded. The installation and operation of any garbage grinder equipped with a motor of three-fourth horsepower (0.76 hp metric) or greater, shall be subject to the review and approval of the superintendent of public works; 
(4)  Any waters or wastes containing strong acid, iron pickling wastes, or concentrated plating solutions, whether neutralized or not; 
(5)  Any waters or wastes containing iron, chromium, copper, zinc, or similar objectionable or toxic substances; or wastes exerting an excessive chlorine requirement, to such degree that any such material received in the composite sewage at the sewage treatment works exceeds the limits established by the Thorn Creek Basin Sanitary District; 
(6)  Any waters or wastes containing phenols or other taste-or odor-producing substances, in such concentrations exceeding limits which may be established by the Thorn Creek Basin Sanitary District as necessary after treatment of the composite sewage, to meet the requirements of the state, federal or other public agencies of jurisdiction for such discharge to the receiving waters; 
(7)  Any radio active wastes or isotopes of such half-life or concentration as may exceed limits established by the Thorn Creek Basin Sanitary District in compliance with applicable state or federal regulations; 
(8)  Any waters or wastes having a pH in excess of nine point five; 
(9)  Any mercury or any of its compounds in excess of 0.0005 mg/l as Hg at any time except as permitted by the Thorn Creek Basin Sanitary District in compliance with applicable state and federal regulations; 
(10)  Any cyanide in excess of 0.025 mg/l at any time except as permitted by the Thorn Creek Basin Sanitary District in compliance with applicable state and federal regulations; 
(11)  Materials which exert or cause: 
a.  Unusual concentrations of inert suspended solids (such as, but not limited to, Fullers earth, lime slurries, and lime residues) or of dissolved solids (such as, but not limited to, sodium chloride and sodium sulfate); 
b.  Excessive discoloration (such as, but not limited to, dye wastes and vegetable tanning solutions); 
c.  Unusual BOD, chemical oxygen demand, or chlorine requirements in such quantities as to constitute a significant load on the sewage treatment works; 
d.  Unusual volume of flow or concentrations of wastes constituting "slugs" as defined in section 27-36; 
(12)  Waters or wastes containing substances which are not amenable to treatment or reduction by the sewage treatment processes employed, or are amendable to treatment only to such degree that the sewage treatment plant effluent cannot meet the requirements of agencies having jurisdiction over discharge to the receiving waters. 
(f)  Disposition re hazardous or nuisance waste or waters. If any waters or wastes are discharged or are proposed to be discharged to the public sewers, which waters contain the substances or possess the characteristics enumerated in subsection (e) above, and/or which are in violation of the standards for pretreatment provided in chapter 1, EPA Rules and Regulations, subchapter D, Water Programs Part 128-Pretreatment Standards, Federal Register Volume 38, No. 215, Thursday, November 8, 1973, and any amendments thereto, and which in the judgment of the Thorn Creek Basin Sanitary District may have a deleterious effect upon the sewage works, process, equipment, or receiving waters, or which otherwise create a hazard to life, or constitute a public nuisance, the village or the Thorn Creek Basin Sanitary District may: 
(1)  Reject the wastes; 
(2)  Require pretreatment to an acceptable condition for discharge to the public sewers; 
(3)  Require payment to cover the added costs of handling and treating the wastes not covered by existing taxes or sewer charges, under the provisions of Division 3 of this article. 
If the Thorn Creek Basin Sanitary District permits the pretreatment of waste flows, the design and installation of the plants and equipment shall be subject to the review and approval of the Thorn Creek Basin Sanitary District and subject to the requirements of all applicable codes, ordinances and laws. 
(g)  Owner maintenance of pretreatment, etc., facilities. Where preliminary treatment or flow-equalizing facilities are provided, they shall be maintained continuously in satisfactory and effective operation by the owner at his expense. 
(Ord. No. 817, Art. IV(§§ 1-7), 2-25-80) 
Sec. 27-45. - Protection of sewage works from damage. 
    No unauthorized person shall maliciously, willfully, or negligently break, damage, destroy, or tamper with any structure, appurtenance, or equipment which is a part of the sewage works. Any person violating this provision shall be subject to immediate arrest under charges of disorderly conduct. 
(Ord. No. 817, Art. V(§ 1), 2-25-80) 
Sec. 27-46. - Powers and authority of inspectors. 
(a)  Right of entry; inquiry limitations. The superintendent of public works and other duly authorized employees of the village, the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency and the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, bearing proper credentials and identification, shall be permitted to enter all properties for the purposes of inspection, observation, measurement, sampling, and testing in accordance with the provisions of this division. The superintendent of public works or his representative shall have no authority to inquire into any processes, including metallurgical, chemical, oil refining, ceramic, paper or other industries beyond that point having a direct bearing on the kind and source of discharge to the sewers or waterway or facilities for waste treatment. 
(b)  Observance of safety rules; liability. While performing the necessary work on private properties referred to in subsection (a) above, the superintendent of public works or duly authorized employees of the village, the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency and the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency shall observe all safety rules applicable to the premises established by the company, and the company shall be held harmless for injury or death to the village employees and the village shall indemnify the company against loss or damage to its property by the village employees and against liability claims and demands for personal injury or property damage asserted against the company and growing out of the gauging and sampling operation, except as such may be caused by negligence or failure of the company to maintain safe conditions as required in section 27-44(g). 
(c)  Private property easements. The department of public works and other duly authorized employees of the village bearing proper credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter all private properties through which the village holds a duly negotiated easement for the purposes of, but not limited to, inspection, observation, measurement, sampling, repair and maintenance of any portion of the sewage works lying within such easement. All entry and subsequent work, if any, on said easement, shall be done in full accordance with the terms of the duly negotiated easement pertaining to the private property involved. 
(Ord. No. 817, Art. VI(§§ 1-3), 2-25-80) 
Sec. 27-47. - Penalties for violations. 
(a)  Notice of violation; permit revocation. Any person found to be violating any provision of this division except section 27-45 shall be served by the village with written notice stating the nature of the violation and providing a reasonable time limit for the satisfactory correction thereof. The offender shall, within the period of time stated in such notice, permanently cease all violations. The village may revoke any permit for sewage disposal as a result of any violation of any provision of this division. 
(b)  Fine; continuing violation. Any person who shall continue any violation beyond the time limit provided for in subsection (a) above, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and on conviction thereof shall be fined in the amount not exceeding $500.00 for each violation. Each day in which any such violation shall continue shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(c)  Liability of violator. Any person violating any of the provisions of this division shall become liable to the village by reason of such violation. 
(d)  Fine; subsequent violation. Any person found to have been previously in violation of any provision of this division, and thereafter having been deemed to have corrected said violation and thus be in compliance, shall be subject to the following fine schedule upon being found in violation of the same provision: 
(1)  One thousand dollars for a subsequent violation; 
(2)  Five hundred dollars for each day beginning on the 15th day following the date the subsequent violation is found and said violation continues. 
(Ord. No. 817, Art. VII(§§ 1-3), 2-25-80; Ord. No. 2006-18, § 2, 5-22-06) 
Secs. 27-48-27-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - WASTEWATER SERVICE CHARGES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Water and sewer rates and charges, § 27-21 et seq. 

Sec. 27-51. - Basis for computation of charges. 
    The wastewater service charge for the use of and for service supplied by the wastewater facilities of the village shall consist of a basic user charge for operation and maintenance plus replacement, a debt service charge and a surcharge, if applicable. 
(1)  The debt service charge shall be computed by dividing the annual debt service of all outstanding bonds by the number of users, usage. Through further divisions, the quarterly debt service charges can be computed. 
(2)  The basic user charge shall be based on water usage as recorded by water meters and/or sewage meters. It shall consist of operation and maintenance costs plus replacement and shall be computed as follows: 
a.  The estimated projected annual revenue required to operate and maintain the wastewater facilities including a replacement fund for the year, for all works categories. 
b.  Proportion the estimated costs to wastewater facility categories by volume. 
The adequacy of the wastewater service charge shall be reviewed annually by certified public accountants for the village in their annual audit report. The wastewater service charge shall be revised periodically to reflect a change in debt service or a change in operation and maintenance costs including replacement costs. 
(Ord. No. 818, Art. I(§ 1), 3-10-80) 
Sec. 27-52. - Measurement of flow. 
    The volume of flow used for computing basic user charges and surcharges shall be the metered water consumption read to the lowest even increments of ten gallons. 
(1)  If the person discharging wastes into the public sewers procures any part, or all, of his water from sources other than the public waterworks system, all or a part of which is discharged into the public sewers, the person may be required to install and maintain, at his expense, water meters of a type approved by the village for the purpose of determining the volume of water obtained from these other sources. 
(2)  Devices for measuring the volume of waste discharged may be required by the village if these volumes cannot otherwise be determined from the metered water consumption records. 
(3)  Metering devices for determining the volume of waste may be required to be installed, owned, and maintained by the person. Following approval and installation, such meters may not be removed, unless service is canceled, without consent of the village. 
(Ord. No. 818, Art. I(§ 2), 3-10-80) 
Sec. 27-53. - Debt service charge. 
    The debt service charge calculation and rate shall be as established by the village. 
(Ord. No. 818, Art. I(§ 3), 3-10-80) 
Sec. 27-54. - Basic user rate. 
(a)  There shall be and there is hereby established a minimum charge and a basic user rate for the use of and for service supplied by the wastewater facilities of the village. 
(b)  The calculations and rate for the basic user rate, the excess charge rate and the minimum flat rate charge shall be as established by the village. 
(c)  In the event use of the wastewater facilities is determined by the village to be in excess of the prescribed standard, the village may require such flat rate user to install metering devices, at his own expense, on the water supply or sewer main to measure the amount of service supplied. 
(Ord. No. 818, Art. I(§ 4), 3-10-80) 
Sec. 27-55. - Computation of wastewater service charge. 
    The wastewater service charge is computed by the formula as shall be as established by the village. 
(Ord. No. 818, Art. I(§ 5), 3-10-80) 
Secs. 27-56-27-60. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - BILLING AND COLLECTION[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Water and sewage rates and charges, § 27-21 et seq.; billing, due date, unpaid bills, §§ 27-26, 27-27. 

Sec. 27-61. - Billing. 
(a)  Rates or charges for service shall be payable quarterly. The owner of the premises, the occupant thereof and the user of the service shall be jointly and severally liable to pay for the service to such premises, and the service is furnished to the premises by the village only upon the condition that the owner of the premises, occupant and user of the services are jointly and severally liable therefor to the village. 
(b)  Bills for sewer service shall be sent out by the village collector on the first day of the quarter succeeding the period for which the service is billed. 
(c)  All sewer bills are due and payable 15 days after being sent out. A penalty of five percent shall be added to all bills not paid by the fifteenth day after they have been rendered. 
(Ord. No. 818, Art. III(§ 1), 3-10-80) 
Sec. 27-62. - Delinquent bills. 
    If the charges for such services are not paid within 30 days after rendition of the bill for such services, such services shall be discontinued without further notice and shall not be reinstated until all claims are settled. 
(Ord. No. 818, Art. III(§ 2), 3-10-80) 
Sec. 27-63. - Lien; notice of delinquency. 
(a)  Whenever a bill for sewer service remains unpaid for 105 days for quarterly service after it as been rendered, the village collector shall file with the county recorder of deeds a statement of lien claim. This statement shall contain the legal description of the premises served, the amount of the unpaid bill, and a notice that the village claims a lien for this amount as well as for all charges subsequent to the period covered by the bill. 
(b)  If the user whose bill is unpaid is not the owner of the premises and the village has notice of this, notice shall be mailed to the owner of the premises if his address be known to the village collector whenever such bill remains unpaid for the period of 105 days for a quarterly bill after it has been rendered. 
(c)  The failure of the village to record such lien or to mail such notice or the failure of the owner to receive such notice shall not affect the right to foreclose the lien for unpaid bills as mentioned in the foregoing section. 
(Ord. No. 818, Art. III(§ 3), 3-10-80) 
Sec. 27-64. - Foreclosure of lien. 
    Property subject to a lien for unpaid charges shall be sold for nonpayment of the same, and the proceeds of the sale shall be applied to pay the charges, after deducting costs, as is the case in the foreclosure of statutory liens. Such foreclosure shall be by bill-in-equity in the name of the village. The village attorney is hereby authorized and directed to institute such proceedings in the name of the village in any court having jurisdiction over such matters against any property for which the bill has remained unpaid 105 days in the case of a quarterly bill after it has been rendered. 
(Ord. No. 818, Art. III(§ 4), 3-10-80) 
Sec. 27-65. - Revenues. 
(a)  All revenues and moneys derived from the operation of the sewerage system shall be deposited in the sewerage account of the sewerage fund. All such revenues and moneys shall be held by the village collector separate and apartment from his private funds and separate and apartment from all other funds of the village, and all of said sum, without any deductions whatever, shall be delivered to the village collector not more than ten days after receipt of the same, or at such more frequent intervals as may from time to time be directed by the president and board of trustees of the village. 
(b)  The village collector shall receive all such revenues from the sewerage system and all other funds and moneys incident to the operation of such system as the same may be delivered to him and deposit the same in the account of the fund designated as the "Sewerage Fund of the Village of Crete". The collector shall administer such fund in every respect in the manner provided by statute of the Revised Cities and Villages Act, effective January, 1942. 
(Ord. No. 818, Art. III(§ 5), 3-10-80) 
Sec. 27-66. - Accounts. 
(a)  The village collector shall establish a proper system of accounts and shall keep proper books, records, and accounts in which complete and correct entries shall be made of all transactions relative to the sewerage system, and at regular annual intervals he shall cause to be made an audit by an independent auditing concern of the books to show the receipts and disbursements of the sewerage system. 
(b)  In addition to the customary operating statements, the annual audit report shall also reflect the revenues and operating expenses of the wastewater facilities, including the replacement cost, to indicate that sewer service charges under the wastewater cost recovery system and capital amounts required to be recovered under the industrial cost recovery system do in fact meet these regulations. In this regard, the financial information to be shown in the audit report shall include the following: 
(1)  Billing data to show total number of gallons billed; 
(2)  Debt service for the next succeeding fiscal year; 
(3)  Number of users connected to the system; 
(4)  Number of nonmetered users. 
(Ord. No. 818, Art. III(§ 6), 3-10-80) 
Sec. 27-67. - Notice of rates. 
    A copy of this article properly certified by the village clerk shall be filed in the office of the recorder of deeds of Will County, and shall be deemed notice to all owners of real estate of the charges of the sewerage system of the Village of Crete on their properties. 
(Ord. No. 818, Art. III(§ 7), 3-10-80) 
Sec. 27-68. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provisions of this division shall be fined not less than $100.00 nor more than $750.00 for each offense. A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day or part thereof on which a violation occurs or continues or is permitted to occur or continue. 
(Ord. No. 818, Art. III(§ 8), 3-10-80; Ord. No. 2003-35, § 2, 9-22-03;Ord. No. 2006-43, § 17, 12-11-06) 
Sec. 27-69. - Access to records. 
    The Illinois Environmental Protection Agency or its authorized representative shall have access to any books documents, papers and records of the village which are applicable to the village system of user charges for the purpose of making audit, examination, excerpts and transcriptions thereof to ensure compliance with the terms of the special and general conditions of any state grant. 
(Ord. No. 818, Art. III(§ 9), 3-10-80) 
Secs. 27-70-27-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - WATER 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 27-76-27-85. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - DROUGHT CONDITIONS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 88-15, § 1, adopted June 27, 1988, added provisions, pertaining to water restrictions during drought conditions, designated as §§ 27-29 and 27-30. For purposes of classification, such provisions have been redesignated by the editor as Div. 2, §§ 27-86 and 27-87, herein set out. 

Sec. 27-86. - Restrictions on water usage. 
(a)  The president and board of trustees of the village (hereinafter referred to collectively as the "village board") may, after due and careful consideration of prevailing weather conditions tending to create drought conditions, upon the passage and approval of a resolution, effectively ban the usage of water by any person, firm or corporation drawing water from the village's municipal water supply for private outdoor usage during times of general drought and when the public interest will be deemed to be served thereby. In this connection, the phraseology "usage of water" shall mean the continued withdrawal of water for outdoor usage from the village's municipal water supply. Such phraseology is not intended to restrict the use or reuse of water for indoor domestic use or uses or general commercial or industrial uses. 
(b)  The village board may ban water usage in one of three different stages depending upon the severity of prevailing weather conditions and the extremity of resulting drought conditions. Usage of water for nonessential outdoor uses shall be restricted in accordance with the following: 
(1)  Stage I restrictions. Stage I restrictions shall limit the usage of water to the extent that those who have an even-numbered mailing address shall be allowed to use water for outdoor purposes only on even-numbered days during the period of time in which the village board's Stage I restriction shall be in force and effect. Those village residents having an odd-numbered mailing address shall be allowed to use water for outdoor purposes only on each odd-numbered day during the said ban period. 
(2)  Stage II restrictions. Stage II restrictions shall restrict water usage to the extent provided under a Stage I restriction, but shall further restrict water usage to the extent that such water usage provided for under a Stage I ban shall only be allowed during the hours of 7:00 p.m. to 9:00 a.m. during a Stage II restriction. The determination as to whether a particular day and date shall be considered as an even-or odd-numbered day or date shall be ascertained by reference to the start of the time during which outdoor usage of water is allowed. In this connection, the first "7:00 p.m. hour" shall determine whether the day and the date is considered as even or odd in number. When a Stage II restriction on water usage has been declared, washing of cars or motor vehicles shall be prohibited. 
(3)  Stage III restrictions. Stage III restrictions on water usage shall effectively prohibit the usage of water for any outdoor purposes in its entirety. Exceptions to a Stage III restriction may be granted only by appropriate action of the village board. 
(c)  Exceptions to general restrictions on water usage. During the time during which an official Stage I or Stage II restriction is in effect, an exception to such restriction shall consist of usage of water for outdoor purposes in relation to newly sodded yards or other newly planted landscaping and to water usage required in filling swimming pools and cleaning motor vehicles. 
(Ord. No. 88-15, § 1, 6-27-88; Ord. No. 95-52, § 2, 10-23-95) 
Sec. 27-87. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2003-35, § 2, adopted Sept. 22, 2003, deleted § 27-87, which pertained to penalties for violation of water restrictions and was derived from Ord. No. 88-15, § 1, adopted June 27, 1988. 
Secs. 27-88-27-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLES V-IX. - RESERVED 

Secs. 27-101-27-1000. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - PENALTIES 

Sec. 27-1001. - Penalty; compromise payment. 
(a)  Unless a section or division provides a specific penalty, whosoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this chapter shall be (a) guilty of an offense and fined not less than $100.00 nor more than $750.00. Except when fines and costs are paid by compromise payment as provided in subsection (b) below prior to court, the court clerk shall add to the fine any and all costs and fees upon an authorized disposition. 
(b)  Any person accused of a violation of this chapter may settle and compromise said claim without a court appearance by payment of one half of the minimum required fine to the village clerk at the village hall within ten business days of the date of violation if the compromise box designation is so checked on the complaint and notice to appear form. 
(Ord. No. 2003-35, § 2, 9-22-03; Ord. No. 2006-43, § 17, 12-11-06) 
Chapter 28 - ZONING[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 6; drainage and flood control, ch. 8; mobile home parks, ch. 14; planning and development, ch. 19; subdivisions, ch. 23. 
State Law reference- Municipal zoning, 65 ILCS 5/11-13-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 28-1. - Short title. 
    This ordinance shall be known, cited and referred to as the "Crete Zoning Ordinance". 
(Ord. No. 850, Art. 1, 5-24-82) 
Sec. 28-2. - Rules of construction. 
    The following rules shall be observed and applied in the interpretation of this chapter except when the text clearly indicates otherwise. 
(1)  The word "lot" shall include plot and parcel. 
(2)  The words "building and/or structures" shall include all non-living improvements upon the land. 
(3)  The phrase "used for" shall include the phrases "designed for", "intended for", "occupied for or by", and "maintained for". 
(4)  The masculine gender shall include the feminine and neuter genders. 
(Ord. No. 850, § 12.0, 5-24-82) 
Sec. 28-3. - Definitions. 
    The following words and terms, when used in this chapter, shall have the meaning set forth below, except where otherwise specifically indicated. 
    Abutting: To have a common property line or district line. 
    Accessory building or use: A building or use which: 
(1)  Is subordinate to and serves a principal building or principal use. 
(2)  Is subordinate in area, extent or purpose to the principal building or principal use served. 
(3)  Contributes to the comfort, convenience or necessity of occupants of the principal building or principal use served. 
(4)  Is located on the same zoning lot as the principal building or potential use served with the single exception of such accessory off street parking facilities as are permitted to locate elsewhere than on the same zoning lot with the building or use served. 
    Adjacent: Lying near or in the immediate vicinity. 
    Adjoining: Touching or contiguous, as distinguished from lying near. 
    Advertising: See "sign." 
    Aerials or antennas: Structures or devices used to detect or radiate electromagnetic waves; specifically that part of a radar or of a radio-sending or radio-receiving set that consists of that apparatus that radiates waves or receives them. Structures shall not be located in the front yard or side yard of a residence or business district and shall not exceed the height limitation established by the Federal Communications Commission. 
    Agriculture: The use of land for agricultural purposes, including farming, dairying, pasturage, apiculture, horticulture, floriculture, viticulture, and animal and poultry husbandry, and the necessary accessory uses for packing, treating or storing the produce; provided, however, that the operation of any such accessory uses shall be secondary to that of the normal agricultural activities. Included are truck-farming, poultry farming, beekeeping, raising of fruit and berries, and the selling of agricultural products, but shall not include mechanized industrial animal farms. "Agriculture" shall not include the commercial feeding of garbage to swine or other animals. 
    Agricultural building or structure: Any building or structure existing or erected on land used principally for agricultural purposes, with the exception of dwelling units. 
    Alley: A public or private way, at the rear or side of property, permanently reserved as a means of secondary vehicular access to abutting property. Frontage on the alley shall not be construed as satisfying the requirements of this chapter related to frontage on a dedicated street. 
    Alteration: Any change in size, shape, character, occupancy or use of a building or structure. 
    Animal hospital: Any building or portion thereof designed or used for the care, observation, or treatment of domestic animals. 
    Apartment: See "dwelling unit." 
    Apartment building: See "dwelling, multifamily." 
    Arterial street: See "road classifications." 
    Auditorium: A room hall or building made a part of a church, theatre, school, recreation building, or building assigned to the gathering of people as an audience to hear lectures, plays and other presentations. 
    Automobile laundry: A building or portion thereof, containing facilities for washing more than two automobiles, providing space, water, equipment or soap for the washing of automobiles by the operator or customer. Production line methods using mechanical devices are permitted. 
    Automobile repair, major: The general repair, engine rebuilding or reconditioning of motor vehicles, collision service; such as body, frame and fender straightening and repair and painting of motor vehicles. 
    Auto repair, minor: Incidental repairs, replacement of parts and motor service to automobiles but excluding any operation specified under "automobile repair, major." 
    Automobile service station: Any building or premises used for the dispensing, sale or offering for sale at retail to the public, automobile fuels stored only in underground tanks and located wholly within the lot lines; lubricating oil or grease for the operation of automobiles; and the sale and installation of tires, batteries, other minor accessories, and minor auto repair, but not including a bulk plant, conduct of major auto repairs, automobile wrecking, automobile sales or automobile laundries; provided, however, that the washing of individual's automobiles where no chain conveyor is employed may be included. 
    Awning: A rooflike cover, temporary in nature, which projects from the wall of a building or overhangs the public way. 
    B & B operator: The owner of a bed and breakfast who is required to reside within the dwelling which houses the bed and breakfast operation. 
    Banquet hall: A building, or portion thereof, primarily intended to accommodate large groups of diners on special occasions. 
    Basement: That portion of a building having more than one-half of its height below lot grade.
